	<item>
		<title>How to: Purchase Flowers on a Budget</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/163/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 04 Feb 2015 21:06:41 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[karissa-chamblin]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=163</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers9.jpg"><img class=" wp-image-368 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers9.jpg" alt="flowers9" width="458" height="687" /></a> Giving flowers on special occasions has been around for hundreds of years. It’s one of the most simple yet beautiful gifts you can receive. Although lovely, flower arrangements can also be pretty pricey and so can the florist that arranges them for you. So what are some options for giving pretty but inexpensive floral arrangements on a budget, you ask? I’ll let you in on some easy, cheap and super simple tricks to making your own bouquets that will impress your friends and family without breaking your bank. <strong><strong> </strong></strong> <b>Skip the florist. </b>Most florists do a great job, but they tend to be a bit more traditional and not always in tune with trends of the younger generations. They can also charge a hefty fee for putting together a bouquet for you. Stick to your local farmers market or grocery store when purchasing. Many grocery stores these days have cut flowers by the stems so you can produce your own bouquet, or pre-made bouquets, ready for purchase. <strong><strong> </strong></strong> <b>Go for seasonal flowers. </b>To get the best price and the best quality, choose flowers that are in season. Some flowers -- like carnations, gerber daisies and lilies -- are grown year-round and are all inexpensive, but they also lack the “wow” factor of some higher-end flowers. That’s why it’s important to buy seasonally, so you can get the best flowers, at the best prices. In the spring, choose such flowers as peonies, dahlias or ranunculus. In the summer, choose such flowers as lilacs, hydrangeas or gladiolas. In the fall, go for sunflowers, leucadendron or chrysanthemum. And in the winter, choose lilies, roses or amarylis. <strong><strong> </strong></strong> <strong><strong><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/FLOWERS-AND-SEASONS1.png"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-237" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/FLOWERS-AND-SEASONS1-682x1024.png" alt="FLOWERS AND SEASONS" width="300" height="450" /></a></strong></strong> Once you pick the flowers that you want -- 3 or 4 different types or all the same type -- you can pick out foliage or filler, which adds contrast and texture to your arrangement and fills in negative space. Your store should have a few options depending on the season, such as seeded eucalyptus, cedar branches or lemon leaf. <strong><strong> </strong></strong> <b>Keep it simple. </b>Some of the best arrangements, only have three or so types of flowers in them. You don’t always need a wide variety in one bouquet. Sometimes the huge selection of flowers at the store can be overwhelming so pick a color scheme and run with that. For a funeral, do whites or muted colors. For a friend or a loved one, any color scheme will work, as long as the colors you pick are cohesive. Think pinks and reds or oranges and yellows together. Even a few big stems of one kind of flower can make a huge statement. The most important thing for me when I am creating a bouquet, is making sure my flower choices look natural together. Flowers come from nature, so I like to keep them looking that way as much as possible. <strong><strong> </strong></strong> <b>To create your own hand-tie bouquet:</b> Once you have your flowers and foliage picked out, you can start creating. You will need scissors or shears, and a piece of twine or string of some sort and a clean table to work with. Lay your flowers out and group them by type. Then process each stem by getting rid of any leaves or thorns on the bottom half of each stem. <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers1.jpg"><img class=" wp-image-356 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers1.jpg" alt="flowers1" width="650" height="433" /></a> Next, take your biggest flower and hold it in your non-dominant hand using your thumb and first finger about halfway down the stem. This will be your center. Then take a foliage stem and place it at an angle over the center flower. Then turn them slightly. Continue with that technique, adding a flower or two and then foliage or filler, each stem slightly lower each time. Place and turn, place and turn. <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers16.jpg"><img class=" wp-image-370 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers16.jpg" alt="flowers16" width="650" height="433" /></a> <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers15.jpg"><img class=" wp-image-371 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers15.jpg" alt="flowers15" width="650" height="433" /></a> <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers14.jpg"><img class=" wp-image-372 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers14.jpg" alt="flowers14" width="650" height="433" /></a> You want to be sure you are creating balance but don’t worry if something isn’t perfectly symmetrical. Use your eye for placement of each stem and constantly be looking at the top to make sure it looks good. <strong><strong>  </strong></strong> I chose to make my bouquet rather small and romantic but you can use this method to make yours as big as you would like, by using more flowers. You can also use this same method for a bunch of hydrangeas, tulips, or any monochromatic bouquet. <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers13.jpg"><img class=" wp-image-373 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers13.jpg" alt="flowers13" width="650" height="433" /></a> Once you are satisfied with the size and look of your bouquet, you can tie it off. For a sturdier hold for a wedding bouquet or funeral, use florist tape from the craft store. If you are just wrapping up the flowers as a gift, I like to use pretty twine or raffia. <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers12.jpg"><img class=" wp-image-374 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers12.jpg" alt="flowers12" width="650" height="433" /></a> <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers11.jpg"><img class=" wp-image-375 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers11.jpg" alt="flowers11" width="650" height="433" /></a> <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers10.jpg"><img class=" wp-image-376 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers10.jpg" alt="flowers10" width="650" height="434" /></a> From this step, chop the stems an inch up if you are wrapping the bouquet or at the length you need for the vase, if you are putting them in a vase. Then wrap them or place them in water. For the wrapping, you can use craft paper, tissue paper, newspaper or cellophane. <strong><strong> </strong></strong> <strong><strong><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers21.jpg"><img class=" wp-image-360 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers21.jpg" alt="flowers2" width="650" height="433" /></a></strong></strong> <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers3.jpg"><img class=" wp-image-361 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers3.jpg" alt="flowers3" width="650" height="433" /></a> <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers4.jpg"><img class=" wp-image-362 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers4.jpg" alt="flowers4" width="650" height="433" /></a> <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers5.jpg"><img class=" wp-image-363 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers5.jpg" alt="flowers5" width="650" height="433" /></a> <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers6.jpg"><img class=" wp-image-364 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers6.jpg" alt="flowers6" width="650" height="434" /></a> <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers7.jpg"><img class=" wp-image-365 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers7.jpg" alt="flowers7" width="650" height="433" /></a> <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers8.jpg"><img class=" wp-image-366 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/flowers8.jpg" alt="flowers8" width="650" height="433" /></a>
<h6>And Voila! You have a hand-tied bouquet that will look expensive but will have saved you loads of cash. Once you get the hang of how to make a hand-tie, you will be able to make tons of gorgeous bouquets for your loved ones, without paying for all the extras at a florist.</h6>
<h6></h6>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Apply to Law school</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-apply-to-law-school/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 01 Feb 2015 21:35:50 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[katie-sass]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=174</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The prospect of applying to law school can be a daunting one, but it doesn’t need to be.

Although it isn’t necessary to have hands-on legal experience before starting law school, it is very helpful to have an idea of where you want to take your legal career. That way, you can research specific programs offered at each school and make the most of your law school experience.

In the law school community, it is common knowledge that the two most important components of your application are the LSAT and GPA. By the time you decide to apply to law school, your GPA is probably pretty set in stone. And so alas, it is time to channel your energy into rocking the LSAT.

&nbsp;
<h6><strong> THE LSAT </strong></h6>

<hr />

There is no way getting around it: the LSAT is a challenging exam. Each person is different, but you can expect to dedicate a few months to studying for it. Depending on your preference, you can sign-up for a prep class or study independently using previously administered exams (purchased at LSAC.org). What matters most is that you study to the best of your ability and take the test only when you’re ready (since every score is reported to law schools). When studying, try to take practice exams under test-like conditions to best prepare for test day.

The <strong>LSAT is offered four times per year</strong>: February, June, September/October, and December. Besides the June exam, each LSAT is administered on a Saturday morning at 8:30 AM. The June LSAT takes place on a Monday at 12:30 PM. The exam is divided into four graded sections, one experimental section, and a writing sample. The final section is the writing sample: a short argumentative essay that is not graded as part of your final score. However, law schools will receive a copy of the writing section so don’t completely flub it.

There are <strong>three types of sections</strong> in the LSAT: logic games (1), logical reasoning (2), and reading comprehension (1). Each section has 25 questions—give or take—so your raw score will be out of 100. Your final score is calculated into a number between 120 and 180.

While it is preferable to take the LSAT before the admissions cycle opens, the September/October and December test dates are popular options for admission to programs starting in the fall of the following year. If you do decide to take the LSAT during the admissions cycle for the year you want to apply, try to have the rest of your application ready for submission by the time your score is released.

On the day of your LSAT, remember to <strong>relax</strong>! It’s hard to not feel the pressure, but try to not let your nerves get the best of you. You’ve studied hard and taken several practice tests, so you’re ready to nail it.

&nbsp;
<h6><strong>THE WRITTEN APPLICATION </strong></h6>

<hr />

Through the application process, <strong>LSAC.org</strong> will become your favorite website. Through the Law School Admissions Council (LSAC) website, you can register for the LSAT, send your academic transcripts, and submit applications for each school. You can also apply for fee-waivers for the LSAT and applications on this site.

Applying to law school can be expensive, but fear not! Schools offer need-based <strong>fee-waivers</strong>. For instance, current members and recent alumni of Teach for America, Peace Corps, and AmeriCorps, as well as those serving with the U.S. military, may qualify for such waivers. Many schools also get students’ information from LSAC and distribute merit-based fee-waivers. This can make a big difference since application fees are generally around $75, plus a $22 processing fee.

For the written component of the application, you will likely need to submit a short personal statement (about 2 pages), a resume, and two letters of recommendation. Some schools may require a supplemental essay. For the personal statement, the most important thing is to <strong>remember to be you</strong>! Admissions committees have read it all, so it’s best to let your personality shine and demonstrate why you’d be a great addition to their class. This is your opportunity to show yourself beyond the numbers – take advantage of it.

Perhaps the most important advice: <strong>APPLY EARLY</strong>! Most schools review applications on a rolling basis and start releasing admissions offers before the official application deadline. Because of that, you can bolster your chances of getting into your dream school by submitting your application early in the cycle.

&nbsp;
<h6><strong> I SUBMITTED MY APPLICATIONS…NOW WHAT? </strong></h6>

<hr />

Once you’ve submitted your application materials, let out a huge sigh of relief and prepare yourself for the waiting game. Due to the nature of a rolling admissions process, you won’t know when you’ll hear back from each school – it could be weeks, it could be months. However, most people receive decisions by April.

When hearing back from schools, you will be faced with one of three options: accept, deny, or waitlist. If you are waitlisted at your dream school, don’t lose hope! Many students get accepted off the waitlist each year. Once you’ve heard back from all the schools, it is time to make a decision. While it is ultimately up to you, things to consider include: tuition and scholarship offers, clinical opportunities at the school, program offerings for your specific interest, region where you want to work after law school, student environment, and employment statistics.

&nbsp;
<h6>Picture source http://pixshark.com</h6>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How to: Unclog a Toilet</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-unclog-a-toilet/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 01 Jan 2015 23:44:04 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[lauren-montgomery]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=232</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[
<ol>
	<li> <span style="color: #000000;"><strong>DON'T PANIC</strong> </span>- the worst thing that can happen is your toilet overflowing with poop water.  Gross, but in the grand scheme of things, it's an easy fix.<br /><br /></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><strong> Plunge WITHOUT flushing</strong></span> - sometimes all it takes is some upper body strength and patience.  Place the plunger into the toilet bowl, angling the opening over the toilet's drain.  Do this quickly so the plunger doesn't fill with water; you'll need the air trapped within the plunger to provide suction. Move the plunger quickly in short up and down motions without removing the plunger from the drain opening. Your goal is to <span style="text-decoration: underline;">PUSH</span> the clog through, not <span style="text-decoration: underline;">PULL</span> it out.<br /><br /></li>
	<li> <strong>Do the FLUSH &amp; PLUNGE</strong> - if plunging alone doesn't work, try flushing your toilet and repeat step 2 as possible post-flush. Vigorously plunge while the toilet is making noise. Use your judgment here, though—if your toilet is filled close to the top, you may not want to take the chance of making it overflow.<br /><br /></li>
	<li><strong> If all else fails, TURN OFF THE WATER</strong> - if plunging didn't do the trick and the toilet is still running and/or filling with water, turn the valve located on the pipe leading from the toilet to the wall counter-clockwise (the valve will be near the ground behind or beside the toilet base).  This will keep the toilet from overflowing.  Leave it off for a couple hours; the bowl should completely drain of water, at which point you can try turning on the valve and repeating step 3.<br /><br /></li>
	<li>If you own your home (and props for that, by the way), <strong>CALL A PLUMBER</strong> - if you've plunged your heart out, it might be time for a professional.  A plumber will most likely snake your toilet using a device called <a href="http://www.familyhandyman.com/plumbing/toilet-repair/how-to-fix-a-clogged-toilet/view-all">a "snake",</a> which feeds a cable into the pipe and clears obstructions by turning the upper handle.  Remember, if you're renting, call your landlord or super first!  FYI, you can buy a snake of your own, if your toilet clogs frequently.</li>
</ol>
<h4 style="text-align: center;">And there you go! <br />It ain't glamorous - but someone's gotta take care of it, and again, we've all been there. High fives all around for stepping up and taking care of business!</h4>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><em>Gif Credit: Isaac Arjonilla</em></p>
]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Help a Friend Through A Break Up</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-help-a-friend-through-a-break-up/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 01 Feb 2015 18:44:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[CAITLYN]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=241</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_526" align="aligncenter" width="615"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Helping-a-Friend-through-a-Breakup.jpg"><img class="size-large wp-image-526" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Helping-a-Friend-through-a-Breakup.jpg" alt="Photo Credit: Isaac Arjonilla" width="615" height="410" /></a> Photo Credit: Isaac Arjonilla[/caption]

First, take a deep, deep breath. And now another. When a friend goes through a break up, it is hard not to take on their pain as your own. You’re probably tempted to say whatever will stop their heartache in this moment: bash the ex, admit you never liked the control-freak anyway, tell the friend “you’re going to be fine, you’re SO AMAZING, you’re going to find someone new SO FAST! With a six-pack &amp; a MAN-BUN!!!” While this may feel right at the time, these condolences can set up tension in the future for your friendship. In my experience, many people reach out to exes after break ups, resulting in a temporary patched up Frankenstein-like relationship with the ex, or in some cases, a full reconciliation and reinstatement of the relationship. In these cases, a strain can result as your friend remembers all of the nasty things you said about the ex right after their previous break up. <strong>You should never say you hate the ex, or list qualities you disliked about them.</strong> Your friend <span style="text-decoration: underline;">MAY</span> get wine drunk and play her favorite game of "let's make fun of my exe's shitty poetry," your friend <span style="text-decoration: underline;">MAY</span> fervently agree with you post break-up when you start sharing how much you hated ex-love interest's habit of leaving cereal bowls in the sink, but <strong>mark my words sister-friend</strong> - if she ever reconciles with the ex, the damage is done, and it may be impossible for her not to resent you for feeling that way towards a person they now are close to again. She may also feel ashamed to tell you if they choose to reconnect with the ex in the future, as they remember all of the things you said about them before. Either way, when your friend is going through a break up, there are two goals: 1) help her through the immediate heartache as much as you can and 2) preserve the friendship in the future by making sure she never has to feel guilty, or protective, of future decisions. Instead, do your best not to criticize the ex. Listen to her, and if she begins to bash them, try and stay understanding but objective. Try and respond by focusing on your genuine concern for her. If she says: <em>“He/She is the absolute worst - they’re a liar and I hate them!”</em> try and say something like <em>“I understand, I hate how much they have hurt you. It makes me so sad to see you in pain like this.”</em> This way your friend feels loved and validated, but there is no risk of future resentment if they do choose to reconnect with the ex . You may think, “There is NO freaking way my friend would ever get back with her ex, ESPECIALLY after this” but you have to remember that break-ups are an incredibly painful experience. People reach out to their exes for a whole assortment of reasons. I've heard it all:
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><em>"Yeah, true... he cheated on me, but he makes such damn good omelets! What if I never meet another omelet maker as amazing as him?! I'm just gonna text him.... for the omelets."</em></p>
(<strong>Full disclosure:</strong> I, too, have been this person. Many, many times.  I once called an ex because Braveheart made me cry &amp; they stopped selling the brownies we liked at the coffee shop down the street. No one is above the painful break-up Braveheart/brownie phone calls. <strong>We're all a mess at some point or another.</strong>) So, yes, we, as humans, are not usually our most logical selves post-break up, nor do we often care about doing what is best for ourselves in the future. The heartache is all encompassing: It's in the songs we're listening to, it's in the empty passenger seat next to us, it's in the stupid bottle of untouched mouthwash sitting on the bathroom counter. We are often desperate to fill the void, to stop the hemorrhaging of emotions, and just. make. it. all. stop. The phases of breakups mirror the phases of grief, which actually makes total sense, as it often feels as if something beautiful and living has died. One of these phases of grief is bargaining, and the quickest way to make the loneliness stop is trying to negotiate with an ex to end the break-up. As a friend, you must stay mindful of this possibility and be a reliable, consoling shoulder to cry on. Don't judge, don't berate - just keep breathing and listening. Another emotional, knee-jerk response is to build her up with compliments and positive (yet unrealistic) expectations. “Don’t worry! You’re going to have all the boys/girls fawning over you in no time! You’re going to be with someone new in a month! You’re such a catch!” It may feel like this is exactly what your friend needs to hear right now, but in reality, it may be more harmful than you think. First, she most likely can’t even envision herself with someone else right now - she’s still trying to cope with not being with that <strong>ONE</strong> person. Thinking about a relationship with someone else may cause her to focus on the loss all over again. Secondly, there may very well NOT be suitors pounding down the door very soon. Dating is tough for ANYONE, fresh from a breakup, or not. In the weeks after the break-up, your friend will be in a vulnerable state, and if admirers aren’t appearing as fast as she imagined, it could be harmful to her burgeoning confidence. She may think, “What is wrong with me? Why doesn’t anyone want me? Will anyone love me again?” Instead, emphasize how she now has an opportunity to concentrate on herself and her passions, or focus on fun events in the future to keep her mind off of relationships in general: <em>“I know this is so hard right now, but think about the art fair we have coming up next week! It will be so nice to take our minds off this stuff for a while, right?”</em> or <em>“ It probably feels impossible to see this break-up as anything positive, but maybe some good will come out of it now that you will be able to focus on your writing for a while! You always seem your happiest when you’re writing new pieces!”</em> You may feel helpless faced with your friend’s pain, and you may feel the urge to constantly give advice and affirmations.  It is important to remember that break-ups are usually long processes, with volatile emotional ups and downs. No matter the quality of your advice, your friend is going to make their own (sometimes illogical) decisions that might not even make sense to themselves at the time. It is normal to begin taking it personally and becoming frustrated when she isn't taking your advice, but do your best to remember that your friend’s brain on a break-up is not it’s normal self. As long as they are not hurting themselves or others, try and respect their decisions.<strong> The SINGLE most important responsibility of a friend during a break-up is to listen earnestly and compassionately, </strong>(even if it <strong>IS</strong> the 32nd time this month your friend wants to talk about their ex’s annoying text habits.) Processing such a significant change takes some serious working through for your friend, and in her head, these thoughts can become very overwhelming. Simply by expressing them to you, she is able to slowly start working towards accepting a new normal- one where she is single, content, and surrounded by only those quality people who love her (like you!).]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="personal-pr"><![CDATA[Personal PR]]></category>

			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_edit_last]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_pukka_box_size]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[big]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_pukka_secondary_image_id]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1397]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_thumbnail_id]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2294]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_wp_rp_related_posts_query_result_cache_expiration]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1462914573]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_wp_rp_related_posts_query_result_cache_5]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:10:{i:0;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"234";s:5:"score";s:18:"21.670158148867074";}i:1;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2901";s:5:"score";s:18:"20.818345968373514";}i:2;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"770";s:5:"score";s:17:"18.89756942622189";}i:3;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1669";s:5:"score";s:18:"18.786429724520374";}i:4;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1705";s:5:"score";s:18:"18.566323443201608";}i:5;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2773";s:5:"score";s:18:"17.400135362900482";}i:6;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"746";s:5:"score";s:18:"17.180029082081717";}i:7;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"768";s:5:"score";s:16:"17.0918340036784";}i:8;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2735";s:5:"score";s:18:"16.824771218010433";}i:9;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2537";s:5:"score";s:18:"16.369098865730255";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Take Care of Yourself When You&#039;re Sick</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-take-care-of-yourself-when-sick/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 03 Feb 2015 19:19:32 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jenna-perelman]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=256</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<em>We've all been there: you go to bed at night with a tickle in your throat and somehow by the time you wake up, you're snotty, feverish, and achy. Gross. You stumble to your medicine cabinet and...what?! No ibuprofen? In a daze, you go to make some tea but then you realize you're out of honey, lemon, and herbal tea bags. So you crawl back into bed, call your best friend, and she comes over to take care of you in a jiffy.</em> But sometimes, your best friend's not around. Or maybe you moved to a new city and don't know anyone yet. Or maybe you don't like people. Fear not: it is possible to take care of yourself when you're sick! Here are some tried and true tips:
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">1. Prepare for illness BEFORE you actually get sick. No one likes to go to the drugstore when they’re running a fever. Keep over-the-counter fever reducers, pain relievers, cough drops, and nasal decongestant handy at all times. Canned food also helps: canned beans make a quick and healthy protein dish and canned soups (go for low-sodium) are super convenient too.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">2. Keep antibacterial wipes in shared spaces. Wipe down handles on doors, toilets, and sinks. This will help keep your roommates and/or family members healthy.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">3. GET SOME SLEEP. Your parents were right. Sleep is the most important thing for fighting off any illness.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">4. Hydrate. Water is your best friend, but soda water, ginger ale, or lemon-lime soda can help settle an upset stomach.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>5. Just to be clear - Eat soup. Really. <a href="http://abcnews.go.com/Health/story?id=117888">That stuff has magical qualities</a>. </strong></p>
  <em>So go stock up on these goodies before the next illness strikes! XOXO Jenna</em>   Picture source http://www.thebeanplan.com/]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Check Your Car&#039;s Oil</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-check-your-cars-oil/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 19 Feb 2015 07:26:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[alex-regalado]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=391</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[While driving to work one beautiful morning, I noticed another display signal light up on my dashboard. After consulting my dad, I discovered that it was my oil light, and I needed to check the level of oil in my car. <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/oil1.jpg"><img class="  wp-image-393 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/oil1.jpg" alt="oil1" width="650" height="366" /></a> It turns out checking your oil is one of the easiest and most important ways to maintain the life of your car. The first thing you’ll need to do is pop the hood. In my car, there is a switch labeled “hood” underneath my wheel (it should be located somewhere near your knees on either the side “kick panel” or on the driver leg “tunnel”). <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/oil2.jpg"><img class="  wp-image-394 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/oil2.jpg" alt="oil2" width="650" height="366" /></a> Once it’s popped open, you’ll need to push another lever to actually lift the hood up. This is found by gentling moving your fingertips around underneath the slightly lifted hood, until you find the level. When you find it,  push it up or to the side (depends on the car) and pull the hood up at the same time. <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/oil3.jpg"><img class="  wp-image-396 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/oil3.jpg" alt="oil3" width="650" height="366" /></a> <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/oil4.jpg"><img class="  wp-image-397 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/oil4.jpg" alt="oil4" width="650" height="366" /></a> To keep the hood of your car up, find the stand. It will generally be sitting along one of the edges of your engine bay (either the front, left, or right sides). Pull it from its resting place, and prop it up against the inside of the hood. There should be a hole in which the stand fits perfectly (usually it is a square and sometimes there is an arrow pointing to it). <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/oil5.jpg"><img class="  wp-image-398 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/oil5.jpg" alt="oil5" width="650" height="366" /></a> <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/oil6.jpg"><img class="  wp-image-399 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/oil6.jpg" alt="oil6" width="650" height="366" /></a> Now it’s important to mention that for my car, a Toyota Rav4, they recommend that you check your oil after your engine has been off for at least 10 minutes. You should research and see what’s best for your car. Once your hood is open, you need to find the dipstick. It will looks like a small handle and should be a bright color such as yellow or orange. In the picture below you can see that mine is orange. <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/oil7.jpg"><img class="  wp-image-400 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/oil7.jpg" alt="oil7" width="650" height="366" /></a> Pull it out to find your oil indicator. To pull, I had to first push down on a silver lever underneath, and then lift up on the orange handle. <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/oil8.jpg"><img class="  wp-image-401 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/oil8.jpg" alt="oil8" width="650" height="366" /></a> You’ll need to first pull out the dipstick, wipe it with a paper towel or napkin, and re-insert it. Then pull it out again, and you’ll be able to see the actual oil level. <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/oil9.jpg"><img class="  wp-image-402 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/oil9.jpg" alt="oil9" width="650" height="366" /></a> <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/oil10.jpg"><img class="  wp-image-403 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/oil10.jpg" alt="oil10" width="650" height="366" /></a> I’ve heard there are two ways to see if you need to change your oil. The first is if there isn’t enough. Below is the amount of oil that is normal, as indicated by the markings on the dipstick (the lower marking is the lowest recommended level while the top marking is the highest recommended level). <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/oil11.jpg"><img class="  wp-image-412 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/oil11.jpg" alt="oil11" width="650" height="366" /></a> This next picture shows what a low amount of oil looks like. This is when you’d need to add more. <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/oil121.jpg"><img class="  wp-image-413 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/oil121.jpg" alt="oil12" width="650" height="366" /></a> I have also heard that the cleanliness or color of your oil is telling. If you rub a little oil between your fingers and it leaves a smudge, then it is dirty and you need to add clean oil. If you rub it and it's just greasy and clear, then it should be fine. To add more oil, find the oil cap (which in my car was located right above the dipstick and is generally on the top of the center part of the engine). Unscrew it and pour in the right type of oil for your car. To find out which type to use, you can check your manual, look online, or visit a mechanic (or check the oil cap itself. As you see below, mine recommends 5W-30). It’s different for each type of car. <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/oil13.jpg"><img class="  wp-image-414 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/oil13.jpg" alt="oil13" width="650" height="366" /></a> Pour your oil in small doses and check the dipstick each time to make sure you don’t overfill. You want the oil to get close to the maximum line as indicated by the top marking on the dipstick but make sure you don’t add too much or you could damage your engine.
<h6 style="text-align: center;">I hope this helps!</h6>
<h6 style="text-align: center;">XOXO Alex</h6>
&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>TWIGG Tip: Calling a Tow Truck</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/twigg-tip-calling-a-tow-truck/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 25 Jan 2015 06:28:25 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[CAITLYN]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=564</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/Calling-a-Tow-Truck.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-large wp-image-2252" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/Calling-a-Tow-Truck-1024x1006.jpg" alt="Calling-a-Tow-Truck" width="1024" height="1006" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Understand Internet Speeds</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-understand-internet-speeds/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 03 Feb 2015 04:02:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[alex-regalado]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=760</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><i>I think by now I have Time Warner on my speed dial. I’ve called many times with many questions (disclosure: they are very friendly!) that by now I feel like I understand internet speeds pretty well. Here’s what I’ve learned...</i> There are two basic ways internet speed is measured:</p><p><b>Download Speed: </b>How quickly information travels from the Internet to your computer (definition from Time Warner Cable).</p><p>– When an internet plan is presented, there will always be a faster download speed than an upload speed (For example 50mbps download and 5mbps upload). This is because we spend more of our time online surfing the web, i.e. clicking on links and waiting for that information to load.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><b>Upload Speed: </b>How quickly information travels from your computer to the Internet (definition again from Time Warner Cable)</p><p>– This has to do with adding stuff online. Uploading a picture, posting a status, tweeting… whenever you add anything of your own you are using your upload speed. Even though you might do it often, it usually happens a little at a time. That’s why when you upload a video, it tends to take a longer no matter what speed you have. Most internet providers will not give you more than 5mbps for uploading, which is enough for the average internet user.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong> All speeds are measured in terms of megabits per second (mbps). A lowercase "b" means bits, while an uppercase "B" means bytes.  There are eight bits in a byte, meaning you need eight megabits per second to move one megabyte file. One digital photo, for example, might be one or two megabytes in size, and would take 16 megabits to “move” or load. Bits move bytes! So if your average internet speed gives you 15mbps, then you could load that two megabyte photo in about a second. Pretty good! Your speed doesn’t affect what you can do- just how fast it will happen. If you and your roommate are both trying to click on a two megabyte photo at the same time, and your speed is still 15mbps, then it will take twice as long – two seconds. Therefore, one more person won’t make much of a difference.</p><p>But let’s say you have FIVE roommates, and you are all trying to load two megabyte photos at the same time with your 15mbps speed, it would take you each 5 seconds. That is a noticeable lag, and that’s when you would probably want to increase your internet speed. This gets even more complicated when you add different devices into the mix. If you’re getting a Facebook notification on your phone, you’re streaming Netflix on your TV, and you’re using Google Drive to write an essay – all of these things are using the same 15mbps and affect how quickly you can do things. <strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><strong>So how are you supposed to pick the right plan?</strong> Some providers allow you to interactively pick how many people you live with and how many devices you use and then they will estimate what speed you need to comfortably use the internet. But let’s say an average house is two people, each with phones and laptops, and one TV that uses streaming capabilities. A standard internet plan of 15mbps download and 1mbps upload should suffice. If you have four or more people and there are many devices, you would want to get the largest plan available. Additionally, if you are someone who works primarily online and is downloading or uploading frequently, then the faster the better! After you pick the right speed, and your internet is still being slow, some reasons why it might be lagging are:</p><ul><li style="padding-left: 30px;">Routers can become overloaded or misfunction. Usually rebooting helps.</li><li style="padding-left: 30px;">Your computer – internal RAM can affect how fast your computer processes the internet</li><li style="padding-left: 30px;">Your provider’s routers – sometimes there’s a problem with the internet straight from the source</li><li style="padding-left: 30px;">Modem's signal – is it too far away? Is something disrupting it?</li></ul><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><p><i>Hopefully this helps prevent the curse of bad wifi! </i> <strong><i>XOXO Alex</i></strong></p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Report a Crime</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-report-a-crime/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 03 Dec 2014 04:05:42 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[sonali-kohli]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=764</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Unfortunately, part of the whole “being an adult” thing is knowing what to do if you're the target of a crime. Reporting a crime is a pretty straightforward process, and one you that’s important to understand in case you’re robbed, your home is burglarized, or you are harmed in any other way. Here are some tips:

<strong><strong> </strong></strong>
<ol>
	<li><b>Call 911 if you are in immediate danger</b>. If possible, call from a landline. Tell the dispatcher your name and location in case the call is dropped. Tell them if anyone is hurt, and what is wrong. (<a href="http://www.lapdonline.org/communications_division/content_basic_view/6461">Here’s a helpful guide</a> so you know when to and not to call 911.)</li>
</ol>
<strong><strong> </strong></strong>
<ol start="2">
	<li><b> If you’re not in danger, do not call 911</b>. Instead, use the seven-digit phone number for your local police or sheriff’s station (a quick Google search will find it for you).There are also sometimes different numbers to call, depending on the crime you witnessed. For example, the Los Angeles Police Department has a list of numbers to call for specific crimes<a href="http://www.lapdonline.org/report_a_crime"> here</a>, and New York police have a similar guide<a href="http://www.nyc.gov/portal/site/nycgov/menuitem.6a42a9ac540cd25ecedeb11056a09da0/"> here</a>.</li>
</ol>
<strong><strong> </strong></strong>
<ol start="3">
	<li><b> Report in person</b>: you can always go into the nearest precinct and report a crime in person.</li>
</ol>
<strong><strong> </strong></strong>
<ol start="4">
	<li><b> Take preemptive action now</b>. You should already know the number of your local precinct, as well as where the station is. Find out the phone number and address, save them in your phone now and stick a copy to the fridge. It’s very easy—New Yorkers can find their local precinct<a href="http://www.nyc.gov/html/nypd/html/precinct_maps/precinct_finder.shtml#"> here</a>, and Angelenos can find it<a href="http://www.lapdonline.org/our_communities"> here</a>.</li>
</ol>
<strong><strong> </strong></strong>
<ol start="5">
	<li><b> Always report the crime. </b>There are many reasons people choose not to report crimes. You might be traumatized and not want to relive the crime, or you might think there’s no use in reporting the crime because of the very low likelihood of the criminal being arrested or prosecuted—that’s sometimes the thought process for women who have been sexually harassed or assaulted. If you’re mugged, report it. If a man grabs you on the street, report it. Police can’t address a problem unless they are aware of it, and the more women who report a crime, the more likely it is that police will pay attention to it.</li>
</ol>
<strong><strong> </strong></strong>
<ol start="6">
	<li>If you’re a student, <b>reporting the crime to the school might not be enough</b>, particularly in cases of sexual assault. Universities often<a href="http://qz.com/308490/campus-rape-a-guide-to-the-debate-thats-roiling-american-universities/"> have their own guidelines</a> of judging and punishing sexual harassment and assault, so if you want to pursue legal action you may need to do so separately from your school’s proceedings.</li>
</ol>
<strong><strong> </strong></strong>

<b>Other resources: </b>The national<a href="http://www.justice.gov/actioncenter/report-crime"> Department of Justice</a> and the<a href="http://www.fbi.gov/contact-us"> FBI</a> also have guides for how to report different kinds of national crimes, which can be useful to read through.

&nbsp;

Header picture from Safer Students Midland Police.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Stay Abroad</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-travel-and-stay-abroad/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 03 Dec 2014 04:09:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[claire-perelman]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=768</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_526" align="aligncenter" width="615"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Boarding-an-Airplane-1024x684.jpg"><img class="size-large wp-image-526" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Boarding-an-Airplane-1024x684.jpg" alt="Photo Credit: Isaac Arjonilla" width="615" height="410" /></a> Photo Credit: Isaac Arjonilla[/caption]

As an avid traveler, I learned a lot of things the hard way before I figured how to master travel accommodations. Here are some guides that have worked for me when traveling, and I hope these will inspire you to explore all your options!

<hr />

&nbsp;
<h6>How-To: Hostels</h6>
<ol>
	<li>    Book <strong>BEFORE</strong> you get to the city. Know where you will be traveling? Find an Internet café, use your phone, or call ahead and make sure they have some beds for you! You do not want to show up in a foreign city with nowhere to stay!</li>
	<li>    <strong>LOCK UP YOUR STUFF.</strong> I have stayed in plenty of hostels with eight other people in the same room – make sure to buy a locker or a lock for your luggage to make sure your things are safe! You never know what may happen.</li>
	<li>    Make friends! Hostels are the best for exchanging travel stories with others, meeting people your own age, and possibly spending the night out with some Australians traveling alone. Or was that just me?</li>
	<li>    <strong>BRING YOUR OWN LINENS AND TOWELS.</strong> If you’re traveling light, at least cover the bed with your own scarf. You never know when the management decided to wash the linens before you arrived.</li>
	<li>    Embrace it! Hostels can be loud, quiet, and sometimes host events of their own. This is the beauty of a hostel – there are so many people going in and out at all times you never know what you may find! And, make sure you know what they have to offer. Many hostels offer a free continental breakfast. If you are traveling on a budget – definitely go get some of that!</li>
</ol>
Extra tip: I love St. Christopher’s Inns! They have them all over the world and have been some of my most comfortable stays.
<h6>How-To: Air B &amp; B</h6>
<ol>
	<li>    Decide what you want out of your Air B &amp; B experience. There are a variety of routes you can go down – your own apartment, your own room in a house full of other travelers much like a hostel, or a shared room in a quiet apartment.</li>
	<li>    Make sure you know exactly what is provided! Some Air B &amp; Bs provide everything – linens, towels, soap, the works. Others will not. <strong>Read the fine print</strong> – I cannot stress this enough!</li>
	<li>    DO <strong>get in touch with the host</strong>! Talk to them a little bit before booking anything. Ask specific questions on how far away the beach is, clubs, etc. Many times, they do not speak English, so make sure you are getting all of the information you need no matter how long it takes!</li>
	<li>    Ask where you can lock your things and how often the host will come by. I have stayed in some Air B &amp; Bs with the host, and other times I have lived in my own separate apartment. Depends on your preference!</li>
	<li>   <strong> DO try it</strong>! Although it is not as communal as a hostel, it is many times a lot cheaper and you can split it by rooming with other friends. It is also a great idea for couples traveling abroad looking for some privacy!</li>
</ol>
&nbsp;
<h6>How-To: Hotels</h6>
<ol>
	<li>    Looking to spend some money? Invest in a hotel room.</li>
	<li>    Make sure it is close to where you want to be in the city! Check the location and the surroundings before booking a room – and make sure to check the price!</li>
	<li>    <strong>ENJOY IT!</strong> Oftentimes, you may book a hotel room if you are traveling for a long period of time and need some real R&amp;R. So go ahead – take a nice long bath and watch some free TV.</li>
	<li>    Do not stay for too long! The whole fun of traveling is really being in the culture – so why not try living more with the civilians?</li>
	<li>    Make sure you are getting your money’s worth! Free Wi-Fi? Use it. Free breakfast? Eat it!</li>
</ol>
&nbsp;
<h6>How-To: Couch Surfing</h6>
<ol>
	<li>    <strong>BE CAREFUL</strong>. Couch surfing is one of the least reliable ways to travel, abroad and in the United States.</li>
	<li>    Make sure to speak with your host before you arrive, and feel out how the environment is going to be.</li>
	<li>    If you cannot afford to spend any money on living situations – DO couch surf. It is free, but you are also literally living on someone’s couch for an unknown period of time and things may get a little weird. Make SURE to <strong>lock up your things</strong> – and carry your valuables on you at all times!</li>
	<li>    DO know when to bow out. Are you uncomfortable? <strong>LEAVE</strong>. Did the host not tell you certain things about the accommodations? Do not feel the need to stay! Couch surfing is very laissez-faire; do not feel obligated to stick around any longer than your "spidey senses" tell you to.</li>
	<li>    When in doubt, bring a friend! Couch surfing is (in my opinion) the most dangerous way to travel because people hosting are not necessarily checked out by the couch surfing company or getting paid – so they may be hosting guests for a myriad of reasons. If you are traveling with someone you know and trust, couch surfing may seem a little less daunting.</li>
</ol>
&nbsp;
<h6>In the end, any of these four housing accommodations will work depending on your situation and level of comfort. Are there any tips you've picked up through your travels? Leave them in the comments below!</h6>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Review Your Credit Card Options</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/credit-card-options/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 03 Feb 2015 04:10:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[alex-regalado]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=770</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_936" align="alignnone" width="615"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Credit-Cards1.jpg"><img class="size-large wp-image-936" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Credit-Cards1-1024x695.jpg" alt="Photo Credit: Isaac Arjonilla" width="615" height="417" /></a> Photo Credit: Isaac Arjonilla[/caption]

&nbsp;

Even though I was terrified of having a credit card and owing money to some big corporation, it has definitely made my life a lot easier. Through having work cards and life experiences, I've gathered up some basic knowledge that may help you out. If you'd like to read more in depth, you can read <a href="http://credit.about.com/od/creditcardbasics/tp/credit-card-types.htm">here</a>.

&nbsp;

<hr />

<h6>Standard</h6>
A basic credit card will give you a preapproved limit. For example, you might get $1000 to start, and once you spend that, you can’t use the card again until you’ve paid your bill. You don’t have to pay the entire bill every month; you just have to pay above a minimum that the company charges. But be careful with that—the balance flows over into the next month, and you have to pay interest on each dollar you put off. That interest can vary, depending on whether you have a student card or a regular card.

<em>Examples: Visa, Mastercard, Discover</em>

&nbsp;
<h6>Charge Card</h6>
A charge card doesn’t have a preapproved limit like the standard credit card, so you can spend as much as you like! The tradeoff is that there’s no minimum. You have to pay the total amount at the end of each month to avoid a late fee.

<em>Examples: American Express</em>

&nbsp;

<hr />

<h6>What’s the difference between all the credit card brands?</h6>
Visa and Mastercard don’t actually issue their own cards. They partner with banks or credit unions who do issue cards, and act as a second financial advisor for the account. So the bank is the one handling the money and setting the limits and rates- therefore you can have two Visa cards that have different terms. Visa and Mastercard are payment networks that the banks use to help handle your money.

Discover and American Express are the same, but they issue their own cards and both don’t have as big of reach as Visa or Mastercard. Some smaller stores or shops may not accept either brand, so it’s a good idea to have multiple credit cards- like a Visa and a Discover so that you know you can have a credit card available for use almost anywhere. American Express is known for charger MORE interest, and only offers a charge card. But it also gives you more perks than a Visa card would. Discover issues standard cards, and is known for having great cash back incentives.

&nbsp;

<hr />

<h5> Some more specific types of cards:</h5>
<h6>Rewards Cards</h6>
These are signed up for specifically because you earn points toward gaining something like airline miles or cash back rewards. They function the same as a standard card.

&nbsp;
<h6>Balance Transfer Cards</h6>
These are also the same as a standard card, but start out with 0% interest. Balance Transfers allow people with some credit card debt to pay off their balance on one card by transferring it to this new card. Normally transfers add up- sometimes charging 3% of the amount transferred. But this 0% interest doesn’t last forever- so you have to transfer quick.

&nbsp;
<h6>Business Credit Cards</h6>
These cards allow you to differentiate between personal and business spending, which is just one example of the options it gives you when managing your account that are helpful for business owners.

&nbsp;
<h6></h6>
<h6>But be careful! Don’t charge more money than you have, because you can get in big trouble if you don’t pay it off on time. Try to keep your credit score high even when you’re young!</h6>
<h6>XOXO Alex</h6>]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>The Sticky Business of Wallpaper</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/the-sticky-business-of-wallpaper/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 30 Jan 2015 05:23:46 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Carol-Elliott]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=1066</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[One of the nice benefits of owning your own place is to be able to decorate the walls the way you want. Most rentals have white or off-white walls throughout an apartment to make it generic enough for everyone’s taste. Once you are in a position to decorate a room the way you want to, adding wallpaper is a creative option. I grew up in a time (long ago) when all the walls in our house were wallpapered except the bathroom.  I might add that we only had one bathroom.  But that is another article. “How to raise six kids with only one bathroom and no shower.” The walls in the house always made a big statement walking in because there were large colorful flowers, paisley patterns, and even a cactus pattern throughout the kitchen walls.
<h5 style="text-align: center;">PURCHASE</h5>

<hr />

Today there are only a few places you can still get wallpaper, usually local paint stores and online. The chain paint stores will have large wallpaper books to look at with lots of samples, but also have websites that offer a larger variety. You will order the wall paper based on the size of the room so you will need to <strong>measure the length and width of the room</strong>.
<h5 style="text-align: center;">PREPARE</h5>

<hr />

To get prepared, just like if you were painting a room, <strong>you will need space</strong> to put a ladder against the wall as you hang the paper. Move any furniture to the middle of the room and away from the wall. You will need room to roll the paper out and cut strips for the height of the wall so you will need a table or a makeshift one from plywood to help with cutting the paper. You will also need a tray or tub with water in it to dip the wallpaper in since the wallpaper is self- adhesive. Long ago we used to have to prepare the wallpaper paste and lay the paper out to apply the paste completely on the back of the paper. It was a sticky mess. To prepare the walls for the papering, you will need to make sure there aren’t any holes or nails in the wall and remove the outlet covers. Use spackle to fill in any holes and make sure the <strong>wall is as smooth as possible</strong>. By putting on a primer on the walls, the removal of the wallpaper will be easier once you change your mind and want to redecorate. You will want to redecorate. This is an important product because otherwise it can take hours peeling off the last wallpaper before apply the new wallpaper or deciding to repaint the wall. When you cut your strips of paper make them a couple of inches longer than the height of the wall. You can trim the paper with a pair of good scissors at the bottom once the paper lines up with the top of the base board. If your paper has a pattern that has to be matched, you will need to match up the pattern before you cut to make sure you have a long enough strip of paper. You may need to cut the top and bottom to match the pattern. It will also take a little more wallpaper if you are matching a pattern. Fill your tray with <strong>lukewarm water</strong> and roll up the sheet of paper with the paste side out. Soak the paper for at least 30 seconds and slowly pull up the paper making sure all the paper is completely wet. Most walls are not perfectly straight so the best way to make sure the paper hangs straight is to hang the second sheet of wallpaper from the corner edge first. To make sure the paper hangs straight down the wall from the ceiling, <strong>tie a piece of string</strong> that is weighted at the bottom to a pin and let it hang down from the top of your wall.  That string line will guide you to make sure your paper is hanging in a straight line from the ceiling. Then you can go back and hang the corner piece of wallpaper which you will have to cut to meet the corner of the wall instead of wrapping it around the corner. Wrapping around corners can cause air pockets and then ripped paper. Almost cut the paper at the corners.
<h5 style="text-align: center;">HANG</h5>

<hr />

As you hang the wallpaper, place the top left corner of the paper on the wall and use a wallpaper brush to slowly <strong>press down on the paper diagonally</strong> making sure there are no air bubbles or wrinkles in the paper. If there are, gently pull up the paper and use the brush to make the paper smooth.  When you get to the next corner of the wall, cut the paper at the corner to make sure it fits tight and there are no air bubbles. Always go back and make sure the seams are completely attached to the wall by wiping them with your brush and adding any additional water if needed. There is also wallpaper border that can be added to a painted wall by itself or added on the top of the wallpaper. When using it with wallpaper it is best <strong>to leave some wall space</strong> to overlap the border on instead of placing the wallpaper all the way to the top of the ceiling. Adding a border to a painted room is a great way to get a feel for wallpapering before you wallpaper a whole room and it adds some color and design to a painted room. Even to those off-white walls.
<h5 style="text-align: center;"></h5>
<h5 style="text-align: center;">VOILA</h5>

<hr />

&nbsp;
<h6 style="text-align: center;">Wallpapering can be a little sticky but if you own the walls it’s worth the time!</h6>
<h6></h6>
<span style="color: #808080;">Picture source www.freegreatpicture.com</span>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Stay Balanced In the Midst of a Big Life Change</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-stay-balanced-in-the-midst-of-a-big-life-change/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 16 Jan 2015 05:24:12 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Contributor Coordinator]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2428</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h6 style="text-align: center;">My life up until now has always been go go go.</h6>
<h6 style="text-align: center;"></h6>
<h6 style="text-align: center;">People that know me say I am a go getter: Full of energy.</h6>
<h6 style="text-align: center;"><span style="color: #ff9900;"><strong>A few months ago that all came to a halt when I decided to quit my job and change </strong><strong>my path.</strong> </span></h6>
<h6 style="text-align: center;"></h6>
<span style="font-size: 16px;">I was terrified. My friends and family were terrified. Heck, even random people I met on
</span><span style="font-size: 16px;">the streets were terrified, but something happened inside me and my world shifted.</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;">
Through this journey of self discovery and learning how to be a business owner I discovered a
</span><span style="font-size: 16px;">very key factor. It is something that we are reminded of every day on social media, through each
</span><span style="font-size: 16px;">other, hidden in the subtext of movies, you name it. It is the <em>“Stop and smell the roses”</em> moment,
</span><span style="font-size: 16px;">the <em>“Life is what happens when you are making other plans moment”,</em> the realization that time
</span><span style="font-size: 16px;">has passed and you have no memory of what has occurred other than a foreboding feeling that
</span><span style="font-size: 16px;">something important was just missed. I am talking about the importance of being <strong><em>present.</em> </strong>My
</span><span style="font-size: 16px;">life and goals are able to come together because I acknowledge the absolute awesomeness of
</span><span style="font-size: 16px;">living in the moment.</span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 16px;">Understand that although simple it </span><span style="font-size: 16px;">is not easy to truly live in the moment. We are constantly
</span><span style="font-size: 16px;">surrounded by distractions and business as usual. Therefore, our thoughts are constantly on ten
</span><span style="font-size: 16px;">thousand different worlds at once. If you think about it we </span><span style="font-size: 16px;">actually don't live in the moment as
</span><span style="font-size: 16px;">much as we'd like to. We are always more concerned with the past or the future to focus on the
</span><span style="font-size: 16px;">NOW.</span>
<ol>
	<li><strong><span style="font-size: 16px;">Distractions and Speed of Thought</span></strong></li>
</ol>
<span style="font-size: 16px;">In order to truly live in the moment you have to be </span><span style="font-size: 16px;">constantly reminding yourself to remove these constant distractions from your thoughts </span><span style="font-size: 16px;">and just focus on this one moment in time. This one second of every millisecond of every </span><span style="font-size: 16px;">moment. Sounds complicated right? Well it kind of is although </span><span style="font-size: 16px;">it isn't. You just have to </span><span style="font-size: 16px;"><span style="color: #ff9900;">SLOW</span> down. Make a conscious effort to be mindful of what is going on in your head.</span>
<ol start="2">
	<li><strong><span style="font-size: 16px;">Open Your Eyes to the Physical World Around You </span></strong></li>
</ol>
<span style="font-size: 16px;">The beautiful thing about living in the </span><span style="font-size: 16px;">moment is that you are able to enjoy and notice beauty all around you. You begin to </span><span style="font-size: 16px;">appreciate nature, people, the world around you because </span><span style="font-size: 16px;">you are no longer distracted </span><span style="font-size: 16px;">by all the "other" things that consume your thoughts.</span>

&nbsp;
<h6 style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 16px;">That’s it! Two steps! </span></h6>
&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 16px;">They are both very important and take a huge amount of discipline and </span><span style="font-size: 16px;">awareness. If you can conquer these two, you will have a more fulfilling life and alleviate a lot of </span><span style="font-size: 16px;">stress. Fast paced movement can leave you feeling empty and defeated sometimes, as you </span><span style="font-size: 16px;">tend to just miss the things that make life, well, life! </span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;">In closing, living in the moment is an </span><span style="font-size: 16px;">everyday practice that takes commitment and determination. But mastering this simple art form can </span><span style="font-size: 16px;">open up your world in ways you never thought possible.</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;">Try it :)</span>

<span style="color: #008080;"><strong><span style="font-size: 16px;">Kris
</span><span style="font-size: 16px;">Founder
</span><span style="text-decoration: underline; color: #ff9900;"><span style="font-size: 16px;"><a style="color: #ff9900; text-decoration: underline;" href="http://kssolife.com">KSSOLiFe.com</a></span></span></strong></span>

&nbsp;

<hr />

Read our <strong>Winging It Spotlight</strong> on the all female founding team of KSSOLiFe below:
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/the-winging-it-spotlight-kssolife-on-how-to-start-a-business-with-purpose/">10.16.15 - The Winging It Spotlight: KSSOLiFe on How To Launch a Business (with Purpose!)</a></strong></span></p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Survive Winter In The City</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-survive-winter-in-the-city/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 30 Jan 2015 00:18:32 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[katie-sass]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2671</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<em>What is this white stuff falling from the sky, and why can’t I feel my nose?</em>

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/snow.gif"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-2766" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/snow-300x161.gif" alt="snow" width="360" height="193" /></a>

&nbsp;

When I decided to volunteer for a year through the AmeriCorps VISTA program in Chicago, I knew one of my biggest challenges would be the infamously brutal Chicago winter. Having lived my entire life in Southern California, I had no idea what to expect. Scarves, boots, and sweaters were a fashion accessory, not a means of survival. Coats were something I wore maybe one night a year and invariably regretted as I nearly died of heat exhaustion. Ugg boots were the awful fashion statement from middle school that I shamelessly wore with shorts (did I just admit that publicly?). And snow was only experienced in the mountains.

&nbsp;

As much as I tried to gather advice on how to survive my first “real” winter, the truth is that it was much more of a process of learning by doing and experiencing. And while I generally think that’s the case for most people, here are some key takeaways to set you on the path to dominating your first winter.

&nbsp;

Importantly, it’s a mistake to think moving to a colder climate necessitates an entirely new wardrobe--although that certainly does not minimize the fun of purchasing weather-appropriate clothes. With a few key purchases, you can easily transition your wardrobe. The most important items are a puffy jacket, thick socks, and something to keep your ears warm. I’m also a big fan of sweater-tights. I purchased my coat at a discount store, and it was the best $100 I spent that year. I kid you not, I wore it every single day for four solid months. By the time winter ended, I swore I would never wear that damn coat again. Nevertheless, it saved my life. Also, keep in mind that once the temperature reaches a certain low point, fashion takes the back seat to survival. You gotta do what you gotta do to stay warm, no matter how ridiculous you look.

&nbsp;

There is something quite magical about fresh-fallen, untouched snow covering the city streets. Yet, the romanticism of snow quickly gives way to a slushy, dirty reality, one that get increasingly frustrating as the season progresses. The shift in attitude tends to occur at the start of the new year as the Christmas lights come down and the hustle and bustle of the holidays gives way to the monotony of everyday life. This is the time when your resilience is tested and you earn your winter survival street cred.

&nbsp;

[caption id="attachment_2672" align="aligncenter" width="540"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/image01.jpg"><img class="wp-image-2672" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/image01.jpg" alt="My first snowfall! " width="540" height="540" /></a> My first snowfall![/caption]

&nbsp;
<h4>When 30 degrees becomes “warm” weather...</h4>
One of the crown achievements of my life has been surviving the Polar Vortex and the historically cold Chicago winter of 2014 (most days 26°F with low temperatures at or below zero, WHAT?). You know it’s a big deal when the city of Chicago shuts down because it is TOO COLD to be outside. My roommate kindly referred to it as “rip your face off” cold. However blunt, the phrase resonated. I distinctly recall getting brain freezes simply by virtue of walking outside and losing feeling in my feet while waiting for a bus. Or hailing a cab simply because I couldn’t possibly stand outside any longer.

&nbsp;

Beware of ice, and make sure your shoes have traction. The last thing you want to do is slip and fall on your butt. I carried a pair of flats in my purse so I could change out of my clunky snow boots once I got to work. Another thing: beware of wearing nice shoes in the snow. The salt on the street will cling to your shoes and make a nice ring on them. As sick as you’ll be of wearing big boots, it’s not worth ruining your nicer items.

&nbsp;

The cold has a strange way of making your skin insufferably dry. Moisturizer is your new best friend. As much as I tried to save money, in hindsight I wish I’d splurged on quality moisturizer.

&nbsp;

Winter is synonymous with Netflix. If you don’t already have an account (or more realistically, don’t have access to a friend’s), you’ll want one. On those cold evenings, you’ll be glad you can curl up on the couch and binge-watch a series. You’ll be spending most of your time indoors, so it’s important to keep your mind busy.

&nbsp;

A gym membership is also something to consider. I quickly realized that my physical activity during the winter months consisted of walking a block to the bus and then walking around my office/apartment. Try to go to the gym straight from work/school. Odds are, if you go home first, it’ll be nearly impossible to leave the warmth of your apartment.

&nbsp;

Get used to constantly feeling like you’re doing a strip tease. Seriously. Example: In the morning, you put on all your layers before going outside. You get on the bus, and it is oppressively hot and sweaty. You take off your coat to avoid passing out. You put it right back on once you reach your stop. You walk inside a building, and of course the heater is on full blast to over-compensate for the outside temperature. The jacket comes off, maybe even the sweater. This process of dressing and undressing occurs throughout the day.

&nbsp;

Seasonal affective disorder is <strong>real</strong>. It’s not a bad idea to invest in Vitamin D supplements and/or a sunlamp. After weeks or months of being cooped inside, it starts to get to you. It’s normal to feel that way, so preventative measures are definitely worth trying.

&nbsp;

[caption id="attachment_2673" align="aligncenter" width="540"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/image00.jpg"><img class="wp-image-2673" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/image00.jpg" alt="Don't forget the power of a good smile: It releases endorphins, serotonin, and dopamine to make you feel happier. This is me, reminding myself to smile, even in the winter. " width="540" height="540" /></a> This is me, reminding myself to smile, even in the winter. Smiling releases endorphins, serotonin, and dopamine to make you feel happier. So get smiling![/caption]

&nbsp;

Just when you thought my sole job was to be the bearer of bad news, here is one little glimmer of positivity: living in a densely populated area of Chicago, I never had to worry about shoveling snow. In that sense, winter is the city is much easier than in more suburban and rural areas.

&nbsp;

I wish I could use this article to allay any fears about city winters. By no means are they easy. But what I can guarantee is this: after surviving an exhausting winter, there is no feeling as blissful as sunlight touching your skin for the first time in months. I developed a newfound appreciation for sunny weather. What was once a commonplace feature of life in SoCal became something to be cherished. The second the temperature rises above the 30s and 40s, you’ll want to spend every waking second basking in this newfound warmth. Just as the trees start to grow leaves again, you will also feel yourself come alive, reborn and ready to take full advantage of the luxury of outdoor activity. Suddenly, that arduous winter feels like a distant memory. lt was all worth it.

&nbsp;

As challenging as it was in the moment, Chicago taught me that I’m stronger than I ever knew possible. It gave me the grit and strength of spirit that only comes from tough-earned experience. I often used the euphemism of character-building, but in hindsight, I realize it’s true. That damn Polar Vortex made me a better person.

&nbsp;

<em>Gif from tumblr.com</em>]]></content:encoded>
