	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Hidden Costs of Pet Care</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/hidden-costs-of-pet-care/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 02 Mar 2015 04:44:11 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[lauren-montgomery]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=113</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_137" align="aligncenter" width="222"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/linus-copy.jpg"><img class="alignnone wp-image-380" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/linus-copy.jpg" alt="linus copy" width="222" height="297" /></a> Linus Montgomery taken by Lauren Montgomery[/caption]

Let me kick you a scenario: you’re moving into a new apartment (congrats, by the way) and, after searching through all the complicated legalese of the lease agreement, you eventually find what might be the most (and perhaps only) enjoyable piece of information contained within that labyrinth of a document. Hidden between the policy on painting and a long-winded harangue about mold, you come across a phrase that may change your life forever:
<p style="text-align: center;">“<strong>Pets are allowed with a deposit.</strong>”</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">Your eyes widen and your mind immediately starts making elaborate plans for the wonder of furry motherhood. What kind of pet will you get? What will you name it? Fernando? Gerald (after President Gerald Ford)? <em>Cat</em>herine Hepburn? What will your couples Halloween costume be? Before you know it, you have everything all planned out and you’ve started dancing.</p>
And now it’s time to start thinking realistically, especially when it comes to the expenses that come along with pet ownership. Don’t get me wrong, it’s a great plan and I’m sure you’re an excellent dancer, but there’s more to getting and keeping a pet than having a permanent cuddle buddy and an opportunity to have the most famous ferret on Instagram. Becoming a pet owner is a commitment that last for years, sometimes decades, and that can add up to a lot of dough, expected and unexpected. Of course you have to think about the big ones, like potential <strong>vet bills</strong> (which are usually <em>astronomical</em> for the services rendered), but it’s the everyday stuff that really adds up, as well as unanticipated costs, that can really put a strain on your budget.
<p style="text-align: center;"><strong>The first real expense you have to worry about is the actual price tag on the animal itself.</strong></p>
Whether you’re adopting or rescuing, any animal is going to cost money to bring home. Depending on the breed, average costs run from $100-$250, and it can get even pricier when it comes to more “exotic” animals or when you’re buying from a breeder. This amount typically covers health-related fees (microchipping, neutering/spaying, flea and tic medication, etc.), all of which should be completed before you bring your new pet home. The next slightly cumbersome amount comes in the form of the <strong>pet deposit</strong>. This is only applicable if you’re a renter, and is also dependent on what kind of animal you’re bringing home. This deposit covers any incidentals that may occur as a result of owning a pet, but doesn’t cover larger repairs (like if your cat decides to rip out the entire carpet). This amount doesn’t typically exceed $200, but will set you back anywhere from $100-$150. After these two heavy sums, your pet-related expenses get substantially less expensive but also much more persistent. You’ll be swiping your card the most when it comes to food, although buying in bulk is always a more frugal and responsible option; pet food tends to last longer than human food, so stacking your shelves with bags of kibble or cans of Shredded Beef in Gravy Cheese Sauce (yum, right?) is probably your best bet. Try Costco, Smart &amp; Final, or even Amazon for good deals on high-volume food. Dishes, while not necessary, are pretty cheap at places like Target and Petco, coming in at about $4, or $12 if you feel like getting fancy.
<p style="text-align: center;"><strong>Now let’s talk about poop.</strong></p>
Poop is a pretty big deal when it comes to pet ownership. Not only to you have to smell it, look at it, and dispose of it (with varying degrees on grossness), but you also have to pay for your pet to do his business. Cats are probably the most expensive when it comes to number 2, since they’re so finicky and high-maintenance in matters of the butt. You only have to buy the litter box once (it’s about $15, so don’t be fooled by trendy haute couture-esque boxes), but the litter ($8-$20, depending on the weight) is something you’ll have to buy once every couple months or so. Dogs are much easier to deal with financially, as you can use old plastic bags for pickup and store-bought baggies are only about $7 for a pack of 100. Mice and other rodents will put the least amount of strain on your wallet, since they do the dirty on whatever old newspaper you have lying around. <strong>Transportation</strong> is a pretty small investment in the grand scheme of things. Dogs, of course, require a leash ($10-$20 for a good sturdy version), and you’ll need a carrier if you ever need to travel with your cat ($30 for a basic carrier, up to $80 for a more deluxe version).
<p style="text-align: center;"><strong>Once you have to basics covered, all other expenses tend to fall under the umbrella of “Really Cool But Unnecessary.”</strong></p>
<strong>Toys</strong>, while crucial to maintain your pets’ physical and mental health, frequently cost more than they’re worth, and often times you can make them yourself. Your cat will need a scratching post for about $20 (unless you don’t mind if they use your couch), and all dogs love a squeaky toy or two, but once you stock the toy chest with the nuts and bolts, try filling it up with DIY games using old socks, ratty t-shirts, or, let’s face it, an empty cardboard box.   Pinterest is a really good tool for this, so do some pinning if you need some inspiration or direction. Pet beds are also another avoidable expense. A cushy bed costs $15-$50, so try putting an old pillow in a cardboard box instead. <strong>Grooming</strong> comes in somewhere between necessary and lavish. Most pet grooming can be done at home, but if you have a particularly large or difficult pet it might be a good idea to visit a groomer every once in a while. Grooming prices depend on the breed, size, and species of pet, thus running between $35 and $70 for various services. You can also save a bit more by getting a la carte services, such as tooth brushing and nail clipping ($5-$15, respectively) for things that you can’t do yourself. Becoming a pet owner is about so much more than having enough money to afford a pet, but being aware of the fiscal obligations is the first step in understanding what it means to be responsible for taking care of another life, a life that is completely dependent on you for its survival. And once you’re sure that you can financially support Fernando, it’s time for you to dance away, my friend. Dance away.

Hope you found this helpful! <strong>Your TWIGG How-To girl, Lauren</strong>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Write Code</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-write-code/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 01 Mar 2015 05:35:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[krisha-agatep]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=199</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In today's society, coding has become an invaluable skill with many K-8 schools introducing computer science into their curriculum. Let's start with the basic building blocks of a website: HTML and CSS. HTML stands for HyperText Markup Language and provides the basic structure for your code that your browser can read and interpret into what you see on the screen. CSS, or Cascading Style sheet, allows you to style your HTML exactly how you want it. The best way to learn code is try it yourself and testing it in your browser. In order to do that, first create a folder on your computer called "My First Code" (or any folder name of your choosing). Then open up any text editor such as Notepad on PC or TextEdit if you're on a Mac and create a new text file called index.html. It's always good practice to start with the bare bones structure of an HTML page.</p><pre><code>
&lt;!DOCTYPE html&gt;

&lt;html&gt;
&lt;head&gt;
    &lt;meta charset="utf-8" /&gt;
    &lt;title&gt;My First Code&lt;/title&gt;
&lt;/head&gt;
&lt;body&gt;

&lt;/body&gt;
&lt;/html&gt;
</code></pre><p>This piece of code tells your browsers that it is an HTML document type. Most of the elements must have an opening tag, for example, and a closing tag. Forgetting to close a tag could potentially ruin the structure of your site so it's important to make sure that your code is organized. Now let's start with actually displaying code on your screen. Try inserting this line of code between the opening and closing body tags:</p><pre><code>
    &lt;h1&gt;My First Website&lt;h1&gt;
    &lt;p&gt;Hello world!&lt;/p&gt;
</code></pre><p>The &lt;h1&gt; tag is a heading tag and &lt;p&gt; is a paragraph tag. Now double-click your index.html file to run it in your browser and watch magic happen! Now this definitely doesn't look all that pretty or cool... yet. That's where stylesheets or CSS comes in. The next step is to add an internal stylesheet in your index.html file by adding this between the &lt;head&gt; tags.</p><pre><code>
&lt;style&gt;
    body {background-color:lightgray}
    h1   {color:blue}
    p    {color:green}
&lt;/style&gt;
</code></pre><p>Typically it is best practice to create an external stylesheet that we link to from the HTML but for demonstration purposes, an internal stylesheet will work just as well. In the end, your finished code should look like this:</p><pre><code>
&lt;!DOCTYPE html&gt;

&lt;html&gt;
&lt;head&gt;
    &lt;meta charset="utf-8" /&gt;
    &lt;title&gt;My First Code&lt;/title&gt;
&lt;style&gt;
  body {background-color:lightgray}
  h1   {color:blue}
  p    {color:green}
&lt;/style&gt;
&lt;/head&gt;
&lt;body&gt;
&lt;h1&gt;My First Website&lt;h1&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Hello world!&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/body&gt;
&lt;/html&gt;

</code></pre><p>Let's run this in your browser by refreshing your index.html page in the browser. And voila! You just wrote your first piece of code! The great thing about web development is that there is an infinite amount of free resources to get you started on any coding language you can possibly imagine. Here are a few of my favorites:</p><ul><li><a href="http://www.w3schools.com/" target="_blank">W3C Schools</a></li><li><a href="http://www.codecademy.com/" target="_blank">Codecademy</a></li><li><a href="http://www.codeschool.com/" target="_blank">Code School</a></li><li><a href="http://code.tutsplus.com/" target="_blank">Tuts+</a></li></ul><p>Happy Coding! Photo: <a href="https://www.flickr.com/photos/railsgirlsssa/15573101257/in/photolist-99G3Vy-heBgu-9aDWu7-jXuywP-a9WcZv-cFuNaL-gLLxs3-9XiANs-h2FSu9-cE6Qa7-pJ9drP-bs8bbZ-p4HvtQ-dZ1GSB-gXFShk-pGy1Fx-9k7dbR-dZ6bNb-asSqMk-gLLmaF-p4LumT-fDg4bw-gGfQya-6nzyR-qjZJ4N-JxpZq-pNSM51-hLfxE-arGR3X-7N4ko8-oSuVCy-aa9ZPy-gLLqKy-gWxqGK-gXzC9R-bD3k2S-cm9NDo-9k7mAH-qjSVeg-52CvjR-dgc34B-cyHfwS-9nNQko-poaKag-dAJGth-i75eih-pxu1bY-8WXxFD-5jqo2g-5yc9ae">Flickr</a> / <a class="owner-name truncate" title="Go to RailsGirls Salvador's photostream" href="https://www.flickr.com/photos/railsgirlsssa/" data-track="attributionNameClick" data-rapid_p="34">RailsGirls Salvador</a></p>]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_jetpack_related_posts_cache]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:1:{s:32:"8f6677c9d6b0f903e98ad32ec61f8deb";a:2:{s:7:"expires";i:1458470059;s:7:"payload";a:3:{i:0;a:1:{s:2:"id";i:799;}i:1;a:1:{s:2:"id";i:804;}i:2;a:1:{s:2:"id";i:2411;}}}}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Report a Drunk Driver</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-report-a-drunk-driver/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 01 Mar 2015 23:33:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[CAITLYN]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=227</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_526" align="aligncenter" width="615"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/Reporting-a-Drunk-Driver.jpg"><img class="size-large wp-image-526" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/Reporting-a-Drunk-Driver-1024x683.jpg" alt="Photo Credit: Isaac Arjonilla" width="615" height="410" /></a> Photo Credit: Isaac Arjonilla[/caption]

A popular question submitted to us at TWIGG How-To concerns reporting a drunk driver. Specifically, many ladies are curious what pertinent information they should collect and what to do when they are driving alone and don’t have access to a hands free device since in many states, using your phone while driving is illegal.<strong><strong> </strong></strong> For the best answer, we turned to one of our experts, Jim Muratet, a retired Deputy Sheriff of the Riverside County Sheriff’s Department.

<hr />

<strong><strong> </strong></strong>
<h6><b>PREEMPTIVE STEPS</b></h6>
1) ALWAYS know where you are, both the street or freeway, and your direction of travel. <strong><strong> </strong></strong>Being aware of your location and the the nearest cross streets is important in case of emergencies.  This way you can always tell the dispatcher where you are, speeding up your assistance.  At the on ramp to a freeway or on the transition roads, when you are changing freeways, there will be signs which will tell you where you .  At intersections just glance at the street signs to know where you are; if you’re not very good at this and have a GPS you can put it in <b>map mode </b>and it will tell you what roadway you are on, your direction of travel, and most will tell you what cross street you are approaching. Your GPS should be mounted on the windshield to the left side of the steering wheel. Place it low against the dashboard (to comply with California Vehicle Code). <strong><strong> </strong></strong> 2) Enable hands-free driving each time you get into the car, just in case. <strong><strong> </strong></strong>When you drive, most new cars are enabled with bluetooth through the stereo so you can talk on the phone hands free. If your car does not have this I recommend getting a blue tooth head set or at the very minimum a single ear bud. This will allow you to talk on the phone hands free while you are driving. Every time you get into the car activate these or put in your earbud. If you have a holder for your phone keep your phone in it and put it high on the dashboard so you can activate your phone by hand without looking away from the road.
<h6><b>WHEN YOU SPOT THE DRUNK DRIVER</b></h6>
<strong><strong> </strong></strong> 3) Call 911 If you happen to spot a drunk driver stay behind the car and keep your distance.  Call 9-1-1 on your cell phone. You may end up getting a different law enforcement agency (local police or sheriff’s department) dispatch center. Just tell them where you are and they will direct your call. <strong><strong> </strong></strong> 4) Share as much relevant information about the situation as possible Once you have a dispatcher on the phone tell them <b>where you are</b> (westbound I-10, northbound I-5, eastbound 91, ect).  Tell them what the <b>nearest cross street or freeway exit you are approaching or have just passed</b>.   Tell them <b>what you are seeing</b> (swerving in the lanes, driving with the lights off, speeding up or slowing down). <strong><strong> </strong></strong>The dispatcher will ask you for the<b> license plate number of the vehicle</b>, the <b>license plate state,</b>  the <b>make and model</b>, <b>color</b>, and <b>any other distinguishable items on the vehicle</b>.  It is okay if you are unsure of any of these details, just provide as much as possible. <strong><strong> </strong></strong> 5) Answer the dispatcher’s questions They will probably ask your name and phone number. It is okay to give this information. They may ask some other questions. If you are not sure of the answers just tell them that..  They may ask you to follow the vehicle and will be updating the officers as they are responding. Do so only if you feel comfortable and if there is no risk to you. The law enforcement agency will update their officers and <b>when they get closer they may ask you to turn on your hazard lights so they can spot you in traffic.</b> Once they are in position they will move in behind the vehicle and initiate the vehicle stop. Since you are a safe distance from the car they should be able to do this. <strong><strong> </strong></strong> Jim Muratet, Deputy Sheriff (Ret.) <strong>Riverside County Sheriff’s Department</strong>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Get Noticed on LinkedIn</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-get-noticed-on-linkedin/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 03 Mar 2015 02:01:34 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jenna-perelman]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=260</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[You’ve heard it before and I’m here to tell you again – LinkedIn is a crucial part of today’s online job search! Take full advantage of the site’s opportunity to present yourself using the following tips and stay tuned for the rest of the LinkedIn series on TWIGG How-To:

<hr />

- Don’t neglect the bio! This gives you the opportunity to describe yourself quickly. It’s a little like the cover letter – something potential employers can scan without having to go through your whole page. Be sure to include keywords so you will be found in searches.

- Remember that just like your resume, your LinkedIn profile is a living document. Update it regularly.

- Have a catchy, descriptive headline – this is CRUCIAL! Your headline shows up next to your name all over LinkedIn, so people see this even when they haven’t clicked to look at your full profile.

- You can reorder your skills and even entire sections of your profile so you can present the most compelling information at the top. Have a lot of awards? You can move that section higher in your profile to showcase your accomplishments. All sections of your profile can be reordered.

- Skills can be reordered too! Consider placing the skills in which you earned the most endorsements at the top or the ones that you want people to see first, regardless of endorsements.

- Join relevant groups like alumni associations and job seeker organizations. Once you’re in a group, you can send messages to members with whom you aren’t directly connected. If you aren’t in the group, you would have to send the member an “InMail,” which is available only for premium (read: paying) LinkedIn members.

- Seek out endorsements from previous employers and colleagues - these are basically online references.

- Have a profile photo! Giving your profile a face will make you look much more professional, and you’ll be more likely to get responses from people.

- Add the industry you work in. This is a section in the very top part of your profile, in all the information next to your profile photo (which you’ve included, right?).   Some LinkedIn facts, courtesy of LinkHumans (find more <a href="http://www.businessinsider.com/optimize-linkedin-profile-recruiters-come-to-you-2014-7">here</a>):
<ol>
	<li>Adding a profile photo can result in 14 times more views than someone without.</li>
	<li>Your profile is 5 times more likely to be viewed if you join and are active in groups.</li>
	<li>Members who include skills get around 13 times more profile views.</li>
</ol>
&nbsp;
<h6>Okay, so now you're ready to go out there and get a job! Any other tips on getting noticed? Leave them in the comments below!</h6>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Master the NY Subway</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-master-the-ny-subway/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 02 Mar 2015 18:43:26 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jackie-serame]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=639</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_853" align="aligncenter" width="615"]<a style="color: #000000;" href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Taking-the-Subway.jpg"><img class="size-large wp-image-853" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Taking-the-Subway-1024x683.jpg" alt="Photo Credit: Isaac Arjonilla" width="615" height="410" /></a> <span style="color: #000000;">Photo Credit: Isaac Arjonilla</span>[/caption]

Navigating public transportation systems is tricky—New York City’s subway system is a prime example. New York has 4 main subway lines, local and express trains, <i>and</i> separate uptown and downtown platforms at some stops. Of all the subway systems I’ve become familiar with, New York is by far the least friendly for new-comers, thanks to the lack of clear signage on the platform and on the train. What does this mean for you? Always know where you’re going ahead of time; or, read this article to know what to look out for. <span style="color: #000000;"><strong><strong> </strong></strong></span> <span style="color: #000000;"><b>WALKING TO OR FROM YOUR DESTINATION: </b></span> <span style="color: #000000;">While most people naturally walk around thinking “the street numbers are getting larger and the avenues are getting smaller”, it makes a world of difference when you start thinking in traditional compass terms (north, east, south, west) since you won’t always be able to see the street signs coming out of the subway exit. Knowing that you’re facing west, and that you’ll need to walk east out of the exit, will help you avoid walking in the wrong direction for twenty minutes.</span> <span style="color: #000000;"><strong><strong> </strong></strong></span> <span style="color: #000000;">Also, become familiar with the tall buildings (i.e. knowing that if the Empire State Building is close to 33rd and 5th will give you some bearings), then try to memorize which avenues run north or south (e.g. Broadway is a one-way road heading south). I’m not saying you should study the entire map of NY, but if you’re taking the subway to work everyday then get to know the main streets and landmarks surrounding your office.</span> <span style="color: #000000;"><strong><strong> </strong></strong></span> <span style="color: #000000;"><b>BUYING A TICKET:</b></span> <span style="color: #000000;">Should I get an unlimited card, or not? Typically the answer is <i>not</i>. The math is simple, just don’t forget to include the 5% you get back. Usually it’s obvious when an unlimited monthly metrocard is necessary—taking the subway 2+ times a day or you’re on vacation exploring New York. <a style="color: #000000;" href="http://bigappled.com/2014/09/15/nyc-subway-trick/">This</a> is a great article on how to save money if you’re just visiting.</span> <span style="color: #000000;"><strong><strong> </strong></strong></span> <span style="color: #000000;"><b>THINGS TO CONSIDER WHEN ON THE MOVE: </b></span> <span style="color: #000000;">Make sure to check for the following:</span>
<ul>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Which subway line do you need?</span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Is the entrance Uptown or Downtown only?</span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Which stop are you getting off at and roughly how many stops will it be? (do <i>not</i> rely on having the train’s stops spelled out for you on the train!)</span></li>
</ul>
<span style="color: #000000;"><strong><strong> </strong></strong></span>
<h6><span style="color: #000000;">Lastly, of course, do not panic! If you speak English don’t be timid to ask someone a question—New Yorkers are usually quite nice when visitors admit they’re lost. With minimal preparation, you’ll be ready to tackle that subway in no time!</span></h6>
<span style="color: #000000;"> </span>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_webdados_fb_open_graph_specific_image]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_wp_rp_related_posts_query_result_cache_5]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:10:{i:0;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1045";s:5:"score";s:17:"25.11521479516655";}i:1;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1581";s:5:"score";s:18:"24.166298836003346";}i:2;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"768";s:5:"score";s:17:"23.49335436267984";}i:3;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"262";s:5:"score";s:18:"22.529678188759227";}i:4;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2671";s:5:"score";s:18:"17.390750113343316";}i:5;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1527";s:5:"score";s:17:"16.70352197466135";}i:6;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2654";s:5:"score";s:17:"16.11877257974116";}i:7;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"227";s:5:"score";s:18:"12.878152971996553";}i:8;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2975";s:5:"score";s:18:"12.375524115461767";}i:9;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"3384";s:5:"score";s:17:"11.79077472054158";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Decorate a Small Space Efficiently</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-decorate-a-small-space/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 02 Mar 2015 18:59:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[karissa-chamblin]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=644</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Decorating your living space, (whether it be your first apartment or your college dorm) in my opinion, is a necessity for living a full life.  Having a home that you feel comfortable in, can be proud of, and reflects you as a person can greatly affect your mood on a daily basis. Sometimes though, decorating can be a challenge. For the majority of young adults, we most commonly lack space and money to achieve the look we really dream about. But those factors don’t have to hold you back if you know the tricks. I have lived in and decorated more tiny apartments then I care to remember but each one of them reflected me as a whole, made me happy, and didn’t break my bank. Here are five simple tricks and example pics to get the biggest bang for your buck, and the most out of your space. <strong><strong> </strong></strong>
<h5 style="text-align: center;"><b>Color Is Important.</b></h5>
When you are deciding on a general look for a smaller space, it is important to note that everything needs to be cohesive. Making sure each room has a similar color scheme and feel, will make the space flow better and seem larger. It is important to not weigh down the space with heavy colors. Whether you choose warm tones like soft reds, pinks, and beiges, or you choose cool tones like bright blues, greys and whites, make sure they are fresh and light. Keep the walls neutral and use pops of color in the artwork or throw pillows.

[caption id="attachment_137" align="aligncenter" width="225"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Decorating-a-small-space-1.jpg"><img class="alignnone  wp-image-647" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Decorating-a-small-space-1.jpg" alt="Decorating a small space-1" width="225" height="338" /></a> source: stylemepretty.com[/caption]

&nbsp;
<h5 style="text-align: center;"><b>Skip The Big Furniture.</b></h5>
Everyone loves a great big comfy couch, but they are SO wrong for small spaces. They are usually overstuffed and take up way too much room. When looking for seating, opt for a more streamlined sofa that is low to the ground and small in scale. Bonus points if it’s a sleeper sofa. Loveseats are a great alternative to a full size sofa, as well as smaller side chairs with a recliner option. Also, using a coffee table with space to store underneath is always a good idea. Side tables that have drawers or shelves for extra storage is another great space saver.

[caption id="attachment_137" align="aligncenter" width="225"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Decorating-a-small-space-2.jpg"><img class="alignnone  wp-image-647" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Decorating-a-small-space-2.jpg" alt="Decorating a small space-2" width="225" height="338" /></a> source:cupcakesandcutlery.com[/caption]

<strong><strong> </strong></strong>
<h5 style="text-align: center;"><b>Think Multi-Purpose.</b></h5>
When creating your new space, it is important to always think functionality. If you don’t have room for a dining table, office desk, or a vanity for doing makeup, combine them by using a bistro table with bar stools underneath and hang a mirror above it. The bar stools can then be moved around for additional seating, without taking up a ton of space. If you don’t have a closet, hang your clothes from a horizontal pole over your bed as a fun headboard. Use bookshelves to divide a room and also to get more storage space.

[caption id="attachment_137" align="aligncenter" width="225"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Decorating-a-small-space-3.jpg"><img class="alignnone  wp-image-647" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Decorating-a-small-space-3.jpg" alt="Decorating a small space-3" width="225" height="338" /></a> source: Slownoodle.com[/caption]

<strong><strong> </strong></strong>
<h5 style="text-align: center;"><b>Use Empty Space.</b></h5>
Empty space is everywhere and you just have to be creative when using it, because the possibilities are endless! Plastic bins or baskets can easily be filled with shoes, jewelry or blankets and slid underneath your bed. Hang temporary shelving all the way up your walls for displaying books and knick knacks or dishes in the kitchen. Side tables with big empty bottom shelves can perfectly fit baskets for extra storage. Pretty decorative trays or shallow baskets can be used to neatly organize remotes on a table. The middle of your kitchen is a great place to put a rolling cart to store cutting boards and cookbooks, and the cart can be moved to the side if you need more space.

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Decorating-a-small-space-5.2.jpg"><img class="wp-image-654 alignleft" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Decorating-a-small-space-5.2.jpg" alt="Decorating a small space-5.2" width="235" height="313" /></a>     <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Decorating-a-small-space-4.jpg"><img class="wp-image-655 alignright" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Decorating-a-small-space-4.jpg" alt="Decorating a small space-4" width="234" height="312" /></a>
<p style="text-align: center;"></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"></p>
<p style="text-align: center;">source: awesomedorms.tumblr.com</p>
&nbsp;
<h5 style="text-align: center;"><b>Shop On A Budget.</b></h5>
Before you start decorating your space, set a monthly budget for decor items. I think the best spaces are ones with character and that look like a collection of wonderful things that have been picked up over time. Take your time when decorating. Not everything has to be from one store or one style or picked up at one time. Stick to your budget with the idea that you can buy a little at a time. My favorite inexpensive stores to shop for decor items are Ikea and Target. Ikea is awesome for storage items and furniture, and Target is perfect for smaller items and replicas of higher priced, on trend styles. I often find vintage pieces at my local thrift stores for super cheap.

[caption id="attachment_137" align="aligncenter" width="225"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Decorating-a-small-space-6.jpg"><img class="alignnone  wp-image-647" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Decorating-a-small-space-6.jpg" alt="Decorating a small space-6" width="225" height="338" /></a> source: Ikea.com[/caption]
<h6></h6>
<h6><strong> Having a home (no matter how small) is a truly wonderful feeling and shouldn’t be stressful. So be smart about space, be wise about purchases, and keep it simple. These tricks will surely help you make a beautiful home.</strong></h6>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Build Your Credit History</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-build-your-credit-history/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 01 Mar 2015 02:13:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jackie-serame]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=744</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="text-align: center;">Having a credit history can help you get an apartment, car, house, loans, etc. If you wanted to rent an apartment, for example, your credit score would or could signal either: you will be a responsible tenant that always pay your bills on time and in full (with a <span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>high credit score</strong></span>), or you might be an awful tenant since you tend to max out your credit cards and are slow to pay them down (a <span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>low credit score</strong></span>). If you don’t have any credit history, you might be asked to provide pay stubs, bank account information, and/or (in this case) make a large rent deposit.<strong><strong> </strong></strong></p>
<p style="text-align: center;">Don’t wait until you’ve got a bad credit score; it’s important to know right NOW what having “credit” really means or how to start building a credit history.</p>

<h5 style="text-align: center;"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Here are some insider tips on what you need to know!</span></h5>
&nbsp;
<ol>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><b> As soon as you have a steady job, apply for a student credit card (if you’re a student)</b></span></li>
</ol>
First and foremost, student credit cards are easier to be approved for than your typical high-rewards credit cards and innately have lower credit limits—typically the limit is a realistic amount that you can pay back based on your salary at the time and how much money you have in your bank account. The only reason you should be doing this is to start build your payment history, which is one of the factors of your credit score. Not sure which credit card to get? <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/credit-card-options/"><strong>We have an article on that!</strong></a>
<ol start="2">
	<li><b></b><span style="color: #000000;"> <b>Pay your bills on time and in full</b></span></li>
</ol>
Once you’re approved, just charge a small amount that you can afford (perhaps the internet bill, coffee, gas, etc.) every month and <b><i>pay it in full and on time</i></b>. While carrying a balance to the next month isn’t the end of the world, it’s good to get in the habit of paying your credit card in full to work towards the highest credit score. Carrying a balance also subjects you to paying interest, and no one enjoys paying more for what they bought. The worst you can do for your credit history is forget a payment or purposely avoid paying your bills on a maxed out credit card… If you might be susceptible to that, you’re not ready for a credit card.
<ol start="3">
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><b> Check your credit score every now and then</b></span></li>
</ol>
Federal law states that everyone is entitled to one free credit report every 12 months from each of the three national credit bureaus [<a href="http://www.annualcreditreport.com/">http://www.annualcreditreport.com/</a>]. Make sure that you’re building your credit in the right direction and that all of the information is correct and up to date. If your score isn’t as high as you expect it to be, review your habits and look into what steps could benefit you—this can range from lowering your credit card utilization (the amount of credit you use versus the amount of credit you’re given) to opening another credit card account. Here are great articles from CreditKarma that further detail what is accounted for in a credit score and on what a good credit score would be: <a href="https://www.creditkarma.com/article/what-goes-into-credit-score">https://www.creditkarma.com/article/what-goes-into-credit-score</a> <strong><a href="https://www.creditkarma.com/faq/what-is-a-good-credit-score">https://www.creditkarma.com/faq/what-is-a-good-credit-score</a></strong>   Picture source creditscorequiz.com]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Become a Baseball Fan</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-become-a-baseball-fan/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 03 Mar 2015 10:16:48 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Rachel Wiegardt-Egel]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=746</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>&nbsp;</p>[caption id="attachment_883" align="aligncenter" width="865"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/about-us/our-team/"><img class="size-full wp-image-883" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/TWIGG-Baseball-2.jpg" alt="Photo Credit: Author" width="865" height="690" /></a> Photo Credit: Author[/caption]<h5 style="text-align: center;">Baseball and I….we got a love thing.</h5><p style="text-align: left;">I've been going to baseball games since before I can remember. Cheering as the Oakland A's won their twentieth game in a row (a still unbeaten American League record), rooting against the New York Yankees dynasty of the late nineties, watching as the Boston Red Sox won their first world series in almost 90 years—these are some of my most vivid childhood memories. But most of my female friends didn't watch baseball as we were growing up. Maybe they just didn't like it? Or maybe no one ever taught them how to love the game because they're girls.</p><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><p>But baseball isn't a boys' club anymore, and women make up almost half of all Major League Baseball fans. These days, if you're baseball-illiterate, you're just as likely to get caught off guard in a conversation about last night's crazy playoff game with your lady coworkers as you are to nod along without a clue as your dad and brother go on and on about Kershaw's ridiculously low ERA.</p><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><p>There's so much to gain from being a fan. Yes, ballplayers are often attractive (see <a href="http://www.buzzfeed.com/mattbellassai/a-bootylicious-tribute-to-baseballs-finest-butts#.uc4jDzRap">this <i>Buzzfeed</i> homage</a> for proof). Yeah, you probably look damn cute in a baseball tee. But most of all, baseball fandom offers equal footing. In a ballpark, when your favorite slugger knocks one out of the park or a young upstart pitcher miraculously throws a perfect game, it doesn't matter if you're male or female—it only matters that you're a fan.</p><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><p>So let's talk about baseball, ladies.</p><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><h3><b>Basics (or, "I can carry on a conversation about the game we're watching.")</b></h3><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><p><b>The Goal:</b> To get more "runs" (points) than the other team. A team gets a run if one of their players crosses through all of the bases when that team is hitting, or "at bat."</p><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><p><b>Innings:</b> There are nine innings in a game. Each inning is split into two—the top and the bottom. One team bats in each half and the other team plays different positions in the field, trying to prevent their opponents at bat from scoring runs. After three players on the batting team get called out by the umpires, it's the other team's turn to bat. The "home team" is the team whose stadium the game is being played in— they bat in the bottom of each inning (which gives them the advantage of having a last chance to bat if they're losing at the end of the game).</p><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><p><b>The Positions:</b> A baseball field is a square (known as a "diamond") with a base at each corner (first base, second base, third base, and home base). There's a raised area called the pitcher's mound in the middle of the diamond. Beyond the diamond or "infield", there's an "outfield," surrounded by a wall.</p><ul><li>Pitcher: Stands on the pitcher's mound, throws the ball for the batter to try to hit. His pitches are called either "balls" or "strikes."</li><li>Catcher: Squats behind home plate, catches the pitches.</li><li>1st Baseman: Responsible for covering first base, which usually means either catching a throw from another player and tagging out the batter as they run to first base or fielding a ball that comes to them.</li><li>2nd Baseman: Responsible for covering second base, which often means fielding a ball that comes to second base and throwing it to first.</li><li>3rd Baseman: Responsible for covering third base, which often means fielding a ball that comes to third base and throwing it to first or second.</li><li>Shortstop: Responsible for covering the area between the second baseman and the third baseman.</li><li>Right fielder: Covers the outfield area behind the 1st baseman—this usually means catching balls that are hit in the air or fielding a ball hit on the ground and throwing it to the infield.</li><li>Center fielder: Covers the outfield area behind the 2nd baseman—this also usually means catching balls that are hit in the air or fielding a ball hit on the ground and throwing it to the infield.</li><li>Left fielder: Covers the outfield area behind the 3rd baseman—this too usually means (you guessed it!) catching balls that are hit in the air or fielding a ball hit on the ground and throwing it to the infield.</li></ul><p><strong><strong> <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/TWIGG-BASEBALL.jpg"><img class=" size-large wp-image-880 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/TWIGG-BASEBALL-1024x748.jpg" alt="TWIGG BASEBALL" width="615" height="449" /></a></strong></strong></p><p><b>Three Ways a Player Can Get Out:</b></p><ul><li>They hit the ball and someone on the other team catches it without the ball bouncing—called a "fly ball." This can happen in either "fair territory" (the area of the field within the lines branching from home plate through the outfield) or "foul territory" (outside the lines).</li><li>They get tagged out at one of the plates after the ball is fielded by the opposing team. When there's another player running after, the defending player can simply tag the base; in this case, the first runner can't turn around and has to keep running to the base the fielder has just tagged—called a "force out." If the fielders can throw the ball quickly enough to beat runners at two bases, both runners are out and it's called a "double play."</li><li>They strike out. To throw a strike, a pitcher has to get the ball in the "strike zone" (the area above the batter's knees, below the midpoint between the batter's waist and shoulders, and over home plate). If the pitcher throws three strikes, it's a "strikeout." If the batter swings and misses, or if he hits the ball into foul territory, that is also considered a strike. (However, a foul ball is never the third strike that would end the hitters at bat.)</li></ul><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><p><b>A Few Ways to Get on Base and Score: </b></p><ul><li>Get a hit: Getting a hit allows the batter to run to a base. The number of bases they run through before they have to stop (to avoid getting out) determines what the hit is called. One base = a single. Two bases = a double. Three bases = a triple. All four bases = a home run. Whenever someone gets a home run, the team gets one run for each player who was on base and now gets to run to home base: if the bases are "full" (meaning there is a player from the team at bat on every base at the time of the home run), the team at bat gets four runs and it's called a "grand slam."</li><li>Get a "walk:" if a pitcher throws four balls that are outside the strike zone and the batter doesn't swing at them, the batter gets to walk to first base and all runners advance.</li><li>Get hit: by far the least pleasant way! If a batter gets hit by a pitch (unintentionally, of course), they advance to first base.</li></ul><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><p>That's it! That's all you've got to know to understand most of what happens in a game of baseball. Now let's get into some of the juicier details:</p><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><h3><b>Intermediate (or, "Yeah, that's right. I know things.")</b></h3><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><p><b>Sacrifice Fly:</b> When a fly ball is hit, a runner who is already on base has to stay on the base (they're not allowed to run to the next base). However, if a batter hits a fly ball deep into the outfield, there is sometimes time for a runner to run to the next base after the ball has already been caught and the batter is out. This is called "tagging up"—the runner must wait until the ball is caught and then they can take off in a sprint for the next base. This is only possible when there are zero outs or one outs: if there are already two outs and the ball is caught, that's the third out and the other team is up to bat. If a runner scores while tagging up, the batter is said to have hit a "sacrifice fly," also called a "sac fly:" they sacrificed being on base to advance the runner.</p><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><p><b>Pop Fly:</b> A short fly ball hit into the infield. Often goes very high in the air—hence the name "pop" fly.</p><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><p><b>Stealing a Base:</b> Sometimes, when a runner who's on base is really fast, they run to the next base as the pitcher is throwing a pitch. If the catcher, after having caught the ball, throws it to the next base quickly enough to beat the runner, the runner is out, but if the runner is "safe" (meaning they made it to the base before the catcher's throw did), they're said to have "stolen" the base. Sometimes a pitcher will throw a "wild pitch" or the catcher will miss the ball (called a "passed ball") and the runner can easily run to the next base.</p><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><p><b>Error:</b> When a fielder mishandles the ball in a play that should have led to an out. For example: if an outfielder catches the ball and seems to have control over it, but then drops it and allows the runner to advance or remain on base, that would definitely be considered an error.</p><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><p><b>ERA:</b> In baseball statistics, this is the number of runs a pitcher gives up on average per nine innings they pitch. The lower, the better!</p><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><p><b>AVG:</b> The average number of hits a player gets per at bat, calculated by dividing the number of hits by the number of at bats. It's pronounced as if it's multiplied by 1,000, so having a batting average of .200 is called "batting two hundred."</p><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><p><b>American League/National League: </b>These are the two leagues within Major League Baseball (with teams in the U.S. and Canada). Each league has three divisions with five teams each: East, West, and Central. There's one major difference between them: in the National League (examples: San Francisco Giants, Chicago Cubs), the pitcher bats with all of the other players on the team. But pitchers have to devote so much time to practicing pitching over their career that they're usually not the best at batting (to put it rather gently). So the American League (examples: Oakland Athletics, Boston Red Sox) has a solution: they have a "designated hitter" in the lineup who hits in place of the pitcher but doesn't have a position in the field.</p><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><p><b>Postseason:</b> Another advantage to becoming a baseball fan: there are games pretty much any day of the week during baseball season, and the season covers about half the year—always something to watch! Starting in April, each team plays 162 games in about 180 days. With 30 teams in the MLB, there are literally <i>thousands</i> of games. At the end of September, the regular season ends and the best teams from that year compete in the postseason playoffs to become that year's champion.The first round of the playoffs is the Division Series: in this round, four teams from each league compete and the two who beat their opponents in three out of five games move on to the Championship Series. The team from each league who wins four out of seven games moves on to the World Series to face the other league's representative in a best-of-seven game series.</p><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><h3><b>Advanced (or, "Bow down to my baseball knowledge.")</b></h3><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><p><b>Balk:</b> When a runner is on base, sometimes a pitcher will make a movement that makes it appear like he is going to pitch the ball when in fact he has no intention of doing so in that moment. Although this happens rarely, if it happens when there is a runner on base, the umpire will call it a balk and any runners will get to advance one base. The idea here is that the pitcher can't trick a runner into taking off for the next base while actually intending to throw him out.</p><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><p><b>Infield Fly Rule:</b> Another rule to prevent trickery! Think about this scenario: if there are runners at first and second and a batter hits a pop fly to the second baseman, the runners on first and second will stay on the base because they assume the catch will be made and the batter will be out. If the second baseman can easily catch the ball but decides last minute not to catch it, the ball is still in play but the runners are still on their bases. The fielders can easily throw players out at third, and/or second base, either of which would be a force out. And that would be ridiculous, right? So when an umpire sees that a pop fly is hit in the infield when there are fewer than two outs and there is a force play at third base, and the umpire thinks the ball can be caught with ordinary effort, he will signal that he is invoking the infield fly rule. If the ball drops to the ground in this case, the batter is still out and the runners don't have to try to run to the next base.</p><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><p><b>Dropped Third Strike:</b> When a pitcher throws a third strike but the catcher doesn't catch it, the batter has a chance to run to first, even though they've struck out. They usually get thrown out by the catcher before they make it to first. But hey, worth a try!</p><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><p><b>Wild Card:</b> Since there are only three divisions in each league, and there need to be four teams playing in each league's Division Series, there's a fourth playoff team from each league called the "wild card." There is a one game playoff between the two teams in each league who have the best record of wins vs. losses (who are not already going to the playoffs) to see who will win the wild card for each league.</p><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><p>If there's one thing I've learned in my 23 years watching this sport, it's that something unexpected happens in basically every game. Things will be going along, business as usual, when all of a sudden, even the seasoned baseball experts around you will start saying, "Whoa, never seen that before!" So if you don't know what's going on, don't be afraid to ask questions. Ask them to your partners in fandom, or ask them here!</p><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><p style="text-align: center;">Suggested Supplemental "Reading:" go watch <i>A League of Their Own</i>. It's a movie about the All-American Girls Professional Baseball League that cropped up when all the male ballplayers went to fight in World War II. It's got Geena Davis (who's certainly doing her part these days to create a damsel-free world over at the <a href="http://seejane.org/">Geena Davis Institute on Gender in Media</a>), Rosie O'Donnell, Tom Hanks, Madonna, baseball, ladies, 40s dance numbers…has there ever been such a winning cinematic combination??</p><h5 style="text-align: center;"><br /><span style="text-decoration: underline;">It's amazing.</span> <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Watch it.</span></h5><p>&nbsp;</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Work Remotely</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/a-guide-to-working-remotely/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 28 Feb 2015 03:59:12 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[emily-hsiang]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=758</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[It’s 2015, and the working world is changing. Not everyone works in an office, and it’s nice to know your options. For example, there are now coworking communities where you can pay rent to work in a communal area instead of owning your own office. Cool, right? Another option, especially in the startup tech boom of this era, is working remotely. I work in a film production startup. Since it's a startup, everyone needs to do everything. And when everyone is trying to do everything, everything gets interrupted. It's fun for sure - days of petting kittens and chatting and eating lunches together - but they are not productive. I was editing an ad, going nowhere and getting really frustrated, when my manager said, "Why don't you stay at home tomorrow morning and work at home?" That's when we started to try "remote working.” Now I've remote worked for a whole year, and I can honestly say that it was the best thing that has happened to me professionally and emotionally. What is remote working? Well, remote working is literally, working remotely. You can work at home (or a cafe, or at the park or in a cave) in your own comforts and be in charge of your own time. <strong><strong> </strong></strong>
<h6><b>BEING REMOTE </b></h6>
Stay at home, go to a cafe, do a work-study session on Skype as you edit your film while your friend does her homework 12 hours away. Getting stuff done in your own setting is awesome. <strong><strong> </strong></strong>
<h6><b>WHAT DOES IT MEAN</b></h6>
Being remote means your manager won't be judging you for everything you do. That's good because you can work without eyes probing your back, but note that the quality of work you present at the end of the day becomes the sole indicator of your work of the day. Remote working doesn't give you a magic code for slacking off, instead you have to work twice as hard and be dedicated to make sure things go right. <strong><strong> </strong></strong>
<h6><b>COMMUNICATION</b></h6>
Communication is your go-to for every situation. Asking questions are easy to be looked over because, well, you're alone all the time. Making sure you all are on the same page is super important. Our team uses Slack (<a href="http://www.slack.com">www.slack.com</a>) for our communications. Everything on it gets saved, and we're on there for work only. <strong><strong> </strong></strong>
<h6><b>BE DISCIPLINED</b></h6>
Trust is a huge thing in remote working. Would you trust Bert Simpson for taking out the trash nicely? No, ‘cause he never finishes anything he does. Would you trust Batman to save Gotham? Yes, ‘cause he's cool and rad like that. People have reputations. Team members have to trust in each other for remote working to work. <strong><strong> </strong></strong>
<h6><b>DON'T BAIL</b></h6>
Trust needs building and time, and the only way to do so is to be responsible. Own up to your mistakes when you do something wrong. Yes, it’s terrible being wrong, but part of being in a team means solving problems. I once promised a theater that I’d send them the DVD to our film, and forgot about it. The theater only remembered that there was supposed to be a DVD like hours before the screening. She sent me probably 16 emails. It was 12:30 a.m. and I panicked and cried and called my manager. After she calmed me down, we ended up sending a digital movie file to the theater and the crisis was solved. Even then, she could tell I was crying a bit and spent even more time comforting me and telling me that it was okay. My boss could have bailed on me that night, but she didn't. She picked up the phone, took responsibility and helped me. That kind of dedication to work is profound.
<h6>I hope this article gave you some new perspective on your working options, and also explored the world of remote working. Maybe it's not for you and maybe it is, but I hope you get to try new experiences while you're young and see what the best fit is. Any interesting working environments you want to share? Leave it in the comments below!</h6>
<h6></h6>
<h6>Picture source ercwttmn, Flicker</h6>]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2306]]></wp:meta_value>

		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_wp_rp_related_posts_query_result_cache_expiration]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1462914918]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_wp_rp_related_posts_query_result_cache_5]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:10:{i:0;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2182";s:5:"score";s:18:"19.142332765612956";}i:1;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"3092";s:5:"score";s:18:"17.756038404493065";}i:2;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1695";s:5:"score";s:17:"17.21626037281668";}i:3;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1651";s:5:"score";s:18:"15.250512467421249";}i:4;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1631";s:5:"score";s:18:"14.862200438404198";}i:5;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"234";s:5:"score";s:18:"14.862200438404198";}i:6;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2654";s:5:"score";s:18:"12.125197829378079";}i:7;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"310";s:5:"score";s:17:"11.54983368448803";}i:8;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"3321";s:5:"score";s:18:"11.127215497234697";}i:9;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2382";s:5:"score";s:18:"11.127215497234697";}}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Write a Salary History Like a Boss</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-write-a-salary-history-like-a-boss/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 03 Mar 2015 04:04:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[shaina-rivera]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=762</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Applying for a new job may be a complicated and stressful time. The process of the applying, interviewing, and negotiating salary may be an unnerving experience. But you shouldn’t sweat it! Creating a salary history is just another supplemental reference employers may request to review a candidate. Many recruiters use salary histories as a screening tool of what they may offer candidates. It may be tricky since many employers use it as a bargaining tactic when negotiating possible pay. But remember, salary histories serve as a timeline of what you’ve earned. f you’re a high-wage earner or even applying to an entry-level position, you can still write a stellar salary history in less than 15 minutes! Here’s a couple of dos and don’ts when developing your salary history:

&nbsp;

<b>Do: Read the directions carefully!</b>

Does the employer want you to include this information on the application? Or on your cover letter? Or as a separate document?  Make sure you follow your employer’s instructions. If salary is not explicitly asked for, don’t include it.

&nbsp;

<b>Do: Organize your information</b>

Create a separate document that lists important detailed information for each position you’ve held. Include  the name of your position followed by your employer’s name, how long you spent inthat position, and your starting and ending salaries. If you don’t know your salary, putting your starting and ending hourly wage will work too. Start with your current or most recent position and then repeat this information for each position you’ve held. Include all full-time jobs and positions that are relevant to what you’re applying for.

&nbsp;

<hr />
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Example:</span></p>
<strong>Information Decision Support Associate
</strong><em>Apex Health Solutions, Palo Alto, CA</em>
<em>November 2011 – Present</em>

Starting Salary: $43,290
Current Salary: $47,850

&nbsp;

<strong>Technology Support Assistant
</strong><em>BIOLIVE Enterprises Inc., Seattle, WA.</em>
<em>May 2009 – November 2011</em>

Starting Salary: $41,075
Ending Salary: $42,694

&nbsp;

<hr />

<b>Don’t: lie about your salary!</b>

This is obvious. Many recruiters will verify your salary. If you’re caught lying about your salary (or on your resume), you’re only hurting yourself and your chances for gaining a new job.

&nbsp;

<b>Don’t: forget to breathe</b>

Again, applying is stressful! And if you’re anything like me, I’m a perfectionist who likes to have everything in order from my cover letter, resume, salary history to a list of my professional references. However, don’t forget to take a step back and understand that it’s all a simple process. Don’t overcomplicate things. More importantly, don’t feel discouraged if your salary is less than where you want it to be.

<strong><strong> </strong></strong>
<h6>Now that you have the tools and several tips to guide you, developing your salary history should be effortless! And that is how a confident, intelligent, and motivated lady develops a salary history.</h6>
&nbsp;

Picture from Liz Ryan of Forbes.com]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How I ALMOST Did My Taxes</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-i-almost-did-my-taxes/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 01 Mar 2015 04:11:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[alex-regalado]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=772</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[My mother broke the news early last night – I would be doing my own taxes from now on. I had been dreading this, but at the same time felt confident that I could do it! How hard could it be? Well… I’m not exaggerating when I say that my mother and I ended up laughing in hysterics at how ridiculous the process was. I didn’t want to title this a “How To” guide, because I honestly still don’t know how to do it! Therefore, this is my experience trying to do my taxes, and what I learned. <strong><strong> </strong></strong>

<hr />

<h6></h6>
<h6><b>The Basics</b></h6>
All your employers for the past year will need to send you <a href="https://turbotax.intuit.com/tax-tools/tax-tips/IRS-Tax-Forms/What-is-a-W-2-Form-/INF14812.html">a W2</a> by Jan. 31. This will tell you the total amount of money you made for the year, and the amount of taxes taken out. It’s illegal for them to not send them, so follow up if you don’t receive one (they may have the wrong address for you). You will receive three copies: one for federal, one state, and one for you. <strong><strong> </strong></strong> You can also receive 1099s for miscellaneous income like freelance work. I received one for a contest I actually won! Since it was over $500, they had to send me a 1099, and I have to claim that on my taxes. There are probably other things you can receive, but those are the only two that I can have and had to look up. <strong><strong> </strong></strong> The basic process is that employers will send you these forms (W2 or 1099) to let you know how much you paid, and based on the types of documents they send will determine the form you have to fill out. Thankfully most of the instructions and guides that you will need can be found online. I’ve attached the chart below that tells you what form you need to fill out.

<hr />

<h6></h6>
<h6><b>The “Norm”- 1040EZ</b></h6>
My mom suggested that we start with the 1040EZ form, since that’s what most people use to file their taxes. This form is for single or joint fillers (married) who have no dependants. That’s me! It’s a federal tax form, so after you’re done you attach the federal copy of your W2. My mom also pulled out last year's form she filled out for me, and suggested that I save all my tax information in case I ever get audited (good to know!) <strong><strong> </strong></strong> Basically you just fill out the form. You name, info, and social security number at the top. In <strong>Box one</strong> you add up all the money you earned on your W2s, including any tips you earned. Apparently there is a limit for how much tips you have to claim, but I’m not sure what that is. If you make tips, you should research what that is so you don’t over claim. <strong><strong> </strong></strong> <strong>Box two</strong> says “taxable interests.” This comes from investments, savings, 401Ks, etc (none of which I have) so I didn’t fill that part out. <strong>Box three</strong> is for unemployment, which I also did not have. <strong>Box four</strong> asks you to add the previous boxes, and that’s your adjusted gross income. So for me, it was just Box one (the total of my W2s). <strong><strong> </strong></strong> <strong>Box five</strong> was a bit complicated. If you are claimed as a dependant by someone, check yes and write the amount. Since I graduated college in June, and my parents supported me for the first half of this year, they can claim me. So I checked yes. But how much money would I put? We found there is a chart for this too in the 1040EZ instructions (so many charts). It’s called the “Tax Table,” and it says based on the fact that you made $____, your parents can claim $____. So once you find that number for Box five, you subtract your adjusted gross income from the amount your parents claim (Box four from Box five). This new number is your taxable income. The next section is where you can record how much taxes have already been taken out of you income (this is the most important part!) Your W2s and other forms will list how much taxes were taken out total, so add all those up and list that for Box seven. I’m not sure what earned income credit is, or combat pay election, so we skipped those parts. <strong><strong> </strong></strong> Then once you have the number you were actually taxed, you go back to that tax table above and figure out how much you SHOULD have been taxed. Most of the time, it’s less than what you were actually taxed, and you’ll get your tax refund! You subtract what you should have paid from what you paid, and put that amount in Box 13a. You can also add your routing info to get the refund sent directly into your account. <strong><strong> </strong></strong> If you actually paid less than what you should've, you’ll have to pay more. There is a rule that said “if you make less than $10,000 you don’t have to file.” You might as well file if you’ve been paying taxes from your income, because you’ll probably get a refund. But if you add it up and you don’t get a refund, and you make less than $10,000, then you don’t have to file. <strong><strong> </strong></strong>

<hr />

<h6></h6>
<h6><b>1099s</b></h6>
Everything was going smoothly until we took a closer look at my 1099. I asked my mom, “Where do I include the money I won from the contest?” It didn’t belong in Box one, so we researched more. Back on that first chart I showed it, it states that if you have a 1099MISC you have to use a 1040 form instead (yes there is a 1040 form and a 1040EZ form). Then I was confused! Do I have to fill out both forms? My mom assured me that you only have to fill out one form, and that is based off what kind of income you have. Okay! So we started to fill out the 1040 form, but found that for 1099MISC you had to fill out an ADDITIONAL form- Section C? That’s when we decided to take a break. My only advice is to read all the instruction manuals provided and ask for help from a tax savy friend! <strong><strong> </strong></strong>

<hr />

<h6></h6>
<h6><b>Conclusion</b></h6>
If you have dependants, or have more complicated incomes, then the process is different. My parents have their taxes done for them, and I see why! I also have heard that TurboTax is free, and lets you know if you fill something out incorrectly. It might be easier to fill them out online, which is what I’m going to try to do soon.   Please note: we are not and do not claim to be tax advisers and we suggest speaking with a tax professional or your accountant for advice specific to your situation. This is general information and simply Alex's experience with filing her taxes.
<h6>Picture Source http://www.fbnstatic.com/</h6>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Decode Acronyms You&#039;ll Encounter in College</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/acronyms-youll-encounter-in-college/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 03 Mar 2015 04:16:01 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jenna-perelman]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=775</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[You’re in college: you’re learning from incredible professors, making tons of new friends, and growing in more ways than you could possibly imagine. When I first got to college, there were a dozen different acronyms that were part of the school’s lexicon - things I had simply never heard of before. It took me a while to pick up on my school’s specific abbreviations and acronyms, but here are some pretty universal ones to help get you started! <strong><strong> </strong></strong>
<h6><b>Degrees</b></h6>
<strong>BA</strong> = Bachelor of Arts <strong>BS</strong> = Bachelor of Science <strong>BFA</strong> = Bachelor of Fine Arts <strong>MA</strong> = Master of Arts <strong>MS/MSc</strong> = Master of Science <strong>Ph.D</strong> = Doctor of Philosophy (in this instance, “philosophy” doesn’t just mean the field of philosophy. It more accurately follows its original Greek meaning of “love of wisdom.” Doctorates are awarded to a variety of disciplines.) <strong><strong> </strong></strong>
<h6><b>Handy Terms</b></h6>
<strong>ASL</strong> = American Sign Language <strong>FAFSA</strong> = Free Application for Federal Student Aid <strong>GIS</strong> = Geographic Information Systems (broad term for a computer system designed to work with spatial and geographical data) <strong>IT</strong> = Information Technology <strong>STEM</strong> = Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics <strong><strong> </strong></strong>
<h6><b>Class Related Terms</b></h6>
<strong>TA</strong> = Teaching Assistant (can be undergraduate or graduate students) <strong>RA</strong> = Resident Assistant (usually an older student assigned to live in the dorms and help younger students acclimate to college life and keep students safe) <strong>GSI</strong> = Graduate Student Instructor (a graduate student teaching assistant)
<h6>Picture source www.cappex.com</h6>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Understand Health Insurance Terminology</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-understand-health-insurance/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 03 Mar 2015 04:17:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[devin-saragosa-harris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=778</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[With the Affordable Care Act (also called “Obamacare”) passed in 2010, health insurance became much more accessible in the United States than ever before. Unfortunately, <strong>it didn’t become any less complicated</strong> or confusing, especially for those of us who are now dealing with health insurance decisions for the first time.
<h5 style="text-align: center;">Here are some basic terms  and definitions when discussing health insurance to help get you started:</h5>

<hr />

<b>Premium: </b>the fees you pay every month to have insurance, generally a set amount (what you think of when you say “buying health insurance”). These fees cover both what insurance companies believe you will use in health care during the year plus some fees for administrative costs. <b>Deductible:</b> an amount of money you have to pay before your insurance “kicks in”. <b>Co-Pay:</b> a set amount for a certain service that you pay for. Generally, co-pays are used for drugs. For example, your pills may cost $40 over the counter, but you can pay $5 as a co-pay every time you buy them. <b>Out-of-Pocket (OOP):</b> All of the extra fees you, the insured party, pay. Another piece of information that is important to note when it comes to health insurance is that, in the United States, expenditures are a bit out of control. The US has the highest national expenditures for health care, and we do not even have universal health care (we also do not have the best health outcomes, even with these crazy costs). For this reason, the federal government plays a difficult game where it simultaneously tries to reduce unnecessary costs while increasing access to health care, which increases costs. It is because of this overspending that group and managed care plans (like HMOs) were created – to keep prices more contained for everyone involved. The basic health insurance types are: <b>FFS</b> (Fee-For-Service): The old-school type of health insurance, where your insurance company pays for every service individually – every diagnostic test, every x-ray, every doctor’s visit. Insurance companies have largely moved away from FFS because it encourages overuse by hospitals, which get paid more for doing tests and procedures that are not necessarily helpful or essential. <b>HMO </b>(Health Maintenance Organization): comparatively low “cost-sharing.” In generaly, this means you have lower premiums, deductibles and co-pays (which is great for your wallet!). However, they have less flexibility -  you have to stay within their network and choose doctors and specialists that are part of the HMO. If you really want to see a specialist that isn’t part of the HMO, your insurance will probably cover little to none of the cost. HMOs also use Primary Care Physicians as gatekeepers, which means that you have to see your PCP to get referrals to go to most types of specialists. Side note: women’s health specialists like obstetrics/gynecology doctors (OB/GYNs) generally can be seen without a PCP referral, even in the HMO model. <b>PPO</b> (Preferred Provider Organization): These plans cost more (higher premiums, deductibles, co-pays) but give the insured parties more flexibility. It is still cheaper to use services by doctors within the group, but if you want to see someone outside of the PPO, the PPO will absorb some of that cost. <b>POS</b> (Point-of-Service): This is a hybridized model, with more choices for the patient. POS is like an HMO in that you generally need to use a PCP to get specialist referrals, but then you can see specialists outside of your network, which is more like a PPO. Like the other plans, you incur higher costs with care outside of your network, but low costs if you stay within your network. In general, these plans really depend on how much flexibility you think you will need. If you are not picky about your doctors and it looks like your HMO has good doctors that are available close to your area, then it will be cheaper to choose an HMO. But if you are willing to spend more, you will get more choice in who your doctors are and where these doctors are located in reference to you. Big names like Kaiser and Blue Cross Blue Shield offer different plans, depending on your needs or your employer’s needs. Both Kaiser Permanente and Blue Cross Blue Shield offer HMO and PPO plans, and Kaiser Permanente offer POS plans in California.

<hr />

<b>But do you really </b><b><i>have</i></b><b> to buy health insurance? </b>That depends on what you mean. As young adults, many people do not feel the need to pay for health insurance, <i>especially</i> if they are uninsured or if their employers do not offer it. It makes sense – high costs for something that you might not use during the year. Insurance companies call this demographic the “young invincibles,” because these are young adults who believe they are immune to or do not have to worry about illnesses. So, in terms of necessity, oftentimes twentysomethings do not need insurance, at least not to the same extent that older adults need insurance. However, there are definite benefits to having health insurance. First, under the ACA, most preventive care services are fully covered and do not require co-pays. A full list of covered services can be found <a href="https://www.healthcare.gov/preventive-care-benefits">here</a>. Having access to preventive care, such as vaccines and routine screenings, has been linked to reduced illness morbidity and disability later in life in published studies. This means less pain and less costs in the long-term because of avoided hospitalizations, surgeries, and medications. Secondly, being young means you have a good shot at being healthy, but it is never a guarantee. Many illnesses affect older adults but are still seen in younger adults, just at a lower rate. Furthermore, accidents and injuries are always a possibility. The decision to stay uninsured as a young adult because of the “invincibility” belief is a form of gambling, but those decisions are personal and dependent on what you know about your health, your family history of illness and, of course, your financial state.

<hr />

Beyond the question of necessity, there is the question of <b>what happens if you are not buying insurance</b>. First, under the ACA, young adults under the age of 26 can stay insured through parental/guardian insurance. But if this is not an option, there are penalties under the Affordable Care Act – for 2015, you will have to pay $325 or 2% of your yearly income, whichever is higher. These penalties are increasing on a sliding scale as each year passes, and can be seen <a href="https://www.healthcare.gov/fees-exemptions/fee-for-not-being-covered/">here</a>: It should be noted that if you are unemployed, you may be eligible for an exemption from the penalty, depending on your income and if the fee is unaffordable. If, for one reason or another, you are uninsured and you need health care, you will still receive care if you visit the emergency room. Emergency rooms in the United States are required to treat all people who enter, but it will be more expensive. To find out if an emergency room, hospital, or doctor’s office in your area takes your insurance, you should call, and call before you desperately need it.

<hr />

&nbsp;
<h5 style="text-align: center;">Being proactive about your health care is the best way to protect both your wallet and your health. Let us know if there are any other terms you found confusing when dealing with health insurance and we'll be sure to explain more in a future post!</h5>
&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
