	<item>
		<title>Pumping Gas Tips</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/pumping-gas-tips/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 03 Mar 2015 04:30:48 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[alex-regalado]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=788</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-size: 16px;">I remember the moment clearly; I was stopping for gas and reaching over to peek out my window and see what side my tank was on, when I thought there had to be an easier way. So I researched and found that there had been an arrow indicator the entire time that told me which side the tank was on! My life changed, and I decided there had to be other helpful tips when it came to pumping gas. This is what I found:</span>

&nbsp;
<ul>
	<li></li>
	<li>
<h6><strong><span style="font-size: 16px;">Which Side is the Gas Tank on?</span></strong></h6>
</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<ol>
<ol>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Look at the gas icon on your dashboard. In most newer cars <strong>there is an arrow</strong> that points in the direction your tank is located! Lifehacker has <a href="http://lifehacker.com/instantly-see-which-side-of-your-car-the-gas-tank-is-on-1174049329">a helpful video</a>, in case you need help finding it.</span></li>
</ol>
</ol>
</ol>
&nbsp;
<ul>
	<li></li>
	<li></li>
	<li></li>
	<li>
<h6><strong><span style="font-size: 16px;">Properly Dispensing Gas</span></strong></h6>
</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<ol>
<ol>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;"><strong>Don’t get in and out</strong> of your car while pumping gas. It creates static electricity and could potentially cause a fire, <a href="https://www.extension.purdue.edu/cfs/programs/gaspump/resources/gaspump-handout-long.pdf">according to Purdue University</a>. Keep your cell phones inside, because they can emit electrical charges too.</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;"><strong>Wait three seconds</strong> after you are finished pumping to take the nozzle out, so all the fuel has a chance to get in the tank.</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Turn your gas cap <strong>three clicks</strong> to make sure it’s properly closed</span></li>
</ol>
</ol>
</ol>
&nbsp;
<ul>
	<li>
<h6><span style="font-size: 16px;"><strong>When (and When Not) to Fill Up</strong></span></h6>
</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<ol>
<ol>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Fill up your car <strong>in the mornings</strong>, when the temperature is cool. As the <a href="http://greenbaywi.gov/csa/weights-measures/tips-for-pumping-gas/">city of Green Bay’s tip sheet</a> points out, gas expands in warm temperature. So the cooler the weather, the more gas you’re actually getting.</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Don’t fill up <strong>when a tanker truck is delivering</strong> gas to a station, Green Bay suggests. Dumping that gas probably brings up dirt and sludge, which can get into your tank.</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Fill up <strong>when your gas tank is half empty</strong>. For one thing, you never want to be low on gas in case of emergencies. But it’s also good for your wallet—gas evaporates when there’s air, particularly warm air. So more gas in the tank means less space for it to evaporate.</span></li>
</ol>
</ol>
</ol>
&nbsp;
<ul>
	<li>
<h6><strong><span style="font-size: 16px;">In Case of Emergencies</span></strong></h6>
<ol>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">If there is a flash fire, do not attempt to take the nozzle out of your car, Purdue says.<strong>Get away from the vehicle</strong> and notify an attendant to shut off the pumps.</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">If you get gas on your hands, don’t panic! Stay away from heat and fire, and proceed safely to a bathroom. Soap and water won’t do it - you need <strong>a dish soap that cuts grease</strong>, or an acid like lemon juice. Then you can wash with water.</span></li>
</ol>
</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 16px;">There are some more helpful <a href="http://www.cudlautosmart.com/Research/Article.aspx?pageId=95&amp;articleId=2">money-saving tips here</a>. Have any other advice? Let us know in a comment. Thanks for reading!</span>
<h5>XOXO Alex</h5>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:10:{i:0;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2021";s:5:"score";s:17:"26.28466309374405";}i:1;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"391";s:5:"score";s:18:"21.965694594720063";}i:2;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2806";s:5:"score";s:18:"21.747296011121115";}i:3;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1527";s:5:"score";s:18:"21.747296011121115";}i:4;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1981";s:5:"score";s:16:"19.9714114709814";}i:5;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1788";s:5:"score";s:18:"18.528420186252916";}i:6;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"219";s:5:"score";s:18:"18.528420186252916";}i:7;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1553";s:5:"score";s:18:"16.589619072000843";}i:8;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"564";s:5:"score";s:18:"16.589619072000843";}i:9;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1775";s:5:"score";s:18:"16.351194255078557";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Use iMessage Abroad</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-use-imessage/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 03 Mar 2015 04:38:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[victoria-stark]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=791</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I've been out of the United States for almost 5 months now, with at least 4 more to go until I see the the sweet California coast again. Homesickness is something that hits all travelers at one point or another, and when it hits, something we normally take for granted suddenly becomes the only thing keeping us mentally sane: <strong>WIFI</strong>. <strong><strong> </strong></strong> With today's technology, it's easier than ever to keep in touch with your family, friends, boyfriend, girlfriend, ex-boyfriend, or even your boss if you feel so inclined during your travels. Using iMessage for iPhone has bolstered my mental health more times than I can count since I've moved to Madrid, and I know my mom is forever grateful to Apple that she can hear from me before taking off from a strange Czech airport or on a bus in the German countryside. <strong><strong> </strong></strong> Here's how to save money, avoid roaming, and keep in touch with everyone back home while you're traveling by using iMessage.

<hr />

<strong><strong> </strong></strong>
<ol>
	<li>Make sure to turn off your data. You'll be saving hundreds of dollars by just completely shutting it off. For context, I turned my data on for 10 mins, twice a week, for a few months in South Africa when I was an idiot 17 year old, and racked up close to $500 in charges. <strong>DON'T DO IT</strong>! An added benefit of just turning it off is distancing yourself from Instagram, Facebook, etc. Your newsfeeds are way more interesting when you can't check every 5 minutes, and you will be more in the moment during your travels. To turn data off on your iPhone, go to Settings -&gt; Cellular and move the toggle to the off position. The upper left corner of the screen should say "No Service".</li>
</ol>
<strong><strong> </strong></strong>
<ol start="2">
	<li>iMessage works over wifi, and you can use the app on your laptop, tablet, or phone. You can also access Facetime through iMessage on your computer. Basically, if you are connected to wifi, you can send and receive iMessages, as long as that the person you're messaging is using iMessage as well. You'll know if you're using iMessage if the "Send" button is blue. If it's green, it means you're not connected to wifi - but if you turned your data off nothing will happen anyway because you aren't connected.</li>
</ol>
<strong><strong> </strong></strong>
<ol start="3">
	<li>So where to get wifi if you're traveling? Most establishments will have some sort of Internet, and while it can seem embarrassing to ask for the wifi password alongside your latte or cerveza, it's worth it. I always tell myself, "I'm obviously a tourist anyways (bright red hair is not native to many countries I have visited) and I won't see this waiter ever again so I'm gonna check my emails, damn it!" Feel free to use a variation of this, and learn the word for "password" in the native language of the place you're traveling. People love helping out a tourist that puts a little effort in!</li>
</ol>
<strong><strong> </strong></strong>
<ol start="4">
	<li>Now that you have access to wifi, iMessage, and all the internet wonders that come along with it, use your powers wisely. It's nice to be able to keep in touch with your loved ones at home, but limit yourself to checking in once a day or in case of emergency. You'll get used to, and maybe even revel in, the feeling of exploring a new place completely unattached.</li>
</ol>
<h6><strong> Happy travels!</strong></h6>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Hike Safely</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/hiking-safely-a-how-to-guide/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 03 Mar 2015 07:40:58 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jenna-perelman]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=1045</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1051" align="aligncenter" width="615"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Hiking-Safety-Tips.jpg"><img class="wp-image-1051 size-large" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Hiking-Safety-Tips-1024x683.jpg" alt="Photo By: Isaac Arjonilla" width="615" height="410" /></a> Photo By: Isaac Arjonilla[/caption]<p><span style="color: #000000;">Hiking is a great form of exercise. It’s inexpensive, and getting to the top leaves you not only with a feeling of accomplishment but also with an incredible view of the nature below. One of the best things about hiking is the quiet alone time, but it’s for this exact reason that hiking can be dangerous. Read on for some tips about how to stay safe while hiking!</span></p><ol><li style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #000000;">Tell someone where you are going and when you will return. REMEMBER to check in with them when you get back.</span></li><li style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #000000;">Stay on marked trails.</span></li><li style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #000000;">Do not climb on waterfalls -- the rocks can be slippery!</span></li><li style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #000000;">If it's cold out, dress in layers and avoid cotton clothing, which will make you colder after you sweat a little bit.</span></li><li style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #000000;">Carry a whistle. Three short blasts signals distress.</span></li><li style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #000000;">Carry a water bottle. Make sure you stay hydrated by drinking water regularly! </span></li><li style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #000000;">Wear bright colors.</span></li><li style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #000000;">Hike with a buddy.</span></li></ol><p><span style="color: #000000;"><strong><strong> </strong></strong></span> <span style="color: #000000;"><strong>IF YOU’RE LOST:</strong></span></p><ol><li style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #000000;">If your cellphone works in the wilderness, you should describe your location to rescue personnel by telling them which trailhead you started from and how long you have been hiking.</span></li><li style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #000000;">Stay where you are.</span></li><li style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #000000;">Make shelter.</span></li><li style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #000000;">Stay warm and dry.</span></li><li style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #000000;">Be visible and heard.</span></li><li style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #000000;">If helicopters are searching overhead, seek an opening rather than a thick tree cover. Lie down so you look bigger from the air</span> (<a href="http://gastateparks.org/Safety-Tips">according to the folks at the Georgia Department of Natural Resources</a>).</li></ol><p><span style="color: #000000;"><strong><strong> <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/TWIGG-TIP-hiking.jpg"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-1046 size-large" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/TWIGG-TIP-hiking-749x1024.jpg" alt="_TWIGG TIP hiking" width="615" height="841" /></a></strong></strong></span></p><h5 style="text-align: center;"> </h5><h5 style="text-align: center;"> </h5><h5 style="text-align: center;"> </h5><h5 style="text-align: center;"><span style="color: #000000;">Good luck, and happy hiking!</span></h5><p>&nbsp;</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Become a Substitute Teacher in California</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-become-a-substitute-teacher-in-california/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 03 Mar 2015 03:00:33 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Olivia-Hernandez]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=1094</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[So, you just graduated college and are now on the market searching for an exciting career. This is going to be your dream job. You know the one that you will love and be perfectly happy doing for the rest of your life? It’s out there, but it might not be available for you just yet. In the meantime you have bills to pay and need to get a job as soon as possible.

Before you begin to cry, question your life choices and your degree path, consider working as a substitute teacher. Yes, remember that old person who used to come to your class when your teacher was absent? The one that would tell really corny jokes and recap for  you their life story? That’s the one. If they can do it, why can’t you? You get to work with kids in a classroom, build your resume, and learn invaluable intrapersonal skills. <strong><strong> </strong></strong>

Substitute teachers are in pretty high demand at almost every school district, and the application process is relatively simple if you are not a convicted felon. It is a process though; but have no fear, as a former substitute teacher I am here to guide you through it all. <strong><strong> </strong></strong>

<hr />

The first step to becoming a substitute teacher is to <strong>take the CBEST</strong> which stands for California Basic Education Skills Test. The test covers basic math, reading, and writing skills. As a college graduate this test should be a breeze. The link for more information on the test is <a href="http://www.ctcexams.nesinc.com/about_CBEST.asp">here</a>. On this website you will be able to register for the test.

&nbsp;

After taking and passing the CBEST there is a <strong>series of documents you must accumulate</strong> and send as a complete packet to the Commission on Teacher Credentialing in Sacramento, CA. What you will need to gather is:
<ul>
	<li>official transcripts that post your degree</li>
	<li>a copy of your passing CBEST scores</li>
	<li>a completed application form</li>
	<li>a completed live scan form</li>
	<li>and you must pay a processing fee of 70 dollars</li>
</ul>
All of the necessary forms and paperwork can be found at the Commission on Teacher Credentialing website. It can be slightly confusing to navigate, so <a href="http://www.ctc.ca.gov/credentials/leaflets/cl505p.pdf">here</a> is the direct link to the necessary documents. It will take <strong>anywhere between one to two months for all the paperwork to be cleared.</strong> Once it is, you will receive an email containing your Emergency 30 day Substitute Teaching Permit, which means you can substitute teach for grades k-12 for no more than 30 days in a row for one class; that would be considered a long-term sub and requires a different credential. <strong><strong> </strong></strong>

&nbsp;

<strong>Once you have your sub permit, you can apply to any district.</strong> Substitute teaching is a great way to earn some decent money while you continue to search for your dream job. The pay can range anywhere from 105 to 145 dollars a day depending on the district. You may not be called to work every day, so I recommend applying to multiple districts in your area to increase your chances of being called. If you prove to be a superb substitute teacher, teachers will talk and you will start to be called more and even be requested to sub.

&nbsp;

So take a deep breath, reflect on everything you have accomplished in life, and slowly take the first steps into adulthood and your search for a career. Your dream job is out there and you will find it. For now, just take your time and enjoy the post-grad, pre-adult life as much as possible. Good luck!<strong> ☺</strong>

&nbsp;

Header Photo: Huffington Post]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Share Video Files Between MACs and PCs</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/sharing-video-files-between-macs-and-pcs/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 04 Mar 2015 04:49:32 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[alex-regalado]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=103</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>&nbsp;</p>[caption id="attachment_918" align="aligncenter" width="615"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/PC-to-Mac.jpg"><img class="size-large wp-image-918" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/PC-to-Mac-1024x709.jpg" alt="Illustration Credit: Sonia Chu" width="615" height="426" /></a> Illustration Credit: Sonia Chu[/caption]<p><span style="color: #000000;"><i>Did you know that not all files are transferrable between Macs and PCs? I found that out the hard way when I made a video for a friend on my PC and then tried to open it on her Mac. It wouldn’t work! So if you and your friend are on opposite sides of the Mac vs PC war, you should know these handy tips.</i></span></p><h5 style="text-align: center;"><strong>THE BASICS</strong></h5><hr /><p>  To review, <strong>Mac</strong>, or <strong>Macintosh</strong>, are computers designed by Apple. <strong>PC</strong> really stands for “Personal Computer,” but it’s the common nickname for any computer with a Microsoft operating system (this could mean Toshiba, Windows, Dell, etc.) <strong>MOVs</strong>, or <strong>QuickTime files</strong>, are Mac coded, and they don’t always work on PCs (unless the program QuickTime is updated on your PC computer, which you can download for free online). <strong>Windows Media Video (wmvs)</strong> were developed by Microsoft and won’t run on a Mac.</p><h5 style="text-align: center;"><strong>SAVING THE FILE</strong></h5><hr /><p>  When you save, or export, a video, you can choose the format that you want. Think of it like a Microsoft Word Doc versus a PDF. Similarly, there are different types of video files. If you need to work between two systems, use a file format like <strong>MPEG4</strong>, which works on both. There are also different programs to save or export these files. If a file is saved as, say, a <strong>.mov file</strong>, you can use a software like MPEG Streamclip to convert them to a more general format, such as MPEG4. Make sense?</p><h5 style="text-align: center;"><strong>SHARING THE FILE</strong></h5><hr /><p>  You can use portable hard drives to share files between computers, but some hard drives only work for either Macs or PCs. Windows hard drives are called NTFS (it isn’t important to know what that stands for) and include brands like Seagate. Mac hard drives are called HMS and include brands like LaCie. This means I can’t plug my LaCie hard drive into a PC and share my files. If you are tech savvy, you can format your hard drive to FAT32, a formatting system that is compatible for both Macs and PCs. But for the rest of the population, using a cloud-based system such as Dropbox or Google Drive is another way to share files. <strong><strong> </strong></strong> <i>Hope this brief introduction into the differences between MAC and PC video files will help you out!</i> <i>XOXO Alex</i></p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Prepare for the Presidential Election</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-presidential-election-primer-101/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 03 Mar 2015 23:39:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[kelly-zhou]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=230</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[When are you supposed to register to vote? What day is Election Day? Can I mail my ballot in? If you haven’t been paying attention to the upcoming presidential election, don’t fear. The race will have no incumbents—President Barack Obama is finishing up his second term—so it promises to be interesting. Candidates will likely announce in mid-2015 and the majority of the events will happen during 2016, so you’ve got at least a couple months until you have to pay attention to politics. While plenty of well-known names (Hillary Clinton, Jeb Bush, to name a few) have been bandied about so far, these politicians have yet to officially commit to running or file documents, as of January 2015.
<h6 style="text-align: center;">In the meantime, here’s a handy timeline of the basics so you can follow along:</h6>
<strong>In 2015: Candidates announce their runs.</strong>

<hr />

Data analyzed by FiveThirtyEight shows that most candidates in most years declare more than 200 days (or 6-7 months) before the Iowa caucuses. Those caucuses happen in January 2016, putting candidate announcements likely before June 2015. Democrat and former Secretary of State Clinton is expected to announce in spring 2015, and potential Republican candidates Sen. Rand Paul of Kentucky and Texas Gov. Rick Perry also likely won’t make a final decision until spring or later, the Washington Post reported. For the 2008 election, Obama announced his candidacy on Feb. 10, 2007.   <strong>January 2016: Early primaries and caucuses.</strong>

<hr />

Historically, the Iowa caucuses kick off the horse race of presidential nominations. The 2012 Iowa caucuses took place on Jan. 3, and the New Hampshire primary followed a week later on Jan. 10. These early races are significant in media attention, generating support and determining which candidates will keep pursuing their presidential campaigns. These primary elections continue to run through June throughout the country.   <strong>May 23: Last day to register to vote in the California primary.</strong>

<hr />

You have to register to vote at least 15 days in advance for any election in California. You can pick up a paper registration application at your county elections office, DMV branches, the library or the post office. Or just register online. Requests to vote by mail must be received by your county elections officials at least seven days ahead of the election, aka May 31. Visit the Secretary of State’s website for more info.   <strong>June 7: Primary election in California.</strong>

<hr />

Go to a polling place anytime from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. Don’t forget to actually look up where your polling place is, too. The political parties can choose to allow only voters who registered as that party (Democrat or Republican) or to also allow voters who declined to state a party affiliation.   <strong>July 18-21: Republican National Convention.</strong>

<hr />

Watch on television as the Republican Party delegates officially nominate their presidential and VP candidates at the Quicken Loans Arena in Cleveland, Ohio.   <strong>Summer 2016: Democratic National Convention.</strong>

<hr />

The Democratic Party delegates will officially nominate their presidential and VP candidates; stay tuned as the dates and location for the DNC have yet to be decided.   <strong>Oct. 24: Last day to register to vote on Election Day.</strong>

<hr />

Once again, make sure to register so you can actually cast a ballot in November. Not sure if you’re registered? Check your state websites. For California voters, visit the Secretary of State’s website here.   <strong>Nov. 8: Election Day!</strong>

<hr />

Go to a polling place anytime from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. Same as the primary, make sure to look up where your polling place is. The winner is determined by Electoral College votes: Each state has a certain number of electoral votes, which is the same as the state’s number of congressional members. For example, California has 55 electoral votes. In most states, whichever candidate wins the popular vote wins the electoral votes (winner take all). The candidate to reach at least 270 electoral votes is the victor. So proudly wear those “I voted” stickers and stay glued to your television for exit polling results. If your candidate wins, pop some bubbly.
<h6>photo source rockthevote.com</h6>
&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:10:{i:0;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"3154";s:5:"score";s:18:"36.573539922458586";}i:1;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"812";s:5:"score";s:18:"20.743573910761796";}i:2;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"227";s:5:"score";s:18:"20.743573910761796";}i:3;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"764";s:5:"score";s:18:"16.027264022545165";}i:4;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"174";s:5:"score";s:18:"16.027264022545165";}i:5;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"3092";s:5:"score";s:17:"15.82996601169679";}i:6;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2537";s:5:"score";s:17:"15.82996601169679";}i:7;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"3425";s:5:"score";s:17:"7.221835825288449";}i:8;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2735";s:5:"score";s:17:"7.221835825288449";}i:9;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"788";s:5:"score";s:17:"7.221835825288449";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Adjust to Life After College</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-life-after-college/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 03 Mar 2015 23:48:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[claire-perelman]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=234</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_537" align="aligncenter" width="615"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Staying-Happy-after-Graduation.jpg"><img class="size-large wp-image-537" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Staying-Happy-after-Graduation-1024x683.jpg" alt="Photo Credit: Isaac Arjonilla" width="615" height="410" /></a> Photo Credit: Isaac Arjonilla[/caption]

Life after college – or “The Real World” – is not as scary as it seems. In fact, I think it is positively fabulous. But before we get into that, we should debunk some myths about college, life after college, and what you are “supposed” to be doing.

<hr />

&nbsp;

<b>MYTH #1: College is the best 4 years of your life. </b> This is highly unlikely. Although college may have been a blast, it is also possible you spent most of it studying in your room at all odd hours of the night. Going into the adult world believing that what you just left behind was the highlight of your life is not a very solid foot to set out on. Remind yourself that college was just that – college. You may have spent anywhere between two and six years “living the dream” in an undergraduate university, but that does not mean you cannot live the dream in the adult world. It is simply a different kind of lifestyle. Try to start your path into the adult world in a positive light – knowing that your new life will be different, but possibly even better in its new way.

<hr />

&nbsp;

<b>MYTH #2: You will stay best friends with your college BFFS… forever.</b> Although we would all love to believe our “besties” will last us forever, we all have been through at least 21 years of life and have hopefully realized that not everyone sticks around – and that we do not necessarily want everyone to stick around. Yes, some of the closest friends you made in college will be at your wedding – or hey, maybe even in your wedding! But we all left high school, and we know that not everyone stays your best friend for life. I think this is one of the hardest transitions to make in the working world. Transitioning friendships will always be tough, no matter what life stage you are in. Now that you are no longer seeing your friends at the library, in the center of campus, or out at fraternity parties, it is going to take more of an effort to keep the people you value in your life. So make the effort! If you appreciate their friendship and they are lending something positive to you, work for the relationship. As my dad once told me – “sometimes you have to be the glue in the friendship.”

<hr />

&nbsp;

<b>MYTH #3: It is extremely hard to get a job right out of college. </b> Okay, this one is true. You have to apply for a LOT of positions. You can do this! This is probably the most difficult thing entering the non-university world. It took some of my friends months before they were able to find a full-time job that they wanted. Others had full-time jobs straight out of graduation. The timeline is different for everyone. Do not beat yourself up because you cannot find a full-time job in your field right after college. Give yourself some downtime. Work at a paid internship. Get two paid internships that are both part-time. There are so many options – do not limit yourself because everyone around you seems to have their life figured out. Because they probably don’t.

<hr />

&nbsp;

<b>MYTH #4: Your friends who are still in college will understand what you are going through.</b> Most of them will not. They are still in college! So were you, just a minute ago! So cut them a break. Most of my friends still in college do not understand what a difficult transition it can be to the adult world after graduation, and they continue to talk to me about school gossip and their exam papers. Although I care about what they have to say, sometimes it feels as if we are now on two different planets. I am searching for an adult life – I no longer want to hear about exams or think about who is taking who to what sorority formal. I want to talk about values, and work, and when I might go to graduate school. But just because your friends are still in college does not mean you cannot still connect with them. Try to find that middle ground where you know your personalities connect on a deeper level. If you still feel disconnected, search for more post-undergraduate friends! I have joined Meetup and been introduced to mutual friends who are also going through the same thing. It definitely helps!

<hr />

&nbsp;

<b>MYTH #5: You have to attend graduate school right after college.</b> This is obviously not true. Now that you have graduated undergrad, the world is your oyster! Do not feel pressured to go straight to graduate school. And remember that in some fields, graduate school is unnecessary. Most of us have been in school since we were 5 years old, and I think we deserve a break. However, if you know exactly what you want to do and it’s a necessity to attend graduate school immediately – all power to you! But if you do not know what you are going to do or you feel extremely burnt out – take a year off. Maybe two! GRE scores are good for five years for exactly this reason.

<hr />

&nbsp;

<b>MYTH #6: You have to move back in with your parents after you graduate.</b> This is a fabulous way to save money. While you are looking for a job, you may want to move back in with your parents, eat their food, and get some extra loving while you transition to the “Real World.” However, it is not necessary. Plenty of my friends -- myself included -- stayed in the city where we graduated university and live with roommates while working full-time. We knew we did not want to move back in with our parents, no matter how much money it would have saved. After living on my own for four years, I knew I could not do it. But do not at all feel embarrassed if you do move back in. The majority of my friends did move home, at least for six months, while they gathered themselves together and subsequently found jobs. We’re all still very young – take advantage of the downtime while you can!

&nbsp;
<h6 style="text-align: center;"><span style="color: #ffcc00;"><b>TRUTH: It is all going to be absolutely fine.</b></span></h6>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:10:{i:0;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1094";s:5:"score";s:17:"24.86879648477716";}i:1;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2889";s:5:"score";s:18:"22.671571907440942";}i:2;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2386";s:5:"score";s:17:"22.50912102762414";}i:3;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"775";s:5:"score";s:17:"22.50912102762414";}i:4;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"241";s:5:"score";s:17:"21.28253908187956";}i:5;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1631";s:5:"score";s:17:"20.66871176524774";}i:6;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1651";s:5:"score";s:17:"20.63770339214744";}i:7;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"770";s:5:"score";s:18:"20.182446408012645";}i:8;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2773";s:5:"score";s:18:"19.428230945644735";}i:9;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2735";s:5:"score";s:18:"19.428230945644735";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
		<title>Budget Travelin&#039; &amp; Hostel Livin’: A TRAVEL How-To Guide</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-master-budget-traveling-hostel-livin/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 04 Mar 2015 04:05:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chelsea-hawkins]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=262</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>So you want to see the world? Of course you do! But travel isn’t always cheap or easy and when you’re globetrotting you tend to learn things by mistake.  Unfortunately, being lost in a country where you don’t speak the language or your phone is out of data is not the ideal time to find out you’re broke and have boarded the wrong train. <strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><ol><li> If you’re planning to go across the country or halfway around the planet, you need to do some pre-planning. Long before you book flights or buses or a place to stay, consider your budget, whether or not it will be safe to travel alone, and how you plan to get around. Compare prices for transportation and read up on other people’s experiences. Be realistic about what you can do and really think about what you want out of the trip. I like going off on my own or with a single companion; I know I don’t like tours or group trips or all-inclusive stays, so I plan according to what I know I can afford to do around what experience I’m looking for.</li></ol><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><ol start="2"><li>When you’re picking out a hostel, read reviews. Seriously. Read them. I know online reviews need to be taken with a grain of salt, but when you’re looking for a place to lay your head, you want to know it’s going to be safe. <b>Pro tip: map where the hostel is going to be.</b> It’s so important to know how to get to and from the hostel, and to ensure it’s in a place where you feel comfortable. Sometimes the cheapest places to stay can be far out on the edge of the city, so if you end up spending a lot on taxis, metros and buses, it doesn’t do much good.</li></ol><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><ol start="3"><li>Read up on what your hostel has to offer. Not all hostels have complimentary WiFi and a lot of hostels won’t offer up towels or clean sheets for free. If you don’t want to be out of a few Euros, you’re going to want to <b>pack a bath towel and face cloth</b>. Also, a lot of hostels offer lockers but no locks; <b>bring a pad-lock </b>to ensure you can keep your valuables secure. <b>A reusable, refillable water canteen</b> is also helpful and will save you a lot of money if you’re touring about. Also, when I say bring shower shoes, I mean it. <b>BRING SHOWER SHOES</b>. Other things that are sometimes helpful but not absolutely necessary: a very small first aid kit with a few bandages and a little ointment and ibuprofen. If you’re anything like me – or most 20-somethings I know – your hangover will thank you.</li></ol><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><ol start="4"><li> Take advantage of hostel kitchens – they’re there to be used! I saved so much money traveling by cooking breakfast or packing lunches. Plus it’s a nice way to bond with people in the hostel. If you can, take advantage of the community the hostel offers: there are usually things like bar-crawls and walking tours for free or very cheap. One of my best experiences to date has been a hostel-hosted bar crawl with a bunch of random Australians, Canadians and New Zealanders in Edinburgh.</li></ol><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><ol start="5"><li> In places where it’s appropriate, learn to haggle. Don’t be shy. I was so scared the first time I did it but if something seems too expensive try to get a lower price – and if you don’t like the price offered, walk away. People in the markets know a tourist and there’s always a tourist price. I’ve seen people sucked into making a purchase just because they felt pressured but you don’t have to!</li></ol><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><ol start="6"><li>And finally, the world isn’t as scary as you think but your safety IS important. Trust your gut, paper maps are always useful so carry one, and always try and be aware of your body and belongs. Don’t be timid or scared, but I know from experience that sometimes the best thing you can do is trust yourself. In each place make sure to l<b>ook up the emergency phone number</b> (<a href="http://www.sos112.info/uk.htm">the European Union’s</a> is 112, for example), and find out where the closest police station is.</li></ol><p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p><h6>Honestly, there is nothing that can replace what you get when you travel. Breaking out of your comfort zone and exploring places you don’t know – whether it’s a city or an ocean away – can really teach you a lot about who you are, what you’re capable of and how brave you can be. Ask questions, be prepared and do your research and you’ll be able to truly embrace all the experience can offer.</h6><p>&nbsp;</p><h6>Gif from http://afterglobe.dk/</h6>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="travel"><![CDATA[Travel]]></category>

			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_edit_last]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_pukka_box_size]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[medium]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_pukka_secondary_image_id]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1352]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_thumbnail_id]]></wp:meta_key>

	<item>
		<title>Menstrual Cup Basics</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/menstrual-cup-basics/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 04 Mar 2015 05:12:12 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[alex-regalado]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=1001</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[When I first encountered this product I was amazed and disturbed all at once. So many years of using pads and tampons had left me pretty closed off to any new inventions concerning Aunt Flo, but this product offers to solve a lot of “period problems.” The concept is simple: a small cylindrical plastic container that is inserted into your vagina to collect your period blood. You dump it out and insert it back in. That’s it! After trying it for half a year and conducting extensive research, I’ve compiled this list of facts that will help you decide if the Diva Cup, or similar products, are right for you.

&nbsp;

<strong> 1. This is what it looks like:</strong>

<strong><strong><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Diva-Cup.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1002" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Diva-Cup.jpg" alt="Diva Cup" width="208" height="278" /></a></strong></strong>

<i><a href="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:DivaCup.jpg">http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:DivaCup.jpg</a></i>

&nbsp;

<strong>2. It’s made of silicone, is chemical free, and eco-friendly.</strong> While using tampons increased your risk of Toxic Shock Syndrome, a fatal and rare bacterial disease, the Diva Cup has no known health risks. Silicone is compatible with our bodies and won’t hurt us. And because it’s not made of something disposable like cardboard or cotton, you are helping the environment and not risking your health.

&nbsp;

<strong> 3. It lasts twelve hours and holds a lot of blood. </strong> Probably one of the best reasons to use a Diva Cup. You only need to change it twice a day: when you wake up and before you go to sleep.  So leaks are virtually eliminated if the cup is inserted correctly.

&nbsp;

<strong>4. It’s reusable, and can save you money.</strong> A one time fee of $30 gets you one of these bad boys. The company recommends you replace it every year, but it’s really up to you and how long you are comfortable using it. If you boil it or wash it in hydrogen peroxide you can eliminate discoloration. <strong><strong> </strong></strong>

&nbsp;

<strong>5. After some practice, it’s easy and comfortable.</strong>

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/diva-cup-2.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1003" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/diva-cup-2.jpg" alt="diva cup 2" width="338" height="124" /></a>

<i>http://veganomical.com/2013/02/20/the-divacup/</i>

At first it’s hard and you feel really weird. You start by folding it into a U shape and then inserting it up into your vagina. I found it to be easiest when I was sitting on the toilet for both insertion and removal, and then going at an upward angle with the cup. After pushing it in about an inch or two, you can release the cup. You have to hold onto the tip and rotate it so that it folds out completely and then attaches onto the walls of your vagina to stay secure. If I had any leaks while using the cup, it was because I forgot to rotate it after inserting. The tip was too long for me and would poke my insides; I ended up taking it out and cutting off a little bit with the scissors to make it the perfect length (which is allowed). To remove, I would sit on the toilet and push a little (kind of like doing a kegel exercise). This would push the cup down far enough for me to grab it. You can pull from the tip, or you can reach in deeper and grab the sides of the cup and pull it out. You can just dump everything into the toilet and wash it with soap in the sink. Takes a couple tries, but so did tampons. When you’re actually wearing it you can’t even feel it. Great for exercising, and it doesn’t spill.

&nbsp;

<strong> 6. It’s fairly easy to clean, but can be a little gross. </strong> Using a Diva Cup requires you to really get to know your body. Oftentimes you have to reach inside your vagina and have to pull it out. You also see your period blood up close and personal, and learn a lot more than you probably wanted to know. But it’s easy to hand-wash it with soap and water after each use, and carry it in it’s little portable bag if you are traveling.

&nbsp;

<strong> 7. It comes in all sizes, colors, and brands. </strong> The Diva Cup specifically comes in two sizes, one for women who haven’t had a baby and a larger one for women who have. You can visit their website to read even more and see if it’s the one for you: <a href="http://divacup.com/">http://divacup.com/</a>  The technical term is a menstrual cup, and you can use other brands like Mooncup, Instead, Lunette, or Miacup. I can only speak for the Diva Cup. Besides slight variations in color and style, most work the same way.

&nbsp;

<strong> 8. It has fairly positive reviews, and only one freak accident. </strong> From what I can find, these menstrual cups work like they are supposed to, and a lot of women love them. There are two weird backlash stories that I’ve heard. The first was the Diva Cup getting caught in a girl’s skin and ripping it. She assumes it was her hymen, but it might have been the actual vaginal wall, and she described it as being really painful. Here’s the <strong><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n7sIutkZoIw">video</a></strong>. This seems to be extremely rare, but there are always risks. Another woman detailed the cup exposing a extreme odor. However, the cups are odorless which means it must have come from here. So the cup might not hide any smells coming from down there, but neither do tampons.

&nbsp;

<strong> 9. Don’t use if...</strong> -You are under 13. -You are going to have sex (take it out during intercourse). -You have a yeast infection. -You just had a baby. -You are putting on topical medication down there.

&nbsp;
<h6>I cannot say this enough: it changed my life. I know it's not for everyone, but if you've read this and it sounds like a good option for you then give it a try!</h6>
<h6>XOXO Alex</h6>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Jalapeno Eyes: A How-To Guide</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/jalapeno-eyes-a-how-to-guide/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 05 Mar 2015 05:17:27 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[CAITLYN]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=1006</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[
<h5 style="text-align: center;"><span style="color: #000000;">Allow me to paint a scene for you: </span></h5>
<p><span style="color: #000000;"> You’re out with the gals enjoying a fresh bowl of the delicious Vietnamese dish, pho. You spice it up as you like: a dash of basil here, a squeeze of lime there and some juicy jalapenos to top it all off. Voila!</span> <span style="color: #000000;"><strong>But then disaster strikes.</strong> Forgetting your fresh jalapeno soaked fingers, you rub your eyes and suddenly...your eyeballs are on fire.</span> <span style="color: #000000;"><strong><strong> </strong></strong></span></p>
<h5 style="text-align: center;"><span style="color: #000000;">What do you do?!</span></h5>
<p style="text-align: left;"><span style="color: #000000;">Well if you’re this lucky lady, you rush to the bathroom and basically push your head under a running sink - to no avail. Then, you <i>bike</i> home - tears streaming down your face - and try to take your contacts out and douse your eyes in eye drops. But although you’ve washed your jalapeno fingers a million times, all this is doing is making it 3,000 percent worse as residual jalapeno juice is still on your fingertips. </span></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="color: #000000;">The burning intensifies.</span></p>
<p><span style="color: #000000;">Then, you call mom to no answer. (Why does this always happen in times of an actual crisis?!) Desperate, with bright red eye balls you spend what feels like eternity googling “JALAPENO IN MY FACE” and discover the heaven-sent tip I am going to share with you now.</span></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="color: #000000;"><b>Take milk shots to your eyes.</b></span></p>
<p><span style="color: #000000;">You heard me. Fill a shot glass to the brim with milk, push your eye to the rim, and look up. The relief after taking milk shots to your eyeballs  is like nothing I can describe to you. To rid your hands of the lingering pepper juice, rub your hands with olive oil thoroughly, then wash with soap and water.  </span> <span style="color: #000000;">If you are in a restaurant, order a glass of milk and do this in the bathroom.</span> <span style="color: #000000;">You, with your perfectly fine eyes, may think I am crazy. You may be worried what the wait staff may think as you’re carrying a glass of milk to the bathroom, and you may be worried about what a fellow bathroom patron may think as you’re sobbing into a sink pouring milk down your face. But let me tell you something, none of that matters in the tiniest bit when you’re dealing with searing eyeballs. You’re too busy wondering how you’re going to get around with no eyeballs because there’s no way you aren’t burning layers of important cornea right now.</span> <span style="color: #000000;"><strong><strong> </strong></strong></span></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="color: #000000;">So do it.</span></p>
<h6 style="text-align: center;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong> Then email me and we can laugh about it and drink wine in solidarity.</strong></span></h6>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<hr />
<p><span style="color: #000000;"><strong> <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Jalapeno-Eyes.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-large wp-image-1008" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Jalapeno-Eyes-614x1024.jpg" alt="Jalapeno Eyes" width="614" height="1024" /></a></strong></span> <span style="color: #000000;"><strong> </strong></span></p>
<h6>Gif source https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z-KzGKoLHXk</h6>
]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Drink Responsibly</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-drink-responsibly/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 16 Mar 2015 19:14:50 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jackie-serame]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=1329</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[First of all, I’d like to point out that <i>yes</i>, there is such a thing as building your alcohol tolerance[1] (just like any other drug out there). With that said, if you’re new to social drinking or have never really had more than one drink in a sitting <b>please continue reading this</b>. This is not an invitation to purposely take a shot every hour to train your liver, but there are things you can do stay ahead of your BAC (blood alcohol content). We all have our stories but most of us could do without them… Most people learn their limits through trial-and-error and my goal is to save you from erring—and possible embarrassing yourself:

<hr />

<strong><strong> </strong></strong> <b>1) EAT</b>. If there’s one thing you get from this article, please please please eat a burrito or something substantial (think carbs and protein) <i>before</i> engaging in any festivities. Handfuls of popcorn/ nuts/ bread/ chips (even with dip) between Fireball shots will not save you. Not eating is the fastest way to take you out of the game with no second chances. Don’t even think about telling yourself you’ll get food once you’re there—socializing and the challenge to keep up with the more experienced drinkers usually gets in the way. I’ve been there.
<ul>
	<li>      Why: Food in the stomach will slow the entrance of alcohol into your bloodstream by preventing it from entering your small intestine which absorbs alcohol faster than the stomach[2]</li>
</ul>
<strong><strong> </strong></strong> <b>2) DRINK WATER. </b>If the room starts to tilt, slow it down and get a glass of water. I’m not your mother; if you’re raging your face off, keep going! But don’t ignore your body’s cues (and let’s not get over-confident). Grabbing water every now and then throughout the night could save you from an awful morning, plus it keeps something in your hand to hopefully deter others from handing you “another one” ... hopefully. Just tell everyone it’s a vodka tonic.
<ul>
	<li>      Why: Non-alcoholic liquids will slow your consumption of alcohol, as well as counter the dehydrating effects from drinking.</li>
</ul>
<strong><strong> </strong></strong> <b>3) KNOW WHEN TO GO HOME. </b>SOS! You’ve reached the last actionable stage (oops) of drinking. It’s time to go home. If you listened to my advice in number 1, this stage shouldn’t just creep up on you. If it does, you literally have 5 minutes to get to the nearest bathroom (<i>do not lock the door</i><i>, in the event that you pass out – which is very likely—at least a homie can get to you!)</i>. If you had a good meal and have paced yourself relatively well for the past few hours, once your motor-skills drop off (i.e. slurring words more often, the room is spinning, it’s harder to concentrate or stand, etc.) tell a friend or someone there that you need to go. Don’t ever just disappear: searching for drunks is the worst and can be very scary for that person looking for you! Have someone you know take you back. I live in the city so going home alone at this stage is <i>not </i>an option, but usually you’re not the only one who’s ready for lights out and someone will be more than happy to get out of there with you.
<ul>
	<li>      Why: By going home, no one can pressure you to drink past your already-pushed limits and at this point you are most likely to think you can handle another one—why not, right? If you do end up getting sick, at least you can save yourself some embarrassment and clean up at your own expense in the morning. Lastly, passing out in your own bed is typically preferred to a sticky bathroom floor.</li>
</ul>
<strong><strong> </strong></strong>
<h6>These are the biggies that can keep your good night <i>good</i>. If you can follow these steps successfully and repeatedly, you’re well on your way to being that awesome person at social events versus “the mess that can’t handle liquor”. You never want to be that person… or that person’s friend. Spread the knowledge.</h6>

<hr />

<strong><strong> </strong></strong> [1] George F. Koob, Ph.D., the director of the <a href="http://www.niaaa.nih.gov/">National Institute on Alcohol Abuse</a> and Alcoholism. Developing tolerance to alcohol -- or any drug -- means it takes more of that drug to produce the same effect -- or, looked at another way, the same amount of the drug produces less of an effect. [2]<strong><a href="http://www.acha.org/"> American College Health Association</a></strong>   Picture source: http://41.media.tumblr.com/3cb44e629e2cfb8ec37a4ab5eb323ff6/tumblr_mh377uQYyT1ryin08o1_r1_1280.jpg]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1329</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2015-03-16 19:14:50]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2015-03-16 19:14:50]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Understand Birth Control Options</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/howtounderstandbirthcontroloptions/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 23 Mar 2015 23:40:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[devin-saragosa-harris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=1459</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h5 style="text-align: center;"><span style="color: #000000;">BIRTH CONTROL BREAKDOWN</span></h5>
<span style="color: #000000;">
In Fall of 2014 I took a Planned Parenthood Health Education Training course, and found it to be extremely informative! Below is some of the information I learned and wanted to share, as well as some helpful links at the bottom of the article. <span style="color: #999999;">Note: if you have any questions about birth control, please contact your doctor. This list is to serve merely as an introduction to the types of birth control available.</span></span>

<span style="color: #000000;">Birth control is often used to prevent pregnancy, but birth control can also be used to alleviate symptoms from menstruation like painful cramps, and can even help with acne! There are several common forms of birth control available in the United States, and they each have their own benefits and drawbacks. Effectiveness can vary between brands and types, as well as whether or not it is taken correctly.</span>

&nbsp;

<hr />

&nbsp;

<span style="color: #000000;"><strong><strong> </strong></strong></span>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span style="color: #000000;"><b>THE PILL</b></span></span></p>
<span style="color: #000000;">Hormonal pill that is taken every day. Generally contains estrogen and progestin (“combination pills”), although some pills are progestin-only.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><i>How does this prevent pregnancy?</i> These hormones keep eggs from releasing from the ovary, and make cervical mucus thicker. In both cases, sperm generally cannot come into contact with an egg for fertilization.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><i>Effectiveness</i>: 91-99 percent</span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><i>Benefits:</i> Simple and convenient. In addition to preventing unwanted pregnancies, the combination pill has been linked to a myriad of positive health benefits, including reduced symptoms of PMS, reduced menstrual cramps, lightened and more regulated periods, reduced acne and some protection against pelvic inflammatory disease.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><i>Drawbacks</i>: Some women have a hard time remembering to take their pills every day. Progestin-only pills have to be taken at the same time every day to confer protection, so it is especially important for these pills. Side effects of the pill vary, but they may include spotting, breast tenderness, nausea, changes in mood and a lowering of sex drive.
</span>

<span style="color: #000000;"> </span>

<hr />

&nbsp;
<p style="text-align: center;"><strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span style="color: #000000; text-decoration: underline;">DEPO-PROVERA (BIRTH CONTROL SHOT)</span></span></strong></p>
<span style="color: #000000;">A shot that is given every three months. The shot releases the hormone progestin into the bloodstream.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><i>How does this prevent pregnancy?</i> Progestin keeps eggs from releasing from the ovaries, and it thickens cervical mucus.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><i>Effectiveness: </i>94-99 percent</span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><i>Benefits</i>: It confers effects for three months, so you don’t have to take a daily pill or change a patch every week. It can also be taken by women who cannot take estrogen-containing contraceptives. Periods generally get lighter and fewer, and about half of women on the shot do not get their periods at all (which may be a benefit or a drawback, depending on your preferences).</span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><i>Drawbacks:</i> Some women forget to make regular appointments to get their latest shot, and this leaves them without protection until they get their shot. Depending on your insurance coverage, the shot can also be costly. Furthermore, it is a shot, so if that is something that sounds terrible to receive four times a year, this is probably not the best option for you! Side effects include irregular bleeding, changes in mood, nausea, changes in appetite and weight gain. Because of the nature of the shot, there is no way to eliminate the effects until the shot wears off three months post-injection.</span>

<hr />
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span style="color: #000000;"><b>THE PATCH</b></span></span></p>
<span style="color: #000000;">A beige patch that is applied to the skin for a week. The patch is changed once a week for three weeks in different locations on the body. On the fourth week, no patch is used. The patch releases estrogen and progestin.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><i>How does this prevent pregnancy?</i> The patch uses the same hormones as the birth control pill. It keeps eggs from releasing from the ovary, and it thickens cervical mucus. Both of these prevent sperm from reaching egg for fertilization.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><i>Effectiveness:</i> 91-99 percent</span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><i>Benefits:</i> It is easy and simple. It does not require a doctor’s appointment for application, or daily pills. The patch can help regulate periods, as well as make them lighter and shorter. The patch can also help with PMS symptoms, acne, menstrual cramps, and protects against pelvic inflammatory disease.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><i>Drawbacks:</i> The patch can cause bleeding between periods, especially during the first few months. The patch can also cause breast tenderness, nausea and skin irritation on the patch’s location. Women may have higher risk of blood clots using the patch compared to other birth control options, but risks for this are still low.</span>

<hr />

&nbsp;
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span style="color: #000000;"><b>INTRAUTERINE DEVICE (IUD)</b></span></span></p>
<span style="color: #000000;">A small, plastic device that is inserted into the uterus by a physician. The device is flexible and T-shaped. Two types of IUDs exist: copper and hormonal. Copper IUDs do not release hormones, and hormonal ones do.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><i>How does this prevent pregnancy?</i> The copper IUD creates an inflammatory response in the uterus that disrupts sperm movement and thus prevents egg fertilization. For the hormonal IUD, the device releases progestin which prevents eggs from leaving the ovary, and thickens the cervical mucus so that sperm cannot fertilize the egg.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><i>Effectiveness:</i> 99 percent</span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><i>Benefits:</i> IUDs are a very long-lasting form of birth control – the copper IUD can last for 12 years and the hormonal IUDs can be effective for 3-5 years. While the upfront costs for IUDs may be higher, their longevity actually makes them one of the cheapest options for birth control. For women who do not want to take a hormonal birth control, the copper IUD is an effective, simple option. The hormonal IUDs can reduce period length and severity.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><i>Drawbacks:</i> The high upfront cost can be a deterrent, but this is dependent on personal access to health insurance and coverage of the IUD. The insertion of the IUD requires a doctor’s appointment. For the copper IUD, periods may become heavier and severity of cramps may increase. Period irregularities can also increase with the hormonal IUD. Some complications may occur with the physical IUD, such as infection from the device or the device slipping out. These are less common side effects, but they require a prompt doctor’s visit.</span>

&nbsp;

<hr />

&nbsp;
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span style="color: #000000;"><b>BIRTH CONTROL IMPLANT</b></span></span></p>
<span style="color: #000000;">A thin, flexible rod that is inserted into the arm by a healthcare provider. The rod releases a hormone called progestin.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><i>How does this prevent pregnancy?</i> Progestin prevents eggs from leaving the ovaries, so sperm cannot reach the eggs. Progestin also thickens cervical mucus, which prevents sperm from fertilizing the egg.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><i>Effectiveness:</i> 99 percent</span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><i>Benefits:</i> This is a long-lasting form of birth control, which offers protection for up to three years. It can be used by women who cannot take estrogen. It does not require any memory of daily pills nor regular doctor’s appointments. For most women with the implant, periods become lighter. Many women (1 in 3) will stop having their period altogether after one year, although this may be a drawback, depending on your personal preferences.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><i>Drawbacks:</i> High upfront cost, although this depends on access to health insurance and insurance coverage of the implant. The implant may make periods heavier, and may increase spotting or bleeding between periods. Less commonly, women may experience breast tenderness, pain at the insertion site, discoloring or scarring at the insertion site, headaches, weight gain and nausea.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">In addition to these forms of birth control, barrier methods are another way to prevent pregnancy. The most common forms of barrier contraceptives are the condom, the female condom, and the diaphragm.  Of these, condoms are the most accessible, and can be purchased at most grocery and drug stores. Female condoms are carried by certain drug stores, online, or at local clinics. You have to see a health care provider to get a diaphragm.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><strong><strong> </strong></strong></span>

<hr />

&nbsp;

&nbsp;
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="color: #000000;">People choose to go on birth control for a range of reasons, so if you have any desire in starting birth control you should make an appointment with your doctor to talk over what options would be the best for you. The type of birth control that you choose to use is personal and depends on your lifestyle, but all types can help give you peace of mind and more control over your body. </span></p>
And if you have any questions about types not included here feel free to ask!

We love to help you make the best decision for <i>you</i>.

<span style="color: #000000;">Some helpful reference websites:</span>
<span style="color: #000000;">Plannedparenthood.org/health-info/birth-control</span>
<span style="color: #000000;">http://www.cdc.gov/reproductivehealth/unintendedpregnancy/contraception.html</span>

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Spackle Small Holes In Your Wall</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-fill-small-holes-in-your-wall/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 21 Apr 2015 05:54:04 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[lauren-montgomery]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=1524</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Filling a hole in a wall may seem daunting, but don’t worry - it’s one of the easiest home repairs out there.  Whether you’re moving out of your apartment and want that security deposit back, to keep your walls looking all Martha Stewart Living, or to keep everything insulated, knowing how to fix a small hole will always be a useful skill to keep in your back pocket.  It will also make you feel like a genuine home improvement hero.  You’ll need: spackle or joint compound, a sponge, finer grade sandpaper, and a spackle knife (optional) in order to dive in.

<hr />

<iframe src="//www.youtube.com/embed/sqXYuOUAU9g" width="425" height="350" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe>

<strong><strong> </strong></strong>
<h6>Steps</h6>
1) Tidy up the hole. If there are rough edges or pieces of rogue drywall, trim them away with some sandpaper, a utility knife or even some scissors. You want to have an even surface to work on.

&nbsp;

2) Clean the area of wall surrounding the hole. Dampen an old sponge and wipe down the area you’ll be patching. You’ll use the damp sponge again in step 4, so keep it handy.

&nbsp;

3) Fill the hole with spackle or joint compound, which can be found at any hardware store. Once the hole is filled, smooth out the excess spackle over the surface of the wall - you can do this with a spackle knife or even your fingers.  Tip: Don’t go overboard spackling, a little goes a long way.

&nbsp;

4) Lightly go over the area with a damp sponge. This makes it easier to flatten the area so it blends more seamlessly with the surrounding wall.

&nbsp;

5) Once everything is dry, sand it down. Sand the area with a finer grade sandpaper until it’s completely flush with the wall around it. Using a tougher grit sandpaper might damage the wall surrounding the hole you’re trying to fill, and might undo all the work you just did filling; you don’t need to exert a lot of effort sanding the area, so your sandpaper should be similarly delicate.  Depending on your situation, you may or may not need to paint over this newly fixed hole.

If you’re moving out of a rental, you should check with your landlord; some landlords will repaint the entire apartment and won’t require you to do any painting yourself.  If your walls are a color other than white, you might want to purchase the paint yourself - again, ask your landlord what color was originally used to make sure the paint matches - so you can cover up the newly patched hole.

&nbsp;

That’s it! Woo! Have any stories of spackling your wall? Leave a comment below!

&nbsp;

Picture Source: Wikihow

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Drive Safely on the Freeway</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-drive-safely-on-the-freeway/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 21 Apr 2015 06:01:24 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Rachel Wiegardt-Egel]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=1527</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-size: 16px;">Driving on the freeway can be an intimidating proposition: merging, changing lanes at 65+ mph, and navigating giant semi-trucks is enough to give even experienced drivers pause. It’s good to be cautious, but the world is big and it’s important to be able to get yourself from place to place. And in fact, freeways are actually safer in many ways than city streets— no stoplights, no surprise one way streets, no pedestrians (one can only hope).</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;">So, here are some tips to help you conquer any fear of freeway driving and get ready to hit the open road!</span>

<hr />

<h6><strong><span style="font-size: 16px;">Look Far Ahead</span></strong></h6>
<span style="font-size: 16px;">The best drivers are the ones who are always aware of what’s coming. If you’re focused only on the car in front of you, you might miss the sign that your exit is coming up, that two lanes are merging into one, or that there are cars breaking up ahead. Try to always look ahead to where your car will be in approximately 10-15 seconds: this way, you’ll have more time to react and won’t have to slam on your breaks. Know in advance when you have to exit—this will allow you to look for signs and be in the proper lane when the time comes.</span>

&nbsp;
<h6><strong><span style="font-size: 16px;">Learn to Deal with Blind Spots</span></strong></h6>
<span style="font-size: 16px;">Blind spots are the areas around or behind your car that you won’t be able to see in any of your mirrors. Blind spots are dangerous no matter where you’re driving, and fast freeway speeds only multiply the danger.. You can easily figure out where your blind spots are by sitting in a parked car and having a friend walk around you so you can identify when you can’t see them in your mirrors. Compensate for blind spots by <em>always, always, always</em> quickly checking over your shoulder before changing lanes. You can use a handy acronym that my Driver’s Ed teacher taught me: SMOG—after you’ve identified that it’s time to change lanes, <strong>S</strong>ignal (turn your signal on, always at least five seconds before you change lanes), <strong>M</strong>irror (check your side mirror to make sure the next lane is clear), <strong>O</strong>ver your shoulder (glance over your shoulder to make there aren’t any cars hiding in your side mirror’s blind spot), <strong>G</strong>o (change lanes when you’re sure it’s safe). The most important thing to remember about checking over your shoulder is to keep the car steady until your eyes are forward again—don’t veer to the side as you look!</span>

&nbsp;
<h6><strong><span style="font-size: 16px;">Don’t Be Afraid to Merge</span></strong></h6>
<span style="font-size: 16px;">Easily one of the scariest parts of driving, merging is actually super simple after you realize that the key is to merge already going close to the speed of traffic. This way, you don’t have to force the driver behind you to slam on their breaks when you go in front of them. Almost all freeways have merge lanes—lanes used to separate entering or exiting traffic from the cars already on the freeway, which allow you to accelerate to the speed of traffic before merging with it. If traffic is at a standstill, just wait your turn—any decent driver will let you in when it’s your time to go.</span>

&nbsp;
<h6><strong><span style="font-size: 16px;">Be Emergency-Ready</span></strong></h6>
<span style="font-size: 16px;">Car breakdowns and accidents on the freeway can be incredibly dangerous. If you’re ever in an emergency situation and your car’s still functioning, signal, turn on emergency flashers, and pull completely off the roadway onto the shoulder. It’s always a good idea to have a few basics in your car in case you get into an emergency situation, including jumper cables, roadside flares/emergency markers, a first aid kit, a spare tire and tire iron, an ice scraper, a flashlight, and a blanket. For more ideas, check out the DMV’s<a href="http://www.dmv.org/how-to-guides/emergency-kit.php"> guide</a> to packing an emergency kit.</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;">And always have a charged cell phone!</span>

&nbsp;
<h6><strong><span style="font-size: 16px;">Shake It Off (or, Let It Go)</span></strong></h6>
<span style="font-size: 16px;">Whether you prefer to sing along to T-Swift or Elsa, a big key to freeway safety is to simply go with the flow. Accidents happen because people aren’t paying attention and make rash decisions. If you miss an exit, just go to the next one and trust you’ll get back on course. If there’s a slow truck up ahead of you that you didn’t see in time to change lanes, just slow down for as long as you need to until you can safely change lanes. Relax. Everything will be okay. Also, be a kind person: help other drivers enter, exit, or change lanes by adjusting your speed or moving to the next lane if it’s clear. And of course, be smart: don’t text while driving, don’t speed beyond the flow of traffic, and never drink and drive. Texts can wait, speeding is against the law and unsafe, and if you’ve had one too many glasses of merlot, you can always use Lyft or have a sober friend drive you home and help you pick your car up the next day.</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;">If you’re nervous, don’t be embarrassed to have an experienced freeway driver come with you on your next freeway adventure. Now, be safe, be confident, and cue the roadtrip music!</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;"> </span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;">For more info, check out AAA’s advice for freeway driving:</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;"> <a href="http://autoclubsouth.aaa.com/Assets/PDFs/freeway_driving.pdf">http://autoclubsouth.aaa.com/Assets/PDFs/freeway_driving.pdf</a></span>

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 16px;">Gif Source: Eliana Horeczko</span>]]></content:encoded>

		<title>TWIGG Tip: Checking Your Tire Tread</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/twigg-tip/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 08 May 2015 03:58:05 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[twigg2014]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=1553</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<iframe src="//www.youtube.com/embed/zfcO1qGARQI" width="425" height="350" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe>

How can you tell when to change your tires? Watch this TWIGG Tip to find out!]]></content:encoded>
