	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Travel Alone Safely</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-travel-alone-safely/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 02 Jun 2015 07:55:14 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Elena Cherine]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=1581</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[While hotels allow you your own private room, they are typically two to three times more expensive than a hostel.  In the past, I have considered staying in hotels while traveling alone, but this can get lonely and expensive, and ultimately might leave you with fewer funds to travel to more places.
<p style="text-align: center;">
<span style="color: #ffcc00; font-size: 20px;"><strong>But how does one single, attractive, intelligent female navigate the hostel experience and still feel safe?  </strong></span></p>

<h5 style="text-align: center;">Follow these steps!</h5>
&nbsp;
<ol>
	<li><strong><span style="font-size: 16px;">Do research!</span></strong>  Find a hostel that is as close to the heart of the city you are visiting as possible.  Many big cities will have several hostels to choose from.  <i>Don’t be fooled </i>by the hostel websites’ descriptions.  “Only 15 minutes from city center” <i>might</i> mean an interesting and safe walk through city streets.  But in my experience, this often means 15 minutes down a long, deserted road or an obscure, rickety metro line.  Think ahead and consider what you plan to do.  Remember that you want a hostel that is in a safe location day <i>and</i> night because it’s likely you won’t want to end your day at sunset (which is around 4:45pm during the winter months in many European countries).  Plan your trip carefully so you can explore all night long!</li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;"><strong>Always have some form of a reliable map</strong></span>, especially if you don’t have map capabilities on your phone.  Writing down step-by-step directions ahead of time is one way to go, but it really helps to have a picture, especially if the city you’re visiting has winding roads, intermittent countryside, and nearly non-existent street signs.  Having a map is especially important if you arrive to the city at night.</li>
	<li>Some women might feel a little nervous sleeping in a room with eleven people they’ve never met before, many of them unfamiliar men.  I frequently <span style="font-size: 16px;"><strong>bunk in female dorms</strong></span>.  While these dorms are just as likely to provide the adventurous traveler with bunkmates that return late, loud, and drunk, and sometimes, less-than-comfortable mattresses, the few extra dollars I spent on these dorms usually meant fewer roommates and just a little more ease of mind.  I’ve also met great hostel friends in female dorms.  Meeting these friends gave me sightseeing and meal buddies, and also gave me the chance to meet people from all over the world.  While hostels aren’t always the most comfortable, I have always found that when traveling alone, the hostel experience is more interesting and memorable.</li>
	<li>Which gets me to my next point.  Traveling alone is invigorating and eye-opening in many ways.  There is a sense of intense accomplishment and freedom that comes with planning a trip all on your own and being in charge of all the decisions.  But…sometimes it does get lonely.  Fortunately, there are ways to balance this out!  When researching your hostel, <span style="font-size: 16px;"><strong>look for one with a bar and restaurant</strong></span>.  Other hostel residents will often want to meet new people too, and this is definitely the place to go!  I’ve also met traveling friends in hostel kitchens and lounges.  Specifically, I have had good luck with the hostel chain St. Christopher’s Inn.  St. Christopher’s tends to be smaller than other hostels, but they usually have a great hostel staff, a banging atmosphere, and are in a good location.</li>
	<li>Another great way to meet new people while traveling alone is to <span style="font-size: 16px;"><strong>take walking tours of the city</strong></span>.  There are frequently free tours offered in big cities (see Sandeman’s in Europe and Free Tours By Foot in the U.S).  The more expensive ones usually don’t run more than $20 and give you way more information about your city’s history than you could ever have read in a guidebook in the same period of time.  It’s easy to meet people while walking from sight to sight, and there are often people who have broken off from their travel group temporarily and are also on the tour alone.  Move in and get those connections!  Making friends with one traveler could lead to a whole new group of friends.</li>
	<li>To expand briefly, don’t underestimate taking the time to<span style="font-size: 16px;"><strong> talk to people you meet along the way</strong></span>!  Other travelers are just as much of the experience as any landmark or museum–frequently they become the best travel stories later.</li>
	<li>The most important thing as a woman traveling alone is to <span style="font-size: 16px;"><strong>LISTEN TO YOUR INSTINCTS</strong></span>, however faint they might seem.  Finding that balance between reckless adventure and careful safety can be challenging, but it’s incredibly important.  It is <i>always</i> more worth it to back away from something that feels even a little off than to convince yourself you’re being paranoid, and keep trudging through toward something potentially dangerous.  Besides, it’s likely that you are already experiencing the adventure of a lifetime because you chose to travel alone, and have taken the steps to follow through with your ideas. There’s no point in endangering your own safety.</li>
</ol>
<h5 style="text-align: center;">Each mind-boggling tour, centuries-old palace, and eccentric hostel lies in your hands–that’s the beauty of traveling alone.  You’re the only one your decisions affect.</h5>
<h6 style="text-align: center;">Why <i>not   </i>trust your own mind?</h6>
<p style="text-align: center;"></p>
&nbsp;

Photo: stuff.co]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Write an Eye-Catching Cover Letter</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-write-an-eye-catching-cover-letter/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 24 Jun 2015 01:55:38 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Rachel Wiegardt-Egel]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=1631</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[So you’ve started the job search, found a position that sounds interesting, and updated your résumé— now it’s time to write your cover letter! Whether you’re new to the “real world,” changing careers, or looking for a more fulfilling job within your current field, cover letters can be tricky. It’s not just a note to introduce your résumé, it’s an opportunity to grab a recruiter/future supervisor’s attention. But don’t stress over trying to do too much with your cover letter: think of it as the key to landing an interview. You don’t have to say everything in writing—you’ll wow them with your smarts, training, and dazzling personality in the interview itself. So in your application, focus on showcasing three things: strong, clear writing, your interest in the position, and how you would be an asset to the company. Read on for some tips to make your cover letter stand out!

&nbsp;
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/Coke_Facebook.png"><img class="alignnone wp-image-1643" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/Coke_Facebook-300x226.png" alt="Coke_Facebook" width="385" height="291" /></a></p>
<strong>Do Your Research</strong>

Learn everything you can about the company to which you’re applying. It gives you a chance to really gauge whether you want to work for them and why, and to craft your cover letter specifically to the company and position. Many company websites have an “About” section, staff bios, and information on the kind of work they’ve done in the past. You can also check out their Facebook page, Twitter, or Instagram: any 21st century company worth their salt has some kind of social media presence these days, and it can be a great way to learn about their company dynamic.

&nbsp;

<strong>Have a Clear Progression</strong>

Everyone writes cover letters a little differently, so there’s no magic formula—but there is a format that tends to let you tell a good story: short intro, three concise body paragraphs, closing sentence.
<ul>
	<li>Paragraph 1: “This is why I’m interested in you.” Talk about why the company and position are exciting for you.</li>
	<li>Paragraph 2: “This is why you should be interested in me.” Tell them how your previous experiences make you well suited to the position.</li>
	<li>Paragraph 3: “This is what I offer/what I hope to learn.” Discuss what you’ll bring to the table, and don’t be afraid to say what you want to learn. Sharing this will show that you’re interested in professional growth and will have even more to offer as you spend time in the position.</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

<img class=" wp-image-1641 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/ShopifyCoverLetterWebPage-400x339-300x254.png" alt="ShopifyCoverLetterWebPage-400x339" width="365" height="310" />

<strong>Make It Personal and Specific</strong>

Try to tailor your cover letter as much as possible to each company. Ditch the “To Whom it May Concern” address of days past; it’s outdated and makes it seem like you haven’t done the research to know who you’ll be working for. If you know who your supervisor would be, address it directly to them (you can often find out on the job positing or the company website). If you don’t know the supervisor, address the letter to the head of HR. Even “Dear [Company Name]” will suffice if all your other searching fails. Then, make the letter specific to you. Stay away from clichés, and tell the reader a story—perhaps the story of how you became interested in the field or in the company. Back up your statements: if you say, “this position would give me the opportunity to grow,” tell them how. Everyone likes to feel special, so don’t make your future employer feel like they’re getting the same pick-up line as every other company at the bar—tell them why you want to work with them, in particular.

&nbsp;

<strong>Set the Right Tone</strong>

You want to be respectful, but don’t be too humble: you’re awesome, so you shouldn’t be afraid to tell them why you’re an awesome choice for the job. Be professional, but not too formal or stilted. Be honest and genuine: you want the person reading your letter to know that you would be fun to have in the office.

&nbsp;

<strong>Be a Spelling/Grammar Perfectionist</strong>

Take advantage of spell check and grammar check! You want to seem detail-oriented. Errors in your letter make a bad impression and could take you out of the running entirely .

&nbsp;

<strong>Let Your Passion Shine Through</strong>

Tell the company why you’re passionate about the work they do. If you’re not passionate about it yet, pick out a few specifics that you find really intriguing.

&nbsp;

<strong>Wrap Up</strong>

Thank your reader for their consideration, sign off, create a single PDF of your cover letter with your resume and any other application materials, send it out, and think positive thoughts!

&nbsp;

For further tips and sample cover letters, check out the following articles:

<a href="http://www.fastcompany.com/3016727/leadership-now/dont-be-boring-how-to-write-a-cover-letter-that-can-get-you-the-job">"Don't Be Boring: How To Write a Cover Letter That Can Get You the Job" - Fast Company</a>

<a href="http://www.forbes.com/sites/dailymuse/2014/02/06/the-cover-letters-that-make-hiring-managers-smile-then-call-you/">"The Cover Letters That Make Hiring Managers Smile (Then Call You) - Forbes</a>

<a href="https://www.themuse.com/advice/the-8-cover-letters-you-need-to-read-now">"The 8 Cover Letters You Need to Read Now" - The Muse</a>

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

Cover Image: nerdwallet.com

Image: blog.thecatmelon.com]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Bounce Back From Getting Fired</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-bounce-back-from-getting-fired/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 11 Jul 2015 02:06:54 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Caitlin Cohen]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=1651</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[
<p>In June 2011 I was fired from my office assistant job at a major production company, leaving me devastated. My dream was to write and produce for television, but how was that going to happen if I couldn’t even hold on to an office assistant job for more than three months?</p>
<p>A month later I got a job as a copywriter for an SEO company. I’d get to write, even if the writing wasn’t exactly the kind I’d hoped to do, and I was making a livable wage doing it.  Unfortunately, I lasted one week before I was fired for, and I quote, “writing at a junior high level, senior high at best.”  To recap, I had been fired twice in about a month; the second time, because I was deemed not good enough at something I thought was my life’s passion.</p>
<p>August was a tough month for me. I was living at home with my parents at the time, spending my days wallowing in misery. One Saturday morning, I was staring at a cup of coffee I hadn’t started yet when my brother and father came home from playing basketball.  Out of nowhere, I started bawling. My brother realized he needed to take a shower immediately and basically sprinted out of the room, while my father pointed out that this attitude was no way to get a job (unsurprisingly, not helpful). Living with my mom and dad really made me feel like a failure, and I had no faith in my abilities to be an independent adult.</p>
<p>I finally got a job near the end of August as an assistant to a literary manager. She was entirely in film, which was not exactly what I wanted to do (television &gt; film), but close enough. Even though it only paid $500 a week for 11 hour days, I moved to an apartment and thought this would be my gateway to getting my life back on track - until she fired me before 5 PM on day one.</p>
<p>Until last night, I was unsure if I was qualified to write this article.  I am self-sufficient and work at a job I’m good at, but it’s not my dream career and I have doubts about it frequently. I only realized I had something to offer when a friend of mine asked me for advice.   She told me she got fired from her restaurant job, and she was really upset about it.  She remembered I had told her about my inability to keep a job three years ago, and she asked me how I handled it.  I surprised myself by offering what I think was pretty damn good advice.</p>
<hr />
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><b>Realize it happened because it wasn’t a good fit</b>.</p>
<p>Getting fired was not a reflection on you; it was a reflection on your relationship with your workplace.  When I got fired from my office assistant job, I was very upset – but I also remember waking up the next morning and realizing, happily, that I never had to go back there again.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><b>Stay positive.</b></p>
<p>This is, without a doubt, the most difficult step.  While the way my dad told me to stay positive was not helpful (“if you stay negative, missy, you’ll end up being the loser you think you are”), he was right.  Do whatever you need to do to stay positive.  Treat yourself to the best of your abilities.  You want to marathon entire seasons of shows on Netflix?  Do it.  You want to go to the beach in the middle of your Wednesday?  My god, DO IT.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p> <b>Keep busy.</b></p>
<p>The easiest way to stay positive is to take your mind off what happened.  With all this free time, you can finally do all the things you’ve been wanting to do.  Decorate your home like those cutesy apartments you’ve been eyeing on Pinterest.  Exercise regularly.  Read a book.  Be artistic.  Create something.  Learn a new recipe.  Take day trips around your neighborhood or city.  In Los Angeles, there are so many different articles about free things or cheap things you can do in and around town.  I’m sure this is true for just about everywhere, so do some internet research and have fun while you don’t have the work obligation!</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><b>Don’t dwell on your old job.</b></p>
<p>Could you have done something differently?  Maybe.  I know I could have.  My attitude was piss poor, like I was entitled to this shitty job and better than these menial tasks.  That mentality absolutely came across in my work.  Does thinking about what you could have done differently change <i>anything</i>?  No.  Learn the lesson and move on.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><b> Figure out what you need in your next job</b>.</p>
<p>By the time I got fired the third time, I just needed a job that would support me and not fire me.  I stand by my choice, as over the last several years I’ve had the chance to build up a confidence in myself that just did not exist three years ago.  What do you need out of your job?  What is important to you?  What did your old job not do for you?</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p> <b>Keep moving forward.</b></p>
<p>Applying for jobs sucks.  Networking sucks.  But you know what doesn’t suck?  Looking at all the possibilities for new jobs!  Imagining yourself in a new, exciting career!  There are so many options!  This door closed so you could open another cooler, more personal door.  You’re going to have to work for it, and it sure isn’t going to be easy, but let this new chapter be as exciting and rewarding as possible.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Not everything is 100% where I want it to be right now, even three years after that awful summer, but trying to switch careers is a very different issue than getting fired.  I got “getting over getting fired” on lock.  To be fair, there is no single right answer for how to bounce back from getting fired, but these tips helped me get through it.  Don’t beat yourself up – you’re a great kid with a ton of potential.  Now you finally get to use it.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Gif: Buzzfeed</p>
]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Make Your Exercise Routine One That You Can Stick With!</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-make-your-exercise-routine-one-that-you-can-stick-with/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 16 Jul 2015 07:51:20 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[MJ@twigghowto.com]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=1669</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_1671" align="aligncenter" width="600"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/workout-article.jpg"><img class="wp-image-1671 size-full" title="Photo Credit: Matt Dutile / Getty Images" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/workout-article.jpg" alt="workout article" width="600" height="821" /></a> Photo Credit: Matt Dutile / Getty Images[/caption]
<h2 style="text-align: center;">Water is wet, the sky is blue, and exercise is great for you.</h2>
<p style="text-align: center;">We all know these things, but it doesn’t change the fact that sticking to an exercise routine is not easy for most of us. There’s a plethora of reasons for why that may be, but I have a feeling that many people just don’t know where to begin. Let’s face it - lists of “8 Moves for a Tighter Butt/ Stronger Abs/ Thighs That Stop Time” sometimes seem meant for fit people who already have their routines down pat and their s*** together. Where are the lists of,“8 Moves for Just Getting Started,” “10 Tips for People Who Have No Idea What They’re Doing,” and “20 Reasons NOT to Burst into Tears When You Put On Your Workout Clothes?”</p>
<p style="text-align: center;">I don’t have those answers yet, but I do have some stable exercise experience of my own and some really<strong><a href="http://greatist.com/fitness/walking-good-workout-running"> informative</a>,</strong> body-positive, non-condescending links that I hope you find useful. Enjoy!</p>


<hr />

&nbsp;
<h4 style="text-align: center;"><b>Set goals with two “A”s in mind: Adaptability and Achievability</b></h4>
Whether you’ve beat your highest score in a video game or watched your grade go up in a challenging class, you’ve probably experienced the<strong><a href="http://www.mayoclinic.org/healthy-lifestyle/stress-management/in-depth/exercise-and-stress/art-20044469"> “endorphin rush” and excitement</a></strong> that comes with reaching a tangible goal. It’s easy to take that feeling for granted, but I can’t stress how much easier it is to stick with a workout routine when you constantly feel like you’re reaching new levels.<strong><a href="http://www.sparkpeople.com/resource/fitness_articles.asp?id=1595"> Having achievable goals and reaching them regularly really builds confidence and keeps you going</a>.</strong>

For max benefit,<a href="http://www.healthyweightnetwork.com/size1.htm"><strong> don’t focus solely on weight</strong></a>. Weight-loss, especially when it could significantly impact your health, can be a great thing. Focusing too much on weight, however, can be a set-up for disappointment. “<a href="http://www.shape.com/lifestyle/mind-and-body/when-your-weight-fluctuates-whats-normal-and-whats-not"><strong>Not all positive changes can be recorded by a scale</strong>,</a>” and it’s too easy to get discouraged when the number on the scale changes in a way you weren’t expecting.

<strong><a href="http://healthyliving.azcentral.com/examples-shortterm-fitness-goals-1271.html">Instead, focus on things you have more control over</a></strong>. Here are some examples:

Cut your mile-time down by 30 seconds. Increase how many stairs you can climb in 15 minutes. Add five more pounds to your machine/weight routine. Depending on your personal preferences, gain or lose half of an inch in a chosen area. Learn a new move, or improve your skill in an organized activity like yoga, pilates, kickboxing, dancing, etc.<strong><a href="http://www.heart.org/HEARTORG/GettingHealthy/PhysicalActivity/FitnessBasics/American-Heart-Association-Recommendations-for-Physical-Activity-in-Adults_UCM_307976_Article.jsp"> Get 150 minutes of cardio this week</a>,</strong> and 40 minutes of stretching the next.

&nbsp;

<a href="http://greatist.com/discover/july-challenge-wall-sit-2014?utm_source=homepage&amp;utm_medium=textlink&amp;utm_campaign=latest-articles"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1676" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/July2014_MonthlyChallenge_WallSits_Final.png" alt="July2014_MonthlyChallenge_WallSits_Final" width="732" height="972" /></a>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Image Credit: Greatist.com</em></p>

<h4 style="text-align: center;"><b>Fill your calendar (or use some other eye-catching way to hold yourself accountable)</b></h4>
Whether you prefer written or digital planning devices, using some kind of calendar to plan your workouts (and the rest of your day) ahead of time makes it much harder to fall victim to excuses.<strong><a href="http://greatist.com/fitness/how-make-workout-plan-and-stick-it"> Schedule it in the same way you’d schedule a doctor’s appointment.</a></strong>

&nbsp;

When you’re just starting out, give yourself a lot of leeway. Start with two or three times a week that you know you can commit to. This way, if an obstacle arises (as they tend to do), you have plenty of space to re-schedule your workout. And if an obstacle doesn’t arise? You’ve made it to the gym three times a week, no problem. That in itself is reaching a goal; doesn’t it feel good?

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/inspiration-fitness.jpg"><img class=" wp-image-1673 size-full aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/inspiration-fitness.jpg" alt="inspiration fitness" width="494" height="750" /></a>
<h4 style="text-align: center;"><b>Start with baby steps</b></h4>
Walk into any gym, and you see people who rival Beyonce and The Rock when it comes to physical perfection. It’s natural to feel a little nervous next to seasoned gym-goers when you’re still trying to figure out how to use a machine, or you’re lifting dumbbells that look like toothpicks next to everybody else’s. This doesn’t just happen at the gym; I’m guilty of wondering what drivers must be thinking while I run outside, huffing and puffing after five minutes next to people who run miles without breaking a sweat.

&nbsp;

Acknowledge that feeling, then let it go. This is important for your self-esteem and for your physical health as well. Too often we can push ourselves way too far in the name of “keeping up,” and then we rationalize torn muscles and exhaustion with “no pain, no gain.” Not only could you cause yourself some serious knee, back, and shoulder issues, but you’re effectively turning your workout sessions into torture sessions. Can you really see yourself going back to that day after day?

&nbsp;

Instead,<strong><a href="http://lifehacker.com/5950484/how-to-motivate-yourself-into-an-exercise-routine-youll-actually-stick-to"> be realistic, take it slow</a>,</strong> and<strong><a href="http://greatist.com/fitness/how-make-workout-plan-and-stick-it"> make it fun</a>.</strong> Remember that something is ALWAYS better than nothing. (Pro tip: people who are truly seasoned in the fitness game will respect you for doing your thing and doing it safely within your limits. Not like what they think matters, right?)

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/gif-test.gif"><img class=" size-full wp-image-1675 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/gif-test.gif" alt="gif test" width="240" height="192" /></a>
<h4 style="text-align: center;"><b>Give yourself something to look forward to</b></h4>
Finally, make sure every workout has a “reward” component (<strong><a href="http://science.howstuffworks.com/life/exercise-happiness2.htm">outside of the natural high you might be getting anyway</a></strong>). This will be different for everybody. For example, I love to dance, so if my workout involves learning choreography, I’m guaranteed to look forward to it. Other things I do to reward myself are long stretch/walk breaks where I read my favorite magazine, or listen to a new album on Spotify.

Find that thing that makes YOU keep going, and allow yourself to indulge a little bit. Exercise is meant to be a lifestyle, not a trend or a means to an end. It’s so much easier to make something a part of your life when you actually enjoy doing it!

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/women-in-technology-changing-the-world-one-line-of-code-at-a-time/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 19 Jul 2015 00:02:24 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[krisha-agatep]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=1695</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[
<h4 style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/Wine-Night-31.jpg"><img class="alignnone wp-image-1727 " src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/Wine-Night-31-e1437328730695.jpg" alt="Wine Night 31" width="293" height="517" /></a></h4>
<p><em>The TWIGGVP Award is given to two outstanding women on our team that have gone above and beyond to help make TWIGG How-To what it is today! As strong female role models, these women embody the TWIGG How-To values in their everyday life and were voted by their peers as our MVP's, or as we like to call it, our 2015 TWIGGVPs. Watch below for our 2015 TWIGGVP honoree video featured at our first annual Wine &amp; Awards night July 18th, 2015.</em></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>[embed]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z2uNmLo61PI[/embed]</p>
<p><em>Krisha is Team TWIGG's resident web designer and a frequent technology contributor. Read her bio <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/our-team/" target="_blank">here</a> and inspiring story below.</em></p>
<hr />
<h4 style="text-align: center;"></h4>
<h4 style="text-align: center;">To be honest, I never thought I would end up here.</h4>
<p>Prior to graduating from college, I was hoping to pursue a career in graphic design and perhaps someday get a job in magazine design. Then, in my junior year of college, I accepted one of my first marketing internships at a Silicon Valley-based tech startup, where the CEO and Co-founder of the company was a woman. I soon realized that this was kind of a big deal, considering women account for only 14 percent of senior management positions at Silicon Valley startups. Not only did she co-found the company, she also helped build the company’s proprietary cloud software product from the ground up.</p>
<p>A couple months into my internship, I went to my first women in technology meetup at the Google campus in Mountain View. Here I was, a young, bright-eyed college student at one of the coolest tech campuses, surrounded by some of the most brilliant, successful, and inspiring women in the Valley (including my CEO). As cheesy as it may sound, that was the moment I thought to myself, man, I should really learn how to code.</p>
<p>And that’s just what I did. With one web development class under my belt and very little job experience, I took my first job out of college as a web developer in Los Angeles. Now I’m writing for the very website I helped build.</p>
<p>Thinking about women in technology today, a job title like Information Technology Specialist typically isn’t one we associate with women. Very rarely will you hear a teenage girl say, “when I grow up I want to be a computer programmer.” Maybe it’s something about sitting and coding in front of a computer all day that doesn’t sound as glamorous as becoming a brain surgeon or Editor-in-Chief of a fashion magazine. But that is something I hope to change.</p>
<p>From software development to computer engineering, the job possibilities in technology-related fields are endless and they’re never going away. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, there will be an estimated 1.4 million computer science jobs available in the US by 2020, yet in 2013, women made up 26% of the computing workforce.</p>
<p>But it doesn’t have to be this way. Considering women are the leading adopters of new technology, wouldn’t it make sense if we played a significant role in creating and developing the technologies and websites we use today?</p>
<p>Bridging the gender gap starts with changing the way we perceive tech-related jobs. It starts with no longer being intimated by code by taking a few coding courses at codeacademy.com, generalassemb.ly/ or codeschool.com. It starts with inspiring younger girls in our communities to see technology as a viable career path and to get involved with programs like Girls Who Code and Black Girls Code. It starts by the attending local networking events for women in technology such as the one I attended at Google years ago.</p>
<p>We also have to shift the way we think about technology in general. If you think about it, computers are really not that smart. They don’t have the capacity for critical thinking on their own. They only know exactly what you tell it to do. As a programmer, you have the power to control the computer. If you really wanted to, you have the power to create and build an app that could tell you what type of wine you should drink based on your mood that day, where the nearest grocery store is to buy that wine from, and what movie on Netflix pairs well with your selected wine - if you really wanted to, of course.</p>
<p>What I’m getting at is, programming gives you the power to take the needs of society into your own hands and build a creative and intelligent solution to the satisfy that need. And if we as women choose take the leap into technology, we have the power to satisfy those needs, and maybe even change the world, one line of code (and one fine glass of Merlot carefully selected by the app you just built) at a time.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>-Krisha</p>
]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>TWIGGVP Feature: Becoming &quot;Damsel-Free&quot;</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/twigg-vp-feature-becoming-damsel-free/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 19 Jul 2015 00:11:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[karissa-chamblin]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=1705</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[&nbsp;

<img class="aligncenter wp-image-1723" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/image1.jpg" alt="" width="346" height="539" />
<p style="text-align: left;"><em>The TWIGGVP Award is given to two outstanding women on our team that have gone above and beyond to help make TWIGG How-To what it is today! As strong female role models, these women embody the TWIGG How-To values in their everyday life and were voted by their peers as our MVP's, or as we like to call it, our 2015 TWIGGVPs. Watch below for our 2015 TWIGGVP honoree video featured at our first annual Wine &amp; Awards night July 18th, 2015.</em></p>
[embed]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z2uNmLo61PI[/embed]
<p style="text-align: left;"><em>Karissa is an article contributor, specializing in home decor and floral arrangements. Read her bio <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/our-team/">here</a> and inspiring story below.</em></p>


<hr />

<h4 style="text-align: center;">If you had asked me what I wanted to be in high school, my response would have been "a mom'.</h4>
All my years of video productions competitions and classes, art classes, photography classes and my love for interior design meant nothing to me. I just wanted to be a mom. All of my other skills and interests were not nearly as important. They were simply a "plan B". See, I was raised by a woman who was beautiful in every sense. She was "Mom of the Year" every year. But she was insecure with herself. She got married young and had me at 23 years old and my sister two years later. If you had asked her in high school, what she wanted to be, she would have said "a mom". She never once really found herself. She never once put herself before her girls. We were her life. I admired that so much and I wanted to be just like her.But I obviously was smart enough to know I was not ready to have children, so I ventured off to art school, knowing in the back of my head, it wouldn't take me anywhere. I lacked confidence. I lacked motivation. I lacked the ability to dream bigger than I was. It was a natural character flaw that I had picked up from my mom. I was insecure.

I had an emotionally unstable relationship with my high school boyfriend. We were living together right out of high school and I was far too immature to handle a job, a boyfriend who wasn't good for me, and school full time. So being the insecure girl that I was, I dropped out of school without any intention on going back. Things got really bad with my boyfriend and I and after four years, we ended our relationship. I was 20 years old and already a college dropout. I worked two jobs and made a lot of money, but I was insecure and lonely. So when I met this guy, Samuel, I was instantly hooked. Sam and I went through elementary, junior high and high school together but never really knew each other. He was a babe and he played the guitar and I was smitten. He moved in my apartment a month later. Looking back, I'm almost positive my insecurities and desperation for love pushed him too fast into liking me. Six months later, I was pregnant. Not exactly how I planned my life out, but I was going to have a baby with the man I loved and I was so happy. I was 21.

Fast forward to four years, two kids and a mortgage later, and I am a mess. 24 years old and I still have no idea who I am. My only title was "mom". The one I had dreamed of for so many years. I had post partum depression. Sam was working 80 hours a week so that I could stay home with my babies and our relationship was in shambles. My entire existance on this earth was to take care of my kids and I was doing an incredible job but completely ignoring myself as a human and any other human for that matter. I was deeply insecure. I smiled through it all, almost in complete oblivion that I was destroying myself. This beautiful, talented girl, just wasting away and not giving herself a life. Then I got a wake up call. Sam was done. He no longer loved me. The man I had two children with, didn't love me anymore. I died that day. I died for six months straight. I couldn't pull it together. I was jobless, car-less, house-less and I had failed my family. It took me six months of a deep depression to finally realize that I  wasn't dead. I had a second chance to have a life. And this time, I already had the title as "mom".

This new perspective I had gained came with good and bad lights. I was sharing my kids now. For the first time in their lives, I wasn't there for all of their breaths each day. That took some adjusting. It came with guilt and heartache and regret. But it got easier. I was able to do things I had never done before. Things a 25 year old woman was "supposed" to be doing. Getting coffee and just reading a book, going for late night drinks with friends, or just having the time to get a job. I slowly was realizing that I can be a "mom" and still be my own person at the same time. My confidence was growing. I was figuring out what I truly liked and didn't like about everything. It was scary and unfamiliar but it felt good.

A year after Sam and I separated, I started dating. I had been through a year of horrible emotions and painful healing, and I felt like I was ready to see what was out there. I went on several dates, spent a good few weeks with a few of them, but it never felt right. I was able to see that they weren't the one for me because I had confidence in myself. Finally.

Fast forward to today, July 2015. I am in a serious relationship with a man who has not only accepted my flaws and backstory, but has also accepted my children.  Its quite odd to think of peoples journeys and how we all have very different ones and learn different things from each one. I made a lot of poor choices but I regret none of them. Some of them are terribly painful and I still get emotional talking about them. Other's weren't so bad, but taught me a great deal. Through the last two years,  I have discovered who I am. I am no longer that insecure girl. I am Karissa. Part of me is a mother. Part of me is a florist by trade. Part of me really loves to sing. Part of me is intelligent and creative and bursting with love for myself as well as others. I've learned to not care when things don't work out. I've learned to not care when people don't like me. I've learned to KEEP FUCKING TRYING. I've also learned that there is a person out there for everyone. That person will literally love all of your quirks and personality flaws, just as much as they love your body and the way you make them feel. I have finally found that. But only because I was ready. So here's to life. Mine has sucked really bad at times, but I am still standing. I hope that through your struggles and let downs, you know that you are beautiful, strong, intelligent and worthy of the perfect life for you. Don't be afraid to have it all. Don't underestimate your worth. You can be a mom and a baker and a model and a girlfriend and a kick ass whatever the hell you want to be...all at the same time. You just have to be confident enough to do it.

-Karissa

&nbsp;

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

		<title>How To: Fly with Ease</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-fly-with-ease/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 24 Jul 2015 17:12:49 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[diana-chen]]></dc:creator>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[&nbsp;

It’s summer and many of you are traveling, vacationing, or studying abroad (leaving some <i>other</i> people very jealous as they do summer school).  However, while destinations are always full of possibility and adventure, the process of getting there, as we all know, is filled with much less possibility…and is not very fun.  Luckily, you have me to help you out!  While I am not <i>yet</i> a successful businesswoman whose job dictates that she travels internationally, I do have many relatives and friends that live abroad, leading me to embark on at least two 12-hour flights per year.  Without further ado, here are some things I learned on how to travel happily, healthily and beautifully.

&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 16px;"><b>FEEL GOOD</b></span>

In the bustle of things at the airport, you may not have time to look for (or even find) healthy alternatives to that morose plane food.  That’s why it’s important to <i>prepare ahead of time</i>.  Whether you are flying domestic or international, take advantage of nuts and fruits. You can bring pretty much any food you want on a plane (customs restrictions happen when you get to the country, so make sure you eat the food you bring!). Note that the 3.4 ounce liquid and gel-like restrictions still applies to food so that means 3.4 oz or less of jams, applesauce, yogurt, peanut butter and the like.*  This is also a great opportunity to make the granola recipe you’ve had your eye on! Not only do these snacks keep you energized, they also keep your immune system intact.  Speaking of immune systems, if you’re embarking on a long flight, load up on vitamin C.  Finally, if your long flight doesn’t come with enough meals to keep you satisfied (and your granola isn’t doing it), a shaker-cup is the solution.  Bring your favorite protein mix in your carry-on (some powders are sold in travel sizes and many companies offer free samples in travel size), pour, shake and enjoy. It is economical to bring a protein shake onto a long flight as it is compact and can be rationed into multiple snacks.  However, I wouldn’t go with any of the mass gaining protein mixes or anything that doesn’t go down smoothly.  You don’t want to feel bloated, especially on a long flight.  And, just a tip, you can never go wrong with the strawberry or chocolate flavors.

&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 16px;"><b>LOOK GOOD</b></span>

Like any other, your day spent on the plane should be kind to your skin.  To cleanse your skin, carry a toner that suits your skin type.  As general rules of thumb, look for toners that are water based and contain rosewater and chamomile extracts, and stay away from those that are scented, contain dyes and are alcohol based.  Unless you have very oily skin, try to avoid sulfates, as products containing these tend to be very drying.  To get this skin care routine through TSA, bring a small towel and your toner in a travel-size (under 3.4 oz) bottle that can be found at drugstores.  On the plane, pour some dots of toner onto your towel and gently pat it into your face.

Now that we feel refreshed, we need to hydrate.  Glycerin and aloe, or any products containing these, are hydrators that are non-comedogenic (e.g. they won’t clog your pores) and feel great on your face.  They are a big YES.  Stay away from ingredients like stearates, oleths and algae extracts.  These are NO’s and high comedogenic.

For moisturizing, I’ve found that facial oils are a great alternative to lotions when traveling.  The most common facial oil is rosehip oil, which can be found affordably at Target.  Most facial oils that are sold in department stores do not need diluting.  However, essential oils like frankincense, geranium and lavender oils do need to be diluted according to their product labels. Because only a few drops will do the trick for your entire face, the bottles already come in travel size!  YES:  rosehip and chamomile extracts.  NO:  algaes and carrageenans.  For your eye cream, look for products containing retinol (for preventing wrinkles).  Finally, if your face turns red and blotchy on the plane like mine does, vitamin E oil (which can be found at Trader Joe’s in travel size) is a quick fix for reducing redness.

&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 16px;"><b>RELAX</b></span>

Now that we feel and look good, we can do the most important thing of all:  relax.  Rest and relaxation are crucial for health and beauty (and being oblivious to that annoying conversation coming from aisle 7 about whether Caitlyn or Kris Jenner is hotter—<i>really?</i>  It’s 2015).  The foremost thing that has kept lengthy plane rides comfortable (and sane) for me has been to wear the right shoes.  A comfortable pair of flats is perfect for going through TSA swiftly and preventing your feet from increasing a shoe size during your flight.  If you’re confident about the smell of your feet, I also highly recommend you just keep your shoes off for as long as you can on the plane.  This will minimize any swelling that might occur and make stretching easy.  Another great help is compression socks.  These socks produce gradients up your calves that equalize the pressure in your legs, reducing swelling.  They can be bought affordably at CVS, Kohl’s, Walmart and Sears.  Unless you have a venous disorder, low compression (8 to 15 mmHg) should do the trick.  If you have the luxury of lying down to sleep, you <i>should not wear these socks</i>.  In the reclining position, there is no pressure difference between your feet and the rest of your legs.

Now, for stretching.  Stretch <i>everywhere</i>.  Stretch in the lobby, stretch in the aisles, stretch in your seat (just make sure you don’t kick anyone).  No, but seriously.  Staying immobile your entire plane ride will inevitably lead to your muscles becoming coiled and then knotted.  So stretch!  My friend who is a certified personal trainer gave me some great tips on stretching and posture.  For stretching, every action has an equal and opposite reaction, so to stretch any part of your body, tense the muscles <i>opposite</i> to the ones you are trying to stretch.  For instance, to stretch your lower back, tense your lower abdominal muscles.  Information on antagonist muscles such as this and on other techniques for promoting muscle health can be found in <i>Framework: Your 7-Step Program for Healthy Muscles, Bones, and Joints</i> by orthopedic surgeon Nicholas DiNubile and author William Patrick.  I highly recommend it!

Finally, as we get ready for hopefully a long rest on the plane, do a posture check.  Your body is like a game of Jenga, meaning that, to be perfectly aligned, there should be no undue pressure put on any part of your body.  Make sure your upper back is straight and aligned with your lower back.  Basically, when you regard your entire body, you have to make sure that all the force from the weight of your body parts is ultimately directed towards the ground, or straight down.  In terms of your back, you can imagine that your upper back is actually balancing on top of your lower back and adjust your posture so that, if your upper and lower back were stacked like two Jenga pieces, your upper back wouldn’t fall off.  On top of that, check that your neck is straight and that your head is <i>not craned forward</i>.  To check, imagine that you are a bobble-head and find the equilibrium where your head rests steadily on your back.  As many people read or watch movies on the plane, it’s important that you do this to avoid any aches and pains in your neck and upper back later.

Welp!  Now that we’re happy, healthy and beautiful, take a breather and relax.  I’ll see you at the destination!

<span style="font-size: 12px;">*These tips apply for United States TSA and may not be applicable to other countries’ transportation security administrations.</span>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Tip Your Server</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-tip-your-server/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 29 Jul 2015 18:07:42 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[alesha-dailey]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=1757</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h4 style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/20091006_tipsz_xlarge.jpeg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1768" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/20091006_tipsz_xlarge.jpeg" alt="20091006_tipsz_xlarge" width="350" height="233" /></a></h4>
<h4 style="text-align: center;">“How much should I tip?”</h4>
It’s a question each of us has faced at some point or another while staring at that empty line on the bottom of our check. Even though it seems like a simple question that deserves a simple answer, the complexity behind it tends to halt numerous patrons in their tracks. We have all seen the news articles condemning poor tippers and applauding great ones, but how do you know where you stand?

Anyone who has worked in the service industry will tell you that dealing with the public (especially when they’re hungry) is never easy. After working as a server for over 8 years, I can honestly say that the industry is not for the faint of heart. It requires a lot of patience, stamina, and is oftentimes far more challenging than rewarding.

In many countries, tips or service charges are automatically included in your bill. Any additional money you decide to leave is 100% voluntary and typically a reward for outstanding service. However, in the United States, due to our sub-standard minimum wage, service workers end up relying largely on the income provided by tips. This creates an interesting phenomenon where, even though tipping is not required, a certain feeling of obligation is often attached to the practice.

In most U.S. states, service workers are paid a lower base salary than other professions (anywhere from $2 to $9 an hour) because it is assumed by the government that tips will make up the difference. Furthermore, the U.S. Government heavily taxes service workers based off of this assumption. When clocking out at the end of the night, servers are required to claim the amount of tips they made on credit cards and then the IRS calculates an average percentage of that to be applied to cash transactions. In short, when you don’t tip or tip poorly, servers are literally paying for you to eat.

So, to help you successfully navigate the murky gray area that is tipping, here are a few tricks of the trade:

<hr />

&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 16px;"><b>Objectively Evaluate Your Service:</b></span>

It is easy to reduce tipping etiquette down to a question of “good service” vs. “bad service”. However, there are SO many things that can factor into this. The key is to take a walk in our slip-resistant shoes and give the benefit of the doubt. Try not to punish your server for things that are out of their control like the quality of the food or the prices. Some things to consider:
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">• Was your order correct?</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">• Was the food hot or cold when brought out?</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">• How attentive was the server to your requests?</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">• Was he/she professional, friendly, courteous?</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">• Were you there on a busy night?</p>
If there was something wrong with the food or the establishment, complain to the manager, leave a bad review on Yelp, and don’t go there again. At least give your server kudos, they are just doing their job and probably dealing with far worse things behind the scenes.

&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 16px;"><b>The 15-20% rule:</b></span>

By now, everyone has probably heard of this rule. It is perfectly acceptable to tip 15% for standard service and 20% for excellent service, but never less than 10%, even for bad service. Why? In many cases, restaurants have a “tip-out” system in which hosts/hostesses, bussers, kitchen staff, and bartenders share in a percentage of the tips that servers pull in. By tipping poorly, you often times end up impacting more than your server alone. There are a variety of<a href="http://www.onlineconversion.com/tip_calculator.htm"> tip calculators</a> and apps to help you determine what you should leave. A good rule of thumb to remember:
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">• 10%= $1 for every $10,</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">• 15%= $1.50 for every $10, and</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">• 20%= $2 for every $10</p>
&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 16px;"><b>At what kind of establishment are you eating?:</b></span>

If you are at a higher-end restaurant with prices to match, tipping 20% or higher reflects that. If you can’t afford to tip that much, then pick somewhere more in your budget. <i>Don’t skimp on the tip just to save money!</i>

For buffet or non-traditional style restaurants, 10-15% is considered adequate since the amount of attention paid to you as a patron is less (the same applies if you are getting take-out or curbside service).

For baristas and bartenders, the generally accepted rule is a $1 or $2 for every drink.

Fast food is the only circumstance where tipping is not considered necessary and, in fact, some establishments forbid their workers from accepting them. However, if you feel they deserve a couple of bucks, it is sure to put a smile on their face. And, that’s totally worth it right?!

&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 16px;"><b>Coupons/Discounts/Tax:</b></span>

Take it from someone who knows, nothing is more cringe inducing to a server than discount coupons! If you are using coupons or receiving a discount on your bill, calculate the tip based on the amount you would have paid without it. <i>You may only be paying for a portion of the meal, but your server is still doing the full amount of work</i><b><i>.</i></b>

There is a lot of confusion out there in regards to sales tax. To clear things up, you should technically be tipping based off of the pre-tax amount. After all, sales taxes vary widely from state to state and ultimately have nothing to do with the service you receive. Plus, the difference in tip between the pre- and post-tax amounts is mere cents.

Ultimately, as long as tipping remains an issue of choice, the power is in your hands! Yes, it’s our job and we chose to do this work, but just remember that we humble servers are humans too. We have good days and bad days and, in a profession that is often undervalued, sometimes something as simple as a generous tip can make all the difference in the world!

&nbsp;

Some further reading:

<span style="text-decoration: underline;"><a href="http://moneyning.com/money-beliefs/tipping-guide-for-good-and-bad-service-from-an-ex-waitress/">Tipping Guide for Good and Bad Service from an Ex-Waitress</a></span> by Jamie Simmerman via <i>Moneyning.com</i>

<span style="text-decoration: underline;"><a href="http://www.nationaljournal.com/next-america/economic-empowerment/why-you-should-always-tip-your-waitress-20140904">Why You Should Always Tip Your Waitress</a></span> by Lucia Graves via <i>National Journal</i>

And for those of you that enjoy a devil’s advocate approach:

<span style="text-decoration: underline;"><a href="http://www.thrillist.com/eat/nation/why-you-should-stop-tipping-reasons-not-to-tip">Why You Should Stop Tipping Your Server</a></span> by Dave Infante via <i>Thrillist</i>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_jetpack_related_posts_cache]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:1:{s:32:"8f6677c9d6b0f903e98ad32ec61f8deb";a:2:{s:7:"expires";i:1460449775;s:7:"payload";a:3:{i:0;a:1:{s:2:"id";i:102;}i:1;a:1:{s:2:"id";i:2654;}i:2;a:1:{s:2:"id";i:3243;}}}}]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Survive Wearing a Cast</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-survive-wearing-a-cast/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 04 Aug 2015 17:13:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Elena Cherine]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=1775</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h5 style="text-align: center;">Let me paint you a picture.</h5>
You are young, ambitious, standing strong atop a mountain of decisions, clad only with your ample intelligence and fervent determination that going slow is for the weak! Sleep is unappealing and you’ve started filling your days with so many tasks and things to do, you can’t think straight. To be a mover and a shaker in this world, you decide, you must progress forward <i>at all costs</i>, carve out your life with the speed and skill of a master sculptor or risk being cast into a pile of old, rotting stone forever. You grin and bear the stress you’ve created for yourself. You reach for the sparkling chisel you will soon use to sculpt your life–but first you take a quick moment to wave to your neighbor, and suddenly whack your beautiful carving hand into a car door window. You’ve rendered your hand broken and in a hot pink cast for 4-6 weeks.  Just like that, your confident plans begin to deteriorate. A month of Netflix seems to be the only way to go.

&nbsp;

[caption id="attachment_1778" align="aligncenter" width="640"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/b63bf44578590620353ecaa2219095950a1a0e9aabb5a0c7e80fe511e8ac0da0.jpg"><img class="wp-image-1778 size-full" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/b63bf44578590620353ecaa2219095950a1a0e9aabb5a0c7e80fe511e8ac0da0.jpg" alt="b63bf44578590620353ecaa2219095950a1a0e9aabb5a0c7e80fe511e8ac0da0" width="640" height="480" /></a> Photo courtesy of author[/caption]

&nbsp;

But not to worry! You too can survive the perils of having a large, restrictive hunk of plaster wrapped around your arm (or whichever bone you have broken). Take it from someone who will use any excuse to watch TV all day – you can wear a cast and still exercise, see friends, and lead a normal life! The sleep deprivation and avid stress cycles aren’t even a possibility now, because you <i>have </i>to step back and take care of yourself. To learn how to move on with your life despite your cast, and move towards recovery, follow these steps:

<b>1. Embrace the cast.</b> It is a part of your body now and the sooner you quit complaining, the easier it will be to accept it. Give yourself a few days to adjust and then move on.

<b>2. Milk it, baby. </b>Having a cast is the perfect conversation starter in any new situation.  Get your cast story into a concise, entertaining form and tell it with charisma. (Or make up a better story – you were rocking a new skateboard trick, or better yet, the President was in danger and you were there to step in). I’ve had great conversations with all kinds of new people because of my cast, and have even gotten discounts at stores because of it!

<b>3. Don’t give up exercising</b>. Depending on where your injury is, there are a lot of YouTube resources.  I’ve done hands-free yoga videos, ab workouts, and cardio workouts. I’ve found that walking is always a good way to go, and even challenged myself to do left-handed frisbee. If cardio is out of the question because you’ve injured your legs, knees, or feet, boost up those arms. Exercising helped me feel empowered despite having a cast, and I wholeheartedly recommend it. Go slow and check in with yourself – you want to help your body get better, not set yourself back by re-injuring your body. Make sure to do some online research or talk to your doctor about how to protect yourself while your body is healing.

<b>4. Your cast shouldn’t stop you from having a good time. </b>Wear it with confidence. Remember, you’re thinking about your cast 100 times more than any random stranger in the club.

<b>5. Take it easy.</b> Your body is working hard to fix your bones! For me, my injury was a wake-up call. Because I was forced to slow down a little, I realized how much I took my body for granted. Use this time to embrace sleep and healthy foods. Reset your habits, and you’ll start appreciating the incredible, unique body that belongs only to you.

<b>6. Remember this is only temporary.</b> The days might seem slow sometimes, but overall, the time goes by fast.

&nbsp;

There will always be time to sculpt your life and work hard to become the person you want to be. Treat yourself kindly and work on making your body as healthy as possible. It’s the only one you’ve got!

&nbsp;

Picture: https://41.media.tumblr.com/7bb5f51f822fde415ad41a85a46ad91b/tumblr_mvl3p8FsTu1rzzrmvo1_500.jpg

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Change Your Car&#039;s Air Filter</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-change-your-cars-air-filter/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 07 Aug 2015 10:35:40 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[alex-regalado]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=1788</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h6 style="text-align: center;">I think it’s happened to everyone.</h6>
&nbsp;

You go to the mechanic for something routine, and they just happen to find that something else is wrong. For me, it was my car’s air filter. They told me it was urgent that I replace it, and it would cost another $60. Knowing nothing about car maintenance, I reluctantly agreed and went on my way.

Later, I spoke to a mechanic friend about the situation. He told me that sometimes mechanics will lie about the cleanliness of your filter or even show you a different and much dirtier air filter just to convince you to change yours. This made me angry, especially since my friend taught me just how easy it was to check and change your own air filter. I hope this guide will save you some extra cash next time you stop by the mechanic!

Your air filter can be found in a flat black box under the hood of your car.

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/air-filter-1.jpg"><img class=" aligncenter wp-image-1789 size-large" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/air-filter-1-1024x683.jpg" alt="air filter 1" width="615" height="410" /></a>

&nbsp;

To open, find the tension clips surrounding the box. In some cars they are hidden, so you might have to search a bit. To release, press down and away on the extended piece until it opens.

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/air-filter-2.jpg"><img class=" aligncenter wp-image-1790 size-large" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/air-filter-2-1024x683.jpg" alt="air filter 2" width="615" height="410" /></a>

&nbsp;

The look of the air filter varies depending on the car. In the car featured in this article, the filter was cylindrical and made of cloth. In most cars, it will be square, flat, and made of paper. So the first thing to do is look at your air filter. You can see below, the orange one is dirty and should be changed. The pink one is fairly clean and will be its replacement.

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/air-filter-3.jpg"><img class=" aligncenter wp-image-1791 size-large" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/air-filter-3-1024x683.jpg" alt="air filter 3" width="615" height="410" /></a>

You can find out what type of air filter your car needs by looking in your manual, searching online for your make and model, or driving to an auto parts store. It’s important to mention that you should never drive without an air filter installed, so drive to the auto store first, then remove your filter and show it to them so that they can provide you with a new one to purchase or tell you the model number so that you can order one yourself.

The average car should have its air filter checked every 50,000 miles. While you can purchase a cloth air filter and clean it yourself, it is NOT recommended. If you don’t fully dry the filter, the water could get inside your engine and ruin it. So the easiest thing is to buy a fairly cheap paper filter each time. Remember, that an air filter keeps dirt, dust, and rocks out of your engine, so if it looks like it’s filled with dirt and won’t be able to block out any more, then you should change it.

Most filters lay flat inside the black box that is connected to the engine via a black tube. Your filter should be very easy to remove and replace once you try it yourself. Remember to attach the tension clips after you are finished.

See how easy that was?? There’s no need to have anyone else change your air filter again. Hope this helped!

XOXO, Alex]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Edit a PDF</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-edit-a-pdf/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 14 Aug 2015 12:14:11 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[CAITLYN]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=1800</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[
<p>Growing up, I always thought I was a pretty tech-savvy lady. In elementary school, I was that girl who spent way too many hours creating custom Xanga theme templates** and making mean<b> </b>Powerpoint presentations. <br /><br /><i>(**No, seriously, being the best at Powerpoint was this very weird obsession for prepubescent me. So was baring my soul on Xanga. Good times.)</i></p>
<p>For some unknown reason, baby me circa 2001 decided we didn’t need to keep up with new programs, and basically tapped out of learning any new computer skills from then on. I skated by in college learning only what I really, REALLY had to – but after starting my very first ‘big-girl’ job, I learned quickly that an early 2000s computer skillset was no longer going to cut it. <br /><br />It was time to embrace change and get with technology already.<br /><br />One of my first administrative tasks was to edit a PDF file with new language and images. For whatever reason, I had always viewed PDF’s as the “do not touch - final version” of a document. I was convinced I would have to remake the document from scratch on Word and save again as a new PDF, and first day panic set in. With a little Google searching and frantic texting to some older work friends, I learned two magical ways to edit PDFs directly.</p>
<p>If you have not yet seen the PDF light, allow me to rock your world:</p>
<h6><br /><strong>1) You can edit your PDF directly using Adobe Acrobat.</strong></h6>
<p><b>Advantage: </b>With practice, Adobe Acrobat is incredibly easy to use and gives you full control to edit the document as you wish. It allows you to add new PDF pages before and after your document, and merge two PDFs into one.</p>
<p><b>Disadvantage: </b>Purchasing Adobe Acrobat may be cost-prohibitive to some, especially for those with only one off projects.</p>
<p><b>Cost:</b> You can purchase Adobe acrobat <a href="http://www.adobe.com/products/acrobat/pricing.html?sdid=KARFP&amp;skwcid=AL!3085!3!33670697302!e!!g!!adobe%20acrobat&amp;ef_id=VCrdnQAAAcXppMhP:20150402185246:s">from their website</a> for U.S. $14.99 / month or for a flat $449.00. You can also find the program at most office supply chain stores.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h6><strong>2) You can convert the PDF to an editable Word document online.</strong></h6>
<p><strong>Advantage: </strong>Free!</p>
<p><b>Disadvantage:</b> From my experience, these programs never seems to reformat the document correctly and I spend a little extra time fixing the layout.<br />Some different sites also include watermarks on your converted document or have restrictions for how many pages you are allowed to convert.</p>
<p>Here are a few online converters I have used with mixed results:</p>
<p><a href="http://unipdf.com">http://unipdf.com</a></p>
<p><a href="http://smallpdf.com/pdf-to-word">http://smallpdf.com/pdf-to-word</a></p>
<p><a href="http://pdf2doc.com">http://pdf2doc.com</a></p>
<h3 style="text-align: center;">Steps to doctor your PDF</h3>
<hr />
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h6 style="text-align: center;"><strong>HOW-TO: EDIT EXISTING TEXT</strong></h6>
<p>1. Open your PDF document</p>
<p>2.Select <strong>"Edit"</strong>  on the upper toolbar<br /><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1894" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/1.jpg" alt="1" width="468" height="341" /></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>3. Select <strong>"Edit Text &amp; Images"</strong> from the dropdown menu<br /><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/2.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1885" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/2.jpg" alt="2" width="435" height="313" /></a></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>4. On the right toolbar, select <strong>"Edit Text &amp; Images"</strong><br /><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/3.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1886" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/3.jpg" alt="3" width="468" height="255" /></a></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>5. Highlight text you are interested in editing and make changes as needed.<br /><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/4.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1887" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/4.jpg" alt="4" width="468" height="265" /></a></p>
<hr />
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h6 style="text-align: center;"><strong>HOW-TO: ADD TEXT</strong></h6>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>6. Follow <strong>steps 1-3</strong> above, then select <strong>"Add text"</strong> on the right toolbar<br /><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/5.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1888" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/5.jpg" alt="5" width="468" height="267" /></a></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>7. Click where on the document you would like your new text<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/6.jpg"><br /><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1889" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/6.jpg" alt="6" width="468" height="260" /></a></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>8. Type your new text in the text box<br /><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/7.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1890" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/7.jpg" alt="7" width="468" height="265" /></a></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<hr />
<h6 style="text-align: center;"><strong>HOW-TO: ADD AN IMAGE</strong><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/8.jpg"><br /></a></h6>
<p>9. Follow steps 1-3, then select <strong>"Add Image"</strong> on the right toolbar<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/8.jpg"><br /><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1891" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/8.jpg" alt="8" width="468" height="267" /></a></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>10. Find your image in your files (one with you and pizza is recommended)<br /><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/9.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1892" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/9.jpg" alt="9" width="468" height="261" /></a></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/10.jpg"><br /></a>11. Place photo where you would like &amp; <strong>voila</strong>!!<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/10.jpg"><br /><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1893" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/10.jpg" alt="10" width="468" height="257" /></a></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<hr />
<p>Thanks to these two wonderful methods, editing a PDF is easy and quick! If your budget permits, I suggest downloading Adobe Acrobat to meet your editing needs, but don’t be afraid to use the online converters either. It takes some practice to get the processes down, so keep at it! In time, you too will be a PDF master!</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Do you know of another tool to edit PDF’s? Let us know in the comments!</p>
]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Understand Compound Interest</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-understand-compound-interest/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 10 Aug 2015 15:54:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[valentia-angelin]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=1811</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[
<p><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/compound_interest.png"><img class=" size-full wp-image-1822 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/compound_interest.png" alt="compound_interest" width="600" height="400" /></a></p>
<p><b></b>Investing can be a broad and scary topic, especially when you have no previous experience with it. I found investment VERY daunting at first, but after studying Economics at UCLA, I realized it’s a lot simpler when you tackle it piece by piece rather than as a whole. One important concept I think everybody should know about is compound interest. Yes there is some degree of math involved (sigh) but it’s nothing you can’t handle!</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h6><b>So let’s take a step back: what is investing exactly?</b></h6>
<p>Investing is the act of putting your money into something that will generate even more money. You most likely have heard of the stock market, which in the US is currently the most popular method of investing. However, investing is not just limited to stocks. There are many investment vehicles out there, like mutual funds, bonds, options, real estate, commodities, and so on.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h6><b>That makes sense; but why should I invest?</b></h6>
<p>It’s fairly simple. Let’s say you have $1,000 in your savings account. Imagine you’ve set aside this money for emergencies or for your retirement (yes, you need to start this early!). However, an average savings account only gives you about 0.03% return each year. That gives you about 30 cents on your $1,000. Sounds miserable, right?</p>
<p>Investing can change that. Let’s say you invest your $1,000 in a stock instead. This stock increased in price by 10% in 2014. So instead of the 30 cents return from your savings account, you get $100 instead! Basically, investing typically generates higher returns than a passive savings account.</p>
<p>If you think that’s exciting, it’s just beginning.  Compound interest will blow your mind.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h6><b>Okay to the good stuff: what is compound interest?</b></h6>
<p>You might have recalled doing something called compound interest in algebra, but did you know that it’s one of the biggest reasons why investing is so profitable? So continuing the above example, now you have $1,100 in your pocket after letting it increase in value through the stock you invested in. Pretty sweet. However, most investors do not stop investing after a year. Many invest throughout their entire lives, or at least until they feel like they can retire comfortably.</p>
<p>So a rational investor would take the $1,100 you have and reinvest it. What does that mean? That basically means you continue putting whatever you earn in the stock. If in 2015 the stock increases by 10%, it will add 10% on top of your 2014 earnings, giving you a total of $1,210! Basically, it’s interest upon interest. This will continue indefinitely as long as your stock price continues to increase.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h6><b>That sounds too good to be true though. Is there any catch to investing?</b></h6>
<p>Of course there is. For one, a stock might not always increase in price. Sometimes, it might decrease, like what happened in the 2008 recession. Sometimes a company goes bankrupt. There are many ways in which a stock price can go, but if you have done your research you can learn how to spot the good investments from the bad ones.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h6><b>How can I get started?</b></h6>
<p>First, you should ask yourself what your risk tolerance is. That is, are you willing to undertake riskier investments, which often come with higher returns, or do you prefer lower but safer investments? Most financial planners suggest young people who are in college or still early in their careers undertake more risks, simply because you have a lot more years to “recover”. When you are older, you might have more financial responsibilities like a mortgage, supporting a family, etc, but when you are younger, you are less likely to be burdened by such financial responsibilities. However, your risk tolerance is definitely a personal choice!</p>
<p>Second, you should begin to set aside your money for investing. You should create a budget and see how much you can spare each month (or even year) for investing. This is a good habit to practice anyway, since you learn to set aside part of your disposable income.</p>
<p>Lastly, educate yourself about the investment options out there. Here at TWIGG How-To, we will try to introduce you to as many investment choices as possible, but you will still have to read up on your own to see which option works best for you. There are many books and articles online that would definitely help you get started, some of which are listed at the end of this article.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">So there you have it – compound interest 101! Hopefully you gained more knowledge about investing and can now participate in dinner party conversations about y’know, the stock market and all that jazz. Stay tuned for the next article on setting up your own investing account! </span></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Great websites to start your investing journey:</span></p>
<p><a href="http://www.nasdaq.com/investing/getting-started-in-stocks.aspx"><span style="font-weight: 400;">http://www.nasdaq.com/investing/getting-started-in-stocks.aspx</span></a></p>
<p><a href="http://www.investopedia.com/university/beginner/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">http://www.investopedia.com/university/beginner/</span></a></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Header Image from grabbingsand.tumblr</p>
<p>Article Image from pennybuilt.com</p>
]]></content:encoded>
