	<item>
		<title>How To: Edit Video Thoughtfully</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-edit-video-thoughtfully/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 23 Aug 2015 19:15:48 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[alex-regalado]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=1902</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>Hey, it’s Alex the Media Producer for TWIGG How-To! I’m responsible for shooting and editing all the wonderful videos, and I work as a freelance editor in my spare time. I’ve been editing for about four years now, but even I still have A LOT more to learn. No one can <em>really</em> be an editing expert because there will always be new software and techniques to learn. However, <span style="text-decoration: underline;">anyone</span> can edit video.</p><p>This article is not going to teach you how to “cut” and “paste” a clip in your “sequence.” Those are technical terms and are best learned through practice (and by watching online video guides <a href="http://www.lynda.com/Video-Editing-training-tutorials/82-0.html">here</a>). I wanted to share some techniques on my editing <strong>process</strong> so that once you know the basics, you can actually become a great editor. It’s easy to collect bad habits (believe me, I did) that will negatively affect your project overall, so here are some tips on forging an editing process that will lead you to success.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><h6>What the heck do I mean by "process?"</h6><hr /><p>Great question. For me, the editing process consists of all the steps taken to create a video. How are you organizing your footage? How many sequences will you use? All of this will affect the final product, and if you take more steps in advance, you will save yourself a lot of time and stress at the end of the day.</p><p><b><i>Disclosure:</i></b></p><p>I mainly use Adobe Premiere to edit my videos, but some of the concepts will resonate throughout all editing softwares. The examples I use consist of multiple days and interviews, making the video a little more complicated; however, these strategies will still work with a simple video.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><h6>Edit so anyone can pick up where you left off.</h6><hr /><p>Throughout my years I’ve learned that a good editor will work on a project in a way that would allow <b>any</b> other person to open the project and know exactly what is going on. Even if you are the only person editing right now, you might be the assistant editor or work with other people on a video project one day in the future. It’s good to get in the habit RIGHT NOW. Trust me.</p><p>How do you do that? Easy.</p><ul><li><span style="color: #ff0000;">LABEL EVERYTHING.</span> Honestly, this can be a pain but if you do it as you go, it doesn’t take up much time. For example, if you need to change some text on your screen later on, you don’t have to open up each text file to figure out which one you need.</li></ul><p><img class="  wp-image-1914 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/Screen-Shot-2015-08-12-at-11.26.22-AM-300x121.png" alt="Screen Shot 2015-08-12 at 11.26.22 AM" width="449" height="181" /><i></i></p><p><i><span style="font-weight: 400;"><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/Screen-Shot-2015-08-12-at-11.26.22-AM.png">Above is my project bin, and you can see I have labeled the day of shooting with the date and name of the organization. I also separated the audio and video files, and then named each file inside those folders. Now it’s very easy to go back in and find an interview clip.</a></span></i></p><p>&nbsp;</p><ul><li><span style="color: #ff0000;">FOLLOW NAMING/LABELING PROTOCOLS.</span> Consistency is key to an outsider understanding your work!</li></ul><p><i>Quick overview of some terms: </i><b><i>b-roll </i></b><i>just means shots of trees, or people walking- we don’t use the audio, but we’ll put those over our important interview shots. </i><b><i>Cutaways</i></b><i> are like b-roll, but don’t move or have action - so stills of a sign or the exterior of a building, for example. </i><b><i>Verite </i></b><i>is a type of filmmaking in which the camera follows and observes the subject like a fly on a wall.</i></p><p>If I have three days of shooting, and each day has an interview, b-roll, and cutaways, then I will organize each day the same way: one folder for interviews, one folder for b-roll, and one folder for cutaways. This makes it very easy to find footage later on. This obviously changes depending on what type of shots you filmed.</p><p><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/Screen-Shot-2015-08-12-at-11.31.50-AM.png"><img class="  wp-image-1918 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/Screen-Shot-2015-08-12-at-11.31.50-AM-300x48.png" alt="Screen Shot 2015-08-12 at 11.31.50 AM" width="431" height="69" /></a></p><p><i><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/Screen-Shot-2015-08-12-at-11.31.50-AM.png">For both subjects I divided the sequences up by “interview” and “verite,” and followed the same protocol for each person I filmed. A new editor would be able to understand that there were two types of situations the subject was in: one being an interview and the other verite.</a></i></p><p>&nbsp;</p><ul><li><span style="color: #ff0000;">STAY REALLY ORGANIZED.</span> The more you break things down, the easier it is to find something. With so much footage, it’s easy to get lost! But in my project<b>,</b> I’ve separated the original footage, the sequences where I’ve begun to edit clips together, and even the different types of sequences. Really take advantage of the bins (or folders). It makes everything look nice and pretty, rather than a hot mess of files.</li></ul><p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/Screen-Shot-2015-08-12-at-11.38.35-AM.png"><img class="alignnone  wp-image-1926" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/Screen-Shot-2015-08-12-at-11.38.35-AM-300x115.png" alt="Screen Shot 2015-08-12 at 11.38.35 AM" width="441" height="169" /></a></p><p>Here is an unorganized project so you can see the difference:</p><p><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/Screen-Shot-2015-08-12-at-11.39.33-AM.png"><img class="  wp-image-1927 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/Screen-Shot-2015-08-12-at-11.39.33-AM-300x210.png" alt="Screen Shot 2015-08-12 at 11.39.33 AM" width="364" height="255" /></a></p><p><i><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/Screen-Shot-2015-08-12-at-11.39.33-AM.png">It’s embarrassing to admit that this is my project, but it is. In all honesty, I can navigate through this mess and figure out what everything is - so yes you can totally edit this way if you wish, but it would take another person a really long time to figure out what everything is if they opened up this project file and had to make a change.</a> </i></p><p>&nbsp;</p><ul><li><span style="color: #ff0000;">MAKE SURE YOUR FOOTAGE IS LINKED TO YOUR SOURCE FOLDER.</span> When you create a project, you have to import your footage (I’m going to get a little technical here). You choose where that footage comes from. If you edit on your laptop and the footage is saved on your laptop, then every time you open up the project it will automatically link to your footage. However, if you are editing from your laptop and import footage into your project from a portable hard drive, that is where it will link to. Therefore, if you don’t have that hard drive and try to open up the project, it will tell you that your files are missing, and ask you to link everything up. This can happen even if your footage is also on your laptop, but bottom line is if you import footage from one folder, and then end up moving that footage, your project won’t be able to find it and will force you to relink everything.</li></ul><p>This is VERY annoying and sometimes impossible for an outside editor to do, so make sure you keep your footage in one place!</p><p>&nbsp;</p><h6>Help Yourself and take the extra steps.</h6><hr /><p>When I first learned how to edit, I would start a rough cut right away. I have now learned that this is a bad idea and will not give you the best video you can possibly make, especially if you have a lot of different footage. Let’s quickly run through the steps I learned in an editing course:</p><p><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/Screen-Shot-2015-08-12-at-11.46.50-AM.png"><img class="  wp-image-1934 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/Screen-Shot-2015-08-12-at-11.46.50-AM-300x183.png" alt="Screen Shot 2015-08-12 at 11.46.50 AM" width="420" height="256" /></a></p><p>This is meant for an actual full length feature film, but I more or less do the exact same thing when editing a five minute video! Now let’s break it down more in depth, using this example: a five minute video telling the story of three female activists and the power of youth organizing. For each girl we filmed at least one interview, followed their activism "verite" style, and filmed b-roll of locations where they live and work.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><ul><li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="color: #ff00ff;">Organization</span></li></ul><p>As you get footage (it may not happen all at one time if you are filming multiple days) you should organize it into bins in whatever system works best.</p><p>For my example, I will have one bin that is just for that subject. Let’s call her Jocelyn. Inside that bin, I will make a bin for audio and another bin for video, because we filmed them separately. I will do the same for each subject, following a labeling protocol for the bins.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><ul><li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="color: #ff00ff;">Marking &amp; Labeling</span></li></ul><p>Once everything is organized, you should watch or scrub through (quickly look at a clip without watching it in its entirety.) For individual short clips, I label them to indicate whatever they are. One example would be “Jocelyn Eating.” Now if I need a clip of her eating, I can easy find it instead of looking through rows of clips called "MOV_148798."</p><p>For longer clips that have dialogue or multiple activities, like interviews, I mark them up. It’s basically like adding a comment, and lets me describe what is happening and for how long. It looks like this:</p><p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/Screen-Shot-2015-08-12-at-11.49.48-AM.png"><img class="alignnone  wp-image-1937" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/Screen-Shot-2015-08-12-at-11.49.48-AM-300x93.png" alt="Screen Shot 2015-08-12 at 11.49.48 AM" width="429" height="133" /></a></p><p style="text-align: center;"><i><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/Screen-Shot-2015-08-12-at-11.49.48-AM.png">When Jocelyn talks about her club, I used a marker to signify the start and end point. That way if I’m looking specifically for that moment, I can find it more easily.</a> </i></p><p>You can choose to be more detailed, less detailed, whatever. But if you have an hour long interview and want to find one specific story she told, it would take you a long time. Since you should be watching all your footage anyways, it makes sense to take an extra second and mark what is happening as you watch.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><ul><li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="color: #ff00ff;">String Outs</span></li></ul><p>After all your footage is labeled and your interviews are marked up, you can start to make “string outs.” You basically string out the best parts onto a sequence, and cut out the stuff you don’t need.</p><p>The important thing to remember during this step, is that less is NOT more. You should add ANYTHING that is considered usable to your string out, but you can organize it a bit more. For example in this project we found three central themes: their struggle, the work that they do, and the power of youth activism. As I’m stringing out all the valuable interview footage from Jocelyn, it might be a good idea to separate it by topic. I’ll lay out any clips of her talking about her struggle on the left, anything talking about the works she does in the middle, and anything about the power of youth on the right.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><ul><li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="color: #ff00ff;">Assembly</span></li></ul><p>So now that everything is strung out and organized by topic, can we do a rough cut?? Depending on how much footage you have, the answer might be no.</p><p>Specifically because I have three separate stories from three individuals, I decided to lay out each story arc individually. So I made a Jocelyn assembly that in itself could be its own video.</p><p>Your assembly in general should be a skeleton of the project, including everything (and more) that you would want to include, and in order. Again, MORE IS MORE. This is not the time to cut down drastically, but you probably won’t include every clip from your string out.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><ul><li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="color: #ff00ff;">Rough Cut</span></li></ul><p>Now that I have three separate assemblies of all three of my subjects, each with all relevant clips and in the order I want my video to be, I can start my rough cut.</p><p>This is when I can start mixing my stories together, adding b-roll or extra footage on top, and creating a real piece. The focus should be finalizing the story and the audio; worry about the visuals later.</p><p>And one more time: <i>more is more</i>. You usually send a rough cut to someone, like a client or even a friend, for notes, and they can help you decide what you can get rid of.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><ul><li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="color: #ff00ff;">Fine Cut</span></li></ul><p>So you’ve gotten notes back, and you can make any necessary changes. Once you’ve finalized the clips and audio, you can work on the visuals. Color correct and add music and text or graphics. Start to add the final touches, and once you think you’re done, send it back one more time for notes.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><ul><li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="color: #ff00ff;">Final Cut</span></li></ul><p>You’ve reached the end. You’ve gotten your second set of notes, and at this point you should be making small changes and making sure everything looks perfect!<br /><br />Through each of these steps we’ve been gradually getting rid of footage little by little instead of starting with a lot and immediately cutting it down to the final product. This will ensure that you don’t lose out on anything valuable, and that you have a coherent and well-rounded story!</p><p>&nbsp;</p><h6>Final Notes</h6><hr /><p>You won’t have to go this in-depth for every project, but it’s a good idea to train yourself to take these steps now so that you’re prepared and can handle a complicated edit in the future. Take advantage of what your editing software has to offer. I'm loving Premiere's ability to label footage different colors, because it makes it so easy to organize! As an assistant editor, I only get to the assembly stage for my work projects before it gets handed off to another editor, which is again why you would want any editor to be able to pick up where you left off.</p><p>Always always <b>always </b>set up an auto save! Adobe Premiere does it automatically, but I think for Final Cut you can set it up. Also, make sure you keep a copy of all your original footage somewhere else (like another computer or a portable hard drive). That way if something happens to your computer or project, you can at least start over. It’s even a good idea to backup your project file somewhere else if the video is REALLY important.</p><p>I hope this helps you avoid some mistakes I made! If you ever have questions on this, or even want to share some tips, please send me an email at alex@twigghowto.com. Good luck editing!</p><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">XOXO Alex</span></p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Get Comfortable with Public Speaking</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-public-speaking/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 15 Aug 2015 16:09:59 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Rachel Wiegardt-Egel]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=1961</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Get anxious about public speaking? You’re not alone. Studies have shown that public speaking is among America’s top fears</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">—</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">along with spiders, snakes, clowns, and even death. That stomach-churning sensation that happens right before you address a crowd? You’re not alone. Those sweaty palms? You’re not alone. That doubt that you should even be there, speaking about whatever topic you’re supposed to be discussing? You’re definitely not alone. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">We’ve all been there. Back in high school, I was terrified of speaking in public. I would feel like I was on the verge of a panic attack whenever we had to give speeches in class. Now, I work in theater, and it’s a regular part of my job to get onstage and talk to an audience (sometimes hundreds of people) about the show they’re about to see. And I get the occasional flutter of butterflies in my stomach, but the terror is gone. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Fear of public speaking is real, and it’s hard to deal with. But there’s no reason why fear should stand in the way of you sharing your unique wisdom and awesomeness with the world. There are practical steps you can take that will make a huge difference. Here are some that I’ve learned along the way!</span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">First of all, </span><b>be prepared</b><span style="font-weight: 400;">. The more prepared you are, the better you’ll be able to handle any curveballs that may come your way. </span>
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Think about the progression of your speech ahead of time. How will you open? What are your main points? How will you wrap it up? If it helps, write out what you want to say, in an outline or full sentences – whatever works for you. </span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Say it out loud, A LOT</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">—</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">to friends, to the mirror, while you’re cooking dinner, while you pace around your room. </span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Pick out your outfit beforehand, something professional but comfortable. </span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">If you’re not familiar with the space you’ll be speaking in, check it out</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">—</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">where to enter and exit, where to stash any props or visual aids, the size of the place, etc. </span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Prepare note cards to bring with you, just in case you find yourself needing a prompt.</span></li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

<b>Start strong</b><span style="font-weight: 400;">. Take your time as you enter the space. Don’t feel the need to launch into talking as you’re walking in. You’re going to share something amazing, so there’s no reason to make your body language apologetic. Instead, hold your head up high, walk with confidence, get to your mark, breathe in and out. Then start. </span>
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Be welcoming and make eye contact with individual listeners rather than sweeping over everybody</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">. </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">Establish that you’re present and that you’re all in the same room.</span></li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

<b>Keep it conversational.</b><span style="font-weight: 400;"> You, of course, are incredibly prepared, so try your best to avoid reading your speech word for word. </span>
<ul>
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">Speak SLOWLY. Your heart rate will speed up and you’ll feel like you’re delivering the speech at the speed of a sloth. You’re actually probably hurtling along much faster than you think, so counteract this by speaking much more slowly than you think is appropriate. (Timing yourself ahead of time can also be helpful, so you can keep on track.) </span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Do your best to control impulses like touching your hair or rocking back and forth. Pause when you need to instead of using filler words like “um” or “uh.” </span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Most importantly, remember that the more you can own the material</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">—</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">and even make it feel casual and personal</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">—</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">the more the audience will trust your expertise. Make sure you’re invested in what you’re saying: you’re more likely to keep the audience’s attention that way.</span></li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

<b>Be a considerate host of the conversation. </b><span style="font-weight: 400;">Say thank you when you’re done. And if you’re taking questions at any point, repeat each question</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">—</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">it’ll buy you time to gather your thoughts and ensure that everyone can hear.</span>

&nbsp;

<b>Don’t sweat the small stuff. </b><span style="font-weight: 400;">Nobody’s perfect. You’ll probably make a mistake or two</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">—</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">you could get a little tongue-tied, you might forget that perfectly smooth transition you practiced, you might drop your visual aids. It truly is no big deal. Laugh it off and turn it into an opportunity to be charming. As long as you’ve spoken with passion and hit your main points, no one will remember the hiccups and they’ll all leave mulling over the many brilliant points you’ve raised.  </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">The most important thing is to remember that public speaking takes practice, just like any other skill. You’ll come across very few people who are naturally brilliant public speakers. Don’t shy away from it just because it’s hard! Push yourself to get out of your comfort zone and take advantage of public speaking opportunities: volunteer to lead a presentation in school, ask to run a meeting at work, or sign up for a public speaking practice group like Toastmasters. Soon, it won’t feel nearly as scary--though it’s okay to still get a butterfly in your stomach every now and then. </span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Check out the following sources for more great public speaking tips:</span>

<a href="https://www.toastmasters.org/Resources/Public-Speaking-Tips"><span style="font-weight: 400;">https://www.toastmasters.org/Resources/Public-Speaking-Tips</span></a>

<a href="http://www.inc.com/ss/jeff-haden/20-public-speaking-tips-best-ted-talks"><span style="font-weight: 400;">http://www.inc.com/ss/jeff-haden/20-public-speaking-tips-best-ted-talks</span></a>

&nbsp;

Picture from ibtimes.com]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Minimize Road Trip Sleeping Costs</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-minimize-road-trip-sleeping-costs/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 10 Sep 2015 16:21:14 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jenna-perelman]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=1965</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">When I travel, it’s usually by car. I’ve been going on a lot of road trips these days and picked up some tips along the way. Whether it’s a ten-day drive up the Pacific Coast Highway to Portland and back, or a marathon week-long excursion around New Mexico, camping has been my go-to way to spend the night. It’s much cheaper than a hotel or hostel, and it’s nice to be outside after spending so many hours in a car. Here are some of the things I’ve learned throughout my adventures: </span>

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/10425504_10152705492211835_4350653036634836883_n.jpg"><img class="wp-image-2104 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/10425504_10152705492211835_4350653036634836883_n-150x150.jpg" alt="10425504_10152705492211835_4350653036634836883_n" width="344" height="344" /></a>
<ul style="list-style-type: disc;">
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">Depending on their location, conventional campgrounds with restrooms, showers, and running water can be $10-$20 per vehicle, per night. To avoid this cost, I usually camp far away from designated campgrounds in National Forests or on Bureau of Land Management (BLM) land. Provided you follow some guidelines, these lands are free to camp in. The technical term for this is “dispersed camping.” Find more information </span><a href="http://www.fs.usda.gov/detailfull/fishlake/recreation/?cid=stelprdb5121831"><span style="font-weight: 400;">here</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">. Two big takeaways from the site: a) keep your campground within 150 feet from the nearest road so that you do not disturb the land too much. b) Always, </span><b>ALWAYS</b><span style="font-weight: 400;"> practice “</span><a href="http://www.fs.usda.gov/detailfull/fishlake/recreation/?cid=stelprdb5121850&amp;width=full"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Leave No Trace</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">.”</span></li>
</ul>
&nbsp;
<ul style="list-style-type: disc;">
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">Sleeping pads make camping incredibly more comfortable. On my trip to New Mexico, I spent the first night without a sleeping pad. I was freezing the entire night and woke up with aches and pains from the hard ground. The next day, we stopped in Santa Fe and I picked up a self-inflating sleeping pad for $90 (I have</span><a href="http://www.rei.com/product/829820/therm-a-rest-prolite-sleeping-pad"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> this one</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">). Pads are insulated and keep you off the ground so you’re not as cold. Plus, the inch or so of air provides enough cushion to make sleeping more comfortable. I’m now very attached to my sleeping pad, and you won’t find me on a camping trip without it!</span></li>
</ul>
&nbsp;
<ul style="list-style-type: disc;">
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">It may seem counterintuitive, but the colder it is outside, the </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">fewer</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;"> clothes you should wear when you crawl into your sleeping bag to go to bed. Down and synthetic sleeping bags work by using your own body heat to keep you warm, so no need to bundle up excessively! Avoid bulky sweatshirts and sweatpants and instead opt for long underwear and a hat. Full disclosure: I often sleep naked.</span></li>
</ul>
&nbsp;
<ul style="list-style-type: disc;">
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">If it’s cold out at night (think 20-30°F), fill up a water bottle with hot water and take it in your sleeping bag with you. This accelerates the process of heating up your sleeping bag so you get warmer faster. If you’re at your campsite, you can boil water on a camping stove. But if you’re near a city, you can fill up your bottles at a gas station or restaurant in town; I used this trick when I was camping in the Santa Fe National Forest because we had gone into the city for dinner.</span></li>
</ul>
&nbsp;
<ul style="list-style-type: disc;">
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">Talk to locals! Ask people for suggestions about where to camp. One night after 7 hours of solo driving, I pulled off the freeway in a tiny northern California town and tried to find the campground I had seen online. I drove around for 20 minutes but couldn’t find it. I was so tired that I called some hotels and was considering shelling out $100 for a single room, but in one last attempt, I asked the cashier at the grocery store if he knew of any campgrounds nearby. Sure enough, he listed off two or three suggestions and I ended up camping near a beautiful lagoon for much, much less than any of the hotels. Thanks again Howard!</span></li>
</ul>
&nbsp;
<ul style="list-style-type: disc;">
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">There are a few things I make sure to pack on every camping road trip. Here are my essentials (yours might be different depending on your needs!): a can opener, shovel, toilet paper, headlamp, copious amounts of lip balm, sunscreen, sunglasses, sunhat, water bottle, toothbrush, toothpaste, car charger for my phone, cash and credit card, tent, sleeping pad, sleeping bag, and physical maps (you won’t always have cell service!). And though the next two things are not conventionally “packable,” on every road trip, I bring a </span><b>sense of adventure and open-mindedness</b><span style="font-weight: 400;">. </span></li>
</ul>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">The best part about road trips is that you’re in control. Follow your instincts and go where you want to go. Don’t be tied down by hotel reservations! With the right equipment, dispersed camping is a great, inexpensive way to spend the night on road trips. </span>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Boost Your Productivity On the Go</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-boost-your-productivity-on-the-go/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 24 Aug 2015 17:35:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[krisha-agatep]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=1981</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Consider the amount of time you spend just waiting around or going from one place to the next. All of that downtime spent waiting in line or on public transportation on the way to school could be better spent getting your life on track and knocking things off that to-do list. Luckily, there are tons of apps out there that can make our lives much, much easier and more productive. Here are some tips for using your smartphone to boost your daily productivity when you’re on the go:

<hr />

<b>1) Set up a mobile hotspot.</b> Mobile hotspots allow you to use your cell phone data to create your own wi-fi network. They’re very easy to set up and can definitely come in handy when you need internet access on your laptop or other mobile device right away. However, not all data plans provide this service so <b>be sure to check with your mobile carrier</b>.
<b>2) Choose your favorite productivity app and stick to it.</b> For those of you that like to quickly jot down your thoughts, perhaps <a href="https://evernote.com/">Evernote</a> might be the way to go. Maybe you work best by creating a list of things to do and completing these tasks based on priority. In this case, maybe you’d really like the app, <a href="https://en.todoist.com/">Todoist</a>. My personal favorite is an app called <a href="https://www.wunderlist.com/">Wunderlist</a> that allows you to create multiple lists and add tasks under each list. I like this app because it’s very simple to quickly add in tasks and check them off as soon as they’re done. This app in conjunction with good ol’ <b>Apple Calendar</b> app allow me to see at a glance what tasks I have on hand for each day and how best to prioritize my time. Whichever app tickles your fancy, you’ll only be more productive if you create a system that works for you and stick to it.

<b>3) Download Google Drive</b>, and all of Google’s editing apps including Google Docs, Sheets, and Slides. Need to quickly edit a spreadsheet and send it out to all your classmates but you don’t have access to a computer? Use the Google Sheets app on your phone to edit and share documents on the fly. And with Google Drive on your smartphone, there’s no need to search through old emails or dig through folders on your laptop. You can access any important files you may need no matter where you are.

<b>4) Use Venmo to receive and transfer money.</b> <a href="https://venmo.com/">Venmo</a> allows you to easily transfer and receive money from your friends with a tap of a button. All you need to do is connect the app to a debit card or checking account to start sending money back and forth with ease. The app is free to use with these accounts, but beware that if you use a credit card, you’ll have to pay a small percentage. With Venmo, you’ll never have to spend another 30 minutes after dinner with your friends trying to figure out thebest way to split the bill with 6 different credit cards.

<b>5) Learn a foreign language</b>. Ever wanted to learn a language but never thought you had the time? Now it's entirely possible to learn a language without ever having to step foot in a classroom. Download a language learning app like <a href="https://www.duolingo.com/">Duolingo</a> to learn the basics of any language from Spanish, French, to Chinese or German. The great thing about Duolingo is that each lesson is very short and you can be done even when you have a spare bit of downtime. If you have even more downtime, watch YouTube channels in the language that you’re trying to learn to get used to the speed and flow of that language. If you want to progress much faster, use a language exchange app like <a href="http://www.hellotalk.com/">HelloTalk</a> to take what you've learned and speak or chat online with native speakers of that language. Using these three apps I was able to learn a little French before my trip to France last year and now I can successfully order wine at a French restaurant (<i>je voudrais un verre de vin, s'il vous plaît</i>)!

<b>6) Check your app usage</b> <b>to preserve battery life</b>. Nothing’s worse than walking around with a dead phone all day because you spent 3 hours trying to beat level 63 of Candy Crush. If you have an iPhone, just go to Settings &gt; General &gt; Usage &gt; Battery Usage to see which apps are using the most battery life. If they don’t need to be on, be sure to close them out to keep that productivity going all day long.
<p style="text-align: center;">We all live pretty hectic lifestyles and it sometimes can be very easy for life to get a little ahead of us. But with the just the right tools, we are fully capable of getting stuff done, even on the go.</p>
<p style="text-align: center;">What are your favorite productivity apps? Are there any apps you use daily that you just can’t live with out? Feel free to share with us in the comments below!</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Take Care of a Sunburn</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-take-care-of-a-sunburn/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 20 Aug 2015 01:28:32 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[lauren-montgomery]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=1987</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">I am not a doctor;  I feel that, when discussing medical advice and health-related how-to's, it's probably best to clarify that point up front.  I never went to medical school, failed a bunch of tests in biology, and only know the first line of the Hippocratic Oath.  I am, however, an expert in sunburn aftercare. Despite not having a degree in anything having to do with the human body and all the ways it can get hurt, I have had approximately 872 sunburns in my lifetime, which leads me to consider myself an authority in the field; this is not something I'm particularly proud of, but hey, it's been an adventure. One time I got a sunburn so bad I didn't sleep for three straight days and when I finally fell asleep I had a fever dream involving anthropomorphic menorahs teaching me about classy olive oils and when I woke up I thought my house was on fire. Like I said, adventure.</span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">The first (and perhaps most obvious) thing I should say about sunburns is you should try and avoid them altogether.  Skin cancer, muscle-deep pain, blistering, long-term wrinkling, and short-term itching are waiting for you on the other side, so take all the preventative measures you can when outside.  In short, sunscreen.   </span>

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/SPF-rating.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-medium wp-image-1988" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/SPF-rating-300x170.jpg" alt="SPF-rating" width="300" height="170" /></a>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">(Via </span><a href="http://thebeautyproof.com/spf-ratings/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">The Beauty Proof</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">)</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">When hunting for that perfect sunscreen, <strong>make sure it is broad-spectrum and protects against both UVA and UVB rays</strong>.</span> <span style="font-weight: 400;">While UVB rays cause sunburns, both forms of ultraviolet radiation cause cancer. Apply sunscreen to any skin exposed to the sun, and reapply every couple hours or after getting wet (pool water, salt water, even your own sweat). I mean any exposed skin - I have gotten burned in between my toes and the palms of my hands; nowhere is safe. Don't underestimate the power of shade and protective clothing, particularly hats, since scalp sunburns are, unfortunately, pretty common and make washing your hair hurt like a bitch.</span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you're like me, however, the only preventative measure that really works is staying inside like a hermit allergic to the sun, but we all know that abstinence only education doesn't work. Sooner or later you're going to do it, and it's best to understand the consequences and how to deal with those consequences if and when they arise. After all, we're all adults here.  Let's talk about sunburns. (What did you think I was going to say?)</span>

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/kids-sunburn_zps80635d94.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-medium wp-image-1989" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/kids-sunburn_zps80635d94-300x225.jpg" alt="kids-sunburn_zps80635d94" width="300" height="225" /></a>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">(Photo via </span><a href="http://hotmamabodywrap.com/natural-remedy-for-sunburn/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Hot Mama</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">)</span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">At first, you might not even notice that you indeed have a sunburn. Sometimes it's easy to see the first stages of a sunburn when you’re actually out in the sun, with a slight darkening or "pinkening" (yes, that is a word I just made up for this article) of the skin, but it can be hard to gauge what will and what won't become a sunburn. I've found that it often isn't until about 30 minutes to a few hours after being out of direct sunlight that a sunburn shows its full visible potential. If you suspect that your time outside might result in some burns, <strong>my advice is to take a cool to lukewarm shower as soon as possible</strong>; you want to wash off the sweat and sunscreen before it gets too painful to even consider anything touching your skin, even harmless droplets of water.  This will also give you a clean surface to which you can apply any topical agents.</span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Sunburns are a tragic cocktail of pain and itching, two unfortunate ordeals on the spectrum of human experience that, when combined, can really lay you out.  Once you get a sunburn, it's best to take immediate action for these two short-term side effects.  I rely heavily on aloe vera, which is cheap and natural, can be found at any drugstore, and can be applied to the skin as often as you like.  </span><b>Aloe vera soothes the burn and adds moisture back into your skin</b><span style="font-weight: 400;">; it can even prevent the pain, itching, and peeling if the sunburn is mild enough.   </span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">In more serious cases, I've found that </span>ibuprofen and cortisone cream<span style="font-weight: 400;"> make a pretty great team.  Oral drugs like Motrin and Advil are anti-inflammatories, so they will combat both the pain and the swelling, and topical creams containing cortisol (hydrocortisone, corticosteroids) utilize steroids to reduce inflammation and itching.  </span>Follow all the directions on the packaging when taking NSAIDs (Nonsteroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drugs) and/or applying a cortisone cream.<span style="font-weight: 400;">  </span>Do not use a topical cortisone cream with any oral drugs or medications that also contain cortisone.<b>  </b><span style="font-weight: 400;">You shouldn't rely on these methods for too long, however, as it's not suggested to take ibuprofen for an extended period of time; if you find that you can't deal with your sunburn without taking pills for more than 4 to 5 days, it's probably time to see a doctor (again, not me, since I'm not a doctor).  </span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Once you've taken care of your outsides, remember to take care of your insides.  The Skin Cancer Foundation recommends </span>staying consistently hydrated with water while your burn is fresh, since a burn will draw water away from the rest of your body to the affected tissue.<b>  </b><span style="font-weight: 400;">Don't compound your sunburn with a dose of dehydration!  It's super easy to gingerly walk to the fridge and get the Brita; just don't bump into anything or allow anything to touch your tender, fragile skin along the way.  Drinking some cold water will also help draw the heat from your body.</span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Most sunburns are first degree burns, only affecting the outer layer of skin, but some severe sunburns can reach second and even third degree burn classifications, affecting deeper tissue and creating more complicated problems.  Blistering can be a sign of superficial second degree burns, and should not be popped; no matter how tempting it might be to peel them off, try and let nature take its course. Sunburns can also cause nausea, fatigue, the chills, and fevers, all of which are signs that your burn is relatively severe. </span><b> </b>All sunburns are a medical condition, so when in doubt, see a doctor<span style="font-weight: 400;"> (I hope I don't have to remind you how </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">not</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;"> a doctor I am). </span>


<b>Quick tips to ease a sunburn:</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">- Use a cold compress, such as a towel soaked in cold water, on your sunburn several times a day to draw the heat from your body.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">- Don't use vaseline or petroleum jelly on your burns, especially not on blisters - these products won't let your skin breath properly and will trap all the moisture.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">- Take a bath - you may find it impossible to maintain your normal hygiene routine with water pummeling your burned skin during a shower, so try taking a cool bath instead.  No one ever accused a bath of hurling water at your skin so hard that it stings and makes you want to cry.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">- Don't forget to put sunscreen on your sunburn!  If you go outside while burnt, take extra care to apply sunscreen to your already fragile skin.  </span>

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

Header photo from AMC Network]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Start, Keep, and Protect Good Credit</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-start-keep-and-protect-good-credit/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 27 Aug 2015 00:05:05 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[alexandra-forero]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=1998</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">One day you're going to have your first experience where you truly feel like a financially independent adult - and it will be stressful. You might be applying for your first apartment without roommates or buying your first car without a cosigner or, even more monumental, mortgaging a home. No matter which of these things you are doing, your credit will be a factor. By having a true understanding of credit, building responsible credit habits, and maintaining a healthy credit score you can make financial decisions with a lot more confidence.</span></p><p>&nbsp;</p><h5><b>What is Credit?</b></h5><hr /><p>Credit is money you borrow that you can use to pay for purchases and goods ahead of time. Creditors are the parties that lend you money and they make their profit by way of the interest rates charged on the credit you've used but have not yet paid back in full.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><h5><b>What are Interest Rates?</b></h5><hr /><p>Interest rates, more commonly known as annual percentage rates or APRs in the credit world, are a certain percentage you pay back on top of the credit you owe. Think of APRs as the creditor's service fee. APRs can start as low as 5% and go as high as 30%--the average person is estimated to pay 15%. Creditors determine APRs based on your credit score and the type of credit card you choose.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><h5><b>Types of Credit</b></h5><hr /><p><b>Revolving Credit </b><span style="font-weight: 400;">- This is the most popular and common type of credit, where you're given a limit determined by the creditor, carry a balance, and are expected to make a minimum monthly payment.</span></p><p><b>Charge Cards</b><span style="font-weight: 400;"> - These function like revolving credit but require you to pay the full balance every month. If you're a student this is a good option to explore if you want to build credit while keeping your spending in check.</span></p><p><b>Service Credit</b><span style="font-weight: 400;"> - Your agreements with service providers are all service credits. This ranges from utility payments to cell phone bills to gym memberships. Not all service credits are reported on your credit score.</span></p><p><b>Installment Credit</b><span style="font-weight: 400;"> - With this type of credit you are given a set amount of money and have to pay it back on a schedule for a predetermined amount of time. A few examples of this are car loans and mortgages.</span></p><p>&nbsp;</p><h5><b>Why Do I Need Credit?</b></h5><hr /><p><iframe class="giphy-embed" style="max-width: 100%;" src="//giphy.com/embed/8B9hGl5neRTNK" width="480" height="287" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe></p><p>Maintaining a good credit score will not only help you make big purchases, but it will also help you maintain more consumer power. A creditor is more likely to reduce an interest rate or give more rewards to a customer with good credit. And when it does come to big purchases good credit can mean the difference between having to put down $3,500 or $7,000 on a new car or between a monthly mortgage payment of $2,500 and $1,250.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><h5><b>Choose A First Credit Card You Can Use Long-Term</b></h5><hr /><p>At 21, I got my first credit card from Victoria's Secret. Huge mistake. Why? Because the longevity of your credit is second most important factor in determining our credit score (the first is paying credit back on time) and while I would love to think I'll fit into size 'M' Lace Cheekies forever, the truth is I'll probably stop shopping at good old VS within the next 5 years. This means I will either close my credit card, obliterating my first three years of responsible credit history; or I'll have to find a way to make a purchase on my credit card at VS at least once a year until I die; or I'll have to wait until I have an impressive enough credit score that a slight ding won't set me back too far. None of those options sound like much fun.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">So what card should you open? Unfortunately, there is no single one-size-fits-all "best card." That said, look for a card with specialized benefits crafted to your needs. Many banks and credit unions will offer credit cards with low APRs to students and first-time card holders. Other creditors offer cards through corporations, such as airlines and gas stations, that can be used anywhere but gather rewards specific to the company the card is affiliated with. However, </span><b>beware of "special offers" that offer low APRs initially and/or for a set amount of time</b><span style="font-weight: 400;">. Once the introductory period ends the APR may spike or an expensive annual fee might be introduced. Remember to do your research, and don't be afraid to ask creditors questions. Always keep in mind that there is no such thing as free money and that credit companies profit off of what you don’t know. When applying for credit knowledge is power. </span></p><p><iframe class="giphy-embed" style="max-width: 100%;" src="//giphy.com/embed/fNvXkjC50ywBW" width="480" height="354" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>By the time I had reached senior year of college, I had built up enough good credit that I was able to apply for a high-limit credit card. “Oh good!” I thought. “With a higher credit limit, I have more money to spend!” (This is NOT how credit works and was a bad idea.) So, at the tender age of 21, Bank of America gave me a credit card with a $3,000 credit limit. Two years later I'm still paying for the sangria, late-night nachos, and an outfit or five from Urban Outfitters.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">So how can you avoid over-spending and racking up costly interest charges? First, find a card that has a preset limit or work with your creditor to set a limit that works for you. Secondly, be mindful of your spending and check your limit often. Some creditors reward individuals who make payments on time by increasing credit limits without notice (in my opinion this is a dirty trick) and that can lead to overspending. Finally, never, ever, </span><b>EVER </b><span style="font-weight: 400;">rely on credit as a supplementary income, like I did. It is the fastest way to rack up debt, guilt, and a whole bunch of monthly payments that will ultimately put you at risk of hurting your credit score.</span></p><p>&nbsp;</p><h5><b>Pay Your Bills On Time (Not Early) and In Full (If You Can)</b></h5><hr /><p>A big misconception about maintaining credit is that if you charge a purchase and pay it off the same day you're building credit. False. The truth is that your credit is only updated once a billing period has closed and the due date is reached (which is why missed payments hurt your credit, but more on that later). Another misconception is that if you do not carry a balance on a card from one billing cycle to the next, you will not be building your credit. This misconception fuels the belief that you should not pay your bill in full each month, but this is simply not true! As long as a balance exists, whether it’s five dollars or five hundred dollars, on the closing date of a billing period you can pay the full balance on the due date while still building your credit. Additionally, if you pay the balance in full every month you will be paying the minimum amount of interest rather than compounding interest at a monthly rate on credit used for a single purchase.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">There may come time when you make a big purchase, like a mattress or an airline ticket, and you won't be able to pay off your balance in full.  That's okay. The next best option is to make sure you pay above the minimum payment. A minimum payment is what creditors bill you monthly and you MUST pay; it has either been predetermined or, more often than not, it is dependent on the amount of debt you've accrued with the creditor. Think of a minimum payment like this: the more money you've borrowed from a creditor the more they want to make sure you pay it back so the minimum payment will be adjusted accordingly. Paying above the minimum will not only get you out of debt faster and reduce your minimum payment, it will also reduce the amount of interest being accrued on what you owe.</span></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><b>TWIGG TIP:</b><span style="font-weight: 400;"> You can can find out the closing dates for each of your lines of credit by reading your billing statement or calling your creditor.</span></p><p>&nbsp;</p><h5><b>What Happens If I Miss A Credit Payment?</b></h5><hr /><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Missed payments are reflected on your credit score for 7 years. </span><a href="https://www.creditkarma.com/article/late-payments-affect-credit-score"><span style="font-weight: 400;">SEVEN YEARS</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">. More terrifying? Missed payments on student loans are reflected on your credit score </span><a href="http://www.moneycrashers.com/student-loan-affects-credit-score/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">FOREVER</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">. If you miss a payment the only way to mitigate the negative effects on your credit score is to move forward making timely payments and putting distance between yourself and the date of the missed payment.</span></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Two other possible repercussions of missing a payment are an increased rate or late fees, which in my experience are around $25. </span></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><b>TWIGG TIP:</b><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Enrolling in autopay is a good way to make sure you are making payments on time and some creditors will even give you money back or a reduced APR for enrolling.</span></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Overall, the key to maintaining good credit is understanding what affects your credit and how. If independent research just isn’t your thing or you begin to feel overwhelmed, you can seek the help of an expert or someone you trust. Alternatively, credit unions, crisis centers, and community centers often offer free financial and/or credit workshops for locals, the elderly or low-income groups. Check out this </span><a href="http://womenmoneyandsuccessmag.com/resources/low-income-resources"><span style="font-weight: 400;">link</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> for a list of a few online low-income financial planning resources.</span></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Now get out there, make good choices, and build that credit! <iframe class="giphy-embed" style="max-width: 100%;" src="//giphy.com/embed/fysOWwtuDgwgM" width="480" height="194" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe></span></p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:1:{s:32:"8f6677c9d6b0f903e98ad32ec61f8deb";a:2:{s:7:"expires";i:1460449771;s:7:"payload";a:3:{i:0;a:1:{s:2:"id";i:770;}i:1;a:1:{s:2:"id";i:2021;}i:2;a:1:{s:2:"id";i:744;}}}}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Buy a New Car</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-buy-a-new-car/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 04 Sep 2015 17:06:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Caitlin Cohen]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2021</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h5 style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">So you’ve decided it’s time for a new car. </span></h5>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Maybe your car is old, and those maintenances are starting to add up.  Or you’re tired of that stain on the passenger seat.  You’re older now, more adult, and want a more established vehicle than the one you were driving in high school.  It’s your birthday.  The gas is too expensive.   You want something sportier.  It doesn’t matter why - the point is, it’s </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">time</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;">.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Then what’s the problem?  Dealerships.  Salespeople.  Negotiating.  How do you make sure you get the best deal?</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">As someone who has been selling cars for about two and a half years, I see people of all ages and backgrounds struggle with the easiest way to get a good deal.  A lot of them assume they’re going to get lied to, and they end up making the process a lot harder than it needs to be.  Others don’t do any shopping at all and pay a lot more than they should.  So let me help you make the best deal with the least amount of effort!</span>

&nbsp;
<h6><b style="line-height: 1.5;"> 1. What kind of car do you want?</b></h6>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">This is pretty easy.  What are you looking for in a car?  Is gas an important consideration, or would you rather have horsepower?  Do you need a lot of room or do you want something smaller?  How reliable are the cars you’re looking at?  How comfortable?  How fun?  Compare which car has the most of what you’re looking for using sites such as </span><a href="http://www.edmunds.com/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Edmund’s</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> and </span><a href="http://www.caranddriver.com/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Car &amp; Driver</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">.  </span><b>Figure out what kind of car you want and start from there.</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">As an ongoing example, I’m going to use the time when I helped my mom get her car.  She likes sedans and drives 30,000 miles per year.  She wanted a car that was reliable with good gas mileage.  She decided on the Toyota Camry Hybrid.</span>

&nbsp;
<h6><b> 2. Check your credit.</b></h6>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you’re a first time buyer, your credit will be light.  That doesn’t mean it’s bad.  You can have a 730 credit score with two pieces of credit.  It’s just important to </span><a href="https://www.annualcreditreport.com/index.action"><span style="font-weight: 400;">be aware of what your credit is</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> and </span><a href="https://www.wellsfargo.com/financial-education/credit-management/check-credit-score/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">what it means</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">This home credit score might also be different than your auto credit score.  I don’t know how credit bureaus work (all I know is pay your bills on time and don’t live beyond your means = good credit) but the fact that no one has an exact formula on how to get a perfect score versus merely a very good score is pretty bunk.  Down with the patriarchy, I say.  But on a practical level, it’s just something to factor in when checking your credit score at home versus checking it at the dealership.  </span><a href="https://www.creditkarma.com/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Check your score</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> at home to have an idea, of course, but don’t be surprised if the number for your auto score is a little different – especially if you’ve never bought or leased a car before.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If necessary, get a cosigner.  I know it might suck, but if your credit isn’t great you could end up paying thousands of more dollars per year than if you had just gotten that cosigner.</span>

&nbsp;
<h6><b> 3. Leasing or buying?</b></h6>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/09/business/auto-leasing-gains-popularity-among-american-consumers.html?_r=0"><span style="font-weight: 400;">More and more people are leasing</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> now than ever before.  I would say 80% of my sales are leases.  Leasing is a fun way to change out your car every few years while making smaller monthly payments.  I myself am currently leasing.  On the flip side, I also drive less than 10,000 miles per year, and my credit score is decent.  If you drive over 15,000 miles per year, or if you don’t want to deal with getting a new car every two or three years, or if you want to own the thing you’re driving instead of borrowing it, then buying is a good way to go as well.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Since my mom drives 30,000 miles per year as I mentioned, she bought her car.</span>

&nbsp;
<h6><b>4. New or pre-owned?</b></h6>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you can afford it, I would steer towards new.  Most pre-owned cars I sell are fine, but literally 100% of new cars I sell are perfect.  (I also work at Lexus, so I would hope the new cars are perfect.)  Plus, your warranty is going to be the best it could be, nobody’s driven your car yet, and that smell is fantastic.  If you’re leasing, definitely go new – pre-owned leases don’t tend to make sense financially.  This is because the </span><a href="http://www.edmunds.com/car-leasing/the-residual-value-of-leasing.html"><span style="font-weight: 400;">residual</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> is lower.  The residual is the amount you owe at the end of the lease if you want to buy it out, which is a set percentage based on the miles, time leased, and the </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">original </span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;">selling price (Manufacturer’s Suggested Retail Price, or MSRP, for new cars; on a pre-owned car this number is based on a weird calculation of wholesale and other factors that honestly I don’t 100% understand).  If the residual is lower, that means you’re paying for a greater percentage of the car, which means your monthly payments go up.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">However, </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">buying</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;"> a new car can be expensive.  If you can afford it, great!  If not, and you decide you want to buy a pre-owned, make sure you have the </span><a href="http://www.carfax.com/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Carfax</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">.  The Carfax will give you the auto history of the car so you know if it’s been in an accident or had any serious damage.  </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Also, buying a certified car from a dealership means they did a full inspection on a car and it comes with a warranty backed by the manufacturer.  If you buy pre-owned, I would recommend certified. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Only the same make can certify a car.  For example, Toyotas can only certify Toyotas.  There is no such thing as a certified pre-owned Hyundai on a Toyota pre-owned lot.</span>

&nbsp;
<h6><b> 5. Test drive.</b></h6>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">You’ve narrowed down your list to a few types of cars you like.  Now it’s time to make sure you like the way they drive.  Set an appointment with the dealership.  If you have a friend or a referral at a particular dealership, set up your appointment with that person (hey, that’s me!).  It is so much easier to do this with someone you trust.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Ask the salesperson about the different features available. Sometimes you can build the car online in a way that has absolutely nothing to do with the way the car shows up on the lot.  Figure out what features are most important to you and which ones aren’t.  Sometimes the features come bundled – you have to get navigation if you want blind spot monitor, for example.  That’s annoying.  It’s also just how it is.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">My mom set up the test drive without me to make sure she liked the car.  (She did.)  She doesn’t like test driving, but my dad and I made her do it.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">  </span><b style="line-height: 1.5;"> </b>
<h6><b style="line-height: 1.5;">6. Shopping.</b></h6>
<b>MSRP</b><span style="font-weight: 400;">, as mentioned above, is Manufacturer’s Suggested Retail Price.  It is the price they put on the car before you start negotiating.  Once you negotiate, you agree on the selling price.  On a lease, that price is call the “</span><b>capitalized cost</b><span style="font-weight: 400;">,” or “cap cost” for short.  “</span><b>Out the door</b><span style="font-weight: 400;">” is a term for purchase only (the term makes no sense on a lease), and it means the final, total, tax-title-license-and-fees-included amount for the car (the amount you’d write a check for if you weren’t financing).  Finally, keep in mind that tax is based on where </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">you</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;"> live, not where the dealership is located.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">These are basic terms.  There are a lot more terms to know, but I wouldn’t say they’re necessary to getting a good deal.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">You’ve test driven the cars and you’ve narrowed it down to one or two, but now it’s time to price it out.  Leasing is confusing because the rate isn’t APR, it’s something called a </span><a href="http://www.leaseguide.com/glossary/money-factor/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">money factor</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">.   For example, if you have good credit, you might get a money factor of 0.0009.  What does that mean?  You have to multiply that number by 2400 to get the rate to a percentage number that makes sense.  </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">For leasing, then, you have to shop to get the best payment.  It matters a little bit what the selling price is (your payment is based off that number), but if the dealership jacks up the money factor, or your credit isn’t very good, your payment will go up anyway.  Put in an inquiry online after knowing what you want and ask for the best deal.  Once you put out the inquiry, give yourself about a week or two for the timeline.  Incentives change on leases every month.  The pricing a salesperson gives you on June 30 may literally not be available July 1 because the rebates and special money factor rates from the bank have changed. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">While shopping, please keep in mind the salesperson/best friend/referral who test drove you at whatever dealership (hey, that’s me again!).  Salespeople are only paid on commission.  If you like the guy or girl who explained the car to you and let you take it for a spin and spent that time with you, but you still want to shop around to make sure you’re getting a great deal, it’s only fair to give them final shot at your deal.  (If she can’t beat it, at least you did right by her by giving her that last shot.)</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If buying, get financing on your own, either through a credit union or a bank.  If the dealership can match the rate, that’s great!  If they can’t, you at least have a back-up and you’re not stuck with a higher rate than necessary.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Also, go on </span><a href="https://www.truecar.com/#/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Truecar</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> or </span><a href="http://www.edmunds.com/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Edmund’s</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> and price out the typical savings on your car.  Keep in mind what the price of the car listed on Edmund’s is versus the price of the car you’ve chosen.  For example, if Truecar thinks you can get a selling price of $22,000 on a Toyota Corolla that has an MSRP of $24,000, and you ask for $22,000 on a Corolla that has an MSRP of $26,000, you won’t get it.  This is not the dealership’s fault.  They can probably give you the same discount ($2,000), but they can’t match the selling price.  I bring this very obvious fact up because it is surprisingly not obvious to a lot of customers who insist on viewing me as a slimeball.  Please don’t do this!  Use common sense!</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Additionally, </span><a href="http://autoclubsouth.aaa.com/Automotive/auto_buying.aspx"><span style="font-weight: 400;">AAA</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> and </span><a href="http://www.costcoauto.com/enterzipcode.aspx"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Costco</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> have really great programs you can check out as well.  These programs insist the dealership give the customer the invoice of the car in question.  Even if you don’t go through AAA or Costco, </span><b>always ask for the invoice</b><span style="font-weight: 400;">.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Finally, there are often rebates for active military members or recent college graduates on some models.  </span><b>Always ask about those rebates</b><span style="font-weight: 400;">.  It costs the dealership nothing and can save you a good amount of money!</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">When helping my mom get her car, I made sure to get the invoice.  I asked a coworker who had a referral to get me the car.  My mom was particular on color, and it was a very rare color, but because I had an in with my referral they were able to get it for me.  I checked Truecar to make sure the discount looked right, and it did (had to account for the truecar MSRP being less than the MSRP of my mom’s car, but the discount itself was the same!).  My mom got financing through her credit union.  We were able to set everything up via phone, email, and text because I had the invoice pricing, the proper research done ahead of time, and a good reference.</span>

&nbsp;
<h6><b> 7. Get rid of your old car.</b></h6>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">If your current car is on a lease, just return it to the old dealership.  Make an appointment (you’ll be in and out faster if you do).  If you’re switching makes, you will get charged a </span><a href="http://www.hoopdi.com/index.php/car-leasing-tools/lease-end-and-disposition-fees"><span style="font-weight: 400;">disposition fee</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">.  This fee will be on your contract.  This is what I like to call a “because we can” fee, and there’s not much you can do about it.  If the make (car talk for “brand”) is the same, the disposition fee is waived, because the car manufacturer wants to incentivize you to return.  You may also get charged for excess wear and tear, which consists of any major scratches, dents, or dings to the car you might have incurred during the lease, unless you bought that waiver program the last time around.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If your current car is something you own, </span><b>do not</b><span style="font-weight: 400;"> take it to a dealership first.  All too often I see customers pass up on amazing deals for their new car because they didn’t like the numbers the dealership gave them on their old car. These are two separate transactions.  It makes the most sense for you to keep it that way.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Go to </span><a href="http://www.kbb.com/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Kelly Blue Book</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> to get an estimate (and be honest with yourself on the quality of your current car).  Go to your local </span><a href="http://www.carmax.com/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Carmax</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, a nationwide used car dealership, and sell it to them.  Sell it on craigslist.  Donate it.  Dealerships have to put money into your car to sell it on the lot, and then they have to make money on your trade in.  They are a business.  So they will give you a number that still allows them to spruce up the car, maybe even certify it, and then sell it for profit.  That is the biggest reason the number they give you is typically not the number you had in mind.  Your old car deserves better than that number.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you want to sell it to the dealership for convenience’s sake, at least go to Carmax first to see if they can match that number.  Sometimes they can’t.  Sometimes they can.  Then it’s up to you.  What’s more worth it – a little more money, or the convenience?</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If your car has a payoff worth more than the car itself (for example, you owe $12,000, but the car is only worth $9,000), you might have to come out of pocket to get rid of your old car, or that negative equity might just be rolled into your payments.  If you own it outright, bring the title with you to the dealership.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">My mama just gave her old car to my brother when she got the new one.</span>

&nbsp;
<h6><b>8. Going to the dealership.</b></h6>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Okay, you know what car you want.  You know what features you want.  You know what color you want.  The salesperson you’re working with got the car for you (maybe they traded for it, or maybe it was already in stock). </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Make sure you have everything in writing before you go.  Selling price, rate, out the door number.  If it’s a lease, confirm that the amount they’re asking for includes everything (for example, it’s $1000 down, not $1000 down plus drive-offs, which ends up being at least twice as much as you expected; or the monthly payment is $350 including tax, not $350 plus tax).  Confirm the features.  </span><b>Get it in writing</b><span style="font-weight: 400;">.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">You’ll need your driver’s license and current proof of auto insurance to be able to drive the car off the lot.  If your credit is light or there are some issues, they may ask you for some more information (proof of income, proof of residence, more references, etc).  Have that with you too - if necessary.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">By the time my mom and I made an appointment to pick up our car, we were in and out of the dealership in 45 minutes.  Everything was as promised.  No need to make this harder on yourself than it has to be!</span>

&nbsp;
<h6><b>  9. Finance Department.</b></h6>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Now it’s time to sign the contract in the finance manager’s office.  This room can be intimidating.  The one thing to keep in mind is that every single item they are offering you is optional.  You do not have to purchase any of these extra warranties. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">However, some of these items can be helpful, and it’s worth listening to the options to see if any of them interest you (but again, per federal law, you </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">do not have to buy anything</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;"> to take delivery of your car, </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">no matter what your credit score is</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;">).   </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">What you should buy in this department depends on what you like and what you plan on doing with the car.  If you’re buying the car and keeping it for 10 years, an extended warranty isn’t a bad idea.  On a lease, I absolutely 100% recommend the excess wear and tear which waives any charges at the end of the lease due to damages and then you don’t have to worry about anything when you turn it in.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Some of those items you have to buy right then and there.  Tire and wheel, for example, or the aforementioned excess wear cannot be purchased after sale.  You can buy the extended warranty at any time, so I would recommend shopping online for pricing before purchasing an extended warranty.  You will probably be overcharged in the finance department for extended warranty.  The upshot is that you can spread the amount into your car payments instead of paying it all at once.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">See how easy that was?  Don’t you just want to do it over and over again?  Now you can walk confidently into a dealership, knowing you’re about to get a killer deal on any car you want.  You go, girl!</span>]]></content:encoded>
