		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_jetpack_related_posts_cache]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:1:{s:32:"8f6677c9d6b0f903e98ad32ec61f8deb";a:2:{s:7:"expires";i:1460386768;s:7:"payload";a:3:{i:0;a:1:{s:2:"id";i:1961;}i:1;a:1:{s:2:"id";i:1527;}i:2;a:1:{s:2:"id";i:2487;}}}}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Treat Kittens with Fleas</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-treat-kittens-with-fleas/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 29 Aug 2015 00:14:29 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[rachel-ybarra]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2027</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h6><span style="font-weight: 400;">You could call me a cat lady. </span></h6><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">I’ve owned at least five cats and fostered probably double in my short lifetime of 22 years, so I’ve seen it all. Oftentimes when you get a foster kitten, they are not in the best condition. One typical problem is fleas, which are common on kittens from feral mothers that were born outside. They can be extremely hard to eliminate and can infect your house if you are not careful.   Below are some tips that I’ve learned about removing fleas from young kittens.</span></p><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Since these kittens are often too small for topical medicine, the best way to remove their fleas  is to bathe them. Fleas can more easily be found in wet fur because dry fur is a great place for them to hide. Bathe your kitten with just a little anti-tear animal shampoo or even baby shampoo. Items you’ll need:</span></p><ol><li style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Anti-tear animal or baby shampoo</span></li><li style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Small comb</span></li><li style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Tweezers </span></li><li style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">White towel or white paper laid out</span></li></ol><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">You should wear long sleeves or even gloves while bathing your kitten. Kittens have long thin nails and most kittens are not fond of water, so you’ll most likely get scratched. The long sleeves will help to protect your arms.</span></p><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">After the bathing, you have to comb the kitten’s fur out over a white towel. The contrast of the white towel with the black fleas will make it easier to find them. You can also pick through the kitten’s fur with tweezers to find the fleas as well. Rinse any fleas you find down the sink or squish them in the towel before washing it. </span></p><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">It’s important to mention that bathing your kitten will not kill off any eggs the fleas may have laid. I suggest to continually bathing your kitten until it is old enough to receive topical or oral flea medicine. A bad flea problem can kill young kittens and always consult your vet if the flea problem becomes unmanageable. </span></p><p><span style="font-weight: 400;">I hope these tips can spare a flea problem in your apartment, and maybe save a kitten’s life! With so many cats out on the street, fostering can a great way to make a difference; you just have to be prepared for a lot of these cats not being in the best condition. If you have any other questions about kitten fostering, check out </span><a href="http://www.foundanimals.org/pet-adoption/kitten-foster"><span style="font-weight: 400;">this article</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> on Found Animals.  Happy flea hunting!</span></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>Header photo from: http://imgur.com/gallery/QLlJn</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Make An International Call</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-make-an-international-call/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 15 Sep 2015 16:29:12 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[maria-zhou]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2132</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">During a recent trip to London, I found out the hard way that those iconic red telephone booths are just for show. I needed to make an international call, and was clueless about how to do it on my cell phone. After getting my hands dirty and researching, I found out that there are actually a lot of options. Depending on the country and your preferences, different apps and phone plans may work better for you. Here are some ways to call internationally. </span>

&nbsp;

<b>1) Check with your cell phone provider</b><span style="font-weight: 400;">. It differs from provider to provider, but talk to yours because they might have an international plan that works for you. Since I have T-mobile, I chose this option:</span>

<a href="http://www.t-mobile.com/optional-services/international.html"><span style="font-weight: 400;">http://www.t-mobile.com/optional-services/international.html</span></a>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">This allowed me to avoid all those pesky roaming calls and expensive fees!</span>

&nbsp;

<b>2) Get a prepaid calling card.</b><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Depending on your provider, a prepaid calling card may be cheaper than using your a normal cell phone plan with surcharges:</span>

<a href="https://attprepaidcard.amssupport.net/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">https://attprepaidcard.amssupport.net/</span></a>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">I like to use this a prepaid card to call my grandpa who lives in China; this is great when you aren't calling super often, but will need the option to call again. </span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">3) </span><b>Use your computer or download mobile apps. </b><span style="font-weight: 400;">Nowadays, there are tons of free or low cost apps that get the job done, like:</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Skype: </span><a href="http://www.skype.com/en/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">http://www.skype.com/en/</span></a>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Whatsapp </span><a href="https://www.whatsapp.com/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">https://www.whatsapp.com/</span></a>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Google: </span><a href="https://plus.google.com/hangouts"><span style="font-weight: 400;">https://plus.google.com/hangouts</span></a>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Wechat: </span><a href="http://www.wechat.com/en/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">http://www.wechat.com/en/</span></a>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Viber: </span><a href="https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.viber.voip&amp;hl=en"><span style="font-weight: 400;">https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.viber.voip&amp;hl=en</span></a>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Facetime: </span><a href="http://www.apple.com/mac/facetime/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">http://www.apple.com/mac/facetime/</span></a>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Google Hangouts is the best for group chats – they even have fun stickers you can put on your screen (like moustaches)!  </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">I use FaceTime to call a friend in the Peace Corps, which saves the hassle of downloading an app if both parties have access to Apple technology.  My parents use Wechat to keep in touch with friends living and travelling around the world in Germany, China, Australia, and Japan. </span>

&nbsp;

<b>Last thing: </b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Don’t forget to type in the country's code before dialing and to remember to check time zones! </span>

<a href="https://countrycode.org/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">https://countrycode.org/</span></a>

<a href="http://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">http://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/</span></a>

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

Header Gif: Buzzfeed.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Understand The Measles Vaccine</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-understand-the-measles-vaccine/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 18 Sep 2015 23:57:08 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[devin-saragosa-harris]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2166</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">I grew up in Southern California, where summertime meant sun in my hair and sand in my pockets. As a pretty nerdy child (I readily admit this), I never dreaded school starting again, but it was obvious to even the most enthusiastic student that the end of summer meant less freedom and longer to-do lists on the horizon. My mom, to her credit, tried hard to make the shift less painful with our little back-to-school traditions. This time of year still reminds me of going with her to stores in my hometown with my long list of supplies in hand, picking out what was truly necessary and deciding what optional items I didn’t really need. Looking back, I’m not sure how much my personal list agreed with what was on my mom’s list, but she was always a good sport with my sparkly decisions. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Parents’ lists today are relatively similar to my mom’s list during my elementary school years, but there are some disagreements amongst families on what items are necessary versus optional. On many parents’ “necessary” lists (but noticeably absent on others’) are back-to-school vaccinations. With the rise of the anti-vaccination movement, and widely publicized outbreaks in the past few years, vaccines seem to be on everyone’s radar. But what do vaccines do? Do scientists really think vaccines are necessary? And what the heck was going on with measles this year? </span>

&nbsp;

<b>How do vaccines work?</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Vaccines utilize the body’s defense system to create immunity. The normal progress of acquiring immunity involves being exposed to a virus, and surviving the exposure, so that the body knows how to respond the next time it faces exposure. Through the use of </span><a href="http://www.beatricebiologist.com/2014/11/get-your-flu-shot/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">vaccines</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, the body is exposed to a weakened or inactive form of the virus so that the body creates virus-specific defenses; vaccines prepare the body for the next time it is exposed to this virus, and the person does not have to experience the full-blown illness to develop this immunity.  </span>

&nbsp;

<b>What is herd immunity?</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Herd immunity is the concept of protecting the general population from an illness because a high percentage of people have been immunized. Vaccinated persons are protected, due to their prior exposure, but persons who are either too young for vaccination or unable to be vaccinated (for example, due to a compromised immune system) are also protected because the virus does not encounter as many susceptible people. If the virus cannot come into contact with susceptible hosts, the spread of the illness is halted, and vulnerable people are much less likely to come into contact with the virus. The more contagious the virus, the higher a percentage of people vaccinated required for herd immunity to take place. Measles is extremely contagious, so this protection only occurs when about 95% of the population is vaccinated; lower than this, herd (or “community”) immunity is lost and vulnerable populations are not as well protected.</span>

&nbsp;

<b>Measles</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">You might remember hearing about measles after the </span><a href="http://www.nbclosangeles.com/news/local/Timeline-Disneyland-Measles-Outbreak-289520681.html"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Disneyland outbreak</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> in 2015: a single case at the theme park spread to over 100 people across California and neighboring states. While the outbreak was officially contained after several months, knowing the basics about measles can be beneficial to your wellbeing. Measles is an illness caused by a highly contagious virus. Measles is transmitted when infected people cough or sneeze, and the virus can survive in the air for up to a  couple hours. A widespread rash that spreads across the body is the defining characteristic of the illness, although the first symptoms are usually fever, sore throat, runny nose, cough, and red eyes. Measles is especially dangerous for children under age 5 because of its high rate of complications, which include pneumonia and encephalitis. While rates of measles have historically been declining since the introduction of the MMR (measles, mumps, and rubella) vaccine – it was actually deemed “</span><a href="http://www.businessinsider.com/ohio-measles-outbreak-18-year-high-2014-5"><span style="font-weight: 400;">eliminated</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">” in the United States in 2000 – rates of the illness have shot up substantially in the past three years, with 2014 recording the highest rates of the illness in recent memory. This increase in cases can be attributed to an increased influx of cases from other parts of the world (introduction of the virus), and a decreased rate of vaccination (higher susceptibility in the population). </span>

&nbsp;

<b>Vaccination Fears</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">What is causing this decreased rate of vaccination in the United States? Many fears about vaccination can be traced to a paper published in a scientific journal that linked vaccines to an increased rate of autism in children. That journal has since redacted the article, due to the author making up false data for the paper. </span><a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24814559"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Tons of studies</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> have been done on the link between autism and vaccines because of the author’s fake claims, and literally </span><a href="http://www.cdc.gov/vaccinesafety/concerns/autism.html"><span style="font-weight: 400;">none of them</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> have found a link between vaccinating a child and an increased risk of developing autism. Heightened rates of autism over the past few decades can be attributed to the fact that doctors are now diagnosing autism in children at earlier ages. If you are worried about the risks associated with vaccination, read up on the actual scientific literature about it, or talk to your doctor. Vaccines such as the measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine save lives, and any fear about them causing autism is unfounded. Even the </span><a href="http://www.autismsciencefoundation.org/autismandvaccines.html"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Autism Science Foundation</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> agrees. </span>

&nbsp;

<i><span style="font-weight: 400;">I am a current public health student, so discussing vaccines and epidemics are my bread and butter. Hopefully this helps to clear up some questions you might have about these topics, but (as always) if you have more questions send them our way! </span></i>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">More resources:</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">CDC on Measles (FAQ): http://www.cdc.gov/measles/about/faqs.html</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">CDC on Herd Immunity: </span><a href="http://www.vaccines.gov/basics/protection/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">http://www.vaccines.gov/basics/protection/</span></a>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Vaccination Schedules for Measles: </span><a href="http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd-vac/combo-vaccines/mmrv/vacopt-faqs-hcp.htm"><span style="font-weight: 400;">http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd-vac/combo-vaccines/mmrv/vacopt-faqs-hcp.htm</span></a>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">More information on vaccines and the lack of data tying them to autism: </span><a href="http://www.who.int/vaccine_safety/committee/topics/mmr/mmr_autism/en/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">http://www.who.int/vaccine_safety/committee/topics/mmr/mmr_autism/en/</span></a>

&nbsp;

Header Photo: onemedical.com]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<category domain="category" nicename="health"><![CDATA[Health]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_webdados_fb_open_graph_specific_image]]></wp:meta_key>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How to: Keep a Potted Plant Alive</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-keep-a-potted-plant-alive/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 19 Sep 2015 07:18:14 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[karissa-chamblin]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2171</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[So we’ve all been there. You see that houseplants are cool again and you buy a succulent at the store. One week later it's soggy and yellow and looks like a zombie. You then dub yourself “The Worst Gardener Ever” and never touch a living thing again, right? I feel your pain, but taking care of plants really isn’t that hard. It’s all about educating yourself, getting to know your specific plant, and setting a routine for taking care of it. Let’s start by figuring out what is wrong with that cactus or lily or whatever indoor plant you have, and how to treat it.

&nbsp;
<table>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td><b>Symptom</b></td>
<td><b>Cause</b></td>
<td><b>Cure</b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Long, pale leave and/or small new leaves</td>
<td>Not enough light and/or too much nitrogen</td>
<td>Give plant more light and/or reduce fertilizer frequency</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Leaves curl under or have yellow or or brown spots</td>
<td>Too much light</td>
<td>Move plant away from light source, or shade plant with blinds or sheer curtain</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Mushy stems; lower leaves curl and wilt</td>
<td>Too much water</td>
<td>Water only when soil is dry to touch; make sure drain hole is not clogged</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Leaf tips are brown and leaves wilt</td>
<td>Not enough water</td>
<td>Soak pot for 20 minutes in water and let drain; water when soil is dry to touch</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Leaf edges are crinkly brown</td>
<td>Lack of humidity</td>
<td>Mist leaves, or place pot on tray of moist pebbles</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Lower leaves turn pale and drop off</td>
<td>Lack of fertilizer</td>
<td>Fertilize plant regularly during growing season</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Leaves turn yellow or curl and wilt</td>
<td>Too much heat</td>
<td>Move plant to cooler spot in house; be sure plant is not close to a heat vent or on top of the TV</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Plant wilts between waterings; roots growing out of drainage hole</td>
<td>Pot too small</td>
<td>Repot plant into a container one size larger</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/image00.jpg"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-2176" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/image00-768x1024.jpg" alt="Succulents - Karissa" width="525" height="700" /></a>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 12px;"><em>Succulents. Photo by Karissa Chamblin</em></span></p>
<b>Heat and light</b>

Windowsill plants that get leggy (excessively long and straggly stems) may be getting too much heat, not too little sun. Move them to a sunny window for more even growth.

&nbsp;

<b>Water</b>

Give plants room temperature water. Fill a spray bottle or a watering can with water and let it sit on the counter overnight, to let the water filter out the chlorine naturally.

Mist plants frequently, especially in the winter. Give your plants a good soak once a month by putting them in the bathtub and soaking them with the shower head.

&nbsp;

<b>Growth</b>

Pick dead leaves and faded flowers off of plants as needed to encourage growth. Repot houseplants in the spring.

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/image02.jpg"><img class="wp-image-2185 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/image02-768x1024.jpg" alt="Philodendron. Photo by Karissa Chamblin " width="525" height="700" /></a>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em><span style="font-size: 12px;">Philodendron. Photo by Karissa Chamblin  </span></em></p>
&nbsp;

Now that the problems and solutions are laid out for you, I hope you feel empowered and more adventurous in the plant department! Taking care of plants is so much fun and so very rewarding, and it just takes a little practice, patience and attention!

&nbsp;

I will leave you with one of my favorite quotes to get you started. “If you are not killing plants, you are not really stretching yourself as a gardener.”- J.C. Raulston

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:10:{i:0;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"3080";s:5:"score";s:18:"36.145946370175714";}i:1;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2806";s:5:"score";s:18:"23.642280536773868";}i:2;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2191";s:5:"score";s:18:"19.822530338963325";}i:3;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1045";s:5:"score";s:18:"19.750298187227358";}i:4;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2209";s:5:"score";s:18:"19.249880894132097";}i:5;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"3154";s:5:"score";s:17:"16.53142236235916";}i:6;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2832";s:5:"score";s:17:"16.53142236235916";}i:7;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2960";s:5:"score";s:18:"16.031005069263898";}i:8;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2600";s:5:"score";s:18:"16.031005069263898";}i:9;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2431";s:5:"score";s:18:"16.031005069263898";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Entertain a Four Year Old</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-entertain-a-four-year-old/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 19 Sep 2015 07:22:05 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Elena Cherine]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2182</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">You never know when you’ll be at a family party and overwhelmed Aunt Darla will plop her four-year-old son, Indigo,  (your adorable cousin) in front of you so she can drink wine with your mom (because apparently your ability to look engaged 20 minutes into Great Uncle Morty’s recollections of his favorite fishing trips proves how responsible and grownup you are).  While your apple-cheeked, bright-eyed cousin might have seemed incredibly cute from the occasional good-bye hugs he’s given you, or his consistent switching of his </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">w</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;"> and </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">l</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;"> sounds, when he’s your charge, his energy and constant questions seem like a whole different story.  So, what’s the plan, older cuz? Here are 6 idea on keeping a four-year-old entertained:</span>

&nbsp;
<ol>
	<li><b>Make up a story.</b><span style="font-weight: 400;">  These stories can be as basic as you like.  They need three simple ingredients: </span></li>
</ol>
<ul>
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">Some element of magic, like–a wand, a magical land, weird food, a pretty fairy etc.–</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">A conflict.  This could be anything from someone getting lost in the park, to not wanting to </span> <span style="font-weight: 400;">leave the glorious Cupcake City you’ve created, to the protagonist wanting a ham sandwich and being stuck with a PB and J instead. There doesn’t always need to be a villain. Sometimes things like the sandwich debacle are enough because their very nature is villainous to a four-year-old.</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;">Your four-year-old is the protagonist and he or she has some ally. This could be a dog, a superhero, another cousin, or even you!</span></li>
</ul>
&nbsp;
<ol start="2">
	<li><b>Go for a “Nature Walk.” </b><span style="font-weight: 400;">This can literally be up and down the street.  As an extra bonus, read him every street sign and make up what they say (ie: “magic wolves this way” or “for witches and pumpkin heads, turn left”).  The most important thing is to be excited about everything–each brown leaf, each crack in the sidewalk, each wilted marigold.  This can get exhausting but after a while it’ll catch on to your cousin and he’ll do all the excitement and you can retreat to friendly head nods, smiles, and the classic, “Really?  Oh, wow!”</span></li>
</ol>
&nbsp;
<ol start="3">
	<li><b>Find the most very special thing in your purse.</b><span style="font-weight: 400;">  This could be anything from a compact mirror to an old Tic Tac box to a lucky charm you carry.  The main idea here is to inform your cousin that this </span><b>very special thing</b><span style="font-weight: 400;"> is important to you, and that because you think he is such a big boy (or big girl, as the case may be), you have decided to share it with him.  This could keep him happy for a long time.  Maybe you could take a tour of the party and show all the relatives this special thing he gets to hold.</span></li>
</ol>
&nbsp;
<ol start="4">
	<li><b>Pick a song, such as, “The Wheels on the Bus,” and give him movements to add to it. </b><span style="font-weight: 400;">Simpler is better–he’ll love copying what his older cousin does, and he’ll love it more if he can do it well.  This might include clapping, stomping, or turning in a circle.  </span></li>
</ol>
&nbsp;
<ol start="5">
	<li><b>Pick some age-appropriate songs (i.e: “Wheels,” “Macarena,” or “YMCA”) and play them on your YouTube app.</b><span style="font-weight: 400;">  Play freeze dance - dance with the music, freeze when it stops.  After he gets the hang of it, see if you can switch jobs, and you’re the dancer (make sure he doesn’t know how to use a smartphone very well, or you might also end up with 30 selfies of his hands and feet saved onto your phone).</span></li>
</ol>
&nbsp;
<ol start="6">
	<li><b>Lastly, always pretend that he’s got one over you. </b><span style="font-weight: 400;">He’ll love thinking that he’s tricking you.  You might ask if he’s six, and then be awestruck when he informs you that actually, he’s only four! You might leave the room saying you bet he won’t be sitting on the couch when you return (a few seconds later) only to find the little darling sitting there with his hands folded and his little smile beaming across his whole face.  </span></li>
</ol>
&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Enjoy your four-year-old’s wonder at the world, and the fact that these two hours you’re spending with him will probably inform his opinion of you for his entire young life.  You might even be laying the foundation for the relationship you might have as adults.  Get creative and family gatherings will be a piece of cake.  </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Great Uncle Morty’s fishing sagas will be a thing of the past.</span>

&nbsp;

Header Gif: shiftgig.com]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Make the BEST Cup of Tea</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-make-the-best-cup-of-tea/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 19 Sep 2015 07:39:50 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[MJ@twigghowto.com]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2191</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/tea-gif.gif"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-2198" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/tea-gif.gif" alt="tea gif" width="496" height="320" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: center;">Gif from Buzzfeed.com</p>
&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Tea is awesome, for both our tastebuds and </span><a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3249787/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">for our health</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">. That shouldn’t be too hard to believe, seeing how tea has been consumed as a beverage for centuries, starting before 1000 B.C. in China. Since then it has made its rounds, changed form, </span><a href="http://www.teausa.com/14655/tea-fact-sheet"><span style="font-weight: 400;">and become the world’s second most popular drink behind water</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">. </span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Despite this popularity, many of us are quicker to turn to coffee or juice as the non-water beverage of choice. That’s a shame, because tea is much less likely than either of those things to result in caffeine or sugar spikes and crashes. Tea is also renowned for its extremely </span><a href="http://www.marksdailyapple.com/6-tea-ingredients-that-can-help-you-unwind-relax-and-chill-out/#axzz3gCpW0lnq"><span style="font-weight: 400;">beneficial chemicals</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, which can play a role in </span><a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24172303"><span style="font-weight: 400;">perking you up</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, </span><a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26192072"><span style="font-weight: 400;">chilling you out</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, and so much more. </span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">So why do I care so much? I used to work at a tea shop selling loose-leaf tea, and got so many questions about how to prepare it and where it comes from. I could go on and on about all the things that I learned in that year of slangin’ leaves, but I’m going to try to break it down to basics so you can milk this drink for all it’s worth (or go dairy-free, if you choose). </span>

&nbsp;

<b>Know the differences (or lack of)</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">You’ve probably heard of green tea, black tea, and white tea. But did you know that they were all the same leaf? That leaf comes from the </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">camellia sinensis </span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;">plant, and the only difference between the different “colors” of tea is how much the leaf has been processed.</span> <span style="font-weight: 400;">“Processed” in this context means the leaves have been oxidized or manipulated through </span><a href="http://www.upasitearesearch.org/ctc/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">different drying, rolling or breaking methods</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> - it does not have anything to do with unnatural chemicals. There are four official categories of </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">camellia sinensis</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;">: White, Green, Oolong, and Black. </span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">There are teas that do not contain the </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">camellia sinensi</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;">s leaf as well, and these are all considered Herbal. Herbal teas include: 1) Herbal infusions, 2)</span><a href="http://www.teavana.com/tea-info/mate-tea"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Yerba Mate</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, which tends to be high in caffeine, and 3) the antioxidant-rich </span><a href="http://www.teavana.com/the-teas/rooibos-teas"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Rooibos</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, also known as red tea. Herbal teas are simply dried ingredients, and can be as simple or complex as you’d like. </span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Check out the handy-dandy chart I designed </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">just for you</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;"> to get a better idea of what you can get from each type. Again, this barely scratches the surface - but we’ve gotta start somewhere!</span>

&nbsp;

<b>Camellia Sinensis</b>
<table>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td><b>Name</b></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><b>Amount of processing</b></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><b>Features/Uses</b></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><b>Steeping time</b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b>White</b></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 12px;">    Little to none</span></td>
<td><span style="font-size: 12px;"><a href="http://journals.tubitak.gov.tr/biology/issues/biy-08-32-1/biy-32-1-8-0703-3.pdf">Antioxidants</a>, little to no caffeine; soothing</span></td>
<td><span style="font-size: 12px;">No more than 2 minutes</span>

&nbsp;</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b>Green</b></td>
<td><span style="font-size: 12px;">          Little</span></td>
<td><span style="font-size: 12px;"><a href="http://journals.tubitak.gov.tr/biology/issues/biy-08-32-1/biy-32-1-8-0703-3.pdf">Antioxidants</a>; distinct flavor, soothing properties</span></td>
<td><span style="font-size: 12px;">No more than 2-3 minutes</span>

&nbsp;</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b>Oolong</b></td>
<td><span style="font-size: 12px;">       Moderate</span></td>
<td><span style="font-size: 12px;"><a href="http://www.trnres.com/ebook/uploads/yeboahcontent/T_1372500799Yeboah%203.pdf">Moderate caffeine levels</a>; blends well with others</span></td>
<td><span style="font-size: 12px;">No more than 4 minutes</span>

&nbsp;</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b>Black</b></td>
<td><span style="font-size: 12px;">           High</span></td>
<td><span style="font-size: 12px;"><a href="http://www.trnres.com/ebook/uploads/yeboahcontent/T_1372500799Yeboah%203.pdf">Higher in caffeine</a>; some styles can help with water retention; dark, rich flavor;</span></td>
<td><span style="font-size: 12px;">No more than 5 minutes</span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
&nbsp;

<b>Herbal Teas (also known as Tisanes)</b>
<table>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td><b>Name</b></td>
<td><b>      Ingredients</b></td>
<td><b>Features/Uses</b></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><b>Steeping times</b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b>Herbal Infusions                </b></td>
<td>&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 12px;">Literally any dried natural product is fair game</span><span style="font-size: 12px;"> </span></td>
<td><span style="font-size: 12px;">Depends on the herbs used. <a href="http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/265990.php">Ginger</a>, for example, can be great for an upset stomach. Play around with different herbs and see what works best for you!</span></td>
<td><span style="font-size: 12px;">As long as you want!</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b>Yerba Mate</b></td>
<td><span style="font-size: 12px;">
Dried leaves and stems from the Yerba Mate tree native to South America</span>&nbsp;</td>
<td><span style="font-size: 12px;"><a href="http://www.whc-shreveport.com/womens-health-information/Education.aspx?chunkiid=111705">Mateine (a chemical similar to caffeine) is certain to get you going</a>; dark, rich flavors - tastes good infused with chocolate and spices</span></td>
<td><span style="font-size: 12px;">As long as you want!</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b>Rooibos</b></td>
<td><span style="font-size: 12px;">Dried materials from the Rooibos plant native to South Africa</span></td>
<td><span style="font-size: 12px;">Antioxidant rich, caffeine free, and <a href="http://europepmc.org/abstract/med/9209319">possibly good for the immune system.</a>Tastes good with soft, sweet infusions</span></td>
<td><span style="font-size: 12px;">As long as you want!</span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
&nbsp;

<b>Know your options, and how to use them</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">We’re all probably pretty familiar with pre-bagged teas, but loose-leaf tea is another way to get your comfort fix. Loose-leaf tea  can be sold by weight or in airtight tins, and consists of a medley of dried leaves, flowers, fruits, and/or herbs that you portion out yourself for each cup. Below is chart which may help you decide if loose-leaf tea is right for you!</span>

&nbsp;
<table>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td></td>
<td><b>Tea bags</b></td>
<td><b>Loose-Leaf</b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b>Pros</b></td>
<td>
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 12px;">Easy To Find</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 12px;">Already portioned and filtered - easy to use!</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 12px;">Easy disposal</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 12px;">Cheaper one-time purchase</span></li>
</ul>
</td>
<td>
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 12px;">Customizable; Mix and match teas, or modify portions for your liking</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 12px;">Visual experience</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 12px;">Clear, stronger flavors</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 12px;">Can be a cheaper purchase over time</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 12px;">Less waste, for the green folks :-)</span></li>
</ul>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b>Cons</b></td>
<td>
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 12px;">Can seem weaker in flavor</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 12px;">More trash overall</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 12px;">Harder to modify portions and flavors</span></li>
</ul>
</td>
<td>
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 12px;">Slightly more time to prepare </span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 12px;">Strainer to clean after you’re done</span></li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 12px;">Can take practice</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 12px;">Depending on where you purchase, can cost more</span></li>
</ul>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b>Tools needed</b></td>
<td>
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 12px;">Bags on bags on bags</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 12px;">Teabag holder if you choose to reuse while drinking</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 12px;">Water heater</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 12px;">Cup!</span></li>
</ul>
</td>
<td>
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 12px;">Mesh or steel tea strainer</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 12px;">Teabag holder if you choose to reuse while drinking</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 12px;">Water heater</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 12px;">Cup (sometimes you can find one with strainers included)!</span></li>
</ul>
</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you decide you want to give loose-leaf teas a go, you need to know where to find them</span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">:</span></i>
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Whole Foods, Lassen’s, or any other market that focuses on organic, natural foods.</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Tea boutiques and retail chains (the most popular one is Teavana, a Starbucks company)</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Asian markets or neighborhoods tend to be good places to look for quality loose-leaf tea at a reasonable price. </span></li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

<b>Tricks of the trade:</b>

<i><span style="font-weight: 400;">Water Temperature: </span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;">Were you planning to use boiling water to make that cup of happiness before bed? Don’t. When making tea using </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">camellia sinensis</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;"> leaves, boiling water can burn the leaves and leave you with a bitter taste. The simplest way to avoid boiling water is to let it sit for a couple of minutes after you turn off your heating method of choice. You could also drop in an ice cube or two, if you want to speed up the process. And of course, if you actually </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">like</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;"> that bitter flavor, do you. </span>

&nbsp;

<i><span style="font-weight: 400;">Ice, Ice, Baby:</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Remember that tea shop I said I worked at? One of the most common questions I got was how to make iced tea for hot days. The best advice? Make a concentrated version of your tea so that when you add ice, it’s not being watered down. </span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">To do this, steep about twice as many tea leaves/tea bags with about half the normal amount of hot water, and then pour over a cup packed with ice when it’s done. You’ve still got a month or two before summer is officially over, so give it a go in the next couple of weeks!</span>

&nbsp;

Header Image: Wikipedia]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Accurately Size Your Bra</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-accurately-size-your-bra/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 23 Sep 2015 16:30:21 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Rebecca Olson]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2134</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">Bras are probably the single most complicated garment any woman buys, and yet nobody really teaches you how they're supposed to fit. If you hate wearing a bra and think it's uncomfortable -- “The underwires are pokey! The straps dig into my shoulders!” -- you're likely wearing the wrong size.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Bra fitting is an art. It is a nuanced, multi-step process. I'm telling you this not to intimidate you, but so you know that it's more than the girl at Victoria’s Secret taking two measurements over your sweatshirt. Yes, I saw that happen. Yes, I was horrified.</span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">I'm going to walk you through the steps to find a bra that fits you because:</span>
<ol>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Having a bra that fits correctly will make you look better and feel better. </span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">It's empowering to understand your body. Every body is different and hey, wouldn't you know, there are a crap ton of different bras to fit them. </span></li>
</ol>
&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">So let's get started.</span>

&nbsp;

<b>Part 1: Your Measurements</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Knowing your measurements is the first step in getting a good fit. Getting into the right size bra will eliminate the four biggest complaints I hear from women about bras: the straps dig into my shoulders, I have fat under my armpits, the underwires are poke-y, and, for the well-endowed, “boob muffin top.”</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">You'll need a way to measure, a piece of paper to write this down, and a private space. If you have a soft tape measure for sewing, grab that. If you are a normal person and not a crafter/hoarder like me, grab some string and a regular tape measure or ruler. Now take off that shirt and that bra. Be free of it! If you haven't taken a measurement in the past year, chances are it's the wrong size anyway.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">You're going to take 2 measurements: underbust and bust. Underbust is, as it sounds, the area right below your breasts. Wrap the string around you and pull it snug - not so snug that you're stretching the string or really squeezing yourself, but there shouldn't be any slack. Mark the place where the string wraps all the way around you then go measure the length and write that number down.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Next you'll measure your bust. This is the fullest part of your breasts, right over your nipples. You want to measure your breasts at their fullest, so for this one let gravity help you out. Bend at the waist so your chest is parallel to the floor and then take the measurement. You shouldn't pull the string really tight for this; just enough that there isn't any slack but not so much that you're compressing your breasts. Write down that number too.</span>

&nbsp;

<b>Part 2: So what do these numbers mean?</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">The underbust measurement is your band size. Bands come in even numbers and you want it to be snug, so remember basic grade school math and round appropriately. That means a measurement of 30.6" would be a 30" band or a measurement of 41.75" would be a 42" band. If you're right in the middle, I recommend rounding down, though I have seen debate about this. I think it’s more important to stay with a snugger band size if you have larger breasts, but ultimately you should try on both band sizes and decide what is most comfortable for you. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Chances are this number is several inches smaller than what you've been wearing. It will feel a little funny at first to have a snug band, but I promise it will be better in the long run. Bras are designed so the band provides the majority of the support for your breasts. You shouldn't be able to hook it in the front and spin it around, and it shouldn't ride up your back when you lift your arms above your head.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">The bust measurement will translate into your cup size. Contrary to what popular media has told you, small breasts aren't necessarily A cups, and DDs are not necessarily gigantic nor are they are the largest size out there. Cup size is proportional to band size. Start by rounding your bust measurement to a whole number in inches. Next subtract your newfound band size from your bust measurement. This number will tell you your cup size. For every inch, add a cup size. So if your underbust/band measurement was 42" and your bust measurement was 46", 46-42 = 4" or size D cup. Another example:</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Band measurement: 34</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Bust measurement: 36</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">36-34 = 2, or size B cup</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you really don't want to do math, here's a link to a </span><a href="http://www.sophisticatedpair.com/bra-size-calculator/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">calculator</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> that will do it for you. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Remember what I said about DD about not being the biggest cup size ever? This paragraph is for you, my well-endowed friend. If you wear a cup size bigger than D, the naming convention is going to vary by manufacturer -- US versus UK versus Europe at large. Sometimes DD is the same size as E, but sometimes E is the next size after DDD. Don't panic. </span><a href="http://www.breakoutbras.com/sizing"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Here is a chart.</span></a>

&nbsp;

<b>Part 3: Great, where am I supposed to find </b><b><i>that</i></b><b> size?</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If your new measurement is between 34A and 38DD, then you should be able to find a bra in your size in pretty much any retail store. Skip ahead to the next part about bra fit.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If your new measurements are outside of those numbers, I totally understand your sarcasm. The cruel fact is that American bra manufacturers and retailers don't make or carry the diverse selection of sizes needed for every body. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Some retail stores do. You can and should look for specialty bra stores in your area. If there's nothing like that in your town, most places in the US should have a Nordstrom, and they carry a huge selection of bra sizes. Bras in those sizes are not always out on the rack, but a sales associate should be able to tell you what is available in your size. And the internet, of course, has everything. But you'll have to wait, and you'll also likely have to deal with returns and exchanges. There are links for you at the end of the article.</span>

&nbsp;

<b>Part 4: Putting it on-- the swoop and scoop</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Now you have your bra size and you're ready to go try things on, so let's make sure you're putting a bra on correctly. "Swoop and scoop" is the terrible, sports-analogy-sounding method for getting everything into place. Just to be clear, only the name of this method is terrible; the practice itself is great.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Once again, you want gravity to help you out. Throw the bra straps over your shoulders, bend forward at the waist so your chest is parallel to the floor, and </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">then</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;"> hook your bra closed using the loosest set of hooks. Bras stretch as they age, so the other two sets are to keep your bra snug as the elastic loses its snap.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">That's the swoop. Now for the scoop.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Don't stand back up yet. You want to scoop all of the breast tissue into your bra cups. Do one side at a time and push the skin and breast tissue on the side of your chest forward, toward the front of your breast. Repeat for other side. Here's a </span><a href="http://www.herroom.com/bra-fitting-advice,319,30.html"><span style="font-weight: 400;">video link</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> if you're like WTF?!?! right about now.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Now stand up. Your breast should fill the cup all the way. Or most of the way -- we'll talk more about this in a minute. This method makes your breasts looks fuller because they aren't fighting gravity when you put a bra on and also because all of your breast is actually in the cup instead of spewing out the side making armpit "fat" like it was before when your cups were too small. That wasn't fat. It was migrated breast tissue. If you were wearing a cup size that was significantly too small, it may take a bit of time doing the swoop and scoop to get everything to migrate back into place.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Now do three checks. First, turn to the side and look at the underwire. The end of it should be sitting on your rib cage, not your breast. If you were getting poked by underwires before, it was likely because your cup was too small and the end of the underwire was on your breast instead of your chest. If the underwire seems a little close to your breast, try moving up a cup size or try a different bra with wider underwires. Yes, they come in different widths and shapes. You can read more about it at </span><a href="http://www.herroom.com/bra-underwires-design-and-size-manufacturing,912,30.html"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Her Room</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">. You also want to make sure that the front of the underwire is sitting on your chest and not floating above it. If it’s floating, the cup is definitely too small.</span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Next, make sure the straps stay on your shoulders. If you’ve had problems with the straps sliding off of your shoulders, it’s a sign your band was too big.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Finally, turn around with your back to the mirror and raise your hands above your head. Your bra band should stay put. A little bit of movement is normal because you're moving, but you shouldn't need to adjust it when you put your arms back down. As I said before, a snug band will feel different, but you will get used to it. If you really, truly feel uncomfortable, move up one band size, but no more than that. And remember that cup size is proportional, so if you want to go up a band size, also go down one cup size.</span>

&nbsp;

<b>Part 5: Troubleshooting</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">So you put on the bra, the cups are your size...but there's a gap at the bottom or the front. It's weird. Rebecca, you have just told me to buy a bra that doesn't fit!</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Remember when I said there are lots of different breasts? It's still true. Let's now talk about some of the other variables you want to look at when trying on bras.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Are your breasts fuller on top or on bottom? If they are full on the top, your nipples point more toward the ground. If they're full on bottom, your nipples point up. Here's a handy guide from </span><a href="http://brasihate.blogspot.se/2013/02/clarifying-breast-shape-full-on-top-vs.html"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Bras I Hate</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">. There are different styles of bras that are cut to fit full on top vs. full on bottom breasts, so make sure you pick a style that is right for you (link).</span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Are your breasts asymmetrical? Most women are a little asymmetrical. Just make sure that the larger breast fits well in the cup. It’s okay if the other cup is a little big. If you’re asymmetry is more pronounced, you can get a bra with removable padding and put one or both pads in the cup of the smaller breast. </span><b>(A quick health note: while asymmetry is normal, new or pronounced asymmetry can be a sign of a health issue. Make sure you’ve talked to your doctor to establish what’s normal for you.)</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Are your breasts wide-set or close-set? Different bras have cups that are set closer or farther apart. I’ve tried on bras with cups that are too close-set for me and felt like the underwire was gouging my breastbone.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Are your breasts wide or narrow? Remember what I mentioned earlier about the underwire still poking you? Some bras are designed for wider or narrower breasts. It can be hard when just trying on a bra if it's too narrow. If your nipples look wrinkly when you take off your bra, then your cups are definitely too narrow, but the sales associates in the store aren't going to let you wander around in their merchandise for hours so you can figure it out. I will line up two bra cups together to see how the underwires compare. If you start out with a reference, even if it's a reference that you know is wrong for you (i.e. too wide or too narrow) you can tell if the underwire in the new bra is similar or different.</span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">At the end of the day, you want to make sure that your band fits snugly, the underwires are sitting on your ribcage (not poking any breast tissue), and that all of your breast tissue fits inside of and fills out the bra cup. If a bra doesn't fit you well, it's not you! It's the bra. It was made for someone with a different breast shape. It may take some time, but you will find a bra that is the right fit for you.</span>

&nbsp;

<b>Part 6: Resources and Stuff</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Congratulations! You have made it through a massive wall of text and you now know more about bra fit than most Victoria's Secret employees! Take some time and find a bra or two that's right for you. It feels better to wear a bra that fits correctly. It really does.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">I want to leave you with some links, both more bra fitting resources and some places where one can purchase bras in a wide variety of sizes. If you have tips or resources to add, please share them!</span>

<a href="http://www.bratabase.com/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Bratabase</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">: Users provide input on which bras fit their shape best, so you can find recommendations for bras based on ones that you know fit well. There’s also a forum to sell or exchange ill-fitting bras with other users.</span>

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.epbot.com/2013/04/everything-you-never-knew-you-needed-to.html"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Epbot</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">: This article set me on the path to learning more about bra fit.</span>

&nbsp;

<a href="https://www.reddit.com/r/ABraThatFits/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">A Bra That Fits</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">: For you redditors.</span>

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.brastop.com/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Bra Stop</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">: For cup sizes D and up. UK-based retailer that ships to the US.</span>

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.breakoutbras.com/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Breakout Bras</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">: US-based online retailer with a wide variety of sizes</span>

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.petiteplentiful.com/2014/04/guide-where-to-find-28-and-30-bands.html"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Petite &amp; Plentiful</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">: Bra manufacturer guide for small band and cup sizes.</span>
<a href="http://shop.nordstrom.com/c/womens-underwear-lingerie?dept=8000001&amp;origin=topnav"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Nordstrom Lingerie:</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Yes, I already plugged them. But I love a good deal and they offer free shipping and returns for all online orders. That’s pretty sweet.</span>

&nbsp;

Header photo: popsugar.com]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Create A Monthly Budget</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-create-a-monthly-budget/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 05 Nov 2015 00:35:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[cydney-gottlieb]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2192</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[It’s the third Friday of the month. We all know what that means — PAYCHECK! You clock out at 5pm with that sweet, sweet piece of paper in hand. <i>This is going to be a good weekend</i>…

Fast forward three days. You’re at the ATM and your balance is looking…small? But how is that possible? You just got paid on Friday. Confused, you start thinking about how you possibly could have spent that much money in three days.

Slowly, you remember. There was that late-night falafel on Saturday night. The round of drinks for everyone after your girl earned a promotion because you were feeling way generous. The new outfit you bought the day before because, duh, your three other pairs of black jeans didn’t work with the new leather halter-top that you <i>also</i> bought this week because you were feeling Posh Spice circa 1997.

<i>“All right,”</i> you say. “<i>I’ll admit that I have a problem. What should I do?”</i>

Luckily, I’m here to help you create a budget. Here’s what we’re going to do: <i> </i>

<hr />

&nbsp;
<h4>Break it down.</h4>
<strong>First, look at your income</strong>, which should be more straightforward than calculating all of your expenditures (but that comes next). What is your current employment situation? Do you receive additional checks or dividends in addition to paychecks? Are any accounts or funds accessible in case of an emergency, or are you shelving these investments and labeling them as “<a href="https://www.irs.gov/Retirement-Plans/Roth-IRAs">untouchable until age 70 ½</a>”? Do you work freelance and need to subtract money from your invoices to <a href="http://thebillfold.com/2014/03/heres-a-surefire-tax-estimating-process-for-freelancers-rebooted-and-updated/">allocate towards taxes paid</a> at the end of the year? Consider the details that contribute to the larger picture of your financial landscape.

&nbsp;

After looking at what comes in, consider what goes out. If you’re entirely unsure about where to start, look at your bank account and credit card activity, and attempt to collect all of your receipts with each completed purchase. I know that it sounds like a lot of <i>stuff </i>to hold onto, but these details are prime for noticing what you’re doing and where your money is going. Although I prefer to monitor myself with a notebook and pen in hand, there are <a href="http://www.investopedia.com/articles/personal-finance/062314/6-best-personal-finance-apps.asp">many apps out there</a> to help keep track of your personal finances and make a fiscal overview more accessible.

&nbsp;

Likewise, some digital bankcard statements can break down your purchases into categories with a <a href="http://www.barclays.co.uk/CurrentAccounts/BarclaysMoneyTools/P1242632413707">spend analyzer tool</a>. After you’ve acknowledged your (realistic over idealistic) lifestyle habits, try to filter each transaction into a “want” or “need.”  What percentage of your spending can be curtailed? Through this process, you might come to realize that the cost of all of those rainy-day Uber rides can be consolidated into a handful of subway tickets and a spunky umbrella, leaving you with enough money to try out Whole Foods this week (but we’ve still got mad love, TJ’s). Perhaps you can cook for the week, bring lunch to work, and then put the money that you save from not eating out towards purchasing something cool, like a skydiving excursion procured through Groupon.

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/Screen-Shot-2015-11-03-at-9.34.36-AM.png"><img class=" wp-image-2640 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/Screen-Shot-2015-11-03-at-9.34.36-AM-300x225.png" alt="Screen Shot 2015-11-03 at 9.34.36 AM" width="408" height="306" /></a>
<p style="text-align: center;">(Skydive Barnstable; Barnstable, MA; 2013)</p>
&nbsp;
<h4>Consider Priorities and “Needs” First</h4>
<strong>We all have a different personal barometer, so to speak, about what is essential for our lives and current needs.</strong>

Eventually, you’ll come to understand what types of purchases are meaningful for you in your life and might not need to track each transaction periodically. Shelter is key, so<a href="http://www.apartmenttherapy.com/how-much-rent-you-can-really-afford-renters-solutions-186462"> you might want to pay rent</a>. Maybe you have an insurance payment for that. Think about water, gas, electricity, Internet, cable, or other monthly bills (Netflix, Hulu, Spotify etc.).

Not everyone’s budget will be the same. For example, since I own a car and use it in my commute to work, I have to keep track of car maintenance, insurance, gasoline, and yes, even parking tickets.

&nbsp;

&nbsp;
<h4>Consider “Wants” After “Needs”</h4>
<strong>Every now and again, it is okay to afford some luxuries.</strong>

Life gets heated, and we need to kick off our shoes to cool down a little bit. A fan is obviously more affordable than an AC unit. That being said, after seven years in Boston without air-conditioning, I decided to upgrade once I moved across the river to Cambridge last September. I consciously turned this “want” into a “need”, which is now reflected in my energy bill. To combat certain costs, it is perfectly rational and acceptable to reallocate funds in order to make ends meet. For example, even though I’d like to buy a brand-new work outfit, I’m also happy thrifting for clothes if I need to upgrade my wardrobe. Shopping at second-hand establishments is generally cheaper than buying new items, plus the adventure of searching for pieces carries the added thrill-factor bonus when you find something unique <i>and</i> repurposed. Go thrift stores!

&nbsp;

&nbsp;
<h4>Consider Variables</h4>
<strong>It’s important to recognize priorities and investments within yourself, both tangible and intangible.</strong>

Wants will fluctuate, and some of these decisions will affect your monthly inputs and outputs. Fitness is essential for my well-being. I know that I’m going to spend money on yoga classes anyway, so if I can save enough money to buy a membership or class-pack (which offers reduced costs per class) then I’ll actually save a decent amount of money in the long run, even though I’m shelling out more up-front. When maintaining a fiscally independent and responsible lifestyle, it is beneficial to identify opportunities to save through deals or special offers.

&nbsp;

Sometimes I shop at TJMaxx, and sometimes I go straight for the full-price Laundry by Shelli Segal, but if so, this is a carefully planned choice rather than an impulsive buy. If you prioritize experiences and know that a vacation is approaching, it’s probably best to stay in one weekend to read a novel instead of dropping dollars on a concert. The same can be said<a href="http://www.mindbodygreen.com/0-15918/the-benefits-of-buying-in-bulk.html"> for buying certain foods or toiletries in bulk</a> and<a href="https://www.couponcabin.com/ccu/how-to-maximize-your-savings-at-cvs/"> honoring coupons or frequent-buyer discounts</a>. Depending on your situation, it also might be smart to<a href="https://studentaid.ed.gov/sa/repay-loans/consolidation"> condense student loan payments</a> or other funds into a merged transaction. It’s up to you to even out each item and add or subtract accordingly in order to meet your goal “bottom line” for each month, honoring your core needs.

&nbsp;

&nbsp;
<h4>Final Calculations</h4>
<strong>Every calculation is a learning experience, and each decision is an opportunity to adjust forthcoming situations accordingly, realigning formulas in hopes of a better result the next time around.</strong>

Each month, I compile a financial total of all of these elements listed above and include an average of other expected induced costs, such as groceries, toiletries, laundry expenses, appointment copays, and student loans payments. Ordinarily, my total dollar amount will be similar each month, so long as circumstances don’t change too often within my monthly routine.

&nbsp;

By now, you’ve determined your income and expenses subtotals. Subtract your expenses from your income and see where you land. Ideally, you’ll have a positive number, which you can throw into savings.

&nbsp;

Next, I look at any credit card balance or monthly types of rollover payments and see how much I can realistically afford to pay off while still allotting myself enough wiggle room for any unexpected purchases that might arise before my next pay-period. Keep in mind that after a certain amount of time (usually a one-year grace period), your credit card’s <a href="https://www.bankofamerica.com/credit-cards/education/what-is-credit-card-apr.go">annual percent rate (APR)</a> often increases, which means that the more money you have on your credit card, the more you will inevitably pay in order to keep that balance running.

&nbsp;

After crossing off each element from my list, I am left with a reduced number, which helps to inform me of next month’s projected starting amount before the entire cycle begins again. Still, some unexpected situations may occur, and some computations are better than others – so is life.

&nbsp;

&nbsp;
<h4>A Bonus: Consider Potential Savings</h4>
<strong>If you can afford to put money away into a savings account each month, then eventually, you might be able to invest in more long-term options to create a diversified portfolio.</strong>

If you’re already conscious of opportunities to <a href="http://www.bankrate.com/finance/savings/best-savings-accounts-for-different-age-brackets-1.aspx">save</a>, then why not create more <a href="http://www.financiallywisewomen.com/whats-the-difference-between-a-stock-bond-and-mutual-fund/">savings</a>? At this stage in our lives as young women, I will assume that the majority of readers are in good health and without children. If this projection is accurate, then <a href="https://www.mutualfundstore.com/small-large-mid-caps-market-capitalization">mutual funds</a> are most practical when deciding where to <a href="http://homeguides.sfgate.com/care-instructions-money-tree-plant-50174.html">grow your money</a>, as they appreciate quicker than bonds. Therefore, consider discounting other major lifestyle factors when budgeting in order to put away some change for the future. Let’s water our youth — we can afford some risk and excitement!

&nbsp;

You might like to use the <a href="http://www.investopedia.com/articles/07/sharpe_ratio.asp">Sharpe Ratio</a>,<a href="http://www.investopedia.com/articles/07/sharpe_ratio.asp"> but I’m not too keen on </a><a href="https://investor.vanguard.com/investing/investment-calculator">math</a><a href="http://www.investopedia.com/articles/07/sharpe_ratio.asp">, so I</a>, try to adjust my accounts according to this investment formula:

Domestic:
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;">40% S&amp;P 500 Index: blue-chip capitalization stocks within the United States</li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;">10% Mid-Cap Core: Mid-sized companies within the United States, combining equal parts (50% each) growth and value</li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;">10% Small-Cap Core: Small-sized companies within the United States, combining equal parts (50% each) growth and value</li>
</ul>
International:
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;">30% Developed mutual funds within the international marketplace</li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;">10% Developing mutual funds within the international marketplace</li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"></li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

This standard textbook formula will ebb and flow but should still garner substantial gains over time. Although it is difficult to honor these percentages when just starting out and with limited cash flow, you should see optimal results if you are able to recalibrate your mutual funds to this ratio once a year.

&nbsp;

On the contrary, maybe you decide to forgo traditional savings structures to pool your money towards a personal artistic project or someone else’s <a href="http://www.cuppow.com/pages/about">kooky idea</a>. It’s difficult to organize our own thoughts, let alone monitor everyday activity and understand why we do the things that we do. Nonetheless, in the same way that we eventually become aware of certain ideas hidden deep within our subconscious as we grow older, it is possible to focus and extract information about our personal habits if significant enough for our own needs and overall productivity. If you feel that a different type of venture is right for you, then go for it!

&nbsp;

Remember, your personhood requires care in the same way that a major company oversees multiple departments, each with its own annual budget and expected + projected revenue. Activity is often reconciled once per month in order to ensure that the organization can move forward accordingly and prosper in the future. Keep those overdraft protection fees to a minimum and keep yourself in check with self-love!

&nbsp;
<h4></h4>
<h4>Invest in Yourself</h4>
<strong>However we decide best, it’s essential to recalibrate our worth from time to time and reorder what is in front of us.</strong>

If you’re anything like I am, you know exactly where you’ve burred certain papers, books, clothes etc. even though your room might look like a mess. My mind is organized chaos, and so is my financial situation, but they’re both healthy because I’ve found models that work well for me. Personally, I find that a monthly system is the way to go, much like honoring the natural female cycle or energies of<a href="http://allnaturalme.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/IMG_4647.jpg"> moon phases</a> (Yes, I’m this crunchy).

&nbsp;

Of course, this applies to money too. Perhaps you’ve heard this concept before, but some say that a woman is not truly independent until she can generate her own currency and honor her self-worth. It’s empowering to see so many women take charge of their independence (<a href="http://sfaq.us/2015/06/art-as-asset-financialization-and-the-art-market/">Sarah Meyohas</a> for<a href="http://www.bitchcoin.biz/"> Bitch Coin</a>, anyone?), and the best way to take ahold of your future is to know the terrain in front of you. Find what makes you bet on yourself, and invest carefully. Purchase power is real, and so are the <a href="http://www.forbes.com/sites/maggiemcgrath/2015/09/09/desperate-and-in-debt-30-of-millennials-would-sell-an-organ-to-get-rid-of-student-loans/">perils of debt</a>, so let’s be mindful when taking control of our lives and finances, which are inextricably linked.

&nbsp;

“<a href="http://time.com/money/3703658/an-artist-mints-her-own-take-on-bitcoin/">If you’re a woman who is taking a stake in your future and aggressive, you’re a bitch</a>,” says Meyohas.

Take pride in pushing forward to redefine what it means to be a stable woman, noting what we’re giving and taking while also making sure that there’s enough in the bank to support ourselves (physically, emotionally, etc.).  We can choose to rewash at times to conserve resources, but it’s also completely okay to indulge, so long as we buy and consume thoughtfully, spending on our own productions while honoring others’ efforts. Do celebrate that promotion! Maybe a brunch smoothie favor of a possible hangover?

&nbsp;

Wale says that “<a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L9TeasapYJ8">balance a bitch</a>”, and when it comes down to the<a href="http://articles.bplans.com/the-bottom-line-in-business/"> bottom line</a>, I thoroughly support learning when to edit and when to elaborate, investing in her/your/my/their/our individual worth.  hen you notice that your pockets are filling up with quarters from past purchases, pass on this abundance to somebody else whom might need to do laundry after a long shift or invest in a little change within. <strong>#ownit.</strong>

<img class="alignnone wp-image-2643" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/Screen-Shot-2015-11-03-at-11.11.33-AM-284x300.png" alt="Screen Shot 2015-11-03 at 11.11.33 AM" width="186" height="196" />

(Source: <a href="http://www.mzaremba.com/">Matthew Zaremba</a>)

&nbsp;

Header Photo: graphicfairy.com]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Make a Flower Bouquet Last Longer</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-make-a-flower-bouquet-last-longer/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 27 Sep 2015 18:51:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[karissa-chamblin]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2209</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h6 style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Receiving flowers from someone or buying them for yourself is such a wonderful feeling, don’t you think?</span></h6>
&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;"> I've said this before, but they are such a timeless gift. I mean, what’s not to love, right? So to keep that bouquet looking lovely and full of life longer, here are some super simple tips to help you out.</span>

<hr />

&nbsp;

<strong style="color: inherit; font-family: Montserrat, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; line-height: 1.1;">1.CHOP.</strong>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Flower stems can seal up over time which makes it harder for them to gulp up water. To avoid dehydration, give your stems a nice chop every 1-2 days. An inch will do. Use sharp scissors and immediately place them back in water.</span>

&nbsp;

<strong>2.FRESH WATER.</strong>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Change the vase water every time you chop your stems. Clean, lukewarm tap water will do just fine. If your bouquet came with a packet of flower preservatives, sprinkle a little in the water every time you change it. </span>

&nbsp;
<h6><strong>3.LIGHT.</strong></h6>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">The sun is a bouquet’s worst enemy. Direct sunlight will make your flowers droop and turn into mush. It will also heat up the water and stink up your house. Make sure your bouquet is out of direct sunlight and in a place where it doesn't get too warm.</span>

&nbsp;
<h6><strong>4.MIST.</strong></h6>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Many flowers, especially hydrangeas, like hydration through their petals. A light mist from a spray bottle on the blooms, or petals of the flowers, every couple of days can help keep your flowers pretty and hydrated. </span>

<hr />
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">This may seem high-maintenance but it’s really worth it! Just these few simple tricks can add a few days to your fleeting bouquet of goodness!</span></p>
Just remember, cut flowers do not last very long, so don’t feel bad when they call it quits.

Enjoy them while you can!]]></content:encoded>
