		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Spell Out Words Over The Phone</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-spell-out-words-over-the-phone/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 02 Oct 2015 22:26:30 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[CAITLYN]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2238</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">The struggle is real when you’re on the phone with a friendly customer service representative and they just CANNOT understand if you’re saying S or F - and was that a T, V, B, P, or C? (Yes, ma’am - I was absolutely hoping to send flowers to Fusan, not Susan, thanks!)</span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">To avoid these confusions, I noticed that people asked, “Is that S as in Sierra or F as in Foxtrot?” To me, this method seemed amazing, but I always felt intense pressure to remember a single word that started with the letter I needed when it was my turn.</span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Throughout my adult life, I have said the following (to the bemusement of many a phone operator):</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">O as in “old person”</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">F as in “**long pause**…**Don’t say a curse word to sweet Ruth from AT&amp;T.**…</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">
</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">.**Don’t say a curse word**…..“F….F…F as in Footloose?”</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">R as in “Ravioli”</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">S as in “Spaghetti”</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">M as in “Macaroni”</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">(I like pasta)</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">H as in “Heck yes”</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">And the list goes on.</span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">It was when my boss walked by my desk at the exact moment I told the credit card company “S as in Storage Wars” that I decided something needed to change. And fast.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Luckily, I found out that there is an </span><b>official,</b><span style="font-weight: 400;"> internationally recognized designation for each letter of the English alphabet to be used EXACTLY for this purpose. As a gift to you, my fellow young cubicle warriors, behold – the </span><a href="http://life.itu.int/radioclub/rr/ap14.htm"><span style="font-weight: 400;">ITU Phonetic Alphabet and Figure Codes</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> for each letter of the alphabet.</span>

&nbsp;
<table>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td><b>Letter to be transmitted</b></td>
<td><b>Code word to be used</b></td>
<td><b>Spoken as *</b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b>A</b></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Alfa</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">AL</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> FAH</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b>B</b></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Bravo</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">BRAH</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> VOH</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b>C</b></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Charlie</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">CHAR</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> LEE or </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">SHAR</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> LEE</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b>D</b></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Delta</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">DELL</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> TAH</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b>E</b></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Echo</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">ECK</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> OH</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b>F</b></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Foxtrot</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">FOKS </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">TROT</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b>G</b></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Golf</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">GOLF</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b>H</b></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Hotel</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">HOH </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">TELL</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b>I</b></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">India</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">IN</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> DEE AH</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b>J</b></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Juliet</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">JEW</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> LEE </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">ETT</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b>K</b></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Kilo</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">KEY</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> LOH</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b>L</b></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Lima</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">LEE</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> MAH</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b>M</b></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Mike</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">MIKE</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b>N</b></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">November</span></td>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Study Like A Pro (Part I)</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-study-like-a-pro/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 09 Oct 2015 02:56:41 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[diana-chen]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2319</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Coming into UCLA, fall quarter of my freshman year was a bit of a reality check.  Having been babied for most of my high school career, the workload and competition that came with being a student here hit me like a ton of bricks.  However, thanks to some great friends, TAs, and professors, and a passion for what I was learning, I was able to develop the necessary skills to help me navigate my courses. With so many tips, I decided to share <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-study-like-a-pro-pt-2/"><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>TWO articles</strong></span></a> with you all, so be sure to <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-study-like-a-pro-pt-2/">check out part two here</a>.

&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 20px;"><b>Memorization</b></span>

To be blunt, you will need to memorize things in college.  As an undergraduate, your courses will likely serve as the foundations to the basics of your major and as introductions to areas in your major that you can specialize in as a graduate student.  Of course, there are exceptions to this such as engineering and computer science majors.  Chances are you <i>will</i> have to take a handful of courses which cover an abundance of information in a short period of time. That’s when you need to memorize.

While it is common knowledge that memorization involves repetition, the way in which you employ repetition plays a significant role in how effectively information is solidified.  In a course I took in cognitive psychology last year, my professor covered a few proven strategies on how to consolidate information efficiently.

&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 20px;"><b>Distributed Studying</b></span>

The first is the advantage of distributed studying over massed studying.  In other words, spacing your studying out is advantageous over cramming at the last minute.  This is a no brainer, but there are also a few nuanced things you can do to make distributed, or spaced, studying even more effective.

For starters, not all topics you have to study are created equal. The rule of thumb is to make harder items harder to study<b> </b>(I’ll explain this in a bit) and not to devote undue time to “easier” items that are already consolidated.  For instance, a thing I used to do in high school when studying with flashcards was to repeatedly go through all of them, thus viewing each card an equal number of times.  However, what I’ve found to be much more effective in college when using flashcards for biology and psychology classes is to touch on harder-to-consolidate items more often but in varying contexts and to focus on easier (consolidated) items less often and as a refresher.  Thanks to technology, you can find apps, such as those at <a href="https://quizlet.com">Quizlet</a>, that can produce this process for you.  However, there is much <a href="http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/a-learning-secret-don-t-take-notes-with-a-laptop/">evidence to support the advantage of active studying methods (writing notes, drawing diagrams) over passive ones (typing notes, looking at Powerpoints).     </a>

A few ways to make harder items “harder” to study are to change up the setting in which you review these items (dorm, library, porch), to review these items studying new (perhaps unrelated) information, and to review these items during parts of your daily routine not set aside for studying (i.e. when you’re on a jog or eating a snack).  Essentially, by changing up the context in which you retrieve information, you are creating more mental pathways from which you can retrieve the same piece of information.  You establish way more cues that can remind you of the information you need to recall by making harder items harder to study than if you were to study them the same as easier items. This means that you can <i>more easily arrive at the desired piece of information.  By making retrieval itself more difficult (e.g. reviewing harder items after studying other topics), you are consolidating mental pathways that already exist so that, when the time comes, you can more quickly arrive at the desired piece of information.   </i>

&nbsp;

So far, we’ve established a theme of <b>ease of access</b> when it comes to memorization.  My success in memory-based classes has come when I’ve abided by this overarching concept.  As a senior, I’m about halfway into all of my required upper division courses, which I’ve found to be more specialized and integrated than lower division classes.  Therefore, I’ve had to develop a more integrated way of studying.

&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 20px;"><b>Chunking</b></span>

First, I learned (and became obsessed with) a method called chunking, which is basically a sneaky way of storing more information in your brain.  Say you’re going on a trip to Paris during Fashion Week and you want to bring all of your most stylish belongings with you but you don’t want to pay the baggage fees.  Think of your belongings as pieces of information and the TSA one carry-on limit as how much information your brain can hold at one time.  Unfortunately, your beautiful fashion accessories fill up three bags.  Yet, dead set on avoiding extraneous baggage fees, you <i>wear</i> all the clothing in your two extra bags.  So, what was originally four items moves through security as two (you and your carry-on).  Chunking related pieces of information together to create one mental item is a memory shortcut that works similarly.  The goal is to tie pieces of information together so that the retrieval of any one piece leads to the retrieval of all the other pieces.<b> </b>

Since chunking is basically making strong connections, there are various ways you can do it.  A few ways I chunk, or make connections, are by creating visual diagrams, color coding, and using mnemonic devices and memory palaces.

&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 20px;"><b>Visual Diagrams</b></span>
<p style="text-align: center;"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-2334" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/image00-768x1024.png" alt="Study Tips" width="575" height="766" /><span style="font-size: 12px;">In the above diagram, chunk A and chunk B are the final large chunks I consolidated to aid my memory.  However, I began by creating and connecting smaller chunks to form these large chunks.  A1, A2, A2.2, A3</span></p>
Most often, I will create visual diagrams of interconnected pieces of information when studying for memory-laden tests.  When it comes to smaller bits of information that are relevant to a larger concept that I’m already familiar with, I’ll “hang” them onto the chunk that embodies the familiar larger concept.  For instance, my younger sister just told me the other day that she bought some dark blue nail polish.  While this information is new, it’d be easy for me to recall in the future because I know my sister very well.  I know that her favorite color is blue (so it makes sense that she bought blue nail polish) and that she grew up on the coast (so it makes sense that her favorite color is blue).  I also know that she’s very into cosmetics, so it also connects, for this reason, that she bought nail polish.  Now, if you think of all these pieces of information (my sister’s favorite color is blue, my sister is into cosmetics) as boxes and the connections between them as arrows, a visual diagram is made.

Because the concept of my sister is a familiar one, I simply needed to add this new piece of knowledge I gained about her onto what I already knew.  However, I don’t have this luxury when I study concepts that are unfamiliar to me.  Instead, I have to create chunks from scratch.

The good news is, college courses are tried and tested and thus usually build on one another.  This means that you’ll likely have a few pieces of knowledge from other courses to build your “new chunk” on.  Unlike familiar chunks, new chunks are more like the interviewee sitting in front of you at your influential company (sigh, a girl can dream).  While the resume you’ve already reviewed gave you some information on her experience, interests, and perhaps demographics, it is not until you’ve completed your interview that you are able to form a holistic impression of your potential employee by tying in what you <i>learned</i> about her with what you already <i>knew</i> about her.  It also follows that you didn’t form your overall impression of your interviewee right after the interview.  You probably went home and reviewed her resume and what you learned about her during the interview, finding relationships between the things you’ve read and the things she told you.  Only after this process do you have a coherent understanding of who your interviewee is.  And, when her name is later brought up, it is this holistic impression of her, with all the details tied in, which comes to mind.  Now, apply this to neurobiology and voilà, one question about acetylcholine release may remind you of many more muscle-contraction-related answers to come.

&nbsp;

The tips don't end here ladies! <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-study-like-a-pro-pt-2/">Be sure to check out <span style="text-decoration: underline;">part two</span> and let me know if you have any other suggestions!</a>

&nbsp;

Header Photo: CMB.org]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Save Money on Your Energy Bill</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-save-money-on-your-energy-bill/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 19 Oct 2015 02:11:49 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[krisha-agatep]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2382</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you’re anything like me, you probably don’t think twice about how much energy you’re using at home on a daily basis. Then, suddenly, that summer heat wave hits, and next month’s energy bill is $20 higher than it usually is. Fortunately, there is much that can be done to reduce energy usage and cut down your cost of living. Now, I’m not saying that we should all eat dinner by candlelight and hand wash/dry all our laundry, but you’d be surprised how much these simple energy saving hacks can save you money in the long run!</span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 20px;"><b>Promote Better Airflow</b></span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">According the </span><a href="http://energy.gov/public-services/homes/heating-cooling"><span style="font-weight: 400;">U.S. Department of Energy</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">heating and cooling account for about 48% of the energy use in a typical U.S. home. So, when turning on your heating or cooling system, it’s important to </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">remember this fact: heat rises. For us Southern Californians that only know two seasons (moderately temperate winter/spring/fall and flames of hell scorching-hot summer), it’s very tempting to keep that AC on full blast or have three fans directed at your face at all times. You can definitely still do that, but if you want to save some money, try strategically directing your air with a floor fan. If the goal is to cool the room, try placing your fan on the ground directed upward so that the cooler air mixes in with the hot air and bounces off the ceiling or wall, circulating cooler air in the room.</span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you are fortunate enough to have central AC in your apartment or house, be sure to turn off the AC when you leave during the day and create a cave effect with your home by closing all your windows and blinds to keep the cool air trapped. That way when you get back, you’ll be less tempted to turn on the AC or fan. </span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">To stay warm in the winter, you’ll want to look for any open windows or cracks that will let any of the warm air out. Or, if you have a ceiling fan, turn the fan on the lowest setting to circulate the warmer air around the room rather than running your heating system all day.</span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 20px;"><b>Turn Off Appliances</b></span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">While plugged in appliances and chargers won’t rack up your energy bill by significant amounts, turning off your appliances is still one easy way to save money in the long run. Some devices, like computers or televisions, still use energy even when they’re turned off. So, try plugging multiple devices into a power strip to make it easier to turn off or unplug multiple appliances at once.</span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 20px;"><b>Save With the Flip of a Switch</b></span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">It’s no secret that turning off the lights when you leave the room can reduce the amount of energy used. But we can make our lighting choices even smarter by switching to </span><a href="http://energy.gov/energysaver/articles/lighting-choices-save-you-money"><span style="font-weight: 400;">halogen incandescent, CFL, and LED light bulbs</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">. Also, when decorating your room, think about placing lamps in a corner so that the light reflects off of two walls, creating more light in the room. Remember that darker walls absorb more light, so painting your walls lighter colors will brighten up the room, especially in the daytime, when light shines through.</span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 20px;"><b>Get Creative in the Kitchen</b><span style="font-weight: 400;">
</span></span><span style="font-weight: 400;">Try out some of these great </span><a href="http://greatist.com/health/healthy-crock-pot-recipes"><span style="font-weight: 400;">slow cooker recipes</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> for an easy and healthy meal. I know you might be thinking, “Aren’t those things plugged in all day? How does that save energy?” It turns out that crockpots run with </span><a href="http://sustainableliving.uconn.edu/articles/crockpots.php"><span style="font-weight: 400;">lower wattage</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> than conventional electric ovens. Plus, cooking with a crockpot saves you time when you get home from a long day of work or school.</span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Also, salads don’t take very much prep time and are a great way to save on oven or stove usage. Try some of these </span><a href="http://www.food.com/slideshow/quick-easy-cold-salads-102/asian-chicken-salad-3"><span style="font-weight: 400;">delicious salads</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> that surpass the average lettuce/dressing combo.</span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Got any other great energy saving tips? Let us know in the comments below! </span>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Study Like A Pro (Part II)</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-study-like-a-pro-pt-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 16 Oct 2015 02:43:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[diana-chen]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2401</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[So you've mastered<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-study-like-a-pro/"> <span style="color: #000000;"><strong>visual diagrams, chunking, </strong>and <strong>distributed studying</strong><strong>; </strong></span></a>what's next? Check out some more study strategies for those late nights at the library. PS: If you haven't already, be sure to check out part one of my study tips <span style="text-decoration: underline; color: #ffcc00;"><strong><a style="color: #ffcc00; text-decoration: underline;" href="http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-study-like-a-pro/">here</a></strong></span>.

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/Textliner-Highlighters.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-2378 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/Textliner-Highlighters.jpg" alt="Textliner-Highlighters" width="454" height="282" /></a>

<span style="font-size: 20px;"><b>Color Code</b></span>

Sometimes, when I’m taking notes on a textbook that skips around a lot or when I have a professor whose lectures build on multiple previous concepts, I’ll color code to organize the different things I learn into separate wholes.  For example, if I’ve taken some foundational notes on thresholds, detection, and motion from previous lectures in my course on “sensation and perception”, I can assign the colors blue, yellow, and green to these topics respectively and code future items related to these topics in such a way.  If I’m taking notes on paper, I usually color code my bullet points and underline important headings in different colors.  When I take notes on my computer, I’ve found the highlighter tool very useful for color-coding.

&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 20px;"><b>Mnemonic Device</b></span>

Sometimes, when I’ve found some topics too difficult to interconnect effectively or I have not had enough time to form diagrams or color code, mnemonic devices help me out a lot.  Mnemonics don’t require making strong connections between the items of information they contain.  They simplify difficult-to-grasp objects into forms and patterns that are more familiar and easier for your brain to retain.  You’ve most likely heard of auditory mnemonic devices that condense information into easy-to-remember sayings such as “Every Good Boy Deserves Fudge” to memorize the keys corresponding to the lines of the treble clef  (E, G, B, D, F) or “King Phillip Comes Over For Good Spaghetti” to memorize taxonomic groupings of the animal kingdom in descending order (Kingdom, Phylum, Class, Order, Family, Genus, Species).

&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 20px;"><b>Memory Palaces</b></span>

While I have found it helpful to create auditory mnemonic devices to memorize information last-minute, when I have <i>slightly</i> more time and a bit more information I need to retain, I’d much rather use memory palaces.  Trivia fact:  many people who take part in memory competitions utilize memory palaces to remember vast amounts of information.  Basically, a memory palace is, well, a palace of memories.  Otherwise known as the <i>method of loci</i>, this technique involves imagining a place or “palace” with many different locations and the items you need to memorize as objects in certain locations within this place.

Say I want to memorize the different types of biomes and their principal characteristics.  I can start by getting familiar with the biomes so that I can imagine them as postcards of landscapes that display their characteristics.  Then, instead of becoming overwhelmed and viewing these biomes as postcards in a box that I have to take mental snapshots of, I can take these images out of my box and distribute them around my imaginary house.  I can put the picture of the taiga in my mother’s room, because its verdant piney landscape reminds me of the cities I’ve grown up in, and I can put a picture of the tropical rainforest in my sister’s room next to the already hanging photos of our family vacationing in the tropics of Mexico—and so forth.  When I need to think back and retrieve these items, I can walk back through my house and let cues related to my mother’s room bring up the image of the taiga and cues related to my sister’s room bring up the image of the tropical rainforest.  If I cannot recall the image of the tropical rainforest, I can think back to the pictures hanging on my sister’s wall, think about what was hanging <i>next</i> to them, and voilà, rainforest.

&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 20px;"><b>Critical Thinking</b></span>

Luckily, your courses in college will become more integrative as time goes on and require more critical thinking.  Memory techniques may not be efficient or even sufficient for studying for upper divs. I say <i>luckily</i> because learning to study for critical-thinking based classes will help you become a more practical thinker which is very conducive to real life.  Since it is critical thinking that we’re talking about, there’s only one way to go about it.  You must first form and consolidate those deep connections we’ve been talking about.  Then, you need to practice applying this knowledge to real life problems.  Instead of giving you very specific advice, I’m just going to reveal a few pieces of wisdom I’ve gained in the past four years.

First, it’s all about <b>comprehension</b> and <b>familiarity</b>.  The chunking method we’ve talked about has a lot to do with comprehension—seeing relationships between items to understand cause and effect.  However, especially when it comes to S.T.E.M. (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) courses, it is often not enough to simply comprehend why or how something functions a certain way.  Just because you understand how multiple integration works doesn’t mean you’ll be able to come up with the nuanced solution required for its problem on your <i>timed </i>midterm.  If there’s anything I learned taking all my lower division math courses, it’s that “aha” moments can be fleeting.  To be able to anticipate the steps to take just by looking at the <i>design</i> of the problem you’re faced with—to have an instinct as to which out of, say, five possible methods will most likely (and most quickly) lead you to the answer—under a time limit, you need to practice, practice, practice<b> </b>to build that familiarity.

To ease the comprehension process, it’s very important to be proactive about your own learning.  At the end of the day, <i>you are your best teacher,</i> and your professors and TA’s are <i>resources</i> for knowledge.  If you don’t understand topics from your professor’s lectures or simply find a professor’s teaching style hard to follow, you can turn to your TA.  If your TA isn’t helpful, you can turn to a specialized tutoring group for your subject or form a study group.  Or, you can do what I usually do: use the Internet.  Sites like <a href="https://www.khanacademy.org/">KhanAcademy</a> and <a href="http://www.wolframalpha.com/">Wolfram Alpha</a> offer diverse tutorials on a wealth of subjects to suit your learning style.  When I had trouble envisioning RNA transcription from my biology professor’s lectures, a Youtube video visually demonstrating the process was a lifesaver.  When I’ve needed background information on a specific function or program, I’ve even found sites like <a href="https://www.wikipedia.org/">Wikipedia</a> conducive to forming a more integrated concept of the item at hand (but make sure to fact check!).

Secondly, you’ve got to apply what you learn to real life.  I mean, what else is tuition for?  I’ve found doing this to be truly helpful in the consolidation of any knowledge I have.  A lot of the time, these “real life applications” can be to things you learn in other classes.  For instance, I was able to gain a more nuanced understanding of a certain statistical test we used in my Stats 101 class by applying knowledge I had from a previous class on matrices.  This also works the other way around:  to improve comprehension, you can apply what you know to the things you’re learning.  For instance, I was able to comprehend exponential growth models more easily in my calculus class by thinking back to knowledge I had on ecology.  By relating the formulas I was learning to <i>known examples</i> of fish populations and their characteristics, I was not only able to comprehend them more quickly, but more effectively.

&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 20px;"><b>Test Banks</b></span>

The test bank is your friend.  If there’s one thing I’ve learned in college, it is that it separates the wise from the unwise.  Whether it’s from a test bank at your school, fraternity or the Internet<b>, </b>getting the scoop on past tests can be the difference between an A and a B.  My grades overall in mathematics have gone up an entire letter grade when I started making the bulk of my studying be analyzing past tests/test problems.

There are a couple things that I’ve learned to be wary of when working through past tests.  First, pay attention to your professor’s testing style.  Do they stick by the book?  In other words, are test questions very similar to practice questions from your textbook or homework?  Are questions conceptual or computational? Do questions follow a certain pattern of difficulty?  (For instance, many of the math tests I’ve taken have had three foundational problems followed by two tricky ones and a very easy one at the end.)  Considering these factors may save you valuable time studying as well as during the test.  Second, make sure to work through the difficult questions from your homework and past tests so you can get a good idea of how your professor likes to trip students up.  In computational tests, this is usually a key method or step in problem solving that allows for smoothly finding the answer to a difficult problem.  In conceptual tests, this is usually a set of questions that follow a pattern of pointing you to an incorrect “trap” answer when the real answer involves a more nuanced understanding of the topic.  These “street smarts” come in handy in college and the real world alike.

&nbsp;
<h6 style="text-align: center;">Well, this about sums up the wisdom I gained through three years of college.</h6>
<h6 style="text-align: center;"> I feel old saying this, but don’t make the same mistakes I did and <strong><i>make me proud</i>!</strong></h6>
<p style="text-align: center;"></p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>The Winging It Spotlight: KSSOLiFe on How To Launch a Business (with Purpose!)</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/the-winging-it-spotlight-kssolife-on-how-to-start-a-business-with-purpose/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 16 Oct 2015 04:00:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Contributor Coordinator]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2411</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 16px; color: #008000;"><em>The Winging It Girls' Guide has a new series spotlighting awesome women winging it out there. Our goal is to highlight that <strong>ALL</strong> inspiring women have started from square one before finding their success. There are obstacles, triumphs and mistakes - but it's the <strong>winging it moments</strong> in between that matter the most and <strong>make it all worth it.</strong></em></span>

<hr />

Hey everyone - <strong><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/author/caitlin-cohen/">Caitlin Cohen</a></strong> here!

&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 16px;">I sat down with the all-female team behind <span style="color: #ffcc00;"><a style="color: #ffcc00;" href="https://www.facebook.com/kssolife?ref=hl">KSSOLiFe</a></span>, a lifestyle brand based in Austin, TX. <span style="color: #ffcc00;"><a style="color: #ffcc00;" href="http://kssolife.com">KSSOLiFe</a></span> focuses on clothing, documentaries, social campaigns, philanthropy work, and awareness of the world around you, and everything they do is centered around the idea that love has the power to change the world.  </span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 16px;">Kris S (KS), Lani Helm (LH), and Stephanie Forsythe (SF) founded KSSOLiFe earlier this year, and the response they’re getting is impressive.  Lani, KSSO’s head of social media, has been a friend of mine since 2001, and I was excited to sit down with the entire team to hear about starting the company from the ground up, being accepted to their first start-up conference and all the wingin’ it moments in between. Read below to hear them passionately discuss their company, how it came about, and what they see for its future.</span>

<hr />

&nbsp;

<b>KSSOLiFe’s tagline is More Than Just a Brand.  What does that mean to you?</b>

<b>KS:  </b><span style="font-weight: 400;">The reason why we say we’re “more than just a brand” is because we’re beyond just clothing or products or accessories. We’re really focused on bringing awareness to everyday issues, starting with “what does lifestyle mean to you,” “where are your clothes coming from,” overall what fair trade is, the importance of sustainable clothing, the impact that that has on our natural resources and why that’s so imperative that we use these sustainable methods in order to become a more global-conscience society.</span>

&nbsp;

<b>SF:  </b><span style="font-weight: 400;">Kris approached me months ago with an idea for a way to impact people through her love of fashion and industry. My goal was to connect with people and push the desire to make their lives better. In turn, it makes our world better. I jumped at the chance to be a part of KSSOLiFe. I think that getting in and infiltrating people’s way of thinking is the way to go.  You have to start somewhere to foster change, why not with branding that people will actually wear and think about? To me it means unity and everything that falls under that umbrella term.</span>

&nbsp;

<b>LH:  </b><span>What I like about the idea is that it’s kind of mainstreaming being aware of your surroundings.  People love clothing.  </span><i><span>People get excited about that.</span></i><span>  And if we could put a message into that, and reel in people that aren’t gonna necessarily want to sit around and watch documentaries, but they are interested in being part of the solution, then we’re carrying out our brand and our mission.</span>

&nbsp;

<b>Kris, I know you had a full-time job before leaving to focus on starting KSSOLiFe. What was the catalyst, then, for just deciding to leave the ‘safety’ of that behind and going to start KSSOLiFe?</b>

<b>KS:  </b><span style="font-weight: 400;">Well, I loved my old job.  I credit them for a lot of my growth.  They taught me a lot about leadership, management, all that stuff.  I’ve just always had a passion for clothing, so it just kind of made sense that gaining the knowledge and experience in leadership combined with my 10 years of customer service, I just felt ready to take on something bigger.</span>

&nbsp;

<b>Lani, your focus is on social media.  Was the Love Can’t Stop campaign your idea?  What other campaigns are you able to talk to us about?</b>

<b>LH:  </b><span style="font-weight: 400;">We had originally had this idea to do a special needs campaign, and have proceeds from the campaign go to the Special Olympics, so we started doing that; in the meantime we launched the website because we were preparing for this campaign, and Kris and a couple of friends happened to be at a show where they meet a little girl named Jo - rhyme not intended - and she drew a picture that said “Love Can’t Stop.” Kris took a picture of it and it was kind of like, “This has to be our first campaign.”  “Love Can’t Stop.”  Because it is one of the core values that we do have, and it’s our first and foremost value, above everything.  </span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;">So that kind of took off, and “Love Can’t Stop” was, in my eyes, the perfect way to kick this off, because it’s something that everybody can get involved in. We ask that people write out or draw a picture of “Love Can’t Stop,” and I’ve had people text it to us, or just posting it with the hashtags.  We have hashtags that are #KSSO, #KSSOLiFe, and then, you know, #LoveCan’tStop.  </span>

&nbsp;

<b>If you were giving advice to a young woman who wanted to start a company today, what would you say?  What have you learned from your journey so far?</b>

<b>KS:  </b><span style="font-weight: 400;">Well, I’ve learned so much.  Number one, don’t ever put yourself into limitations.  Just because you’ve never done it before doesn’t mean you can’t do it.  And you truly, truly need to believe in what you’re doing.  You really have to put that purpose first, and everything else has to be secondary.  You can’t ever stray from that.</span>

&nbsp;

<b>LH:  </b><span style="font-weight: 400;">I’ve learned lot.  It trips me out that it’s only been two months tops.  I think it’s opened my eyes to a lot of things that are initially ingrained in us.  You want to look for love, you want to respect others and search for equality and all these things, but now that this is something that I’m supposed to represent 24/7, it makes me look at things completely differently.  I see beauty in things.  I get stoked on things more than I used to a few months ago.  I learned how to have a relationship with my best friend.  We’re getting the respect that we feel like we’re giving out.  People want to be involved and do better, I think people don’t really know how.  I’m excited to be a leader in something that’s just different.  It baffles me that the idea of making the world a better place is outside of people’s comfort zones.  I’ve done a lot of growing up in the last few years in general, and now I feel like I get to put those changes and that mentality to life.</span>

&nbsp;

<b>SF:  </b><span style="font-weight: 400;">You put into the universe what you would like to get out of it. I asked for a job where I could be a part of something I believed in and could make a difference. I am convinced that if we can just remind people of who they can be and who they have always wanted to be, we can change our world. What better way than to push them to be better? The way we do. Because let’s face it, we need something that is more than just a brand. We need a purpose and KSSOLiFe is here to remind us of what that is and ignite our passion to live it.</span>

<hr />

&nbsp;
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Read the KSSOLiFe Founders’ original TWIGG How-To’s inspired by their start-up journey below:</span></p>
&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400;"><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-move-out-of-state/"><strong>How-To Move Out of State</strong> </a>by Lani Helm</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;"><strong><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-reinvent-and-simplify-your-life/">How-To Reinvent and Simplify Your Life</a></strong> by Stephanie Forsythe</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;"><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-stay-balanced-in-the-midst-of-a-big-life-change/"><strong>How-To Stay Balanced In the Midst of a Big Life Change</strong> </a> by Kris S.</span>

<hr />

&nbsp;
<h6 style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">P.S. - Are you a wingin’ it lady itching to start your own business?

	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;"><strong><a href="http://fortune.com/2015/04/25/clara-shih-starting-your-own-business/">How much would you sacrifice to start your own business?</a> </strong>via Fortune</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><strong><a href="http://www.businessinsider.com/a-female-startup-founder-reveals-the-hardest-part-about-starting-your-own-company-as-a-woman-2014-11">A Female Startup Founder Reveals The Hardest Part About Starting Your Own Company As A Woman</a> </strong>via Business Insider</li>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Move Out of State</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-move-out-of-state/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 16 Oct 2015 05:47:11 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Lani Helm]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2431</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/How-To-Move-Out-Of-State.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2519 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/How-To-Move-Out-Of-State-300x192.jpg" alt="How To- Move Out Of State" width="300" height="192" /></a>

About a year ago, I made a huge change; this came with no warning to myself or those around me.
<h6 style="text-align: center;"><span style="color: #339966;"><strong> I decided to move from Southern California to Austin, Texas. </strong></span></h6>
My partner at the time had moved to Austin and many signs in my life (my house selling, my family moving, boredom with my job) had begun to point me towards taking a risk and moving elsewhere as well. Though this decision was rash, I had a firm grasp on what I wanted to gain out of life and made sure Austin had that to offer me. I needed to save money, make money, have friends, a social scene, and be somewhere where I could feel “new” and have adventure and continuous opportunities awaiting me. Which brings me to
<h6>1.) <strong>Make sure your destination has potential to set you up for success both physically and </strong><strong>mentally. </strong></h6>
I knew that Austin was a cheaper alternative to California; money has always been a huge stressor for me. Austin also had different laws and education programs in their school district, which would allow me to be in the classroom sooner than in CA. (I am studying to be a teacher.) There were also certain jobs that I was looking into that would pay up to $5 more an hour than in CA. Finally, Austin is prominent for being “weird,” how much more perfect could that be for me? So many things for me to discover and an amazing social scene to entertain my ADHD. Do your research, even if you’re short on decision time.
<h6><strong>2.) Research and apply for housing.</strong></h6>
Before we arrived, I asked around for the best parts of town that were affordable, then I google mapped what areas were within reasonable distance to downtown and the airport, etc. After comparing prices with all of my top contenders, my future roommate and I applied for housing. Once we had an address we were able to...
<h6><strong>3.) Apply for jobs ASAP</strong></h6>
I looked up everything and anything I could qualify for even if I didn’t want it. Better to be temporarily employed someplace you’re not really into than to be stressing about needing a job amongst all the other things you need to do when you first arrive. I had 3 interviews before I had even left California. I was employed by my second day in Austin :) Sigh of relief.
<h6><strong>4.) Bring only what you absolutely need</strong></h6>
If you're a hoarder like me, this does not come easily. I packed everything I thought I “could not live without” FIRST. I did a couple practice rounds of packing the car to know how much space I would have left after the essentials. Basically it came down to, “if I can buy it again, I’m selling it now.” With the money I had began saving I could then...
<h6><strong>5.) BUDGET.</strong></h6>
How much will we need for gas? How much will we need for stopping at hotels/eating on the way? Do I have enough in my savings to cover the first few months of rent comfortably? I also made sure I had enough saved to repurchase my living essentials ASAP (bed, furniture, etc.) and be able to feed myself until my first paycheck.
<h6><strong>6.) Transfer financial and health necessities. </strong></h6>
Don’t move without finding a new doctor, psychiatrist, etc!!! (Especially if you have an ongoing health issue.) I learned this the hard way. Make sure your bank has a branch by you, etc or that you know where you are switching to.
<h6><strong>7.) Bring your best friend to help you explore. </strong></h6>
Whether that be your parent, sibling, or just your “person,” having a bud along for the journey relieves some of the stress and adds to the excitement. Get your ipods geared, make STOPS on the way to see things in other places you may not see again, try new foods together, get out in Fredricksburg, TX and take in that gosh darn AMAZING sunset, laugh and enjoy each other’s company to help pass the time and create more memories. When you arrive, ask what the best part of the town is and experience it with your bestie. Mine and I treated ourselves to kayaking on the lake and hitting the town to dance our hearts out at some of Austin’s favorite bars and clubs. Get excited to be in your new home.
<h6><strong>8.) Hate to say it, but get on Tinder and those other “obnoxious” social apps or websites. </strong></h6>
NO, not for what you think. MEET PEOPLE. Network, network, network. Mention that you’re new in town and need friends. (Especially if your bestie is not staying.. and NO, your partner does not count as “having friends.”) As skeptical as I was, people respond to vulnerability. I was amazed at how many people wanted to help me dive into Austin and welcomed me into their lives! Even though my then partner had already lived out here twice as long as I, I made it a point to make my OWN friends and discover this city for ME. I cannot tell you how many people I met on “that stupid app” that really shaped my kick off here in Austin.
<h6><strong>9.) When people invite you places -  GO </strong></h6>
Sorry but there’s no time for your social awkwardness; continue to dive in and just LET PEOPLE HELP YOU GET EXCITED. What do you have to lose? I know, going out to the hottest club in town on a tuesday night doesn’t sound appealing when you won’t know anyone besides the inviter, you just got dumped, your best friend headed back home, and you’d rather have a marathon of “House” in your pjs.. but just GO. You might enjoy it and, like me, end up meeting some additional best friends. Go to that happy hour with your new coworkers, even though you think you won’t have anything to say. You will start to meet people organically and give yourself that confidence boost that you’re going to be just fine in the friend department. You can NEVER have enough people in your life!
<h6><strong>10.) Find a hobby (Netflix doesn’t count.)</strong></h6>
I joined a kickball team with coworkers and made a personal effort to record one song a month (singing is my get down.) There’s a great app called Meetup! Get on there and find groups with similar interests that have gatherings of that special thing you love! Book clubs, feminist coffee hours, LGBT picnics, volunteer groups, concert goers, poetry slams, the list goes on! Find people who love what you love and GET INVOLVED WITH YOUR RECREATIONAL COMMUNITY!
<h6><strong style="color: inherit; font-family: Montserrat, sans-serif; font-size: 12px;"><span style="font-size: 14px;">11.) If you’re bringing a car, GET REGISTERED get a new license and get your insurance transferred ASAP</span>
</strong></h6>
Again, I learned the hard way. It is vital that you know how long you legally have in your new location to get this done. Save yourself a few unintentional tickets and just make this a priority; trust me.
<h6><strong>12.) DON’T BE SO HARD ON YOURSELF. </strong></h6>
This journey may not start out like you hoped or planned. It WILL get better, and if it doesn’t, you can move back or move elsewhere! No big most everything is temporary. My roommate and I only signed a 6 month lease with our complex to relieve some stress of feeling “trapped” when we didn’t know what the outcome would be..

&nbsp;

Over a year later and I'm still here, stronger than ever! I feel like I can do anything after surviving that ROUGH, abrupt move. I was able to bite the bullet and transition from CA to TX in just 3 weeks. <span style="color: #ff9900;"><strong>Adjusting took longer than that, but this experience turned out to be amazing.</strong></span> I'm not sure if I will stay in Austin, but if I have to drop everything and move to another state again, I definitely know how. Though, in this moment, I’m right where I need to be and I am blessed to call Austin “home.”

&nbsp;

<strong>Lani Helm</strong>

<span style="text-decoration: underline; color: #ff9900;"><strong><a style="color: #ff9900; text-decoration: underline;" href="http://kssolife.com">KSSOLiFe</a></strong></span>

<hr />
<p style="text-align: center;">Read our <strong>Winging It Spotlight</strong> on the all female founding team of KSSOLiFe below:</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/the-winging-it-spotlight-kssolife-on-how-to-start-a-business-with-purpose/">10.16.15 - The Winging It Spotlight: KSSOLiFe on How To Launch a Business (with Purpose!)</a></strong></span></p>
&nbsp;

Header photo: aandamoving.com]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Reinvent and Simplify Your Life</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-reinvent-and-simplify-your-life/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 16 Oct 2015 06:03:55 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Contributor Coordinator]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2434</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[&nbsp;
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/KSSOLiFe2.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-2438" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/KSSOLiFe2-225x300.jpg" alt="KSSOLiFe2" width="225" height="300" /></a></p>
&nbsp;

I struggle every day with terms:<strong> Adult - Woman - Success - Family - Balance - Bills</strong>

The list goes on and on. On an intellectual level, I get them. I went to college, I passed grade school, I KNOW what the definition of these are but how do I incorporate them into my life? For many years I just couldn’t. I lived in complete chaos. One day I figured out the key and I am here to tell you what it is.

&nbsp;
<h6 style="text-align: center;"><strong>I sum it up in one word: PURGE.</strong></h6>
&nbsp;

Ooooh, such a scary concept. The suggestion alone invokes a recoil. It is terrifying to think what happens when we get rid of things. There is a fear of losing valuable pieces of oneself. We are so intertwined in our lives and what defines them. And sometimes, who defines them.

I like to just jump right in when I am doing a complete revamp. <span style="color: #ff9900;"><strong>Start with the people you surround yourself with.</strong></span> Do they add worth to your life? Do you feel better for having them and do they bring out the best version of you? If you answer no, or I don’t know, chances are they have to go. Cut the cord, you’ll already start to feel better. There is nothing wrong or selfish in realizing that sometimes the people we are friends with, are not the best for us. Old friends especially. We all have those people who take you down with them when the ship is sinking. Stop baling their water and let them loose. You’ll be doing everyone a favor.

&nbsp;

Next, alllllll of that stuff. <span style="color: #ff9900;"><strong>STUFF!</strong></span> Things! I am not suggesting being a minimalist. Or selling everything and building yourself a Tiny House. I mean by all means, if that’s what you decide to do, more power to you. I am just giving you permission to let go of the clutter. Not every memory has to have a physical representative. Let go of the mindset that mayyyyyybbbeee five years from now you may need that old closet rod and it is best to lug it around with you. Literal baggage will weigh you down. A good way to get started is to take one corner of your home and go from there. Move space to space and get rid of everything that doesn’t serve you an immediate function. Your head is a catacomb of nostalgia, it is a refreshing feeling to lighten the actual load. Don’t get overwhelmed, just dive in and methodically sort and dispose.

&nbsp;

The last, and most important thing to permanently throw away, is self doubt and loathing. <span style="color: #ff9900;"><strong>Be gentle with yourself.</strong></span> If you haven’t turned out how you planned, so what. Tomorrow is a new day. Stay focused and remember who you wanted to be, not what. You have no power over what has happened and even if your choices lead to a place you never wanted to be, just create your own fork. You never have to live an ordinary life or settle just because you have gotten lazy. Isn’t it extraordinary the power you have? Do not let go of that power.

&nbsp;

I promise you, once you get the ball rolling, your life will be a completely different place. You will breathe easier and feel lighter. Then, all of those weighted words, won’t feel like such a burden. You will have a much better grasp on your world without all the things you have been carrying around with you for so long.

&nbsp;

<span style="color: #008080;"><strong>Happy Spring Cleaning!</strong></span>

Stephanie Forsythe

<span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span style="color: #ff9900;"><strong><a style="color: #ff9900; text-decoration: underline;" href="http://kssolife.com" target="_blank">KSSOLiFe</a></strong></span></span>

&nbsp;

<hr />

Read our <strong>Winging It Spotlight</strong> on the all female founding team of KSSOLiFe below:
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/the-winging-it-spotlight-kssolife-on-how-to-start-a-business-with-purpose/">10.16.15 - The Winging It Spotlight: KSSOLiFe on How To Launch a Business (with Purpose!)</a></strong></span></p>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:10:{i:0;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2238";s:5:"score";s:17:"20.90679486127609";}i:1;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"234";s:5:"score";s:18:"19.355117068605836";}i:2;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1695";s:5:"score";s:18:"17.646470184245096";}i:3;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2428";s:5:"score";s:18:"17.452352964983234";}i:4;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2182";s:5:"score";s:18:"15.623268360888137";}i:5;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"644";s:5:"score";s:18:"14.006819769445086";}i:6;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1705";s:5:"score";s:16:"13.5015244396295";}i:7;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1094";s:5:"score";s:18:"13.396056470272793";}i:8;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2021";s:5:"score";s:18:"12.994715079460377";}i:9;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"3058";s:5:"score";s:17:"12.68434064401552";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Get an IUD</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-get-an-iud-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 23 Oct 2015 04:51:29 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jenna-perelman]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2483</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/How-To-Get-An-IUD.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2527 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/How-To-Get-An-IUD-300x225.jpg" alt="How To- Get An IUD" width="300" height="225" /></a>

What do you know about IUDs? A lot has changed in the world of intrauterine devices, so read up!

&nbsp;

<strong>First off:</strong> IUD stands for intrauterine device. It’s a long-term birth control method that lasts 3, 5 or 10 years, depending on which kind you get.

&nbsp;

A brief background: In the 1970s, there was a problem with a U.S. IUD called the Dalkon Shield. In some women, the Shield <a href="http://www.alternet.org/personal-health/brief-history-iud-strange-ways-weve-tried-stop-pregnancy?page=0%2C1">caused infertility, pelvic infections, and even death</a>. Following the Shield disaster, IUDs became pretty unpopular. But things have changed. IUDs are now recommended as long-acting, reversible contraception for all women, not just women who have already had children. Their popularity is growing among young women, and the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists recommended IUDs broadly for young women and teens in a recent <a href="http://www.acog.org/Resources_And_Publications/Committee_Opinions/Committee_on_Adolescent_Health_Care/Adolescents_and_Long-Acting_Reversible_Contraception">study</a>. Before the Affordable Care Act, IUDs could cost in the range of $800-$1,200, which was a major factor holding women back from this type of contraception. Now, however, most health insurance covers the cost of an IUD.

&nbsp;

<strong>There are three types available:</strong>

Skyla: lasts 3 years, is a hormonal method, and the smallest of the three.

Mirena: lasts 5 years and is a hormonal method.

ParaGard: lasts 10 years, is hormone-free, and made of copper.

&nbsp;

<strong>Recently, I got the Mirena IUD. Here’s my story:</strong>

I wanted a birth control that was long-lasting and easy to deal with. After doing some research, I chose the Mirena IUD because I didn’t want the side effects of heavier, potentially more painful periods that come with the copper IUD. I was intrigued by Mirena’s side effects of lighter periods and that, after a year or two, it was possible I wouldn’t have periods at all. The best part? With my health insurance, my IUD was free. The worst part? Holy hell it was a painful insertion and recovery.

&nbsp;

<strong>How To: Get an IUD</strong>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">1. Check with your health insurance and see if an IUD is covered. With the passage of the Affordable Care Act, most health insurances cover the cost of an IUD. If you’re uninsured, visit your local Planned Parenthood and see if you can receive a reduced-cost IUD. (I &lt;3 you PP!)</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">2. Schedule your appointment during your period. Your cervix is already slightly dilated during menstruation, so insertion will be easier.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">3. Take a high dosage of ibuprofen (pending any allergies) before your appointment. My doctor recommended up to 800mg. The ibuprofen acts as an anti-inflammatory that reduces the cramping you can experience after insertion. Be careful that you do not take too much ibuprofen throughout the day, as high doses of ibuprofen can cause liver problems and stomach bleeding. Read the warning label. No alcohol!</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">4. Have a friend come with you so they can drive you home. The cramping started as soon as the IUD was inserted and I was too uncomfortable to drive home from the appointment.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">5. Prepare for the cramps and other side effects before your appointment. Make sure you have a stocked bottle of ibuprofen or other painkillers. I didn’t have a hot pad but boy did I wish I’d thought of it before. Other necessities: maxi pads and/or pantiliners. Bleeding is common after insertion, and my doctor recommended that I did not use tampons (also I definitely did not want to put anything else up there).</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">6. Have the rest of your afternoon free. I watched movies in the fetal position for approximately 4 hours after my appointment because of the pain. With an 11:40 a.m. appointment time, the cramps became more manageable around 4:30 p.m. This is different for everyone – one of my friends had cramps for an hour and was fine afterwards.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"></p>

&nbsp;

Learn more:

<a href="http://www.plannedparenthood.org/health-info/birth-control/iud">http://www.plannedparenthood.org/health-info/birth-control/iud</a>

<a href="http://www.acog.org/Resources_And_Publications/Committee_Opinions/Committee_on_Adolescent_Health_Care/Adolescents_and_Long-Acting_Reversible_Contraception">http://www.acog.org/Resources_And_Publications/Committee_Opinions/Committee_on_Adolescent_Health_Care/Adolescents_and_Long-Acting_Reversible_Contraception</a>

<a href="http://bedsider.org/methods/iud#alternatives_tab">http://bedsider.org/methods/iud#alternatives_tab</a>

&nbsp;

Header Photo: perdueandkidd.com]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:10:{i:0;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"778";s:5:"score";s:18:"24.204480883934487";}i:1;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2884";s:5:"score";s:18:"21.628772306765654";}i:2;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2994";s:5:"score";s:18:"17.469889223405985";}i:3;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"3004";s:5:"score";s:18:"15.651148645902378";}i:4;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1459";s:5:"score";s:18:"15.651148645902378";}i:5;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1001";s:5:"score";s:18:"15.651148645902378";}i:6;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2487";s:5:"score";s:17:"15.41558257458961";}i:7;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1775";s:5:"score";s:18:"14.264854284782487";}i:8;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2654";s:5:"score";s:18:"12.933940506459848";}i:9;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2832";s:5:"score";s:18:"12.265928218763364";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Lift Weights</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-lift-weights/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 25 Oct 2015 15:15:41 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[MJ@twigghowto.com]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2487</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/weights-869225.jpg"><img class=" wp-image-2562 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/weights-869225-300x200.jpg" alt="weights-869225" width="425" height="283" /></a>

Remember that last article where I gave you some <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-make-your-exercise-routine-one-that-you-can-stick-with/">tips on how to make sticking to a workout routine easier</a>? Awesome! Now, it’s time to get down to the (literal) heavy stuff.

Aerobic exercise is great, but it’s not the only part of the fitness spectrum worth doing. If you’re like me, huffing away on a treadmill or track can get a little tedious. I’ve found that adding the challenge of strength training not only makes my workouts twice as effective, but also way more interesting. Think about it - dumbbells and weight machines are just really, really heavy toys for adults.

Note that I say “adults,” not “men.” Until recently, our society tended to equate muscle with masculinity, which could make the prospect of weightlifting unappealing for many of us. Thankfully, with boss women like Serena Williams and Rhonda Rousey at the forefront of today’s athletic landscape, we’re learning that muscles can be pretty, too.

&nbsp;

Strength training does more than just help you look your best, though. It helps keep you active into old age by slowing muscle deterioration, is a great way to build endurance, and keeps your body running smoother than a well-oiled machine.

&nbsp;

<strong>Start small.</strong>

If you’re just beginning and/or weight training after being out of the game for a long time, start as low as you can. Pick up a free weight or two to judge heaviness, and when you find one you think you can handle, go even lower than that. Starting with too much can <a href="http://www.nerdfitness.com/blog/2014/02/06/strength-training-101-how-much-weight-should-i-be-lifting/">compromise your ability</a> to keep the correct form while doing your movements, and knowing how to do the movements correctly is way more important than proving how much weight you can handle lifting. It’s better to start low and build up safely than to start too high and be out of commission for a week.

I would also suggest starting with weight machines before you move on to free weights. They do a lot of the positioning and formation work for you, allowing you to build strength without fretting too much about what to do and if you’re doing it right.

&nbsp;

<strong>Be slow, not stagnant.</strong>

Any movement that puts heavy strain on your muscles and joints has the potential to be a dangerous one, and taking your time is more than worth it. Don’t get too comfortable once you’ve got your movements down, however. The point of weight training is to build strength and muscle, and you won’t build by doing the same movements and combinations day after day after day. Once you’ve gotten your form right and given your body time to adjust, move on up to the next challenge. You can do it!

&nbsp;

<strong>Know the lingo.</strong>
Knowing the difference between certain phrases is essential to getting a good workout.

<em>Reps vs. Sets:</em>
<ul>
	<li>“Reps” is short for repetitions, or how many times you do a movement in each set.</li>
	<li>“Sets” are just that; sets of repetitions, followed by short breaks.</li>
</ul>
If you’re told to do three sets of eight reps of squats, all that means is you’ll do eight squats, rest, and then repeat two more times, until you’ve done it three times. Pretty simple!

&nbsp;

Different types of weights also have different names.

<em>Free Weights</em>
<ul>
	<li>Free weights refer to barbells or dumbbells - any weight that’s “free” to be picked up (not attached to a machine, basically) is a free weight.</li>
</ul>
<em>Barbell</em>
<ul>
	<li>A bar (around a meter long) that can be lifted on its own on with weights attached to either side. The bar itself is generally around 45 lbs without any weights attached (although some smaller ones can be around 25 - check before you grab), so keep that in mind if you decide to use it!</li>
</ul>
<em>Dumbbell</em>
<ul>
	<li>A dumbbell is a smaller bar (just enough space for a hand) with two weighted ends, which are generally not detachable.</li>
</ul>
<em>Kettlebell</em>
<ul>
	<li>A kettlebell is an extremely dense, heavy ball with a handle. It can be made with cast-iron or plastic, and they’re usually way heavier than they look!
Know how to do things the right way.</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

Say it with me: <strong>Form. Is. Everything.</strong> You won’t get to take advantage of the benefits of weight training if you’re constantly <a href="http://www.livestrong.com/article/274669-what-are-the-dangers-of-lifting-weights/">recovering from torn muscles and messed-up joints</a>. No matter how slow you take it or how light you think the weight you’re lifting is, there’s always a risk of hurting yourself if you don’t keep tension and strain at a minimum, especially for vulnerable areas like knees and your back.  And regardless of how good your form is, if you feel pain, stop. It may not always be a big deal, but don’t start again until you can figure out what’s wrong.

&nbsp;

The rules to follow vary by exercise, but some of the basics are:
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">1. Don’t lock your knees or elbows – like ever. Doing so puts the weight on the joints themselves, instead of the muscles you really want to target.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">2. Keep your core tight. Keeping your core tight dissuades you from lifting with bad posture, directs the energy towards the muscles you’re trying to build, and helps strengthen those abs.
3. Keep your moves fluid. This is another way to prevent injury; many weight lifting injuries are caused <a href="https://books.google.com/books?id=gUoRYgERRZMC&amp;pg=PA542&amp;lpg=PA542&amp;dq=jerky+movements+when+lifting&amp;source=bl&amp;ots=TQlSIkQmD8&amp;sig=iJd7LznUXbPiLVeg891f3tEtr_w&amp;hl=en&amp;sa=X&amp;ved=0CEEQ6AEwBmoVChMI-IfhodH-xwIVy40NCh3MhQtO#v=onepage&amp;q=jerky%20movements%20when%20lifting&amp;f=false">when people use short, jerky movements </a>instead of smooth, controlled ones to reach their desired amount of reps.
4. Build a catalog. Have a few exercises to plan on practicing and improving on over time. My favorites are squats, deadlifts, and rows, all of which have millions of different variations to keep you from getting bored.</p>
&nbsp;

<strong>Find some badass feminine inspiration.</strong>

I’ve found some super-relatable fitness gurus doing their thing on Youtube and Instagram, which are some of the best places to learn new workouts due to the readiness of visual aids. <a href="http://www.massyarias.com/">Massy Arias</a> is one of my favorites; she’s positive, realistic, and has a crazy catalog of exercises for you to try on <a href="https://instagram.com/massy.arias/">her Instagram</a>.  Whether you choose a well-known fitness powerhouse or a really active neighbor as your inspiration, it’s great to have someone whose page you can check any time you need a little extra juice in the gym.

&nbsp;

Get out there, stay safe while training, and nothing will keep you from being your strongest self!]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2487</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2015-10-25 15:15:41]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2015-10-25 15:15:41]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
