	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Argue Rationally and Not Lose Friends</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-argue-rationally-and-not-lose-friends/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 28 Oct 2015 03:59:32 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Caitlin Cohen]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2537</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_2565" align="aligncenter" width="407"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/GOP-Debate.jpeg"><img class="wp-image-2565" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/GOP-Debate-300x163.jpeg" alt="GOP Debate" width="407" height="221" /></a> <em>Photo Credit: AP Images</em>[/caption]

Election season is now at least 18 months long.  It’s rough.  It’s grueling.  It gets personal. Outside of the attack ads and the Super PACS, there’s one concept that continues to strike me about seasoned politicians who are “supposed to know better”:  the arguments often don’t make sense, are based on information that is often disputable or skewed, and are often couched in logical fallacies.

Worse, many of the people you know and love in your life fall for some fairly atrocious arguments regarding political, economic, and social issues, and therefore come to conclusions or opinions that aren’t particularly logically sound.

&nbsp;

I grew up with lawyers for parents, and I went to a pretty strict Catholic school, both of which taught me the importance of backing up thesis statements with evidence and commentary.  Since middle school, it has been important to both stay informed and win meaningless arguments at all costs, but when everyone seems to be using a different set of facts and a different set of values, it’s hard to parse through the arguments on current events issues. Even harder, though, is discussing these issues with friends in a way that doesn’t turn our conversation into a screaming match or a huge fight.

&nbsp;

In this article, I hope to outline some pretty basic ways to a.) get to the heart of an argument (political, economic, social, or academic) to see if it makes sense or not and b.) do so in a civil, productive manner. For those of you who don’t know me, this is very much a “do as I say, not as I do” type of article.  I am terrible at all of this.  Never get into an argument with me.

&nbsp;
<h3>Logical fallacies</h3>
The first thing that I want to discuss are some <span style="color: #0000ff;"><a style="color: #0000ff;" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_fallacies">common logical fallacies</a></span> in arguments that, if you want your argument to make sense, you absolutely must avoid.

A <span style="color: #0000ff;"><a style="color: #0000ff;" href="http://rationalwiki.org/wiki/Logical_fallacy">logical fallacy</a></span> is an error in logic.  <span style="color: #0000ff;"><a style="color: #0000ff;" href="https://web.cn.edu/kwheeler/fallacies_list.html">Logical fallacies</a></span> manifest themselves in many ways, but they  usually surface due to a derailment of the other person’s argument or a leap in logic uncorrelated to the evidence presented.  You’ll recognize many of these fallacies.

&nbsp;

[caption id="attachment_2567" align="aligncenter" width="300"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/donald-trump.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2567" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/donald-trump-300x200.jpg" alt="Newsweek" width="300" height="200" /></a> <em>Photo Credit: Newsweek</em>[/caption]

For example, Donald Trump’s favorite logical fallacy is <strong>ad hominem</strong>, or attacking the person he’s arguing with rather than the argument itself (e.g. saying Megyn Kelly had blood coming out of her when she asked a question regarding Trump’s tendency towards ad hominem attacks on women, and then saying the audience is deviant for thinking he said she was on her period).  Another common political favorite is the <strong>either/or fallacy</strong> – that there are only two options available (i.e. “you’re either with us or against us”).  The <strong>straw man fallacy</strong> is the fallacy that creates an enemy that isn’t there or creates a situation that hasn’t happened yet still takes a stand against it (e.g. “allowing gender neutral bathrooms makes it easier for men to sexually harass women” despite <a href="http://mic.com/articles/114066/statistics-show-exactly-how-many-times-trans-people-have-attacked-you-in-bathrooms">zero cases</a> of men harassing women in a bathroom that allows both men and women).  The <strong>personal incredulity fallacy</strong> argument supposes that because the person arguing doesn’t understand a concept, no one can (e.g. “you can’t have women in the workplace because everything you say will be considered an insult or somehow inappropriate” is more so a commentary about the person saying the statement than anything else). <strong>Anecdotal</strong> <strong>fallacies</strong> supplement personal stories in place of statistical evidence (e.g. “how can you say that racism exists if I’ve never experienced it?”).

&nbsp;

Are you starting to recognize some of these fallacies and connect them with arguments that you’ve seen in the news or heard from your friends?  Great!  Everyone uses them.  My lawyer parents use them all the time (I assume it’s just at home and not in court.).  My personal favorite, when I get lazy, is the <strong>emotional appeal</strong>, which is when I try to get an emotional reaction out of someone instead of using actual logic.  It’s a dick thing to do, but it’s also why I have no friends.

Here is a pretty <span style="color: #0000ff;"><a style="color: #0000ff;" href="https://yourlogicalfallacyis.com/poster">dope chart</a></span> listing logical fallacies.  The next time you get into a serious academic debate with friends about which important factors contributed to the US getting involved in WWI, or the next time you watch a political debate, go ahead and pull this baby out and parse out which arguments are legitimate and which are totally bogus!

&nbsp;
<h3>Sources and evidence</h3>
Do you have a favorite website that you go to for your news?  There are a lot of great sources out there.  Some I like to peruse, even though I know they’re biased (<a href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/">Huffington Post</a>, <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/">New York Times</a>), while some I go to to confirm or deny the veracity of a claim (<a href="http://www.factcheck.org/">FactCheck.org</a>, <a href="http://www.bbc.com/">BBC</a>).  Sometimes, the most unlikeliest of sources can be accurate. Even <a href="http://www.tmz.com/">TMZ</a> has broken one or two serious news stories before.  However, before you quote something as fact to use towards your argument (whatever that may be), you absolutely have to research it through other sites before claiming that it’s true.

&nbsp;

[caption id="attachment_2568" align="aligncenter" width="300"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/gawker_media_logo.png"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2568" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/gawker_media_logo-300x110.png" alt="Photo Credit: Gawker" width="300" height="110" /></a> <em>Photo Credit: Gawker</em>[/caption]

For example, even though I sometimes enjoy reading <a href="http://gawker.com/">Gawker</a> and the sites associated with it (<a href="http://deadspin.com/">Deadspin</a>, <a href="http://jezebel.com/">Jezebel</a>, etc), I would never, ever quote a Gawker article before reading multiple, other sources.  This has to do both with checking their sources – Gawker is most interested in being the first to report something, not the most in depth or accurate – and also with the tone that Gawker uses, which is often not particularly civil.  Remember, we’re trying to argue <em>rationally</em> and <em>without losing friends</em>, not argue using the snarkiest language available in order to put down the other person.

&nbsp;

Sifting through sources can be frustrating. Often, different news sources report on different aspects of stories that might even generate totally different stories.  Often, you can tell if there is a bias in the article and how strong it is, based on how much the author is editorializing. Heavy use of adverbs or judgement words is always a tip-off that this article is not just presenting the facts but trying to impose a certain opinion as well.

&nbsp;

Having the right evidence is extremely important to making a good argument.  It just requires a little bit of work! Once you have the right evidence to back up the argument, you can connect your evidence to your conclusion by very clearly explaining the connection between the two elements within your argument.  Just be sure you’re not using any of the logical fallacies listed above!

&nbsp;
<h3>Civility and respect</h3>
Hey, you know, just be chill.  Don’t interrupt the other person when he or she is talking.  Don’t put down the other person using aggressive language.  Listen respectfully, and then speak respectfully.  This is especially true if discussing anything personal, political, or religious. Smart people disagree with each other all the time.  Play nice.

&nbsp;

Basic definitions that are good to know (all from Dictionary.com).

An <strong>opinion</strong> is a view or a judgement formed about something, not necessarily based in knowledge or fact.

A <strong>fact</strong> is a thing that is indisputably the case.

A <strong>belief</strong> is trust, faith, or confidence in someone or something, often used in a religious context.

An <strong>insult</strong> is a disrespectful or or scornfully abusive remark.

&nbsp;

I’ve seen all of the above become mistaken for each other.  Don’t do that

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/portrait-119851_1280.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2569 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/portrait-119851_1280-300x199.jpg" alt="portrait-119851_1280" width="300" height="199" /></a>
<h3>Knowing when to walk away</h3>
How are you feeling right now?  Are you upset?  How are you feeling in the middle of an argument?  Are you engaged?  Do you feel respected?  Are you angry?

&nbsp;

If you’re starting to get emotional or upset, it is always okay to walk away from an argument, even for just a few minutes.  The worst and most personal comments come out when arguments get heated, and I, for one, have an especially detailed memory concerning mean or hurtful things that people have said to me (no matter the situation).

&nbsp;

What is the purpose of your argument?  If it’s to educate or to broaden your own horizons, then getting too emotional is unlikely to help.  If it’s to win, then maybe reconsider why you’re arguing in the first place, and consider whatever it is that you think you are trying to win.  Or, you know, maybe disregard everything I’ve said.

&nbsp;
<h3>Thoughts about faith-based arguments and buzzwords</h3>
Religion has been a big part of my upbringing, and it’s contributed to who I am and what I believe.  While I am no longer religious, I still consider Jesus’s teachings to be pretty great, and I still believe that a basic understanding of Christianity is essential to understanding the political climate in the US today.

&nbsp;

Religion, by its nature, is based in faith.  You believe without hard proof.  Faith is not logical.  When arguing, attacking someone’s religion is uncalled for, unnecessary, and counterproductive.  Logic and faith are rarely conducive to one another, and that’s okay.  Faith is an important part of life as well – it’s just very separate from logic and reason.

&nbsp;

On the flip side, if your arguments include anything faith-based or religion-based, please consider that perhaps they’re not the most logical arguments.  Not everyone believes that God wrote the Bible, just as not everyone believes in God (again, see above for definitions of belief and fact).  The Bible’s teachings and your belief in God might align with personal truths but, that doesn’t mean they’re actual factual pieces of information.  Enough people disagree about the Bible’s origins and God’s existence; therefore you really can’t use either as sound evidence for any argument.  Using a faith-based argument is, most likely, an extension of the <strong>emotional appeal fallacy</strong> or the <strong>appeal to nature fallacy</strong>, but considering the fact that we’re going to have to hear numerous claims about religion and God in the upcoming political debates, I thought that religion and faith-based arguments merited a special mention.

&nbsp;

Additionally, buzzwords, such as “patriot”, “America”, “progress”, “traditional”, or “science” don’t actually make a good argument.  However, using these words might make a candidate a good politician.  Such is the world we live in.

&nbsp;
<h3>Final thoughts</h3>
We live in a climate where we react first and reason through it later, and this tendency often makes it harder for us to reasonably and productively argue with friends regarding important issues.  It’s important, now more than ever before, to take the time to do the research and argue logically so that we can disagree and live with each other just a little bit more peaceably.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Code in Python</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-code-in-python/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 30 Oct 2015 03:48:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jordan-varney]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2572</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Welcome to your first coding-venture. Coding might be intimidating to some people, but I promise, it’s easy and fun. There are many cool ways to get started as a beginner and easily work your way up. Yay!

&nbsp;

First, we will be coding in a language called Python. Python is a good beginner language because its <em>syntax</em>, the words you write in the language, is more similar to writing English than other coding languages you might encounter in later coding ventures. Some coding languages allow programmers to be very hands on – for example, with where information is being stored in the memory of the computer. Some languages, like Python, are more hands off in that respect. Python is a good beginning coder language because you don’t have to worry about where in memory your information is being stored or making sure you free up memory you don’t need anymore. It takes care of that for you.

&nbsp;
<h3>Step 1: How do I get Python?</h3>
To obtain Python, visit this website: https://www.python.org/downloads/

As you can see at the top, there are cool links to visit if you’re so inclined.

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/image03.png"><img class="aligncenter size-large wp-image-2574" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/image03-1024x96.png" alt="image03" width="1024" height="96" /></a><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/image001.png">
</a>
First, we’re looking at Downloads in order to obtain Python, but Documentation is very helpful later on. Documentation is where you can find information about all the things you can do with Python, supplied by its creators.

&nbsp;

In coding, Google is your friend. If you’re thinking, “I want to do _____ in Python,” someone else somewhere probably has the same question. Try Googling “____ in Python” or any questions about errors that you may come across while coding, and the return search usually yields pretty helpful results. Stack Overflow (http://stackoverflow.com) is a website designed to answer coding questions similar to how Yahoo Answers is set up. Stack Overflow is your new friend.

&nbsp;

For the uses of this tutorial, we are using Python 2.  Go ahead and download Python 2.7.10. Follow the handy-dandy instructions for installing, and open up the IDLE application,

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/image001.png"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-2573" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/image001.png" alt="image00" width="138" height="142" /></a>
You should see something that looks like this:

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/image08.png"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-2575" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/image08.png" alt="image08" width="826" height="180" /></a>
This is the Python Shell. You can directly type in this window and run code.

&nbsp;
<h3>Step 2: How do I write Python?</h3>
Type (don’t copy): <code>print ‘Hello World!’</code> and press return

Now your window should look like this:

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/image07.png"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-2576" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/image07.png" alt="image07" width="812" height="218" /></a>
You just coded! YAY!!!!!!!!!!

Basically, you told the Python <em>compiler</em> in the Python language to print Hello World! A compiler takes the code you write and turns it into binary code of 1s &amp; 0s that the computer can understand.

&nbsp;
<h3>Step 3: How do I write a program?</h3>
Make a new file either by using Command N (Control N on Windows) or going to the header bar and choosing File &gt; New File.

You should get a window that looks like this:

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/image04.png"><img class="wp-image-2577 alignleft" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/image04.png" alt="image04" width="518" height="245" /></a>

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

This is where you can type a lot of Python code (not one line at a time like in the Python Shell) and run it all at once.

&nbsp;

So, once again, type <code>print ‘Hello World!’</code> and save the file as HelloWorld.py. The .py tells the computer to interpret the code in the file as Python code.

&nbsp;

Now you have,

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/image13.png"><img class="aligncenter size-large wp-image-2578" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/image13-1024x250.png" alt="image13" width="1024" height="250" /></a>
Let’s run it!

&nbsp;
<h3>Step 4: How do I run a program?</h3>
Go to the top bar and choose Run &gt; Run Module.

Now you should see this in your Shell:

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/image06.png"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-2579" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/image06-1024x275.png" alt="image06" width="677" height="182" /></a>

You just coded your first program! Look at you go!!

&nbsp;

**Note: Under the Run menu you can see the Python Shell option. So, if you ever close your Shell window you can just click to get a new one there!

&nbsp;
<h3>Step 5: How do I write a program that interacts with the user?</h3>
Let’s now write something a little more interesting. We’re going to write a program that:
<ol>
	<li>Asks for a person’s name</li>
	<li>Displays their name</li>
	<li>Asks for two numbers</li>
	<li>Adds those numbers together and displays the result</li>
</ol>
Let’s go!

&nbsp;
<h3>Step 6: How do I get input from the user?</h3>
First, create a new file. Save it as adding.py.

&nbsp;

<strong>Line 1)</strong> The first line of our <code>program is person = raw_input(‘Enter your name: ‘)</code>

&nbsp;

<code>raw_input</code> tells Python to wait for the user to enter something and then  use that string of characters exactly as it was entered. In Python 2.7, just using <code>input</code> would try to run the words you enter as code. We want our name to be seen as just a string of characters instead of code, so we use <code>raw_input</code>.
We just saw <code>(‘Enter your name: ‘)</code> so this prompt is a familiar instruction . This will print out the words in quotation marks. We don’t have to use <code>print</code> this time because <code>raw_input</code> knows it’s going to print information.
<code>person</code> is  how the program will identify our inputted name. So, we can use <code>person</code> inside the program, and the name we entered will show up when we print.
<strong>Line 2)</strong> To print out the name, the line to write is <code>print (‘Hello ‘ + person)</code>

Once again, we’re printing out information. This time, we’re also printing a variable (what <code>person</code> is). <code>person</code> is not in quotes because we’re not literally printing “person”, rather, we’re printing what is contained in the variable <code>person</code>.

Let’s run it and test!

&nbsp;

Your code should look like this,

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/image12.png"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-2580" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/image12.png" alt="image12" width="980" height="98" /></a>
And when you run it, this should display,

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/image01.png"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-2581" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/image01.png" alt="image01" width="958" height="94" /></a>
So go on! Enter your name!

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/image02.png"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-2582" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/image02.png" alt="image02" width="952" height="122" /></a>
Depending on your name, you should see this,

YAY we just talked to the user!!!!!!!
<h3>Step 7: How do I take in numbers as input in Python?</h3>
If you want to get number input from the user, what do you think it will look like? Use the input example from above, and take a good guess! Write some code!

&nbsp;

<iframe class="giphy-embed" src="//giphy.com/embed/5wWf7H5EhMrLnTMIhQA?html5=true" width="480" height="269" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe>

<a href="http://giphy.com/gifs/danfinkler-sloth-go-on-do-tell-5wWf7H5EhMrLnTMIhQA">via GIPHY</a>

&nbsp;

If you got something like

<code>number1 = raw_input(‘Enter a number: ‘)</code>

you’re super close!!

&nbsp;

However, because we want numbers, we have to tell Python to treat our input as integers and not just as a string of characters (or <em>string</em> for short). Therefore, we have to <em>cast</em> our input to an integer. Casting is a coder’s way of changing one object’s type to another. So, we’re changing our input from a string to an integer.

&nbsp;

<strong>Line 3)</strong> This looks like

<code>number1 = int(raw_input(‘Enter a number: ‘)</code>

Now <code>number1</code> will be an int (integer) in the eyes of the program!

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

<strong>Line 4)</strong> Let’s take in our second number

<code>number2 = int(raw_input(‘Enter another number: ‘)</code>
<code>number1</code> and <code>number2</code> are variables like <code>person</code>. When printed, they will display what’s stored in them, not the name that the program sees.
<h3>Step 8: How do I add numbers together in Python?</h3>
Now we have our two numbers. Let’s add them together!

Any guesses on how to write this next step?

&nbsp;

<iframe class="giphy-embed" src="//giphy.com/embed/12XDYvMJNcmLgQ?html5=true" width="480" height="359" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe>

<a href="http://giphy.com/gifs/luck-good-im-rooting-for-you-12XDYvMJNcmLgQ">via GIPHY</a>

&nbsp;

<strong>Line 5)</strong> If you got something like

<code>number3 = number1 + number2</code>

good job!!!! If not, that’s okay too!
Lastly, let’s print out our final number. We’ve written print statements before, but this one will be a little different because we want to print what’s stored in <code>number3</code> not “number3.”

&nbsp;

<strong>Line 6)</strong> Here it is!

<code>print (‘Your two numbers added together are %r’ % number3)</code>

<code>%r</code> basically tells the program to expect something else to be printed out. <code>% number3</code> tells the program that what it’s expecting is located in <code>number3</code>.

&nbsp;

In its entirety, your program should look like this:

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/image10.png"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-2583" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/image10.png" alt="image10" width="976" height="198" /></a>
Let’s run it!!!!!!

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/image09.png"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-2584" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/image09.png" alt="image09" width="950" height="188" /></a>

YAY]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Change Your Showerhead</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-change-your-showerhead/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 09 Nov 2015 04:14:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[maria-zhou]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2600</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_2658" align="aligncenter" width="392"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/How-To-Change-Your-Shower-Head.jpg"><img class="wp-image-2658" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/How-To-Change-Your-Shower-Head-300x169.jpg" alt="How-To--Change-Your-Shower-Head" width="392" height="221" /></a> Mindy Kaling in "The Mindy Project" dealing with an uncontrollable shower. (Credit: Fox.com)[/caption]

&nbsp;

Showering, or, one could say "hydrotherapy," is a luxury experience that must always be enjoyed and never taken for granted. In my apartment complex I was happy to have enough hot water to shower with at any given time of day, without even realizing I was settling for mediocrity compared to my neighbors. The weak water pressure wasn't just a fact of life that I needed to accept due to the building's irreparable problems, but rather an old, yet easily replaceable shower head.

&nbsp;

A friend who lives in my building told me she changed her shower head so it now has better water pressure and efficiency. Increased water pressure has many benefits, like shortening your shower time and getting you that squeakier, deeper clean.

&nbsp;

An <span style="color: #0000ff;"><a style="color: #0000ff;" href="http://www.collegehumor.com/post/6798632/poor-college-life-water-shower-head">empty water bottle</a></span> with holes in it can be used as a shower head. Luckily, I did not have to resort to that, but it should work just as well to use a water bottle.

&nbsp;

Here's how to change a basic shower head:
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">1. Make sure your water is turned off before you start!</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">2. Cover the drain so that the small parts don't disappear into the plumbing abyss. Use a towel or an upside-down bowl – anything goes here.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">3. Some shower heads can be removed by hand, simply by turning it counter-clockwise. The ones that can't will need the help of a wrench and pliers; one tool to hold it steady and one to turn the head.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 90px;">For additional protection, wrap teflon tape on the part that is going to screw into your new shower head.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">4. Place the new shower head in place and twist clockwise to tighten.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">5. Turn on the water to check for leaks, and adjust as necessary.</p>
&nbsp;

That's it!

&nbsp;

Not only did my quality of life noticeably improve after this, but my roommates get to enjoy it as well!

Remember, you can also call your building’s maintenance or landlord to fix things for you that go beyond a luxurious upgrade.

Best day ever? Yes.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:10:{i:0;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"3277";s:5:"score";s:17:"21.08399049477586";}i:1;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"136";s:5:"score";s:17:"20.93577455041168";}i:2;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2209";s:5:"score";s:18:"20.273060278559534";}i:3;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"644";s:5:"score";s:18:"18.578464557700016";}i:4;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"3192";s:5:"score";s:18:"17.256376687462435";}i:5;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2960";s:5:"score";s:17:"16.89173357387453";}i:6;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"232";s:5:"score";s:17:"16.89173357387453";}i:7;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2382";s:5:"score";s:18:"15.197137853015015";}i:8;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2871";s:5:"score";s:18:"13.959059436259304";}i:9;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2431";s:5:"score";s:18:"13.959059436259304";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Buy The Right Guitar</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-buy-the-right-guitar/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 03 Nov 2015 03:52:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ian-lecheminant]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2622</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Buying a guitar or any musical instrument for the first time can be a daunting task, especially if you don’t know or trust people involved in the musical retail business. The goal of this article is to outline the absolute basics about what to look for when buying your very first instrument.

First a bit about me. I have been playing guitar for about ten years and am currently a staff member and salesperson at Boulevard Music, a medium sized music store located in Culver City, California. I own six or seven guitars and love every one for a different reason. Some even have names… Sorry I tailed off; I got distracted staring at the guitars off to the right of my desk.

Okay; so what do you need to know as you get started?

<hr />

&nbsp;
<h5>What to Avoid When Shopping Around:</h5>
1) <strong>“Super Cheap Guitars” are made quickly (which is why they’re cheap).</strong>  Because the production value is so low, they often have what is called “high string action” which means the strings are high off from the fretboard, forcing the player to apply far more pressure on the string with their left hand than is typically necessary in order to sound an in-tune note. This makes them hard to play, and when an instrument is uncomfortable to play, you are less likely to enjoy playing and practicing on it.

2) <strong>Toy guitars are toys, not real instruments.</strong> They will not stay in tune, which  will make learning the instrument frustrating and nearly impossible.

3) <strong>Buying Guitars Online is not recommended for first time players.</strong> In person, a salesperson can help you to explore a variety of makes and models in a relatively short amount of time.

&nbsp;

<i>*As you gain more experience as a player and become a guitar connoisseur, buying a guitar online won’t be as a big of a deal. You will know what to look for in terms of damage, wear-and-tear, how to talk with the online seller about these problems, and how to go about negotiating the fairest deal for both parties. However; in general, I would not recommend it. I, along with just about my entire group of guitar buddies, think that it is very important to see how a guitar feels in your hands and balances against your body during the purchasing process . More on this later.*</i>

&nbsp;

Now that we know what to avoid, let’s get started on figuring out what you need to look for in your very first guitar!

&nbsp;
<h5>Some General Misconceptions About Guitars:</h5>
1) <strong>Different types of strings are not interchangeable between guitar types</strong>. (We will discuss more about the three main types of guitars below.) For example, you cannot put nylon strings on a steel string acoustic guitar or steel string acoustic strings on a nylon string acoustic guitar. Each type of guitar was designed for a specific string type.

2) <strong>Yes, you can amplify any type of guitar.</strong> How you go about doing this can vary. You can install external and internal electronic pickups/microphones. Some guitars come equipped with this option straight from the factory, while others do not. This option is not necessary for a beginner guitar, unless you plan on gigging or playing shows in the near feature.

3) <strong>All of the guitar types listed here are tuned the same way,</strong> with the notes EADGBE (lowest string to highest string). Yes there are other guitars types on the market such as Baritone, Extended Range 7 and 8 strings, and hybrid bass/guitars. As a beginner, stay away from these specialty guitars.. All you need is a simple and straightforward six string, in one of the three main guitar type styles: (1)Nylon String Acoustic, (2)Steel String Acoustic, or (3)Solid-Body Electric. See the included pictures for reference.

&nbsp;

<i>*Important note about solid body electric guitars in the context of this article: our focus here is on solid body electrics, even though there are chambered, semi-hollow and hollow body electric guitars available on the market as well. These are just variant designs of solid-body electrics. If you happen to come across one you like feel free to pick it up and try it out. The advice presented here can easily be applied to these types of guitars even though I will not be focusing on these types of models specifically.*</i>

&nbsp;

With regard to guitar body size and neck width, guitars are not sized to specific body types and sizes. <strong>Adults should be able to play all full sized guitars in their preferred guitar type</strong> (listed above).

<strong>If you are a lefty, you can play a left-handed guitar,</strong> but most teachers and guitar salespeople would discourage it. It makes learning the instrument harder, since almost all people who play are right handed, and it also limits the types of guitars you can buy off the shelf. Most companies only make a handful of lefty models, which imposes restrictions on the types of guitars that you can purchase as you progress as a player.

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/picjumbo.com_IMG_9085.jpg"><img class=" wp-image-2626 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/picjumbo.com_IMG_9085-300x200.jpg" alt="picjumbo.com_IMG_9085" width="443" height="295" /></a>

&nbsp;
<h5>Three main types or most common guitar types on the market:</h5>
The first step you need to take is to select which type/style of guitar you are most interested in playing. This will help you to determine which type of guitar you will want to buy for your first instrument.

1) <strong>Steel String Acoustic:</strong> Used to play Blues, Rock, Soft Rock, Alternative, Fingerstyle, some styles of Jazz and Pop.

2) <strong>Nylon String:</strong> Used to play Classical Guitar, Flamenco, Latin Jazz, Bossa Nova, Fingerstyle, and Pop.

3) <strong>Solid Body Electric:</strong> Blues, Rock, Alternative, Soft Rock, Heavy Metal, Jazz, Electric Jazz, Fusion, Punk, Grunge, and Pop.

&nbsp;
<h5>How to decide which one is right for you:</h5>
1) <strong>Make a list of your favorite artists and bands.</strong>

2) <strong>Do some research and figure out what sort of guitars occur most often in their songs,</strong> especially your favorite songs). Imagine yourself playing along with these songs one day on your own instrument. Yes, that task may seem impossible now, but if you are determined, just about anything is possible in the world of music.

3) If you decide to go with a solid body electric guitar, <strong>do you have the space in your living environment for a guitar amplifier</strong>? An amplifier is what you plug into an electric guitar to have it produce an audible and often loud sound. Beginners do not need to buy anything fancy; a simple small practice amp will often do the trick.
<i></i>

&nbsp;

<i>*Quick side note about some things to keep in mind if buying a guitar for some else, specifically children: high quality ¼, ½ ,and ¾ size guitars are available on the market. Small bodied nylon string guitars are a good choice for children who are just starting to learn because the nylon string guitar bodies are small enough, comfortable to hold, and the string spacing is just wide enough for fingers to press without the fingers overlapping and getting in the way of other strings. *</i>

&nbsp;

&nbsp;
<h6><img class="wp-image-2613 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/Acoustic-V-Electric.jpg" alt="Acoustic V Electric" width="490" height="343" /></h6>
&nbsp;
<h5>General Shopping Advice:</h5>
1) <strong>If your schedule allows for it, avoid the weekends</strong> - especially Saturday. You will get less one-on-one attention, as the sales personnel will be trying to attend to the needs of more customers than on a typical week day. Sundays tend to be more relaxed but can also be very busy around the holidays. This means that weekdays in the afternoon, when most people are at work, are an optimal time for you to try out multiple instruments in a relaxed environment, where you can take your time and ask questions.

2) <strong>Do not be afraid to ask questions.</strong> The staff understands the buying experience well and remembers what it was like to be a beginner. Most are serious gear nerds, such as myself, and love introducing people to the endless musical avenues that one can venture down after deciding to start playing guitar. One of the highlights of my job is having the privilege of introducing people to the world of music from the perspective of a musician. It is both extremely gratifying and inspiring to witness another person getting excited about playing an instrument on a day to day basis. Playing guitar is an awesome feeling!

3)<strong> Pick a couple of models to try out,</strong> and take your time assessing how they feel in your hands and against your body. If the guitar is comfortable and balanced, you are on the right track to choosing one that will last you a long time. Do not buy a guitar purely for its aesthetic looks, or even worse, because someone insists that one name brand is better, based on popularity rather than on performance.

4) Even if you have never played, <strong>it is generally obvious when a guitar is not going work out for you.</strong> It will feel “wrong” in your hands and against your body. Picking out a guitar is like finding the right pair of pants. Trust me - you will know when you’re on the right track.

5) Guitars are personal. <strong>Pick out one that fits your needs as a player but also looks good to you as well.</strong> Lots of color options are available from various brands, especially when it comes to electric guitars. As has been mentioned before, the better the guitar fits your personality, the more likely you will enjoy playing and practicing on it.

6)<strong> Do not buy something just because it is “brand name.” </strong>Oftentimes, smaller guitar companies put more effort into building high quality instruments,, whose longevity and past successes often mask the quality and value of their current models, as compared to their larger name-brand competitors. This is epically evident in many intro and beginning level guitars. Yes, I am talking about you, Gibson. Just kidding…sort of!

7) <strong>Go with a friend who plays guitar and knows something about it.</strong> They can support you in your decision and give you another valuable opinion regarding how a specific guitar that you may be interested in looks, sounds, and feels. They can also help you keep the salesperson in check.

8) <strong>Remember that you’re not obligated to buy anything.</strong> This is true even if you have set aside the time to make a purchase. If you're feeling overwhelmed by all of the options and models, take some time to think things over, and go back on another day or even to a different store. Most importantly, NEVER buy anything because you feel as though you, as the customer, owe the salesperson for the time they spent with you. Remember, it’s their job to help you!!!

9) <strong>If a salesperson gets on your nerves or is being pushy, just tell them you need some space.</strong> They should/will leave you alone and only check in every now and then to help you assess the options available to you.

10) <strong>NEVER BE AFRAID TO ASK QUESTIONS!!!</strong>

&nbsp;

[caption id="attachment_2629" align="aligncenter" width="464"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/guitar-strings-accessories-01.jpg"><img class="wp-image-2629" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/guitar-strings-accessories-01-300x225.jpg" alt="" width="464" height="348" /></a> Photo: competitionmusic.net[/caption]

&nbsp;
<h5>Some other things to consider:</h5>
Recommended Accessories:

1) Electronic (Chromatic) Tuner

2) Strap

3) Picks

4) Extra Strings (Full set)

5) Basic Beginner Guitar Book/Video Combo or online subscription to guitar related resources.

6) Sign up to begin lessons with an experienced teacher.

&nbsp;
<h5>Things to look out for when examining a guitar:</h5>
1) Is there any obvious structural damage?

2) Is there any cosmetic damage?

3) Does the guitar look like it has been taken care of at the store?

4) Does it come with a warranty?

5) <strong>Does it come with a case?</strong> Soft or hard shell?  Most guitars do not come with a case. There are many options available. Generally, they fall into two categories “soft-shell” or “gig-bag” cases” and “hard-shell” cases, which are like a briefcase for your guitar. They are often made out of a combination of wood, plastic and sometimes even carbon fiber on the most expensive models. Most beginning guitars only need a “soft” gig-bag to protect the instrument. These carrying cases make it easy to transport the guitar, protect it from small impacts and scratches, and keep dust from building up on the finish when you’re not practicing or playing the instrument. The cost of a hard-shell case is typically not worth the cost in relation to the cost of your first guitar.

6) <strong>Is the neck straight?</strong> If you can tell that the neck is bent severely in either direction, stop and ask the salesperson to either fix it or bring you another one if you are seriously considering purchasing that model.

7) Is the string action (string height) low and comfortable?

8) <strong>What do the salespeople have to say about the guitar?</strong> Are they being honest, or are they just haggling with you trying to make a sale? If you want to see how honest a salesperson is, ask them a little about their own guitars and which ones they prefer most within the store. It’s a great way to start the guitar buying process because it breaks the ice and opens up lines of communication between both parties. Also, be sure to let them know about some of your favorite artist and musical styles. This can really save you a lot of time, since the salesperson will generally be able to focus in on the function that you need as a player.

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/Top-Guitar-Brands.jpg"><img class="wp-image-2624 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/Top-Guitar-Brands-300x200.jpg" alt="Top Guitar Brands" width="477" height="318" /></a>

&nbsp;

&nbsp;
<h5>Closing Thoughts:</h5>
It is easy to get caught up with and held back by the endless amounts of information available via the internet with regards to choosing a guitar. At the end of the day, the information presented here is just a mere set of guidelines intended to pique your interest and get you started on the right track. I am aware that this article is full of guitar-specific terminology. Do not let it intimidate you for even a second. It is easy and fun to learn!

There are many resources out there to help you. Do Google searches, ask your friends who play music, or visit a music retailer. Don’t be afraid to ask questions if playing guitar or any instrument interests you. Remember: trust your gut when it comes time to make your guitar purchase. Getting started is hard, but once you begin and learn your first few notes, you will feel great! The ultimate end goal of this purchase is to have fun playing guitar! I promise that you won’t regret it! I am going to go and play some guitar now! Thanks for reading!

&nbsp;

Special thanks to Aaron Sim and Alex Park for reviewing the article and helping me to clarify the information presented.

&nbsp;

Header Gif from Pitchfork.com]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Climb a Mountain</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-climb-a-mountain/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 16 Nov 2015 03:06:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[theresa-ohalloran]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2652</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[John Muir once said, "The mountains are calling, and I must go." Sometimes you just get that itch to get out of the house and go climb a mountain.

&nbsp;

Weekend warrioring varies from person to person. Some people might take a scenic road trip or spend the day at the beach. Others might wander through the desert or get lost in the forest. Like Mr. Muir, I enjoy spending my time in the mountains. Skiing, mountain biking, and rock climbing are all great activities, but some days, all I want to do is get up to the top of a cool peak.

&nbsp;

For the last few years, I’ve been lucky enough to live and work in Colorado and have had the pleasure of exploring trails and mountains throughout this beautiful state. In addition to Colorado, I’ve had a few adventures in the mountains of Utah, Wyoming, Montana, California, Washington state, Nepal, and Iceland.  This lifestyle of mountains and adventure was not always the case for me.

&nbsp;

Several years ago, I was a total hiking newbie. Sure, I liked being outside, and I had even done a few day hikes with friends, but the fact of the matter was that I had never really trekked up a mountain. Shoot, I had never even been backpacking, and I didn’t even own a pair of hiking boots. I won’t bore you with the details, but basically in 2010, I made some great friends, explored some great places, and I kinda became obsessed with mountains. And now here I am, excited to get you excited!

&nbsp;

I am not a mountaineer or a professional guide. I just happen to hike an absurd amount for work and fun and I’d like to think I’ve gained a fair bit of wisdom from my experiences (including my mistakes) in the mountains.

&nbsp;

Mountains can seem daunting, especially if you have limited experience hiking, being at a high altitude, or even being outdoors on your own.  For me, it’s about being prepared for the route, knowing and enjoying the physical challenge, bringing lots of snacks, and taking in the views. With any big project, you just have to take it one step at a time. Literally, just put one foot in front of the other and consider the following information before you tackle that big mountain.

&nbsp;
<h3>The Route</h3>
So, the first thing to consider is the actual route up the mountain. How many miles is the route? To what elevation (feet above sea level) will you be hiking? How steep or exposed is the route? These are all important things to research before you go. If the route is 22 miles roundtrip (the standard route up Mount Whitney) and you’ve never walked/ran more than 4 miles in your life, you might want to train more or start your mountain climbing career with something shorter.

[caption id="attachment_2666" align="aligncenter" width="604"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/Theresa-Mt.-Whitney-14505-ft-10_11.jpg"><img class="wp-image-2666 size-full" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/Theresa-Mt.-Whitney-14505-ft-10_11.jpg" alt="Me on top of Mt. Whitney (highest peak in the continental U.S.) " width="604" height="453" /></a> Me on top of Mt. Whitney (highest peak in the continental U.S.)[/caption]
<h3>Elevation/Altitude</h3>
If you live at sea level and the summit is higher than 8,000 feet, be aware of the potential for altitude sickness. Even if you are extremely fit, it is possible that you might get sick (headache, nausea,  or worse) if your body is not adjusted to the altitude. If you have never hiked at such a high elevation before and you want to help your body cope, you need to stay well-rested, hydrated, and fed. You need to take your time on the mountain.

&nbsp;
<h3>Level of Difficulty</h3>
The difficulty of a hike refers to the route’s steepness or exposure (the risk and consequences of a potential fall) and will range from <a href="http://www.14ers.com/classes.html">Class 1 to Class 5</a>.  Class 1 means that you are walking on level ground. Class 2 means that you are walking on an incline. A Class 3 route is steep and has terrain features (large boulders or snow) that require you to “scramble” aka occasionally use your hands to ascend or descend. A fall on a Class 3 route is unlikely but might result in serious injury. Class 4 means the terrain is steep and exposed, like <a href="https://vimeo.com/71757831">Capitol Peak’s super fun knife edge</a> (the business begins at 1:00), and falls can be fatal. Class 5 is technical climbing, using a rope is recommended, and you pretty much have to be a rock climber or partner with a climber. Class 5 can vary from “easy” routes, like the <a href="http://www.mountainproject.com/v/109495622">West Ridge</a> on Forbidden Peak in the Washington, to much more difficult routes, like those on The Diamond of Longs Peak in Colorado.

&nbsp;

If you are scared of heights, cliffs, etc, really research that exposure and figure out if it is something that you and your hiking partners are are comfortable with. My older sister cried when I took her up Lembert Dome in Yosemite. I think it is just the cutest little granite cliff on the east side of Tuolumne Meadows, but to her it was overwhelming. I was living in Yosemite and some friends and I had been scrambling up the south side of Lembert Dome a few times a week to watch the sunset. When my big sis came to visit, I thought I would be fun to take her up there one evening. It’s totally a safe route, maybe Class 3, but you are on this giant granite slab of rock. All was going well until we got halfway up and she starting getting REALLY scared. Long story short, we got to the top, but now she refers to that evening as “the time my sister took me up a mountain and I almost died.” Totally not true…

[caption id="attachment_2668" align="aligncenter" width="338"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/Theresa-The-Monastery-Big-Thompson-Canyon-11_14.jpg"><img class="wp-image-2668" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/Theresa-The-Monastery-Big-Thompson-Canyon-11_14-225x300.jpg" alt="Climbing the Monastery in Big Thompson Canyon, Colorado" width="338" height="450" /></a> Climbing the Monastery in Big Thompson Canyon, Colorado[/caption]
<h3>Length of Route</h3>
Another thing to consider is how long you think you will be hiking. This will determine the gear and amount of water and snacks you will want to bring. On average, people walk two miles per hour. This could slow to one mile per hour if the terrain is very steep (if you are gaining 1,000 feet in elevation over a distance of one mile) or if you are route-finding and doing a lot of off-trail travel.

&nbsp;
<h3>What to Bring</h3>
Once you have figured out your route and how long you think you will be hiking, it is time to figure out what you are going to bring. <a href="http://www.mountaineersbooks.org/assets/clientpages/zz_tenessentials.aspx">The Ten Essentials</a> are listed in almost every hiking guide, post, forum, etc. as the most important basic gear to bring on your outdoor adventure. This list is definitely a good place for us to start:
<ol>
	<li>Map and compass (a GPS works too)</li>
	<li>Sun protection (sunglasses, sunscreen, and chapstick)</li>
	<li>Insulation (i.e. extra clothes)</li>
	<li>Headlamp or flashlight (You never know if you might get stuck outside in the dark.)</li>
	<li>First Aid Kit</li>
	<li>Fire-making supplies (matches or lighter)</li>
	<li>Repair kit and tools (This is not really specific, but if you are afraid that something might break, bring the appropriate gadgets to fix it. Usually for me, this is just a matter of bringing a bit of duct tape, extra batteries, and a multitool.)</li>
	<li>Extra food</li>
	<li>Extra water</li>
	<li>Emergency shelter (You can purchase an <a href="http://www.rei.com/product/407104/space-emergency-blanket">emergency blanket for about $4 at REI</a>. They are very small, light, and easy to pack. This could come in handy if you are stuck during a storm and need some sort of shelter to keep you warm.)</li>
</ol>
&nbsp;
<h4>Additional items can include:</h4>
Bathroom supplies (toilet paper, a plastic bag to dispose dirty toilet paper, hand sanitizer, and a small shovel)
A small packable towel (in case the is a beautiful lake to swim in, duh)
Bug spray (because mosquitoes are the worst)
Camera

&nbsp;

You don’t need to spend a lot of money on any special hiking clothes or gear to climb your basic mountain. You can go up wearing a dress, running shoes, and a school backpack if you like, but be sure to bring clothes that will keep you warm. Additionally, use shoes that you are comfortable hiking in, and bring a pack that will hold all your food, water, and extra gear.
I’ll share some of specifics of what I currently like to bring, but keep in mind that I accumulated my gear over a long period of time after many, many paychecks.

&nbsp;
<h3>Clothes</h3>
Make sure that your clothes are comfortable and that you have extra layers to keep you warm. Usually, I wear lightweight hiking pants, a short-sleeved shirt, and light, long-sleeved shirt (Mostly for sun protection, this long sleeve shirt will be something that fits loosely and breathes easily.). During your hike, you will feel much warmer hiking up than when you are hiking down. However, as you hike up the mountain, it is likely that the surrounding temperature will become colder and colder ( 3-5 degrees Fahrenheit for every 1,000 feet of elevation gain). I tend to get cold easily, and I HATE being cold. Depending on how high the summit is, it will likely be cold and windy at the top (sometimes below freezing), so I would also recommend (at the very least) a warm jacket, beanie, and gloves. If you are like I am, and you get cold really easily, DO NOT forget these items. I usually bring way too many extra layers, but it is better to be prepared and carry the extra weight than to be cold and miserable. Therefore, I’ll bring a long-sleeved fleece, a down jacket, a waterproof shell, and if it is a multi-day trip, I might also bring a super small/light long-sleeve and long underwear. Like I said, I hate being really cold.

[caption id="attachment_2669" align="aligncenter" width="600"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/Theresa-Kala-Patthar-18448-ft-Sagarmatha-National-Park-Nepal-06_12.jpg"><img class="wp-image-2669" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/Theresa-Kala-Patthar-18448-ft-Sagarmatha-National-Park-Nepal-06_12-300x200.jpg" alt="Kala Patthar (18,448 ft), Sagarmatha National Park, Nepal " width="600" height="400" /></a> Kala Patthar (18,448 ft), Sagarmatha National Park, Nepal[/caption]
<h3>Food and Water</h3>
I also dislike being hungry and thirsty. When I was on Mount Rainier earlier this summer, I overheard one guy saying that he only ate ONE Nature Valley bar during his 15 hour hike to and from the summit! His group also ran out of water! Why would you do that to yourself?! If I’m hiking to the top of a mountain, I’ll bring 3 liters of water per day and enough snacks to eat at least once every one to two miles. I would recommend a variety of snacks, such as apples, sports bars, chocolate, and fruit snacks, in addition to a lunch (perhaps a wrap,sandwich, or last night’s leftovers). Also, if you are hiking with men, don't compare what you have with what they are bringing. They either bring a ton more because they just eat more than you, or they don't bring much because they are afraid of carrying a little extra weight. Just think about how much you would like to eat, and then bring a little extra, just in case.

&nbsp;

Especially if you are hiking at a higher altitude, don’t skimp on water. Dehydration increases the risk and severity of altitude sickness. If you are nervous about your water supply but are unsure about carrying a whole 3 liters at once, check in advance to see if there will be a stream or lake along the trail, and then bring a water filter or iodine tablets to purify the water.

&nbsp;
<h3>Have Fun!</h3>
Last but definitely not least, have fun! If you can convince yourself that the next ten, fifteen, or twenty miles are going to be awesome, they probably will be. Nevertheless, keep in mind the <a href="http://kellycordes.com/2009/11/02/the-fun-scale/">Fun Scale</a> throughout your adventure, especially when faced with making decisions. I can tell you from experience that hiking in the middle a lightning storm is not fun. Neither is hiking while sick or injured. Sure, Type 2 fun is normal however everyone in your group might not be adequately prepared for the sufferfest that might lie ahead. Adventures are supposed to be challenging but REMEMBER that your goal is not just getting to the top of the mountain, but also to make it back home. Even if you don’t make it to the summit during your first attempt, the mountain will always be there, waiting for your return.

&nbsp;

So get psyched! You are going to have a great time in a beautiful place with beautiful views! Sure, the hike won’t always be easy, but the mountains are calling. You should go.]]></content:encoded>
