	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Winging It Spotlight:  How To Recognize Generalized Anxiety Disorder in Yourself</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/the-winging-it-spotlight-meredith-arthur-on-how-to-recognize-generalized-anxiety-disorder-in-yourself/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 13 Nov 2015 03:57:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Contributor Coordinator]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2676</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 16px;">In our next installment of the Winging It Spotlight series, we interviewed <strong>Meredith Arthur</strong>, who wrote an inspiring and in-depth article about living with General Anxiety Disorder. </span></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 16px;">Below, reprinted with permission, is Arthur’s article about <strong>How To Recognize Generalized Anxiety Disorder</strong>, following by a short interview. Give it a read!  </span></p>


<hr />

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/mind-traveller.jpg"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-2705 size-full" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/mind-traveller.jpg" alt="mind traveller" width="800" height="800" /></a>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 16px;">When I was first diagnosed with Generalized Anxiety Disorder (by a neurologist in the middle of a migraine appointment), I thought, “Great! Search terms! Let’s get cozy, Google.”</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;">But I was wrong to assume simple screen time was going to help me find my path with my anxiety disorder. I found little online that informed me in any real way. For one thing, the word “worry” was used again and again. At the time, worry wasn’t what I did or how I identified. Thinking and overthinking, yes. Worry, no.</span><span style="font-size: 14px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">
</span></span>

<span style="font-size: 14px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2709 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/4-300x300.jpg" alt="4" width="300" height="300" />
</span><span style="font-size: 16px;">A few months after my July diagnosis, in Sept 2015, the tennis player <strong><a href="http://www.theplayerstribune.com/mardy-fish-us-open/">Mardy Fish wrote a great essay</a> </strong>that captures the</span>
<span style="font-size: 16px;"> experience of anxiety in vivid detail. At one point he sums it up:</span></span>
<h6 style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 16px;"> <span style="color: #ffcc00;">“I was, objectively, doing great. </span></span></h6>
<h6 style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 16px;"><span style="color: #ffcc00;">And looking back, I wish I had been able to tell myself that. </span><span style="color: #ffcc00;">But doing great wasn’t
something that my frame of mind back then had time to process. </span><span style="color: #ffcc00;">All I could focus on was doing better. It was a double- </span><span style="color: #ffcc00;">edged sword.”</span></span></h6>
<span style="font-size: 16px;">By the time I read Fish’s piece, he was confirming something I already knew. I’d talked to many people to piece together what GAD meant, found <span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong><a href="http://www.amazon.com/The-Worry-Cure-Seven-Stopping/dp/1400097665">a book that helped a lot</a>, </strong></span>and started to figure out my own particular form of anxiety for myself.</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;">The goal of this short FAQ is to help people like me when they’re just beginning their journey. You may be realizing you have anxiety. Maybe you’ve been told that you’re exhibiting some of the symptoms of Generalized Anxiety Disorder. If you are Googling the hell out of your keyboard right now and not finding answers to your questions, welcome, fellow mind traveller.</span>

<img class="size-medium wp-image-2710 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/5-300x300.jpg" alt="5" width="300" height="300" />

&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 16px;"><strong>Q: What is Generalized Anxiety Disorder, exactly?</strong></span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;"><span style="color: #333333; line-height: 1.42857;"><strong>A:</strong> </span>You’ve probably been researching this topic, so I’m not going to give you the same bland answer you’ve already seen about how it’s a psychological disorder characterized by excess “worry” particularly about work, finances, and relationships. I will say that some of the people I know with GAD didn’t know they had it for a long time. They didn’t characterize themselves as “worriers.” Books and doctors tell you that GAD means you worry about worry, but if you don’t even consider it worry, that doesn’t help. And if you are so habituated to pushing away the worry as a coping mechanism, then again, talking in those terms just leads to more trouble.</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;">For me, GAD meant that I was overthinking nearly everything in my life, scrupulously trying to figure it all out. If a problem came up, I’d write it down and begin my crazed attack in every direction. It also meant I had a ton of crippling shoulder and neck pain. I’d be nauseated frequently, especially on buses. I’d get dizzy occasionally, almost to the point of fainting. It was the physical symptoms that led my neurologist to know I had GAD.</span>

<strong><span style="font-size: 16px;">Q: Can a person have GAD and not know it?</span></strong>

<span style="font-size: 16px;"><span style="color: #333333; line-height: 1.42857;"><strong>A: </strong></span>Absolutely. It’s common for people who have GAD to see many doctors before they get properly diagnosed. Gastroenterologist, chiropractor, neurologist, acupuncturist, and gynecologist offices are some of the common stops along the path to diagnosis.</span>

<strong><span style="font-size: 16px;">Q: Is it hereditary?</span></strong>

<span style="font-size: 16px;"><span style="color: #333333; line-height: 1.42857;"><strong>A: </strong></span>I don’t know if this is everyone’s question, but it was one of mine. I wanted to understand where GAD was coming from. Yes, there is a genetic component. As is often the case, that’s only one part of the equation. You may have genetic roots and predisposition to anxiety disorders, but they are also triggered by environmental factors. The death of a loved one, divorce, the sudden loss of a job or your house, or a big change in circumstance can bring on episodic fare-up of GAD.</span>

<strong><span style="font-size: 16px;">Q: If it flares up, does that mean it’s dormant at other times?</span></strong>

<span style="font-size: 16px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;"><strong>A:</strong> </span>My understanding (I’m a patient, not a doctor!), is that you’re predisposed to GAD, but with proper treatment, you can bring your symptoms into check. But since you are predisposed to this condition, when things happen to you, you will be more likely to have bigger anxiety responses than other people. I almost think of it as a GAD <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sine_wave">sine wave</a>, and the equation is your life, and what’s happening in it.</span>

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/I-knew-something-was-wrong-but-not-what.-I-desperately-wanted-to-figure-it-out...-My-diagnosis-was-one-of-the-best-things-that’s-ever-happened-to-me..jpg"><img class="wp-image-2703 size-medium aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/I-knew-something-was-wrong-but-not-what.-I-desperately-wanted-to-figure-it-out...-My-diagnosis-was-one-of-the-best-things-that’s-ever-happened-to-me.-300x300.jpg" alt="I knew something was wrong, but not what. I desperately wanted to figure it out... My diagnosis was one of the best things that’s ever happened to me." width="300" height="300" /></a>

<strong><span style="font-size: 16px;">Q: How messed up are you, exactly? Please be specific.</span></strong>

<span style="font-size: 16px;"><span style="color: #333333; line-height: 1.42857;"><strong>A:</strong> </span>Very recent example: We have had a few ants in the bathroom lately.</span>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/2015-10-29-1446136578-3938525-antcircle-thumb.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-2686" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/2015-10-29-1446136578-3938525-antcircle-thumb-300x202.jpg" alt="2015-10-29-1446136578-3938525-antcircle-thumb" width="300" height="202" /></a></p>
<span style="font-size: 16px;">They appeared to be coming through the window. “We should probably replace the window,” was my immediate thought, and suggestion to my husband, even though we can’t afford it.</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;"><strong>I don’t see 5–10 ants.</strong> </span>I see the inevitable 100–200 ants that I imagine will invade and eventually carry off our house. It’s very hard for me to deal with the here and now when I am <span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong><a href="http://psychcentral.com/lib/what-is-catastrophizing/">catastrophizing</a></strong></span>. (That’s a <span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong><a href="http://psychcentral.com/lib/15-common-cognitive-distortions/">cognitive distortion</a></strong></span>. Learning to recognize cognitive distortions is one important element of cognitive behavioral therapy, the best method for treating GAD.)</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;">A friend put it well: “I realized that I did everything in a rush. Even simple things like brushing my teeth or making coffee. And 80 percent of what I do on a typical day does not require hurrying and rushing. That creates a lot of stress and worry throughout the day.” I know exactly what he means. I sometimes have the feeling that if I don’t get whatever small household task done at any given moment, the world might end. GADs are not known for their patience.</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;">The worst era of my anxiety disorder was the time before I knew I had it. I knew something was wrong, but not what. I desperately wanted to figure it out. I’d go down every known avenue trying to get an answer. My diagnosis was one of the best things that’s ever happened to me. I am very thankful for it.</span>

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/7.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2713 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/7-300x300.jpg" alt="7" width="300" height="300" /></a>

&nbsp;

<strong><span style="font-size: 16px;">Q: If I have GAD, how do I make it go away? Does it last forever?</span></strong>

<span style="font-size: 16px;"><span style="color: #333333; line-height: 1.42857;"><strong>A: </strong></span>Here’s my thinking on it. The ideal situation is that I’m able to ride the wave. Maybe even get to the point where I can hang in the lull for a long time with little anxiety. When stressful things happen, I expect that my particular gremlin will poke his head out of the wave’s crest. Knowing what to do with him and that I’ve survived his visits before helps a lot.</span>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/2015-10-29-1446136684-593560-1112VCF8y81qLIhgaWxg1Hg-thumb.jpeg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-2687" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/2015-10-29-1446136684-593560-1112VCF8y81qLIhgaWxg1Hg-thumb.jpeg" alt="2015-10-29-1446136684-593560-1112VCF8y81qLIhgaWxg1Hg-thumb" width="190" height="104" /></a></p>

<h6 style="text-align: center;"><em><span style="font-weight: 400;">How I ride the sine wave</span></em></h6>
<span style="font-size: 16px;"><span style="color: #000000;"><strong><a style="color: #000000;" href="https://www.headspace.com/">Meditation.</a> </strong></span><strong><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Escitalopram">Medication</a></strong>. A moderate amount of reading and learning (in other words, don’t overdo it). Communication.</span>

<strong><span style="font-size: 16px;">Q: Can anyone develop it? What’s the line between having it and just being a regular stressed out American?</span></strong>

<span style="font-size: 16px;"><strong>A:</strong> Right now, I am seeing the world through anxiety-tinted lenses, so I tend to see anxiety in a lot of people around me. Ultimately, though, the difference between regular anxiety, stress, and GAD comes down to degree. Most people aren’t fainting or getting up in the middle of the night. Most don’t need neck rubs every day. And most aren’t negatively predicting the outcomes of regular social interactions in a way that adds extra stress to daily life.</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;">One of my friends, who learned through my experience that he has GAD too, said, “I tend to project into the future as I experience almost everything. And I’m often planning how to deal with some negative turn of events that might happen in the future, but most likely never will. So I’m worrying in the present about something that will never happen in the future.” If that sounds familiar, you might want to read more about Generalized Anxiety Disorder.</span>

<strong><span style="font-size: 16px;">Q: Is this what has been wrong with me?</span></strong>

<span style="font-size: 16px;"><span style="color: #333333; line-height: 1.42857;"><strong>A:</strong></span> <span style="color: #333333; line-height: 1.42857;">I can’t tell you that, but I can tell you that if anything that I’ve said has rung true, a great place to start is the book </span><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong><a style="font-size: 14px; line-height: 1.42857; background-color: #ffffff;" href="http://www.amazon.com/The-Worry-Cure-Seven-Stopping/dp/1400097665"><i>The Worry Cure</i></a></strong></span><span style="color: #333333; line-height: 1.42857;"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">.</span> </span>Don’t think about the title too much and don’t think about the word “worry.” Just investigate your physical symptoms through the lens of your thoughts, and see if what this book has to say relates to you. If not, then you don’t have GAD.</span>

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/2.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2706 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/2-300x300.jpg" alt="2" width="300" height="300" /></a>

<strong><span style="font-size: 16px;">Q: Will I ever feel better?</span></strong>

<span style="font-size: 16px;"><span style="color: #333333; line-height: 1.42857;"><strong>A: </strong></span>I believe that you will feel better if you have GAD. This is a hard won statement coming from me. I am a skeptic and not one to placate you, reader. But I think that simply the fact of you reading this means that you are going to feel better.</span>

<strong><span style="font-size: 16px;">Q: How do you know?</span></strong>

<span style="font-size: 16px;"><span style="color: #333333; line-height: 1.42857;"><strong>A: </strong></span>Times are changing. People are talking openly about <span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong><a href="https://medium.com/@heatherarthur/depression-ad6566e8928b">depression</a></strong>,</span> anxiety, and other forms of mental suffering in a way that they never did when I was in my 20s. I’m so glad to see it on behalf of my 5-year-old daughter. The more people speak openly about the spectrum of mental conditions, the more they can be helped earlier on.</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;">I wouldn’t have dreamed of writing something this personal just one year ago. I now feel as though my anxiety needs to be an integrated part of me in order to be managed in a healthy way. I hope that others will feel that way too.</span>

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/6.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2711 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/6-300x300.jpg" alt="6" width="300" height="300" /></a>

<strong><span style="font-size: 16px;">Q: What should I do if I’m a friend or family member of a Gaddie?</span></strong>

<span style="font-size: 16px;"><strong>A:</strong> I feel for you. It’s not easy to deal with an anxious person, especially at the high pitch levels that people with GAD specialize in.</span>

[caption id="attachment_2688" align="alignright" width="313"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/2015-10-29-1446136773-4731351-968fullwhataboutbobscreenshot-thumb.jpg"><img class="wp-image-2688 " src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/2015-10-29-1446136773-4731351-968fullwhataboutbobscreenshot-thumb-300x168.jpg" alt="2015-10-29-1446136773-4731351-968fullwhataboutbobscreenshot-thumb" width="313" height="175" /></a> Yeah, I could see where Bob was coming from.[/caption]
<h6 style="text-align: center;"></h6>
<h6><span style="color: #ffcc00; font-size: 16px;">It’s hard to avoid the role of friend-therapist. You might find yourself talking your friend down and trying to give them a more realistic view of their surroundings. The goal is to help them build those muscles for themselves without exhausting yourself. Bottom line: get the oxygen mask on yourself first.</span></h6>
<span style="font-size: 16px;">On the other hand, it can also be confusing because GAD often presents as perfectionism, or invulnerability. How do you help someone who doesn’t seem to need help? Take in the information you have and tune in to your instincts. Is the person talking super fast? Are they in a lot of physical pain? Do they seem complainy? If so, they may need to learn to tune in to how they are responding to the world around them. As a friend, you can help by gently encouraging them to go easy on themselves and stay grounded in the moment.</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;">Send them a link to this piece. Do it with love.</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;">Friends help. A lot.</span>
<p style="text-align: left;"><span style="font-size: 16px;"><i>Meredith Arthur writes to clarify her ideas and create dialogue. Share a response if you have one, or connect with her </i><a href="https://twitter.com/mudaba"><i>on Twitter</i></a><i>.</i></span></p>


<hr />

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/Meredith_Arthur_TWIGG.png"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-2700 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/Meredith_Arthur_TWIGG-300x300.png" alt="Meredith_Arthur_TWIGG" width="300" height="300" /></a>
<h6 style="text-align: center;"><strong>(Meredith Arthur)</strong></h6>
<span style="font-size: 16px;"><strong>TWIGG How-To: How did you decide to share something so personal as your experiences with generalized anxiety disorder?</strong></span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;"><strong>Meredith Arthur: </strong>It wasn't easy to decide to write about Generalized Anxiety Disorder. When you have anxiety, thinking and writing about it is virtually the last thing you want to do. But I had an ace up my sleeve: I was convinced (and still am) that no one has written about it accurately online to date. So as much as I knew it would be uncomfortable, I also felt that I had an insight that others were missing. I wanted people to hear me. More importantly, I wanted to reach people who were just sitting there, staring at their keyboards, trying to Google and figure out what was wrong with them. If I could save them time and confusion, it was worth a few weeks of my own discomfort.</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;"><strong>THT: What impact did the diagnosis of GAD have on your life?</strong></span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;"><strong>MA:</strong> It's changed my life on many levels. I've likened it to someone picking me up off the earth, turning me around 180 degrees, and setting me back down. I feel like I've been given some basic key to understanding how my brain works that I've needed for a long, long time. In a very real way, I can say that my headaches have improved 75%. My neck and shoulder pain is going away. I don't get nauseated much anymore. I'd summarize it by saying that much of the time I can now figure out why I'm feeling the way I am. That wasn't how it used to be. I can't say that everything is simple, but it's a hell of a lot easier.</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;"><strong>THT: Meredith, you run a Facebook page called The Hero Series.  What is that?  How did you come up with the idea for The Hero Series?</strong></span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;"><strong>MA:</strong> I started <a href="http://theheroseries.com/"><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>The Hero Series</strong> </span></a>in the week following my GAD diagnosis. I wrote my first post the day before I turned 40. I was feeling very beaten down by what was happening in the news. I was sensitive to everyone's negative reaction to their news feeds. I was worried about the state of the world. I knew I had to do something to try to change my (and others') perspective. I wrote about it <a href="https://medium.com/@mudaba/the-hero-series-b1eef9f87169#.ol8hzu3hm">here</a>.</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;">The Hero Series is a <span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong><a href="http://theheroseries.com/">blog</a></strong></span>, <span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>a <a href="https://www.facebook.com/therealheroseries">Facebook community</a></strong></span>, <span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong><a href="https://twitter.com/theheroseries">Twitter</a> </strong></span>&amp; <span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong><a href="https://instagram.com/heroseries/">Instagram</a> </strong></span>feeds. The goal is simple: we want to counteract the negativity of the news by providing an alternative news feed. It's a platform where contributors write about the people and ideas that make us believe that change is possible.</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;">To get involved, just "like" the FB page or follow the Twitter or Instagram feeds. We're always looking for new contributors too.</span>

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/3.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2707 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/3-300x300.jpg" alt="3" width="300" height="300" /></a>

<hr />

<h4 style="text-align: center;"><span style="color: #ffcc00;">Are you a wingin' it lady looking to learn more about generalized anxiety disorder and mental health?</span></h4>
<h4 style="text-align: center;">See below for our recommended reading list:</h4>
<span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-life-after-college/">How to: Adjust to Life After College </a></strong></span>by TWIGGie Claire Perelman via TWIGG How-To

<strong><a href="http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/2/75b99926-77da-11e5-a95a-27d368e1ddf7.html#axzz3rL4UtH48"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Anxiety: the office fear factor</span> </a></strong>via Fortune<strong><i>
</i></strong>

<span style="text-decoration: underline;"><a href="http://time.com/4108442/mindfulness-meditation-pain-management/"><strong>Meditation Reduces Emotional Pain by 44%: Study</strong> </a></span>via Time

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Get Along with Roommates (Part I)</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-get-along-with-roommates-part-i/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 22 Nov 2015 16:52:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[diana-chen]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2735</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[When I got the news that I was going to have a roommate in college, the first thing my mom said was, “Don’t be a princess”. Today, after three lengthy years of college (where I never skipped a summer session) which resulted in living in eight apartments, I’ve learned that it’s not that you shouldn’t be a princess, but rather that you shouldn’t be a <em>bad</em> princess.  Traits of a good princess include being diplomatic, confident,self-aware, and being aware of the political climate—in this case, the ideas and feelings of the people you’re living with.  From my experience, all this wisdom can be summed up in four categories. Today I’ll discuss the first two. Stay tuned for Part II coming soon!

&nbsp;
<h3>1.    Know Thyself</h3>
One of the most important things I’ve realized while embracing any new social environment is the importance of self-awareness.  In order to start a relationship in an intimate space off on the right foot, you need to have a clear understanding of <strong>your own boundaries</strong> as well as <strong>the effect –positive or negative – of your actions</strong> on the people around you.

[caption id="attachment_2762" align="aligncenter" width="385"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/2014-01-11-tumblr_mhtksiPT8C1qa3rcxo1_500.gif"><img class="wp-image-2762" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/2014-01-11-tumblr_mhtksiPT8C1qa3rcxo1_500-300x169.gif" alt="2014-01-11-tumblr_mhtksiPT8C1qa3rcxo1_500" width="385" height="217" /></a> We're with you, Jess. From HuffingtonPost.com[/caption]

First off:  boundaries.  As an out-of-stater starting at UCLA, there were no familiar faces within a hundred mile radius when I started my freshman year.  And, as an introvert, it was a challenge to find a niche in a fast-paced school while also fulfilling my penchants for alone-time and one-on-one conversations.  That September, I was lucky enough to meet a few beautiful, interesting, and very social girls (that I’m proud to still call friends) in the dorms next door who introduced me to a handful of people.  Although I bought Christmas presents my freshman year for nine people who I considered my best friends, I only trust and hold a handful of these people close to my heart today.  No matter how <em>comfortable</em> the idea of having a plethora of friends when you embark on college can be, you have to be comfortable as well.  When it comes to roommates and friendships alike, <strong>you should never compromise the feeling of safety in your own space</strong> for pleasing others <em>or</em> to avoid conflict.  If your roommate is doing something that is continuously making you uncomfortable, let them know.  It is much more rewarding to use your energies to reach a compromise early than to wait until things build up and spend your energy on greater issues.

&nbsp;

On the other end of things, if you catch yourself being a bit unreasonable—<strong>be the bigger person</strong>.  If you’re like me, you grew up having the luxury of your own room, or perhaps at least lived around family members who shared your values, habits and idiosyncrasies.  However, your roommate, even if she’s your best friend, may not be privy to <em>all</em> these idiosyncrasies.  The truth is, everybody is different and no two people view the world the same way. This is helpful to keep in mind when you sense tension between you and your roommate over small things.  What you may not perceive as a large nuisance, your roommate might think it’s a big deal (and vice versa).  In general, it is always advantageous to <strong>hone the power of stepping into another person’s shoes</strong> and be sensitive to <em>their</em> comfort level.  Keeping a constant rapport with your roommate throughout the year will not only nourish an easygoing atmosphere, but also help you solve problems before they even start.  Which brings us to…

&nbsp;
<h3>2.    Know Your Roommate(s)</h3>
When it comes to getting to know your roommate (or roommates), do not underestimate the power of <strong>bonding activities</strong>.  Many of the closest friendships I nurtured at UCLA started with unsuccessfully made cookies, lipstick sampling, and Chick-Fil-A.  Even if you’re skeptical about the cheesy activities that bonding entails or feel that you and your roommate are simply too different, these activities establish a certain level of comfort between you and your roommate that can be a foundation if future obstacles arise.

[caption id="attachment_2763" align="aligncenter" width="404"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/johntuckergif.gif"><img class="wp-image-2763" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/johntuckergif-300x139.gif" alt="johntuckergif" width="404" height="187" /></a> One of our favorite bonding activities. From giphy.com[/caption]

So, we’ve touched upon the importance of communication.  With this comes the importance of <strong>empathy</strong>.  To be a decent human being and roommate alike (see a theme here), it is paramount to be understanding of, as well as sensitive to, the cultural differences that may exist between you and those you live with.  For instance, depending on one’s culture, different aspects of sharing a living space and college in general may be hard to adjust to.  For instance, while you may find socializing with those around you to be a positive and rewarding experience, someone who comes from a culture where intimate relationships take longer to build (or someone who is introverted) may not.  Therefore, it is wise to be understanding and not take it personally when a roommate takes longer than expected to warm up to you.  On the flipside, <em>you</em> may come from a home where bedtimes and study times are uniform.  From my own experience, when I’ve asked my housemates to quiet down or turn off the lights when it was my time to sleep, they were not only polite, but most of them didn’t even realize that these things would bother me.  Instead of chalking it up to their lack of sensitivity, however, I concluded that perhaps many of my roommates were used to falling asleep amidst noise or with the lights on. In most of these cases, I was right.

&nbsp;

As you can see, the overriding rule of thumb is to not jump to conclusions when your roommate acts contrary to what you’re used to.  The key words here are <em>used to</em>, as I’m obviously not condoning you not standing up for yourself when something is making you truly uncomfortable (see category 1).  Since most of us didn’t attend a high school with tens of thousands of students from diverse areas around the world, it’s easy to generalize the public to the small demographic we’ve been used to.  My advice is not to generalize.  Especially in college, each person you meet comes from a unique culture and upbringing.  It’s wise, mature, and rewarding to give your roommates the benefit of the doubt.

&nbsp;

Stay tuned for Part II with the final two categories on how to get along with roommates!

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

Header Gif: tumblr.com]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Throw A (Stress-Free) Thanksgiving</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-throw-a-stress-free-thanksgiving/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 20 Nov 2015 01:10:59 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jenny-dorsey]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2738</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Thanksgiving is meant for spending quality time with your family, but it can quickly devolve into a stressful day of cooking and cleaning. For the chef who’s in charge of cooking most of the meal, here are some organizational tips to make this year’s Thanksgiving easier on everyone so you can focus on the most important thing – each other!

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/picjumbo.com_HNCK7936.jpg"><img class=" wp-image-2744 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/picjumbo.com_HNCK7936-300x200.jpg" alt="picjumbo.com_HNCK7936" width="405" height="270" /></a>

&nbsp;
<h4>1. Order delivery of your groceries to arrive Tuesday night.</h4>
Skip the lines (and frequent stock-outs) at the store by ordering groceries online. Thanksgiving orders are usually large enough to qualify for free shipping, not to mention receiving everything Tuesday gives you ample time on Wednesday and Thursday to prep. If you do end up forgetting something, you also still have another day to pick it up!

&nbsp;
<h4>2. Delegate!</h4>
You don’t have to do every single thing for Thanksgiving. It’s easy to feel too rushed to properly delegate on the day of, so it’s important to let your family and friends know what they are each in charge of before the big day. Then you can focus on what you need to do. Here’s a few of the main things that clear up clutter in your mind and free up your day:
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>a)</strong> Set the table and clean the space.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>b)</strong> Delegate drinks for the dinner. Think about wine, punch for the kids, aperitifs / digestifs, etc.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>c)</strong> Check your plateware and silverware. Make sure there’s enough for everyone.</p>
&nbsp;
<h4>3. Prepare your kitchen.</h4>
The last thing you want to do is scramble on Thanksgiving Day to ready your kitchen for some heavy-duty work. Make sure to have some key contributors prepared in advance:

<strong>Buy an oven-safe thermometer for turkey.</strong> I mean the kind you can insert into the bird, close the door and leave on the counter to alert you. Never worry about overcooking again!

<strong>Get comfy kitchen mats.</strong> You’ll be on your feet most of the day, so rubber mats are important to protect your feet from aching. These are generally a good idea for all kitchens.

<strong>Wear proper kitchen shoes.</strong> Cooking all day in slippers or even sneakers is not a good idea. Invest in a nice pair of rubber, anti-slip kitchen clogs and put some insoles in there.

<strong>Sharpen your knives.</strong> Dull knives make for ugly cuts of meat and strangely shaped vegetables. Make sure to sharpen your knife beforehand – lots of kitchen stores can do this for a minimal fee if you’d prefer to not do it yourself. Remember steeling and sharpening your knife are two different things and you need to do both beforehand.

<strong>Free up your counter space.</strong> You’ll need plenty of counter space for cutting and plating, so put away your coffee pots and other countertop items.

<strong>Haul out the appliances before-hand</strong>. Bring out the dusty blender, mixer, potato masher, pyrex and any other tools you’ll need for the meal the night before so you don’t have to break your focus to dig them up.

<strong>Buy stackable leftover containers.</strong> What is Thanksgiving without lots of tasty leftovers? Avoid letting them clutter up your whole refrigerator by using the industry standard of pint and quart containers. You can easily label these with some tape and a sharpie, plus they stack on top of each other to maximize space.

<strong>Get ice.</strong> You will need ice. Go buy some!

&nbsp;
<h4>4. Go disposable!</h4>
It’s simply not imperative everyone gets served in fine china if the food is tasty! You can purchase plenty of nice, china-esque heavy plastic plates, cups, bowls and silver-esque utensils for an easy-peasy cleanup at the end of the night. Recycle these if possible!

&nbsp;
<h4>5. Ditch the recipes (or follow them a little more loosely) to save yourself time.</h4>
Thanksgiving is a time where everyone loves to dive into “The Ultimate Pie Book” or “Stuffing To Make You Yearn for Centuries” but the truth is, unless ingredients are given in weight (grams) and you intend to also weigh everything, the measurements are approximate anyway - so go ahead and use your best judgment instead of wasting time digging butter out of that ¼ cup measure.

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/picjumbo.com_IMG_3413.jpg"><img class=" wp-image-2745 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/picjumbo.com_IMG_3413-300x200.jpg" alt="picjumbo.com_IMG_3413" width="445" height="296" /></a>

&nbsp;
<h4>6. Advance prep is key; reheating is your friend!</h4>
No one gives restaurants a dirty look for preparing things in advance, so you should take the same approach to your Thanksgiving feast. There are many items you can either prepare or at least process the night before to make your day go much smoother.
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>a)</strong> Desserts like pumpkin and pecan pie can be made the night before and reheated in the oven. Yes, the pie crust will still be flaky!</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>b)</strong> Cut your vegetables the night before, like peeling potatoes, dicing onions or trimming asparagus. This will make the cooking process much easier the day of!</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><strong>c)</strong> If you’re kitchen-savvy, sous-vide is a great way to reheat! Premade mashed potatoes, mac-n-cheese and soups are all great options.</p>
&nbsp;
<h4>7. Make sure you have food for yourself to eat during the day while you’re prepping.</h4>
Don’t give yourself a case of the hangries while you’re preparing for Thanksgiving. Buy some premade food and snacks in the fridge for yourself to nibble on throughout the day. Some electrolytes don’t hurt either!

&nbsp;
<h4>8. Play some music. It’ll make the air much less stiff.</h4>
Do this the very first thing or you’ll immediately forget. There’s lots of good playlists for this on Spotify.

&nbsp;
<h4>9. Have a schedule on a roughly 1-hour basis, but give yourself plenty of “buffer” time.</h4>
A schedule is the best way to keep yourself organized and your mind calm. This is also an effective way to effectively cross-utilize appliances (i.e. prepping 2 items to be blended back-to-back) and avoiding changing the oven temperature (i.e. 350F for cookies and roasting some garlic). Things always take longer than anticipated, so instead of being behind give yourself plenty of extra time to sort through the day. That way you can anticipate what you should do the night before and (hopefully) wind up with some breathing time the day of.

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/picjumbo.com_HNCK2390.jpg"><img class=" wp-image-2746 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/picjumbo.com_HNCK2390-300x200.jpg" alt="picjumbo.com_HNCK2390" width="455" height="303" /></a>

&nbsp;
<h4>10. Set a time for entrees to come to the table.</h4>
Set expectations early by letting your guests know when to expect the main courses. To make sure they don’t get hungry, get some pre-made cheese, charcuterie or hummus plates and have your (delegated!) drink guests come early so everyone has something to sip and snack as you put on finishing touches.

&nbsp;

So there you have it! If you follow these steps, you’ll have a fabulous, stress-free Thanksgiving.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Rock An Informational Interview</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-rock-an-informational-interview/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 01 Dec 2015 02:17:53 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Rachel Wiegardt-Egel]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2386</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/How-To-Rock-An-Informational-Interview.jpg"><img class="wp-image-2395 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/How-To-Rock-An-Informational-Interview-1024x683.jpg" alt="How-To--Rock-An-Informational-Interview" width="367" height="245" /></a>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 16px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">As any recent college grad/career-changer knows, finding a job can be a challenge</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">—</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">especially if you’re not sure what field you want to pursue. I’m here to let you in on a well-kept job-seeker’s secret: the informational interview. Informational interviews are underrated and underused, but they’re an invaluable tool. In the past few years, I’ve found my way into working in a pretty niche field and secured a position in the literary department of a theater in Los Angeles. Before my current situation, I’d had four different short-term jobs in this field all over the country, and I can trace every single one of them to a series of informational interviews I did during my senior year of college.</span></span>

<span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 16px;">Perhaps you’ve heard the old adage, “People hire people who they know and like.” No? Well, maybe it isn’t actually a universal saying, but it’s something my dad has repeated enough that it’s started to feel like one for me. The theory is true, though, and it’s the whole idea behind networking. But how do you get to know the right people? You could attend a networking event for a particular field, but how do you even know if a given field is for you? That’s where the informational interview can come in handy.</span>

&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 20px;"><b>WHAT IS IT?</b></span>
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 16px;">An informational interview is meant to give you a window into the career of someone working in a field that you’re curious about. This is an opportunity to hear how this person got to where they are and what the job is actually like on a daily basis.</span></li>
</ul>
&nbsp;
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-size: 16px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Here’s the main thing to know about an informational interview:</span><b> you are not</b><b>—</b><b>I repeat, you are NOT</b><b>—</b><b>there to get a job</b><span style="font-weight: 400;">. You’re there to learn, to make a connection, and to hopefully have a fun and interesting conversation.</span></span></li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 20px;"><b>HOW DO I GET ONE?</b></span>
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 16px;">Start researching companies that you find intriguing, or identify a job that you think could be interesting and see who’s doing that job in your area. Once you’ve found someone that you’d like to talk to, send them an email saying that you might be interested in pursuing a similar career and asking if they would be willing to sit down with you for a short chat about their career path and the work that they do. (Be sure to emphasize that it will be brief!)</span></li>
</ul>
&nbsp;
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 16px;">I’ve generally found that people like to help other people, so it’s rare that someone is unwilling to take 15-20 minutes to talk about their job, even if they’re busy. Plus, what do you have to lose? If you don’t get a positive response, don’t worry about it and just find someone else to email.</span></li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 20px;"><b>WHAT DO I SAY DURING THE INTERVIEW?</b></span>
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 16px;">Prepare some questions ahead of time. Some good sample questions include:</span>
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 16px;">How did you get where you are, career-wise?</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 16px;">Did you go to grad school? Why or why not?</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 16px;">What is a typical day like in your job?</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 16px;">What is most rewarding and most challenging about your job?</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 16px;">What practical advice do you have for someone who might be interested in doing what you do?</span></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-size: 16px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Remember, you’re not the one being interviewed. You want to make a good impression, but </span><b>you’re not there to show off</b><span style="font-weight: 400;">. If they ask you questions, give a concise answer and try to gracefully divert the conversation back to them (</span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">eg:</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;"> “I found what you said about _____ so interesting. I’d love to hear more about that.”).</span></span></li>
</ul>
&nbsp;
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-size: 16px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Even if it’s a fantastic conversation, be sure to offer your interviewee an out when you hit the 15 or 20 minute mark. They may brush off the suggestion that you wrap up</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">—</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">my favorite informational interview lasted for an hour, and we went to get a cup of coffee in the middle of it</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">—</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">but it’s important to be respectful of their time.</span></span></li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

<span style="font-size: 20px;"><b>HOW DO I FOLLOW UP?</b></span>
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 16px;">Send a thank you email, or even a card! Nothing quite beats a handwritten thank you note, even if it takes a bit longer.</span></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-size: 16px;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">If you’re invited to stay in touch, take advantage of the offer. Keep your new contact posted on your job exploration/search</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">—</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">you never know when they might have an opening or know of one at another company!</span></span></li>
</ul>
&nbsp;
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 16px;">It can also be really helpful to ask for “homework” of sorts and then to touch base about that afterward. For example: since I wanted to work in theater, I would ask people what plays they thought I should read, and then I would read those plays and email them some brief thoughts. If you can do something similar, it shows that you’re serious about the work, that you listened to their suggestions, and that you can follow through on a task.</span></li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

<span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 16px;">One of the best things that informational interviews do is to give you a sense of the kind of people with whom you could be spending your days. If you get along really well and see a lot of similarities between yourself and your informational interviewee, it can be amazingly helpful in clarifying whether this career goal is for you. And best of all, this kind of interview gives you a ton of information (it’s right there in the name) while still keeping the situation pretty low stakes for you. So, put on your most charming first-impression work outfit and go exploring! </span>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Covertly Carry a Tampon to the Bathroom</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/covertly-carry-tampon-bathroom/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 22 Jan 2016 09:02:12 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[CAITLYN]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2495</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[&nbsp;

<strong>14 year-old Hannah sent in the following request:</strong>

<em>"I am about to enter high-school and I'm really nervous about how to take a tampon to the bathroom when a lot of my older friends say teachers don't let you bring your purse to the bathroom (they think we will use our phones). Do you have any tips?"</em>

&nbsp;

Fear not, Hannah - we've got 5 tampon carrying tactics below complete with GIF's!

My number one piece of advice is:

&nbsp;
<h4 style="text-align: center;">Carry the tampon to the bathroom.</h4>
<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/tampon1.gif" rel="attachment wp-att-2949"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-2949" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/tampon1.gif" alt="tampon1" width="328" height="321" /></a>

&nbsp;

Having your period is something completely and utterly natural - it should REALLY be nothing to be ashamed of. It's your body doing what it is supposed to do - the same as sweating when you're hot, or blinking throughout the day. For that reason, I would encourage you just to carry your tampon to the bathroom with gusto.

Before you protest though, let me say - I get it. Sometimes you don't want to make a huge feminist stance about the natural processes of the female body and society's shaming every time you head to the bathroom. Sometimes you  just want to take care of business and get back to work. I get it girl, and for that reason, I now present to you 5 other <em>covert </em>ways to take a tampon to the bathroom from your TWIGG How-To sisters.

<hr />

&nbsp;
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/tampon2.gif" rel="attachment wp-att-2950"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-2950" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/tampon2.gif" alt="tampon2" width="347" height="349" /></a></p>

<h4 style="text-align: center;">Tuck it in your sleeve.</h4>
&nbsp;
<h4 style="text-align: center;"></h4>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/tampon6.gif" rel="attachment wp-att-2954"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-2954" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/tampon6.gif" alt="tampon6" width="335" height="264" /></a></p>

<h4 style="text-align: center;">Store it in your sunglasses case.</h4>
&nbsp;
<h4 style="text-align: center;"></h4>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/tampon4.gif" rel="attachment wp-att-2952"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-2952" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/tampon4.gif" alt="tampon4" width="336" height="285" /></a></p>

<h4 style="text-align: center;">Stash it in your bra.</h4>
&nbsp;
<h4 style="text-align: center;"></h4>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/tampon5.gif" rel="attachment wp-att-2953"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-2953" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/tampon5.gif" alt="tampon5" width="326" height="465" /></a></p>

<h4 style="text-align: center;">Carry it in your booties.</h4>
&nbsp;
<h4 style="text-align: center;"></h4>
<h4 style="text-align: center;"></h4>
<h4 style="text-align: center;"></h4>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/tampon7.gif" rel="attachment wp-att-2955"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-2955" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/tampon7.gif" alt="tampon7" width="323" height="431" /></a></p>

<h4 style="text-align: center;">Hide it in your pocket.</h4>
&nbsp;

&nbsp;
<p style="text-align: center;"><strong>BONUS TIP</strong></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/tampon3.gif" rel="attachment wp-att-2951"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-2951" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/tampon3.gif" alt="tampon3" width="330" height="420" /></a></p>

<h4 style="text-align: center;"> Bury it in your bun! (this may only work for my fellow big hair babes, but what the hell right?)</h4>
&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Work / Intern / Volunteer Abroad</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-work-intern-volunteer-abroad/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 11 Dec 2015 02:17:48 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[alesha-dailey]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2654</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/tumblr_n02k2c2cFO1r4wofko1_500.gif" rel="attachment wp-att-2803"><img class=" wp-image-2803 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/tumblr_n02k2c2cFO1r4wofko1_500-300x200.gif" alt="tumblr_n02k2c2cFO1r4wofko1_500" width="341" height="227" /></a>

Two years ago, I decided to take the biggest risk of my life and move abroad. Even though this started out as a spur-of-the-moment decision made in a bar after a few too many cocktails, it was still a well thought-out choice, far from the romanticized conclusion in the movies where the film immediately cuts to the brave heroine boarding a plane for her next grand adventure. It took me a solid five months to plan and prepare everything, which was still a time crunch. I wish I could say that moving abroad to work/volunteer/intern is as simple as first buying a plane ticket and then finding a job, but it’s not.

&nbsp;

Working in a foreign country is undoubtedly one of the most unique, rewarding, transformative, and terrifying experiences you will ever know. Not everyone is fortunate enough to take advantage of learning about new languages, cultures, and all that the world has to offer. As an American, I am undoubtedly endowed with certain privileges when traveling abroad. English is widely used all over the world, and at the very least, understood, which makes communicating significantly easier. Also, the American passport is one of the most powerful in the world, enabling me to gain entry into 147 countries. For many people all over the world, the prospect of moving to another country is not often a choice or the result of a privileged position. It’s important, that if you ever find yourself fortunate enough to be able to venture out into the world for your own personal betterment, to seize the opportunity and embrace what’s in front of you.

&nbsp;

Before you start packing your bags, here are some helpful hints on how to work, intern, and volunteer abroad:

&nbsp;
<h3><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/picjumbo.com_HNCK8177.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2798"><img class=" wp-image-2798 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/picjumbo.com_HNCK8177-300x200.jpg" alt="picjumbo.com_HNCK8177" width="360" height="240" /></a></h3>
<h3 style="text-align: center;">Pick Your Destination</h3>
Sure, this might be the most obvious step, but it is not exactly the easiest. Start Googling every city/country you have ever thought about visiting, and then start researching what the quality of life is like in those places (i.e. job opportunities, access to public transportation, cost of living, healthcare, etc.). All of these details can help you to make an informed decision.

&nbsp;

Keep in mind the kind of work you want to do, and find a place that facilitates your passions. Sometimes, your target country’s economic situation or political climate might present difficulties, which can affect decisions about where you want to live.  If you want to teach English as a second language, think about moving to places in Asia or South America where the demand is greater. Now that they are coming out of their economic downturn, <a href="http://www.independent.ie/business/technology/dublin-to-overtake-london-as-europes-technology-hub-30025030.html">Ireland has a huge startup and tech scene</a>, which is great if you’re interested in computer programming, website design, engineering, etc.  Also, there are many opportunities to work in the hospitality and service industries in places like Australia and New Zealand since these countries make it extremely easy for expats to receive temporary work visas.

&nbsp;

Don’t automatically assume that European countries are the best or easiest places for living abroad. In fact, you might be surprised to learn that European nations are frequently listed as some of the <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2013/11/05/want-to-move-abroad-this-map-shows-the-best-and-worst-countries-to-be-an-expatriate/">worse places for expats</a> who are looking to work, volunteer, and intern, simply because their laws make it mandatory for them to hire EU citizens before they will hire you.

&nbsp;

“But, I don’t know the language!” Don’t let this be an automatic deterrent for you. It is the perfect opportunity to learn a language you always wished you could speak! It is surprising how quickly you can pick up a language when circumstances force you to do so! Plus, as native English speakers, we Americans find ourselves in a unique position: English is often used as the “default” language in many foreign countries, so many companies will hire you because you speak English.

&nbsp;
<h3><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/picjumbo.com_HNCK5096.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2799"><img class=" wp-image-2799 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/picjumbo.com_HNCK5096-300x200.jpg" alt="picjumbo.com_HNCK5096" width="364" height="242" /></a></h3>
<h3 style="text-align: center;">Logistics</h3>
Now that you have decided on where you are going, it’s time to start preparing all of the specific  details. And, by “details”, I mean paperwork…lots and lots of paperwork.

&nbsp;

Assuming that you have a passport (If you don’t have a passport, stop reading this and go get one!), the next BIG items to consider are any necessary visas and/or work permits. Without these, your move abroad won’t last very long. The type of documentation needed for you to move abroad can vary from country to country, and certain requirements can also depend on whether you are interning, working for pay, or volunteering.

&nbsp;

The <a href="http://travel.state.gov/content/visas/en.html">U.S. Department of State</a> website is a great resource for travelers who are figuring out what they need before they leave. This website offers a breakdown on each country’s requirements, what is needed to apply, and how long it takes to approve a visa/work permit.

&nbsp;

“I need insurance?!?” YES! Travel and medical insurance are imperative, no matter the length of time you intend to stay. There are many companies that offer affordable coverage through their benefits packages. My recommendation is to always check with your current medical insurance provider to see what coverage you already have or if they offer different plans. If they don’t, find a reputable company like Blue Cross/Blue Shield, Travel Guard, Allianz Global Assistance, etc. and always compare your options. Things to consider when choosing a travel medical plan:
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">• Pre-existing conditions</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">• Destination(s) of travel and associated health risks</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">• Length of your stay</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">• High-risk activities</p>
&nbsp;

Did you know that your credit card might <a href="http://www.usatoday.com/story/travel/columnist/hobica/2014/08/19/credit-card-travel-insurance-policy/14241701/">offer you general travel insurance</a> that covers everything from lost baggage to flight delays? True story.

&nbsp;

Moving to another country for work can wreak serious havoc on your finances. Residency and taxation issues are some of the biggest grey areas you will encounter when moving abroad. Bear in mind that you will have to adhere to the banking and tax rules of not only your new destination but also your home country. For U.S. citizens, you can owe taxes on the same income in both the U.S. and the nation to which you’ve moved. Regarding this possibility, the biggest piece of advice I can offer is DO YOUR RESEARCH!

&nbsp;
<h3><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/corporate-863694_1920.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2800"><img class=" wp-image-2800 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/corporate-863694_1920-300x200.jpg" alt="corporate-863694_1920" width="376" height="251" /></a></h3>
<h3 style="text-align: center;">Finding Work And Keeping It</h3>
Don’t think that moving abroad means that you are stuck bartending, or working in a hostel (not that there is anything wrong with that!). There are opportunities out there for you to achieve your professional and personal goals no matter what they may be.

&nbsp;

Some of the most popular ways to work abroad include:
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">• Become an international aid worker</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">• Work for a global company</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">• Teach English</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">• Find a work exchange</p>
&nbsp;

If you are under the age of 30 and are willing to work a service position or low-wage office job – office assistant, laborer, bartender, or waiter etc. -– finding work will undeniably be easier. The pay isn’t great, but it’s enough to live on, and you can save up extra money to travel more.

&nbsp;

For those of you with a skill or a college degree looking to add international work experience to your CV, finding work is hard but definitely not impossible. This type of career advancement  requires a lot of time and networking. Plus, certain visa rules require companies to give employment preferences to citizens first.

&nbsp;

Some steps to help you find a job overseas:
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">• Search online job boards like <a href="http://myworldabroad.com">My World Abroad</a>, <a href="http://www.globalplacementsinternational.com/">Global Placements International</a>, and <a href="http://www.globalplacementsinternational.com/">Transitions Abroad)</a></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">• Join expat groups</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">• Network</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">• Apply for jobs from local job boards once you arrive</p>
&nbsp;

If you have the money to spare, working through a third party company to help you find work, internships, and volunteer opportunities will make your search much easier. Plus, a lot of these organizations help you to find housing as well. Some great affordable options include:
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">• <a href="http://www.ciee.org/">Council on International Educational Exchange Work Abroad Program (CIEE)</a></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">• <a href="http://www.allianceabroad.com/">Alliances Abroad</a></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">• <a href="http://worldendeavors.com/">World Endeavors</a></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">• <a href="http://www.bunac.org/">BUNAC</a></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">• <a href="http://www.peacecorps.gov/">Peace Corps</a></p>
&nbsp;

Finding work is one thing, but what about keeping it? Always remember that YOU are a visitor. A particular country's expectations in the workplace might differ greatly from what you are used to back home. This isn’t a negative idea, but a simple reminder that your way is not always the right way. Every country has their own ways of working and it is up to you as the visitor to adapt and step up to the challenges that this can present for you professionally and personally.

&nbsp;

Whether you are sitting in an office, waiting tables, teaching English, working in your field, or volunteering as an aid worker, you are in the midst of an experience that will forever change you as a person. Living in a different country is an adventure that teaches you a lot about yourself and your perceptions about the world. Always remember that you are a visitor and a student of the country and culture in which you find yourself. Open up to it. Embrace it. Learn from it. At the end of the day, no matter the challenges, travel is what it is all about—the chance to explore new places and new parts within yourself.

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/tumblr_m9f8tgTvST1rdt98to1_500.gif" rel="attachment wp-att-2804"><img class=" wp-image-2804 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/tumblr_m9f8tgTvST1rdt98to1_500-300x125.gif" alt="tumblr_m9f8tgTvST1rdt98to1_500" width="346" height="144" /></a>
<p style="text-align: center;">Bon voyage!</p>]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:10:{i:0;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1743";s:5:"score";s:17:"39.63162173404466";}i:1;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1965";s:5:"score";s:18:"23.226291577457822";}i:2;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2846";s:5:"score";s:18:"22.204640329493408";}i:3;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2132";s:5:"score";s:18:"21.393710113263566";}i:4;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"262";s:5:"score";s:18:"21.143383827639337";}i:5;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1581";s:5:"score";s:18:"18.621121390983244";}i:6;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2428";s:5:"score";s:17:"18.22009493952857";}i:7;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2652";s:5:"score";s:18:"18.201680329559643";}i:8;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"791";s:5:"score";s:18:"16.815385968439756";}i:9;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"768";s:5:"score";s:18:"16.815385968439756";}}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Get Along With Roommates (Part II)</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-get-along-with-roommates-part-ii/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 04 Dec 2015 02:03:06 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[diana-chen]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2773</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-get-along-with-roommates-part-i/">part one</a> I discussed knowing yourself, and more importantly knowing your roommate. Here are some more tips to help you avoid a hectic household!

&nbsp;
<h3>3.    Have Your Own Life</h3>
Hopefully, you’ll have the privilege of being able to live with one of your best friends during at least one of your years of college, like I do this year.  Needless to say, the perks of living with someone who knows you well usually outweigh any drawbacks, but it is still important to react wisely when you tussle feathers.  Not only will these constructive tactics ameliorate your relationship as two people living together, but they may also help you maintain a positive friendship.

&nbsp;

First, it’s always important to remember that, no matter how close you are to the person you’re living with, you’re <i>different people</i>.  If you and your roommate started out as friends already, <strong>you should not take small disagreements as signs of the failure of your friendship.</strong>  People are emotional creatures, and what you feel about a situation in a moment of stress may not be generalizable to how you feel about it when you’re calm and more rational.  Which brings me to my second tip…

&nbsp;

[caption id="attachment_2784" align="aligncenter" width="321"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/so-hot.gif"><img class="wp-image-2784 " src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/so-hot.gif" alt="so-hot" width="321" height="247" /></a> Blanche literally cools off when she gets mad at the Golden Girls.[/caption]

<strong>How to cool off.</strong>  Whether it’s when my roommate’s alarm goes off one too many times after a long night or when she hasn’t returned textbooks I’ve leant her in the same condition I gave them to her, I’ve found it advantageous to cool off by <strong>changing my scenery</strong> before reacting to the situation at hand.  Going to the<strong> gym or on a run</strong> have often helped me clear my head and body of any negative feelings, allowing me afterwards to assess a negative situation with a <i>positive</i> outlook.  Sometimes, all you need could be a <strong>snack</strong>. I, for one, get hungry and, in hindsight, would much rather have tackled many problems in my life on a full stomach.

&nbsp;

Above all else, don’t let roommate drama get in the way of your life.  Unfortunately, there are times that differences do arise between even the closest roommates that are fundamentally difficult of overcome.  However, from my experience, it’s always been in everyone’s best interest to <strong>not let personal issues affect the more professional environment of different people sharing a common space.</strong>  For instance, if your roommate is a huge slob to the point that you find it to be extremely disrespectful, it is wiser, as well as less likely to hurt anyone’s feelings, to solve the problem of the mess in your room (e.g. by creating a weekly chore schedule) than to make another person admit to fundamentally contradicting one of your personal values.  Reacting in this professional manner usually saves time and, more importantly, emotional energy that you may need for other aspects of your life.  The importance of delegating your energy to worthy issues, which, in essence, is a component of navigating the world in a way that is <i>kind to yourself</i> brings me to my final thought…

&nbsp;

&nbsp;
<h3>4.    Do What’s Best For You</h3>
For many of us, college is a realm of firsts when it comes to independence.  This implies having responsibility over many more things than we are used to, but something I’ve often forgotten is that the most important thing that I am now almost entirely responsible for is <i>myself</i>.  Too many times, I’ve viewed my responsibilities as deadlines I have to meet, things I have to complete and therefore control.  Today, however, I view them as <i>tools</i> I use to maintain positivity in my in all aspects of my life.  In the same vein, all the tips I’ve shared should be viewed as tools to enhance the relationships between you and those you live with, as well as your own emotional, mental and academic well being.  This means that, when it really comes down to it, <strong>you’re really the only one you can trust to make the important decisions in your life.</strong>  If, at a certain point in your school year, you feel that your living environment is severely destructive to your academic and/or mental health, <strong>trust your instincts</strong> and make the decision to change your environment.  While the decision to move out raises many obstacles and shouldn’t be taken lightly, and the input of those close to you should be weighed in your final decision, the process of figuring out what you, as an adult, need and taking the steps to achieve it is very rewarding.

&nbsp;

[caption id="attachment_2785" align="aligncenter" width="326"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Eo-KmOd3i7s.gif"><img class="wp-image-2785 " src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Eo-KmOd3i7s-300x225.gif" alt="Eo-KmOd3i7s" width="326" height="244" /></a> Sometimes you gotta say bye bye bye to bad roommates![/caption]

Along with all my positive roommate experiences, I’ve had some bad ones, too.  In one case, when the behavior of my roommate impacted my academic, physical and financial well being, I decided it was time to move out.  I found , got a part-time job to make up for the cost, and ultimately developed the awesome time-management skills that make me a great student today.  Furthermore, while my parents were at first stressed about the whole ordeal, they rallied around me when they saw me take initiative over what I believed was best for myself.  I want my experiences to serve as learning tools for you gals, so hopefully, instead of scaring you, the latter one works to empower you.

&nbsp;

When it comes to navigating college, the world and roommates alike, be wise, be confident and <strong><i>do you</i>.</strong>

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

Header Image: ninewaysofknowing.com]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Get A Flu Shot</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-get-a-flu-shot/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 07 Dec 2015 20:01:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[maria-zhou]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2788</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Flu season is upon us, but don't fret; getting a flu shot is super quick. I just got mine a couple of weeks ago and the whole experience flashed by. I am currently on clinical rotations for my pharmacy degree and am required to get a flu shot by the hospitals that I work at to protect myself and the patients that I come into contact with. Even if you don’t necessarily work in a hospital, lifestyles that involve regular interactions with many people (such as going to school) also means possible exposure to and spreading of flu viruses.

&nbsp;
<h3>When To Get Your Flu Vaccine</h3>
The flu vaccine is available during “flu season” beginning in October, and continuing until May. Because it takes about 2 weeks before the antibodies will develop after the flu vaccination, it is best to get a flu vaccine early in October before the peak of flu season. Getting vaccinated triggers the immune system to create antibodies that defend against viruses. The flu virus is always changing so the flu vaccine is remade every year. Getting vaccinated can protect the entire community around you, especially infants and immunocompromised friends.

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/FluShot-01.png"><img class=" wp-image-2789 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/FluShot-01-300x280.png" alt="FluShot-01" width="346" height="323" /></a>

&nbsp;

There are different formulations for those with allergies to eggs and latex, so be sure you mention any allergies you have before getting your flu shot. For the shot, I recommend using your non-dominant arm because you might feel some tenderness.

For those of you who dislike needles, there is a nasal spray available to those who are eligible. The primary difference is that the nasal spray has an attenuated (weakened) virus, while the shot has an inactivated (killed) strain. I prefer the shot because I don’t like the feeling of nasal sprays, but it is an effective option.

&nbsp;
<h3>Where To Get Your Flu Vaccine</h3>
There are many places that offer flu vaccines including your school’s health center or your employer. Inquire as to whether or not they will be offering flu shots, and in the event that you need other options, your doctor’s office, local pharmacy, or health clinic are always reliable options.

&nbsp;

This link is a vaccine locator that can tell you the nearest location that offers a vaccine.

<a href="http://vaccine.healthmap.org/">http://vaccine.healthmap.org/</a>

More information can be found on the website of the center for disease control (CDC)

<a href="http://www.cdc.gov/flu/protect/whoshouldvax.htm">http://www.cdc.gov/flu/protect/whoshouldvax.htm</a>

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

Header photo: rollingout.com]]></content:encoded>
