	<item>
		<title>How To: Change Your Brake Light</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-change-your-brake-light/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 14 Dec 2015 04:03:30 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[alex-regalado]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2806</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[After hanging out with our TWIGG How-To Pit Crew, also featured in <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-change-your-cars-air-filter/">this article</a>, I learned another car maintenance tip that you can easily take care of yourself: changing your brake light. I’ve had many friends ignore it and hope it will go away after a while, but the police WILL notice and WILL pull you over (this has been proven through experience). So on a free Saturday, take your car to an auto supply store and follow these steps...

<hr />

But first! A mini lesson on the taillights of your car. Your <strong>clear light</strong> is the reverse light, and it lights up while your car is in reverse. Your <strong>yellow or amber</strong> light is the turn signal light, and it blinks when you turn on your turn signal. And the <strong>red light</strong> is your brake light, which has two purposes and thus two different shades of brightness. The dimmer shade is when you turn on your headlights during the evening (running light) and brighter shade is when you press your brake (brake light).

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/breaklight1.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2808"><img class=" wp-image-2808 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/breaklight1-300x200.jpg" alt="breaklight1" width="366" height="244" /></a>

&nbsp;

You can change any of these lights, but your brake light may contain two separate light bulbs because of its multiple functions. If it only contains one light bulb, it will be a special double filament bulb, which I’ll explain below. Okay, now we can start:

&nbsp;
<ol>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-size: 16px;">Open your trunk to gain access to all your tail lights. Most often it will be your brake light that needs to be replaced as these are used the most.</span></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/breaklight2.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2809"><img class=" wp-image-2809 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/breaklight2-300x200.jpg" alt="breaklight2" width="380" height="253" /></a><span style="font-size: 16px;"><strong>Peel back the carpet covering the back section of your lights</strong>. There may be plastic push clips or a rotating plastic “lock” that keep the carpet in place, the push clips can be removed by pulling at the carpet however the “lock” type must be rotated to unlock the carpet. Some have to be removed with a special tool, as shown below, which will most likely be included in your car's starter kit. If you have any questions, it's always a good idea to talk to a local mechanic that you trust. </span><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/breaklight4.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2812"><img class=" wp-image-2812 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/breaklight4-300x200.jpg" alt="breaklight4" width="377" height="251" /></a><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/breaklight5.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2813"><img class=" wp-image-2813 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/breaklight5-300x200.jpg" alt="breaklight5" width="376" height="250" /></a><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/breaklight3.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2810"><img class="wp-image-2810 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/breaklight3-300x200.jpg" alt="breaklight3" width="379" height="252" /></a></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Once the back of the light is exposed, look for the wire and plug that are connected to the light that you need to change. <strong>Wires run to each individual light</strong>, but look for the connection directly <i>behind</i> the light to find the right bulb. In this case, we were looking for the brake light.</span><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/breaklight6.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2815"><img class=" wp-image-2815 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/breaklight6-300x200.jpg" alt="breaklight6" width="374" height="249" /></a></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">You should <strong>wipe off the glass on the bulb</strong> after you install it in the plug because the oils on your hand could make the bulb overheat and crack (although this is most common on the brighter headlight bulbs!) Also, it’s important to mention that many different car models have different light bulb types. To find your light bulb model number, you can look in your car manual, online, or you can bring the old bulb to an auto supply shop. I recommend the last one, because if your bulb is dead you’ll probably be on your way there to buy a new one anyways.</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Each <strong>different type of light (reverse, turn, brake) may have a different type of bulb</strong>! As seen below, the brake light is the largest and has two filaments (the thin line between the two prongs). This allows the light to turn on with your headlights as running lights, and turn brighter when you press the brake. The turn light is in the middle and is slightly larger than the reverse light. It’s important not to mix up the light bulbs when replacing them, so only remove the light that is dead.</span><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/breaklight7.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2816"><img class=" wp-image-2816 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/breaklight7-300x200.jpg" alt="breaklight7" width="374" height="249" /></a></li>
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-size: 16px;">The bulbs pictured above contain a metal terminal at the bottom, which is common in most cars. Wedge bulbs, shown below, are made up of only glass. For either type of bulb, the bottom of the bulb will fit perfectly into the socket at the end of the wire. To remove the bulb from the tail light, turn the connector and carefully pull out. Then you can pull the actual bulb from the grey connector.</span><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/breaklight9.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2818"><img class=" wp-image-2818 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/breaklight9-300x200.jpg" alt="breaklight9" width="372" height="248" /></a><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/breaklight10.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2819"><img class=" wp-image-2819 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/breaklight10-300x200.jpg" alt="breaklight10" width="368" height="247" /></a> </span></li>
	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-size: 16px;">When putting the new bulb back to the tail light holder, you must match up the notches and then twist to lock it into place.</span><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/breaklight11.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2820"><img class=" wp-image-2820 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/breaklight11-300x200.jpg" alt="breaklight11" width="364" height="242" /></a></span></li>
</ol>

<hr />

&nbsp;

Okay I’m about to drop another bomb on you: there’s a third brake light. In some cars, you’ll find it at the bottom inside of the rear window, and on trucks it’s on the outside above the back window. For the car we were learning on, it was just above the license plate on the trunk.

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/breaklight12.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2821"><img class=" wp-image-2821 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/breaklight12-300x200.jpg" alt="breaklight12" width="368" height="247" /></a>

These can be harder or easier to change, depending on the car. For the truck, you just need a screwdriver to take out the two screws that attach the red light panel. For others, you may need to go inside your truck and remove it from the bottom. Research online to see how to do it for your car, but these lights can be changed as well. The annoying part is they sometimes have a different bulb type than the other lights.

So besides the crazy amount of bulbs you’ll have to distinguish, the process is definitely doable. Try it out and send tweet us some pictures of the process @TWIGGHowTo! Who says a girl can’t work on her own car?!

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Begin To Understand Intersectionality</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-begin-to-understand-intersectionality/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 19 Dec 2015 03:25:49 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Caitlin Cohen]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2832</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The concept of intersectionality states that different institutions of discrimination cannot be separated from one another. <strong>Intersectionality</strong> refers to the interconnected nature of discriminatory “-isms” and “phobias.” Feminism can’t be focused on the struggle of the educated, white, heterosexual female, as it historically has been in the US, because it leaves people out who experience discrimination in other ways as well. Feminism must include women of color, women in lower socioeconomic strati, queer women, trans women, etc.

You’ve heard the statistic that women make 78 cents to the dollar, right? Unfortunately, <a href="http://www.aauw.org/2014/09/18/gender-pay-gap/">this figure doesn’t tell the whole story</a>. If we look at Black women specifically, they’re paid 64 cents to the dollar (specifically, the white man’s dollar - Black men also experience their own pay gap). Native American women make 59 cents to the dollar. Hispanic women earn a mere <i>54 cents</i> to that same dollar.

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Womens-Pay-Gap-by-Race.png" rel="attachment wp-att-2841"><img class=" wp-image-2841 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Womens-Pay-Gap-by-Race-300x184.png" alt="Womens-Pay-Gap-by-Race" width="416" height="255" /></a>

&nbsp;

Intersectionality is the next piece of the puzzle; it is the way we can share these newfound rights and victories with as many people as possible. If we are going to consider ourselves feminists, we cannot simply focus on the struggle of the middle-class, educated white woman. We must focus on the struggles of <i>all</i> women and be open to <i>all </i>experiences.

&nbsp;

Below is a very basic introduction to intersectionality, and why it matters in your life today. You don’t have to bring it up at every family reunion, but it is very important for you, as an informed member of our society, to be aware of what intersectionality is and what it stands for.

<hr />

&nbsp;

<strong>It starts with empathy.</strong> A knee-jerk reaction when someone points out your privilege is to get defensive. That’s natural. You’ve seen it when you try to tell your guy friends about street harassment, or when a story about assault prompts the “not all men” comment (it’s great that not all men sexually assault, but that doesn’t change much for a woman who was assaulted). It’s important to recognize someone else’s experiences as valid - <strong>and that their valid experiences are not a reflection of you, they’re a reflection of society at large.</strong>

&nbsp;

<strong>It’s essential to understand your own privilege</strong>, whatever that may be. Again, understanding your own privilege is not an attack on you or your work ethic or whether or not you “deserve” what you have. For example, I’m a white, heterosexual, cisgender female from an upper-middle-class suburb. This is not my entire identity, but it does <i>inform </i>my identity. I am proud of what I’ve earned so far in my life, but I’m also cognizant of the fact that I built on opportunities not everyone else has. The most amount of racial discrimination I’ve ever faced was when an idiot kid my age would call me a <i>Jew</i> with a sneer in his or her voice and make jokes about the Holocaust somehow at my expense. I’d usually respond with a confused, blank stare, unable to form a response, because I was too busy thinking, “<i>Really? Are we really doing this right now</i>?” But on a systematic level, my ethnicity has never affected my ability to get into college, get a job, shop without incident, or freely leave an interaction with a police officer with anything more than a speeding ticket.

&nbsp;

So if someone points out how much harder it is to get through school with a background that is less economically stable, <i>this is not an attack on your parents or you</i>. Rather, take this as an opportunity to fight with your fellow feminist sisters for a world in which they have the same advantages you’ve had. Of course you worked hard to get to where you are - we all have. Just don’t forget the help you had along the way. This mindset is essential to understanding intersectionality.

&nbsp;

<strong>Some stereotypes are more harmful than others.</strong> Have you heard of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grim_Sleeper">Lonnie Franklin</a>, <a href="https://grimsleeper.wordpress.com/">The Grim Sleeper</a>? He’s been awaiting trial since 2010 for being possibly the most prolific serial killer in Los Angeles history. If you haven’t heard of him, it’s because <a href="http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3012655/LA-s-Grim-Sleeper-serial-killer-murdered-180-people-cops-turned-blind-eye-victims-drug-addicts-prostitutes-explosive-documentary-claims.html">his almost 200 victims</a> were Black drug addicts and prostitutes.  <a href="http://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-17878180">The term “NHI”</a> means No Humans Involved, and is a derogatory term for murder cases in which the victim is someone the police just don’t care about.  Most of The Grim Sleeper’s murders were classified as NHI.

Or even take <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2015/12/daniel-holtzclaw-trial-guilty/420009/">Officer Daniel Holtzclaw</a>, who raped at least <a href="http://www.buzzfeed.com/jtes/daniel-holtzclaw-women-in-their-ow#.afkbbb003">thirteen Black women</a> between the ages of 17 and 57, all poor or with warrants or with histories of drug use, because he knew they were least likely to speak out. Some were abused at traffic stops. The 17-year-old was abused on her own front porch. Many of the women who finally came forward said they didn’t do so immediately because they were sure nobody would believe them. If these women were white or in a higher socioeconomic class, would he have been able to attack them so brazenly?

&nbsp;

[caption id="attachment_2839" align="aligncenter" width="365"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/ct-oklahoma-officer-daniel-holtzclaw-trial-20151210.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2839"><img class="wp-image-2839" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/ct-oklahoma-officer-daniel-holtzclaw-trial-20151210-300x165.jpg" alt="ct-oklahoma-officer-daniel-holtzclaw-trial-20151210" width="365" height="201" /></a> Pictured: A man upset because he has to pay for his crimes.[/caption]

&nbsp;

Let’s look at another example of a less criminal nature. When Michelle Obama came onto the national scene as presidential hopeful Senator Barack Obama’s wife, she had a much tougher road to climb than any other potential First Lady in history. Michelle Obama, a successful lawyer, a Harvard graduate, a loving mother, a spectacular dresser, and the owner of a beautiful pair of arms, was <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/18/us/politics/18michelle.html?pagewanted=all&amp;_r=0">initially labeled an Angry Black Woman</a> because the media either lied about things she said or purposefully misunderstood her (not to mention referring to her as <a href="http://www.foxnews.com/wires/2008Jun12/0,4670,TVFoxObama,00.html">Barack Obama’s “baby mama”</a>, which, again, no other First Lady has ever been called). I have never seen a national figure make fewer mistakes and still be looked upon with such suspicion. She did something as non-controversial as <a href="http://www.fruitsandveggiesmorematters.org/michele-obamas-lets-move-america-campaign">suggesting kids eat vegetables</a> (just like all moms everywhere do) and other politicians insisted this would <a href="http://mediamatters.org/blog/2014/12/09/how-conservative-medias-attacks-on-michelle-oba/201820">lead to a terrifying (yet healthy) nanny state</a> and fought the <a href="http://www.letsmove.gov/">Let’s Move!</a> initiative. Michelle Obama has a resume any politician would love to have, with the dignity and poise to match, and she still had to prove to the public that she wouldn’t lose her temper at the drop of a hat over some imaginary, perceived slight.

&nbsp;

[caption id="attachment_2840" align="aligncenter" width="353"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/michelle-obama-1024.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2840"><img class="wp-image-2840" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/michelle-obama-1024-300x225.jpg" alt="michelle-obama-1024" width="353" height="265" /></a> #flawless[/caption]

&nbsp;

The main take away here is that, while white women have their own hurdles and stereotypes to overcome, many women of color have much worse stereotypes to contend with. Black and Hispanic women, often stereotyped as angry or emotional, deal frequently with <a href="https://medium.com/@chanda/what-s-the-harm-in-tone-policing-e933d90af247">tone policing</a>. <a href="http://geekfeminism.wikia.com/wiki/Tone_argument">Tone policing</a> is the act of focusing on the tone in which one brings up a grievance rather than the grievance itself.

Maybe the easiest-to-grasp example of someone who’s been tone policed in pop culture this past year is Nicki Minaj. Simply <a href="http://fusion.net/story/170626/nicki-minaj-upset-mtv-vma-nominations-twitter/">pointing out</a>, with the help of some emojis, that black women are<a href="http://fusion.net/story/172439/nicki-minaj-women-race-music-awards/"> not rewarded for their contributions to the music industry</a> started a supposed lightning-fast “feud” with Taylor Swift, a rebuke by Miley Cyrus who entirely missed the point, and a lot of articles that resort to name-calling and telling her to calm down.

&nbsp;

[caption id="attachment_2838" align="aligncenter" width="362"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/1401x788-5969_TR_RS_MINAJ_MANSON_01_129_V3_cmyk.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2838"><img class="wp-image-2838" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/1401x788-5969_TR_RS_MINAJ_MANSON_01_129_V3_cmyk-300x169.jpg" alt="1401x788-5969_TR_RS_MINAJ_MANSON_01_129_V3_cmyk" width="362" height="204" /></a> Also #flawless[/caption]

&nbsp;

When a woman of color points out additional hurdles she has to face, <i>this is not an attack on white women</i>. When a woman of color points out additional hurdles she has to face, she is not making it about herself, she is pointing out a real issue in society that still exists today.  Focusing on the way Minaj airs her grievances or assuming she’s personally attacking you doesn’t help us as a culture move forward. Minaj had a point, and instead of listening to it, two white women who <a href="http://www.rollingstone.com/music/features/taylor-swift-1989-cover-story-20140908">proudly call</a> <a href="http://time.com/3850794/miley-cyrus-feminism-gay-rights-happy-hippie/">themselves feminists</a> either made it about themselves or dismissed the argument entirely due to tone. As feminists, we have an obligation to listen to everyone, even if it makes us uncomfortable.

&nbsp;
There are all different kinds of ways to be a woman. This movement is still gaining momentum and visibility, but here’s the bottom line: you don’t have to know anything about transgender women to still want them to have access to all the same rights you have. Nobody should be fired because they’re transgender or because they’re gay, and it <i>definitely </i>shouldn’t be legal to do so - <a href="http://www.vocativ.com/culture/lgbt/lgbt-rights-kansas/">but in 28 states, it is</a>. <a href="http://www.advocate.com/crime/2015/06/09/anti-lgbt-violence-down-anti-trans-hate-crimes">Being attacked</a> specifically for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unlawfully_killed_transgender_people">your gender expression</a> should be considered a vile hate crime - <a href="http://www.politifact.com/texas/statements/2015/may/13/garnet-coleman/garnet-coleman-said-transgender-person-has-1-12-ch/">but it happens all the time</a>.  And <a href="http://www.motherjones.com/politics/2015/06/transgender-women-disproportionately-targeted-violent-hate-crimes">it’s even worse</a> when you’re a <a href="https://medium.com/hatewatch-blog/in-the-crosshairs-3700fbf2203d">transgender woman of color</a>. As a feminist, equal rights for everyone should be part of the program.

&nbsp;

[caption id="attachment_2837" align="aligncenter" width="364"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/nondiscrimination-protections.png" rel="attachment wp-att-2837"><img class="wp-image-2837" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/nondiscrimination-protections-300x233.png" alt="nondiscrimination protections" width="364" height="283" /></a> That’s a lot of states where you can be legally fired over something that is none of your boss’s goddamn business.[/caption]

&nbsp;

When Caitlyn Jenner’s Vanity Fair cover came out, it received a ton of press - some good, some bad. Some of the transphobic comments were absolutely awful, but perhaps the more frustrating op-eds about that cover <a href="http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/transgender-rights-versus-feminism-what-makes-woman-1501487">came from self-proclaimed feminists</a>. <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/07/opinion/sunday/what-makes-a-woman.html?_r=0">Ironically pointing out</a> that Caitlyn Jenner’s view of womanhood is exceedingly narrow because she got all gussied up in a dress and heels, some feminists are focused on Caitlyn Jenner’s decision to be a rather feminine woman and how that is detrimental to all the progress feminists have made so far. These writers insist they’ve fought for women to be seen as more than a pretty dress and heels.

&nbsp;

And that’s great! Long live Title IX! Long live Brienne of Tarth! But feminism can get ugly when some women choose to be traditionally feminine. Feminism can get ugly when it forgets the cause is fighting for the <i>choice</i> to eschew traditional feminine roles, not the <i>obligation</i> to do so. When these feminists point out that transgender women grew up in a society that identified them as male and thus can never understand all the trials and tribulations and hurdles of growing up a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cisgender">cisgender woman</a>, they <a href="http://rationalwiki.org/wiki/Trans-exclusionary_radical_feminism">ignore the many, many, <i>many</i> difficulties of being a transgender woman</a>. In fact, they are only adding to these obstacles. Focusing on who has it harder is a useless exercise, and refusing to include transwomen because they don’t meet your definition of a woman is discriminatory for the sake of being discriminatory.

&nbsp;

One final note to add is that while Caitlyn Jenner has absolutely added a lot of visibility to transgender issues, she still has a lot of privilege in a lot of other ways - she’s wealthy and she can afford extensive treatments that allow her to “pass” as a woman.  It’s hard enough being transgender, but <a href="http://www.chauntelletibbals.com/politics-of-passing/#.VbkbLzBViko">if you don’t “pass”</a> as a cisgender woman? The discrimination, stress, and even violence and abuse in your life is <a href="http://www.vice.com/read/passing-when-youre-transgender">only worse</a>. No one should have to “pass” to be <a href="http://glbt-hotline.tumblr.com/post/101283097590/the-politics-of-passing">treated with respect</a> or to not have their identity questioned, but when society decides a transgender person doesn’t “look like a woman,” she suffers for it that much more.

&nbsp;

<strong>Representation in the media is incredibly important, which is why appropriation can be so harmful.</strong> There are a lot of <a href="http://www.wmm.com/resources/film_facts.shtml">not-great statistics about the representation of women in film and television</a>. There are tumblrs dedicated to the <a href="http://shitpeoplesaytowomendirectors.tumblr.com/">BS women in that industry have to deal with</a>. As a feminist, I find these numbers upsetting. What’s worse, however, is that these numbers are numbers for ALL women, and that as hard as it is to be a woman breaking into that industry, it’s so much harder to be a woman of color.

&nbsp;

Earlier this year, Minaj lamented a lack of accolades for Black women in the music business despite incredible contributions, and <a href="http://fusion.net/story/172439/nicki-minaj-women-race-music-awards/">the statistics back her up</a>. On the television side, of all TV episodes that aired last year, a paltry <a href="http://thinkprogress.org/alyssa/2012/04/20/468432/women-of-color-in-television-part-1-the-numbers/">one percent</a> were directed by women of color. And think about the roles of women of color on television and in film - not to mention the roles of gay women, which are even fewer and farther between. They are the exception, not the rule.

&nbsp;
Why do we need more representation? With more representation comes more varied roles for women. We are not just the daughter, the wife, the mother, the fill-in-the-blank relation to the male character. With more female characters come more opportunities to tell female stories. This thought process extends to women of color, who for the most part are relegated to either comic relief or hypersexualized beings rather than fully-fleshed out characters. Yes, we have <i>How to Get Away with Murder</i>, <i>Scandal</i>, <i>Jane the Virgin</i>, <i>Being Mary Jane</i>, and <i>The Mindy Project</i>. For main characters in an ensemble cast, we have <i>Black-ish</i> and <i>Fresh off the Boat</i> and <i>Empire</i>. And… that might be it. To give you an idea of how dismal a number that is, in 2015 alone there were <a href="http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/envelope/cotown/la-et-ct-2015-peak-tv-new-record-409-original-series-20151216-story.html">409 television shows</a> on the air. In film, women of color have it <a href="http://mic.com/articles/84899/hollywood-s-problem-with-women-of-color-is-even-worse-than-you-realize">even worse</a>.

&nbsp;

[caption id="attachment_2842" align="aligncenter" width="338"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/gina-rodriguez-quotes.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2842"><img class=" wp-image-2842" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/gina-rodriguez-quotes-300x200.jpg" alt="BEVERLY HILLS, CA - JANUARY 11: Gina Rodriguez poses for a portrait for People.com during the 72nd Annual Golden Globe Awards on January 11, 2015 in Beverly Hills, California. (Photo by Maarten de Boer/Getty Images)" width="338" height="225" /></a> Can I use #flawless a third time? TOO BAD. #FLAWLESS[/caption]

&nbsp;

On top of a lack of representation in media, mainstream culture will often appropriate other cultures and, once it’s put on a white person, deem it “hip” or “cool” or, at the very least, “acceptable.” There have been accusations against <a href="http://www.theroot.com/blogs/the_grapevine/2014/07/katy_the_queen_of_cultural_appropriation_perry_is_at_it_again.html">Katy Perry</a>, <a href="http://bust.com/jay-z-and-azealia-banks-call-out-miley-cyrus-on-cultural-appropriation-she-doesnt-get-it.html">Miley Cyrus</a>, <a href="http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/12/29/the-cultural-crimes-of-iggy-azalea.html">Iggy Azalea</a>, and <a href="http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/08/19/can-t-shake-off-taylor-swift-s-cultural-appropriation-haters-gonna-hate.html">Taylor Swift</a> regarding their appropriation of Black culture, Asian culture, Latina culture, and Egyptian culture used as “costumes” or as street credit.

At face value, there shouldn’t be anything wrong with a performer putting on a show and trying out new kinds of styles and music. The issue, again, is directly related to a lack of representation from these women in the public space. We like their hairstyles, their clothes, their culture - but <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/sep/23/why-black-bum-only-good-white-skin-cultural-appropriation">we don’t like <i>them</i></a>. And many white women get to profit off this unjust system that quiets the very women contributing to their successes.

&nbsp;

<strong>There are a few different waves of feminism.</strong> In the US, we typically place the beginning of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First-wave_feminism">first-wave feminism</a> in 1848, as the first suffragettes began asking for the right to vote. Notable figures include <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lucretia_Mott">Lucretia Mott</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Susan_B._Anthony">Susan B. Anthony</a>.

<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second-wave_feminism">Second-wave feminism</a> began in the early 1960s and is associated with women’s role in society, her right to be financially independent, and her ability to take care of herself (in the 1960s, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/money/us-money-blog/2014/aug/11/women-rights-money-timeline-history">some states still wouldn’t allow women to have their own checking account</a>). It also dealt with the right to work without facing discrimination and reproductive rights. Notable (and somehow still controversial) figures include <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Betty_Friedan">Betty Friedan</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gloria_Steinem">Gloria Steinem</a>.

<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Third-wave_feminism">Third-wave feminism</a>, beginning in the early 1990s, sought to fix some of the issues perceived with second wave feminism, which focused mostly on middle and upper-middle class white women, and to create a more inclusive social movement for gay women and women of color. Notable figures include <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rebecca_Walker">Rebecca Walker</a> and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Judith_Butler">Judith Butler</a>.

<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fourth-wave_of_feminism">Fourth-wave feminism</a>, technically not acknowledged yet by academics, purportedly started around 2008 and takes third wave feminism a step further in order to include transgender women, sex workers, and male feminism as well. Notable figures include Jessica Valenti and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reina_Gossett">Reina Gosset</a>.

<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Men_and_feminism">Male feminism</a> refers to men who are also feminists. They are allies - which means that they trust your lived experiences more than their own. Additionally, many men are recognizing that gender roles hurt men as much as they hurt women and would like to remedy that through feminism.

<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radical_feminism">Radical feminism</a>, or <strong>RadFem,</strong> seek to wholly eliminate the patriarchy. The movement is characterized by women-only spaces, its rejection of transwomen as “real” women, its sex-negative views, and its exclusion of sex workers.

<strong>Intersectionality</strong>, as you can tell by this very brief summation of different feminist waves in US History, is an increasingly important part of feminism.

<hr />

&nbsp;

Further reading/watching.  <a href="http://www.amandlastenberg.com/blog">Amandla Stenberg</a> may only be 17, but she’s a great source on the importance of intersectionality in today’s feminism.

<a href="http://everydayfeminism.com/">Everyday Feminism</a> is a great site as well. It is a combination of think pieces on current events and easy-to-read cartoons about why certain issues are important.

If you’re curious about the effects of the appropriation and hypersexualization of women of color in the media, <a href="http://feminishblog.com/post/64268754861/resources-hyper-sexualization-sexual">here is a good resource</a> for extended reading.

<a href="https://twitter.com/Karnythia">Mikki Kendall</a> is an activist who writes about police brutality, feminism, and race issues.

<a href="http://www.lavernecox.com/">Laverne Cox</a> is a transgender activist with some great information and insight.

<a href="http://janetmock.com/">Janet Mock</a> is another transgender activist.

<a href="https://twitter.com/sophiaphotos">Sophia Banks</a> is a transgender woman who doesn’t “pass” and often discusses her work and activism from her perspective.

<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bell_hooks">bell hooks</a> is a feminist who writes specifically about the intersection of gender, race, and capitalism.

For individual articles rather than sites as a whole, <a href="http://www.telegraph.co.uk/women/womens-life/10572435/Intersectional-feminism.-What-the-hell-is-it-And-why-you-should-care.html">here</a>, <a href="http://www.dogsandshoes.com/2013/12/five-ways-white-feminists-can-address-our-own-racism.html">here</a>, <a href="http://fusion.net/story/50822/stop-it-with-the-feminist-whitesplaining/">here</a>, and <a href="http://carefreeangryblackgirl.blogspot.com/2015/05/my-name-be-righteous.html">here</a> are some very informative articles on intersectionality.

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/How-To-Begin-To-Understand-Intersectionality.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2835"><img class=" wp-image-2835 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/How-To-Begin-To-Understand-Intersectionality-300x210.jpg" alt="How To- Begin To Understand Intersectionality" width="337" height="236" /></a>

&nbsp;

<strong>There’s a lot you personally can do.</strong> The first thing to do is be open-minded. Be critical of your media intake. Ask questions. Look up answers. Cross-check references or articles. Learn, learn, and learn.

Then act on your new knowledge. Treat people the way they deserved to be treated.  Understand there are still major civil rights hurdles and negative socializations to overcome.  When you vote, keep in mind who your vote is going to help and who it might hurt.

If you’re not a member of a group that deals with discrimination, be an ally. Don’t make it about you (if you’re an ally, the worst possible thing you can do is make it about yourself), but be sympathetic to the cause.

Petition. Demand more representation. Be conscious of what message your actions send. Learn, learn, and learn. Listen, listen, and listen.

A good rule of thumb is that if you’re telling someone the “correct” way to be a feminist, there’s a 99% chance you’re wrong. Exceptions include people who have made the study of feminism their life’s work, but other than that, it’s really not your job to tell someone else how to be a feminist.
Again, the above is an overview and absolutely <i>does not</i> cover the vast umbrella of intersectionality. It barely touched on the kinds of <a href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/ruth-bader-ginsburg-reproductive-rights_55ba42c9e4b095423d0e0716">issues low-income women face</a>, for example, or even sex workers. If we at TWIGG How-to are truly to consider ourselves feminists, we must also consider ourselves intersectional.

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

Header Photo: soirart.tumblr]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Pick the Best Art Museum To Tour This Holiday Season</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-pick-the-best-art-museum-to-tour-this-holiday-season/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 22 Dec 2015 02:21:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[patty arteaga]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2846</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[You may question why a guide for visiting a museum might be necessary, since it appears to be a foolproof system: you decide, pay, and visit, all in three easy steps. However, I want to ask you, the reader, to first consider a few preliminary questions.
<ol>
	<li>Why do you go to a museum, and what’s the real, essential reason behind paying to go inside of a building, seeing some stuff, and walking out after a few hours?</li>
	<li>What is it about what’s inside that compels us to visit a specific museum, and are we searching for anything in particular when we visit a certain exhibition?</li>
</ol>
&nbsp;

To help to answer these questions, I turned to Nelson H. H. Graburn, a leading expert in anthropological tourism and museums, who wrote “<a href="http://www.jstor.org/stable/40479310">The Museum and the Visitor Experience</a>”. The article touched upon how visitors expect more of an interactive experience at a museum, whether it be physical, emotional, or sensory. These elevated experiences become more than just <i>viewing</i> a collection inside of a building. Graburn summarizes his findings by breaking down social and cultural experiences into three categories:  the <strong>educational</strong>, the <strong>social</strong>, and the <strong>reverential</strong>. As interested citizens looking to participate in the museum-going experience, we can pick, choose, and seek out specific museums according to these guidelines. If you’re interested in visiting new art museums over the upcoming holiday break, below you will find my top suggestions based on my past experiences, categorized by Graburn’s groupings. Enjoy!

<hr />

<h3> Category: The Educational Experience</h3>
<strong>“...people go to museums to look at themselves or, that museums represent a culture looking at itself.” (Graburn, 18) </strong>

<strong>Are you searching to learn something new and/or fuel an itching curiosity? Or craving to understand more about the world?</strong>

&nbsp;

If you are trusting the institution to help you to interpret subject matters of interest through research, then you are attracted to the educational aspect of museums. Unlike a school, a museum provides a more complete picture of a concept, filled with text, visuals, models, and extra material that enhances your learning  experience. These learning experiences don’t necessarily have to correlate with a specific subject taught at school, but rather about the world around us.

&nbsp;
Also, museums take it one step ahead in our search for the educational experience because they have the power to make various subjects, whether interesting, controversial, and/or complicated, spark a conversation. As an audience, we search for how to view and talk about the occurrences of our society, and as an accessible platform to the general public and knowledge, museums respond to this human need. They have the ability to gather all kinds of resources (artworks, hands on activities, videos, photographs) to create an educational experience that further expands our knowledge of what is taught at schools and what we learn outside of them. We are constantly learning about new subjects, about the world around us, and about ourselves, and museums want to be included in that process.

&nbsp;

<strong>Suggestions: </strong>

1)<a href="http://www.getty.edu/education/adult_learners/index.html">The Getty</a>:

Provides a handful of educational programs, ranging from Kindergarten to Adults.

&nbsp;

2) <a href="http://nmai.si.edu/explore/education/">National Museum of the American Indian</a>:

The exhibitions and programs focus on demystifying the thought that American Indians are people from the past.

&nbsp;

3) <a href="http://www.nga.gov/content/ngaweb/education.html">National Gallery of Art</a>:

Focus on making art more accessible to a wider audience.

&nbsp;

4) <a href="http://www.lacma.org/education-programs">LACMA</a>:

Involves classes on filmmaking, sketching, and providing free activities for families.

&nbsp;

5) <a href="http://www.molaa.org/education.aspx">MOLAA</a>:

Opening to a wider audience to demonstrate the extensiveness of art in Latin America that is often overshadowed.

<hr />

<h3>Category: The Social Experience</h3>
<strong>“...shared experience, a comfortable environment and a minimum of physical and intellectual constraint” (G, 15). </strong>

<strong>Are you looking for a social adventure to share with friends, and is this shared experience more important to you than <i>doing</i> or <i>seeing</i> when at a museum? </strong>

&nbsp;

If your priority is to be with others rather than in the presence of art, then you are searching for the social experience of going to a museum. Many museums encourage this aspect of being “a live museum” where talking, picture taking, and even sharing a meal has become part of the experience. In fact, the increase in social media initiatives to entice participation (<i>i.e.</i> #LacmaPlusYou) during your visit is now a regular feature at museums. Museums want this to be the destination for shared experiences since they offer an inspirational setting, a break away from the day’s ordinary routine.

&nbsp;

<strong>Suggestions:</strong>

1) The Getty:

Picnic tables, gardens, view, and free admission create the perfect day to be outside.

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/image07.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2855"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2855 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/image07-300x214.jpg" alt="image07" width="300" height="214" /></a>

&nbsp;

2) National Museum of American Indian:

Their cafe, which serves food that reflects the American Indian nations, has some of the best food on the National Mall.

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/image06.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2854"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2854 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/image06-300x249.jpg" alt="image06" width="300" height="249" /></a>

&nbsp;

3) National Gallery of Art:

Jazz in the Sculpture Garden in the late summer evenings encourages large gatherings for people to picnic, listen to live music, and be amongst art.

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/image00.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2848"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2848 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/image00-300x197.jpg" alt="image00" width="300" height="197" /></a>

&nbsp;

4) LACMA:

With many outdoor spaces and installations, such as the famous Urban Lights that is very much a part of central point for meeting, create an environment to partake in social activities.

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/image05.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2853"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2853 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/image05-300x200.jpg" alt="image05" width="300" height="200" /></a>

&nbsp;

5) MOLAA:

The weekly cultural events, such as live music in the Sculpture Garden, as well as free admission on Sunday

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/image03.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2851"><img class="size-full wp-image-2851 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/image03.jpg" alt="image03" width="300" height="300" /></a>

<hr />

<h3>Category: The Reverential Experience</h3>
<strong>“...a need for a direct connection to something purer, more eternal, a more sure authority, somehow above the workday world of tasks and decisions.” (Graburn, 13). </strong>

<strong>Are you searching to find a personal and sacred experience amidst artistic beauty? Seeking a break from your daily routines to encounter refuge, solitude, and peace, even in a chaotic environment?</strong>

&nbsp;

If so, then museums offer you the opportunity to explore a reverential experience. With its vastness of space and expansive, impressive collections, museums inspires awe and meditation. With the artwork before our eyes, we can momentarily attain peace through contemplation and pause our daily routines. Even amongst the museum’s chaotic environment, one can still draw in a sense of solitude and simply take a deep breath. These reverential experiences, personally, are most needed in those moments when everything seems to unexpectedly hit you at the same time. Museums and art can provide you with a sense of beautiful sacredness that your soul requires to live in the present moment and in tune with personal solitude.

&nbsp;

Personally, I feel as though traditional art museums and galleries cater to this greater feeling of humility and contemplation. I would recommend going on a weekday where there is less of a crowd, and it can really feel that the museum is all for you. Of course, this depends on the season. Also, keep in mind most museums are closed on Mondays.

&nbsp;

<strong>Suggestions:</strong>

1) The Getty

The view of Los Angeles alone is breathtaking, simulating a temple above the mountain top,  and encourages personal contemplation of your place within city.

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/image09.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2857"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2857 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/image09-300x200.jpg" alt="image09" width="300" height="200" /></a>

&nbsp;

2) National Museum of the American Indian

Where the sweeping, grand flowing curves of the architecture as well as the central dome inspire awe.

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/image04.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2852"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2852 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/image04-241x300.jpg" alt="image04" width="241" height="300" /></a>

&nbsp;

3) National Gallery of Art

With its impressive collection and wide range of artworks house in an immense Neo-Classical building, one can freely wander through the galleries and feel lost (but in a positive way).

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/image01.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2849"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2849 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/image01-300x300.jpg" alt="image01" width="300" height="300" /></a>

&nbsp;

4) LACMA - Los Angeles County Museum of Art

I especially recommend the Broad buildings that house the contemporary collections and have wide, open, and tall gallery rooms, where one can be feel humble in that vastness of space.

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/image02.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2850"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2850 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/image02-300x178.jpg" alt="image02" width="300" height="178" /></a>

&nbsp;

5) MOLAA - Museum of Latin American Art

Their sculpture garden is captivating with a large open spaces and, enclosed by high, brightly colorful walls that draw out the noise of a busy Long Beach intersection.

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/image08.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2856"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2856 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/image08-300x143.jpg" alt="image08" width="300" height="143" /></a>

<hr />

&nbsp;

As you can see, this Guide to Going to Art Museums aims to help the visitor to consider why he/she is going to a museum in the first place.  In its essence, a museum is a building with beautiful, entertaining, and interesting things inside, but it is up to the viewer and his/her attitude to interpret the conditions and value of an experience. All three explanations of why we choose to experience museums can be valid on their own, but we can also be drawn into a place due to a combination of reasons. Of course there are more reasons and more museums than my miniscule list, but I wanted to add museums that have a personal meaning to me and have one time or another, offered me a different experience each time.  Personally, I think that we decide to attend museums because we need help searching to understand a little more about our world (educational), the people around us (social), and ourselves (reverential).

&nbsp;

The following museums that I have chosen to discuss of course only offers a miniscule list of museums available. The list only reflects art museums located in places that I have lived and studied. I do understand that a museum can range from history, science, and discovery learning, however these are the museums that I have had the most personal experiences in as a visitor.

&nbsp;
<ol>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;">The Getty Center, located on top of a hill overlooking western Los Angeles, is well known pre-20th century paintings as well as 19th and 20th century photographs.</li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;">The Los Angeles County Museum of Art (LACMA), right in the center of the busy mid-Wilshire Blvd in Los Angeles, is an “encyclopedia” museum, where their collections spawn from the medieval to contemporary artworks from around the world.</li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;">Museum of Latin American Art (MOLAA), a mid-size museum located in Long Beach, CA focuses on presenting the variety and richness of modern and contemporary art from a region that has long been overlooked in the art world.</li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;">National Museum of the American Indian, the newest museum under the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, DC dedicates itself to presenting to a wider audience the history, life, culture, and artifacts of the indigenous people of North and South America.</li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;">National Portrait Gallery, also located on the National Mall in Washington DC,  is known for it Western artworks, sculpture, and drawings that range from the middle ages to the current era.</li>
</ol>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Get Rid Of Fruit Flies</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-get-rid-of-fruit-flies/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 07 Jan 2016 01:04:14 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Rachel Wiegardt-Egel]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2871</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Fruit flies are gross. Sure, they don’t bite, they don’t sting, and they don’t eat your clothes or carry diseases, but it’s just straight up icky to have them buzzing around your living space. As a born-and-bred Californian who’s always lived in temperate climates, I had never dealt with fruit flies before spending two summers on the East Coast, which showed me just how annoying and persistent these little pests can be. With a lifespan of only eight to ten days, they reproduce like crazy and make your farmers market finds totally unappealing (no one wants to eat a banana covered in fruit fly eggs). Plus, dinner parties are zero fun if your kitchen is swarming with bugs. Do you really want to face all that possible judgment, even from the most understanding of friends? That’s right—I said it—fruit flies can ruin your social life. (A tad facetious, but they’re definitely unpleasant.)

&nbsp;

Of course, the best way to stop fruit flies is to take preventative measures: store fruit in the fridge or in a bowl covered with plastic wrap; keep the garbage in a bin with a lid; wash out any containers you put in the recycling bin; empty the trash, recycling, and compost frequently; and clean your counters regularly. However, if you do encounter an infestation, there are easy, toxin-free, and inexpensive ways to take care of it.

&nbsp;

[caption id="attachment_2908" align="aligncenter" width="300"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/fly-trap.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2908"><img class="wp-image-2908 size-medium" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/fly-trap-300x200.jpg" alt="fly trap" width="300" height="200" /></a> pinterest.com[/caption]

Here’s the method that I’ve personally found to be the most successful: apple cider vinegar traps. Grab a relatively large jar and fill it with a couple inches of unfiltered apple cider vinegar. Then, take an 8 ½ x 11” sheet of paper and roll it into a cone—it should be quite small at the point and have a wide opening. Tape it shut, and place it point-down into the jar. BOOM. Drop the mic and walk away, because a few days of leaving the trap out, or multiple traps if your kitchen is large, should solve the majority of the problem. Fruit flies are attracted to the apple cider vinegar, but once they’ve climbed through your paper cone, they can’t figure out how to get back out.

You can also make these traps with red wine, vinegar with a dash of dish soap, or a piece of ripe fruit, but plain apple cider vinegar has never let me down.

&nbsp;

If flies have already laid eggs in your kitchen’s drains, the problem can be more challenging because they thrive in dark, damp places. If you don’t notice a drop-off in the number of flies even as your traps begin to fill up with them, try pouring a mixture of half white vinegar, half boiling water down the drain to stop them at the source. If the infestation is really bad, it could take up to a couple weeks to get it under control, but don’t give up! Be ruthless and relentless and your home will soon be fruit fly-free.

&nbsp;

[caption id="attachment_2907" align="aligncenter" width="300"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/How-To-Get-Rid-Of-Fruit-Flies.gif" rel="attachment wp-att-2907"><img class="wp-image-2907 size-medium" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/How-To-Get-Rid-Of-Fruit-Flies-300x180.gif" alt="How To-Get Rid Of Fruit Flies" width="300" height="180" /></a> gif from lipstickalley.com[/caption]

For more details on other kinds of traps, check out these helpful articles from <a href="http://everydayroots.com/how-to-get-rid-of-fruit-flies">Everyday Roots</a> and <a href="http://www.goodhousekeeping.com/home/cleaning/tips/a25042/how-to-kill-fruit-flies/">Good Housekeeping</a>.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Extract Images From Google Docs</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/extract-images-from-google-docs/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 04 Jan 2016 10:00:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jenna-perelman]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2874</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/HowTo-Extract-Images-From-Google-Docs.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2898"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-2898" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/HowTo-Extract-Images-From-Google-Docs-300x192.jpg" alt="HowTo-Extract-Images-From-Google-Docs" width="300" height="192" /></a></p>
Here at the TWIGG How-To Headquarters, we use Google Drive for everything. Since our contributors and staff are located all over the country, Google Docs is an invaluable tool because it lets everyone access articles regardless of their location. Part of my job description as Managing Editor is to move a contributor’s article from Google Docs onto our site, which includes all the pretty pictures that contributors provide.

&nbsp;

One of the main flaws of Google Docs – Google Support, are you listening? – is that you can’t copy pictures that are in a document to another medium.

&nbsp;

I know you don’t believe me. Go try it yourself. I’ll wait.

&nbsp;

Back? Since this is such an integral part of our operation, I needed to find a workaround. There are a couple options available to extract images from a Google Docs document.

&nbsp;

Here’s my favorite: You’re going to download the file as an HTML format in a zipped folder. When you open the zipped folder, there will be a separate folder within it named “images” which will contain the images you want. Then you have them at your disposal to use as you wish (for me, that means putting them into articles like this one!)

&nbsp;
<h3>Steps</h3>
<ol>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">In the Google Doc you want to extract images from,  go to File &gt; Download As &gt; Webpage (.html zipped)</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Open the zip folder. <span style="font-weight: 400;">I’m on a Mac so I simply double click on the zip folder in my Downloads, which opens the zip folder using Archive Utility. I can’t speak for PCs but I assume it’s a similar process. </span></span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Ope</span>n <span style="font-size: 16px;">the folder and then open the “images” folder.</span></li>
</ol>
&nbsp;

This is what your final folder should look like:

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/image00.png" rel="attachment wp-att-2875"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-2875" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/image00.png" alt="Extracting images from google doc" width="582" height="139" /></a>
Happy extracting!

Source: <a href="http://techattitude.com/tips-tricks-and-hacks/how-to-extract-images-from-google-docs-document/">http://techattitude.com/tips-tricks-and-hacks/how-to-extract-images-from-google-docs-document/</a>]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Excel in a STEM Major and Get a Job After Graduation</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-excel-in-a-stem-major-and-get-a-job-after-graduation/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 15 Jan 2016 02:00:24 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[johana-munoz]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2889</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/calculator-fun.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2922"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2922 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/calculator-fun-300x200.jpg" alt="calculator fun" width="300" height="200" /></a>

Starting a major in STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) can be a fun, interesting, and challenging endeavor. The sheer number of science and math classes required for these majors can be overwhelming, and sometimes makes it hard to think about what happens after graduating!

&nbsp;

I know I had a difficult time trying to adapt to this new life and keep up with homework, test, quizzes, and group projects (which can be the worst thing since the professor won’t allow you to choose your friends to work with). However, having gone through the experience of studying engineering, which sometimes meant sacrificing friend gatherings, and replacing them with all-nighters, ultimately I was fortunate to find a fulfilling job after graduation in a well-known, successful, company.

&nbsp;

Based on my experience, here are a few tips that might be useful to help you get the most out of <em>your</em> college experience and set you up for success in a STEM workplace.

<hr />

<strong>First and foremost, focus on your classes.</strong>

Your GPA reflects a lot about you, and while it doesn’t have to be a perfect 4.0, somewhere above 3.5 will set you apart from the average student.

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/freshman-year.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2925"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2925 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/freshman-year-300x169.jpg" alt="freshman year" width="300" height="169" /></a>
<h3 style="text-align: center;">Freshman Year</h3>
Join student organizations that pertain to the major you are going after. Since I was studying Industrial Engineering and was born in Colombia, I joined the <a href="http://www.shpe.org/">Institute of Industrial Engineers</a> and the <a href="http://www.shpe.org/">Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers</a>.

Find volunteering opportunities that interest you. There are plenty of opportunities at college like Habitat for Humanity or Relay for Life.

If possible, look for internship opportunities through student organizations (this is difficult as a freshman, but I’ve seen it happen!).

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/sophmore-year.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2926"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2926 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/sophmore-year-200x300.jpg" alt="sophmore year" width="200" height="300" /></a>
<h3 style="text-align: center;">Sophomore Year</h3>
Try to take on responsibilities in an organization. Run for a leadership role to further develop your skills. If you haven’t found an organization you like, don’t worry about it, you can still be successful even  if you’re a little behind.

Talk to professors and try to involve yourself in their research. Becoming a research assistant to a professor or PhD student is a great resume builder, and an opportunity to explore your interests.

Look for internship opportunities that will further you in your educational endeavors by giving you a specific career related track.

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/junior-year.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2923"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2923 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/junior-year-300x200.jpg" alt="junior year" width="300" height="200" /></a>
<h3 style="text-align: center;">Junior Year</h3>
Make sure that you are on track with your classes. You don’t want to stay an extra semester because you forgot to take an elective!

Look for internships for the summer! This is your last opportunity for a summer internship before you graduate next spring.

Attend conferences related to your major or conferences held by the national chapter of the student organizations you have joined. These conferences are great for professional development and present many internships or co-op hiring opportunities in an approachable environment.

If you were able to obtain an internship, doing well could be the key to a company offering you a full time position when you graduate. Imagine how sweet it would be to start your senior year with a full time offer under your belt!

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/senior-year-.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2931"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2931 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/senior-year--200x300.jpg" alt="senior year" width="200" height="300" /></a>
<h3 style="text-align: center;">Senior Year</h3>
Don’t forget to finish up strong! You’ve worked hard and have come this far, you owe yourself an amazing academic finish.

Make sure you have taken all the classes you need in order to graduate as you get ready for graduation!

Have a well-written resume that clearly defines you as the strong candidate that you are.

Start applying for jobs as soon as you start your senior year. Focus on what you have gathered from your experiences with internships and/or co-ops in order to select your best fit. Most STEM companies start looking for applicants around August and September.

Interview well, using the unique experiences you’ve gained through various positions you’ve taken at student organizations, volunteering opportunities, previous internships, etc. Be yourself!

After job offers start coming in, choose the company you believe to have the best culture to help you grow as a professional.

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/celebrate.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2921"><img class="size-medium wp-image-2921 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/celebrate-271x300.jpg" alt="celebrate" width="271" height="300" /></a>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 28px;">CELEBRATE!</span></p>
On a final note, the STEM fields can be difficult, but it’s a great area where you will be faced to solve problems by being creative and using your math and critical skills. It’s a fun, stimulating, and exciting field where you will find your work to be very rewarding! In my position in engineering, I feel challenged every day,, but go home feeling fulfilled by the work I’ve done. Best of luck! I know you can do it!

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Write A Letter Of Recommendation</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-write-a-letter-of-recommendation/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 10 Jan 2016 20:36:32 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Rebecca Olson]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2901</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/How-To-Write-A-Letter-Of-Recommendation.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-2914"><img class=" wp-image-2914 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/How-To-Write-A-Letter-Of-Recommendation-300x225.jpg" alt="How To- Write A Letter Of Recommendation" width="348" height="261" /></a>

I’ve spent some time writing letters of recommendation, but I’ve spent a much larger chunk of time reading them as an admissions reader for the UCLA Film Department. When I write letters of recommendation, I always worry about making sure I portray the person in the best light and don’t ruin their application. As a reader, I know that nobody has the time to delve into the kind of scrutiny I worried about when writing a letter.

&nbsp;

So take a deep breath and remember that the letter of rec is <em>one small part</em> of a larger application and the letter alone isn’t going to break your applicant’s chances of admission. As a reader, the toughest calls weren’t the very good or very bad admissions packages, but rather the ones in the middle. That’s the one situation where a great letter can give your applicant a little boost.

&nbsp;
<h3>Before You Begin</h3>
The first thing you want to do when someone asks you for a letter of recommendation is confirm that you’re the right person to write it. Do you know the person well enough to vouch for their character, work ethic, and/or academic ability?

&nbsp;

If you don’t know them well or can’t endorse their skills, it’s fine to decline to write the letter. But if you’re reading this, I’m guessing that you already feel comfortable writing the letter and you’ve already agreed to it.

&nbsp;

The next thing you should do is ask for a copy of the job description or academic program description. You want to find out what characteristics and skills the program is looking for so you can highlight them in your letter.

&nbsp;

Now we’ll move on to length, content, and structure.

&nbsp;
<h4>Length</h4>
Application readers have a lot of territory to cover, so keep your letter succinct and to the point. One-half to three-quarters of a page (single spaced) is a good length. If it’s shorter than that or you’re really struggling, you may not be the right person for the job. More than a page is definitely too much.

&nbsp;
<h4>Content</h4>
What am I looking for when I read a letter of rec? For me, I want to find out about the applicant’s personality and background that may not have been showcased elsewhere in the application.  It’s a personal reference. Furthermore, the letter of rec should be personal. I’m not suggesting you share the applicant’s life story, but discuss situations where you’ve worked with them and observed their problem-solving skills, ethos, and attitude.

&nbsp;

Please don’t include a laundry list of academic achievements or grades. That tells me you don’t know the applicant well or at all. It’s also redundant because it will be included elsewhere in the application.

&nbsp;
<h4>Structure</h4>
I usually try to write 4-5 brief paragraphs. This isn’t academic writing, so a 2-3 sentence paragraph is totally fine. I do stick to basic academic structure: intro with thesis, 2 supporting paragraphs, and a conclusion.

&nbsp;
<h3>Here’s what I’d suggest:</h3>
<strong>Paragraph 1:</strong> Introduce yourself and explain your connection to the applicant. Highlight 2-3 specific skills from the job description that you know the applicant can bring to the team or program.

&nbsp;

<strong>Paragraphs 2-3:</strong> In each of these paragraphs, provide a brief, specific example of the applicant demonstrating one of the aforementioned skills, like a challenging group project where the applicant got everyone to harmonize or a time the applicant succeeded in the face of adversity.

&nbsp;

<strong>Paragraph 4:</strong> Reiterate the applicant’s qualities and leave your contact information (if you feel comfortable) in case the readers have any follow-up questions.

&nbsp;

<strong>Finally:</strong> If you are passionate about the candidate and how wonderful they are, make sure you show it! Not every letter is glowing and that’s okay, but if you think this person is amazing and talented, put it in writing! As a reader, the letters that stood out the most were the ones where the letter-writer’s care for the candidate shone through.

&nbsp;

So now get writing. I wish both you and your applicant the best!]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:10:{i:0;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"241";s:5:"score";s:18:"21.226956450547945";}i:1;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2238";s:5:"score";s:18:"20.780669347919524";}i:2;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"102";s:5:"score";s:18:"20.780669347919524";}i:3;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1631";s:5:"score";s:18:"19.053219802559752";}i:4;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"391";s:5:"score";s:18:"14.488455031206698";}i:5;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"762";s:5:"score";s:18:"14.221392245957654";}i:6;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2428";s:5:"score";s:18:"14.116260327569117";}i:7;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:2:"74";s:5:"score";s:18:"14.116260327569117";}i:8;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2537";s:5:"score";s:18:"12.283678863820807";}i:9;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1981";s:5:"score";s:18:"12.283678863820807";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Make Coffee</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-make-a-cup-of-coffee/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 19 Jan 2016 01:14:38 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[twigg2014]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2960</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/vg5XV_LO0ls" width="560" height="315" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe>

&nbsp;
<h4>While there are different types of coffee makers, here are the steps for using any standard coffee machine:</h4>
&nbsp;

1- Use the coffee canter to measure your water. Follow the measurements on the canter to see how much water is needed for how many cups. Our coffee maker here can make up to four cups of coffee.

2- Pour the water into the side of the coffee maker. If you open the lid, you'll be able to see two compartments: one empty one for the water, and the basket for the coffee grounds. Don't pour the water into the compartment directly over the canter, because that is where your coffee will go! Place the canter back in the proper position.

3- Add one coffee filter to the basket so it fits evenly and sits at the bottom.

4-  Scoop your coffee grounds over your coffee filter. For an average strength cup of coffee, add about 1.5 tablespoons per TWO cups, or 3 tablespoons per FOUR cups. You can add more or less depending on how strong you like your coffee.

5- Once your water and coffee grounds are in place, close the lid and press on. Since the coffee maker we used is so small, it brews particularly fast (about 5 minutes).

6- After the coffee has finished brewing, carefully pour into your coffee mug and add any extras like cream or sugar. Enjoy!

&nbsp;

If you're more of a tea person, be sure to check out our article on <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-make-the-best-cup-of-tea/">How To: Make the BEST Cup of Tea</a>!

&nbsp;

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Clear Your Browser&#039;s Cache</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-clear-your-browsers-cache/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 05 Feb 2016 01:19:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[krisha-agatep]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2969</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/image01.png" rel="attachment wp-att-2970"><img class="aligncenter size-large wp-image-2970" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/image01-1024x78.png" alt="image01" width="1024" height="78" /></a>

You’ve probably seen this message from time to time while surfing the internet. And I’m sure we’ve all agreed to let the site use cookies without even knowing what cookies are. As a web developer, it’s not uncommon for us to use cookies to store information about a user on our site. But what the heck are <strong>cookies</strong> anyway?

&nbsp;
<h4>Cookies, besides being delicious treats, are essentially tiny bits of data stored on your computer by your web browser.</h4>
There are two types of cookies: first and third-party cookies. <strong>First-party cookies</strong> are set by the website and allow the user to go from page to page on a website without losing any information. Take your favorite clothing brand website for example. On one page, you add a pair of shoes to your shopping cart. When that pair of shoes gets added, that information is added to a cookie stored on your computer. Now when you click to the next page to look for shirts, your web browser reads the cookie and outputs your added items in your shopping cart. Then say for example you’re not too sure about your items so you close your computer to go back to it later. A couple hours later, your items still may be stored in a cookie, and therefore will be in your shopping cart.

&nbsp;

<strong>Third party cookies</strong> on the other hand are cookies set by a third party, typically an advertising network. These cookies track your browsing activity and trends to gather more information about you. Ever wondered how you can shop for flights and then you go on Facebook and see targeted advertisements about hotels in your desired destination? Cookies stored on your computer allow the advertising network to pull specific advertisements based on your browsing history.

&nbsp;
<h4>Don’t worry about cookies storing login information, though. This data is strongly encrypted.</h4>
&nbsp;

If this information does bother you, luckily there’s an easy way to clear your cookies. If you’re using Chrome as your default browser, simply open your Preferences or go to chrome://history/, click the “History” tab in the upper left hand corner, and “Clear browsing data...”

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/image00.png" rel="attachment wp-att-2971"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-2971" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/image00.png" alt="image00" width="932" height="314" /></a>

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/image02.png" rel="attachment wp-att-2972"><img class="aligncenter size-large wp-image-2972" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/image02-1024x897.png" alt="image02" width="1024" height="897" /></a>

&nbsp;

The process for clearing your browser’s cookies are similar for other browsers and can be read online for <a href="https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/delete-cookies-remove-info-websites-stored">Firefox</a>, <a href="https://support.apple.com/kb/PH21411?locale=en_US">Safari</a>, and <a href="http://windows.microsoft.com/en-us/internet-explorer/delete-manage-cookies#ie=ie-11">Internet Explorer</a>.

&nbsp;

From here you can clear all of your history including your browser’s cache. Your <strong>cache</strong> is a lot slightly different than cookies and only store temporary internet files such as website images and scripts in order to load the page much faster the next time you visit it. This is why when you go to a website for the first time, it takes much longer to load because your browser has to download every single file for the first time. If you ever need to clear your cache it’s as simple as going into your browser preferences and clearing it from there, or using the shortcut ‘Ctrl+Shift+R’ (Cmd+Shift+R on OS X). This shortcut is the same for all browsers.

&nbsp;
<h4>And there you have it! A quick and easy way to control the information being stored about you. Have any tips for browsing the web wisely and safely? Share in the comments below!</h4>
&nbsp;

Header Photo: 9gag.com]]></content:encoded>
