	<item>
		<title>How To: Save Money Apartment Hunting in New York City</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-ten-ways-to-save-money-apartment-hunting-in-new-york-city/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 01 Feb 2016 01:30:43 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jenny-dorsey]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2975</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[My husband and friends call me an Apartment Wizard for always finding the best apartments available in my budget within a tight timeline. I moved to NYC right after college and have lived in apartments of all price ranges, including the “very low” price point many younger people find themselves in. I’ve learned many lessons through trial and error as well as watching other apartment sleuths, so here are a few smart tips for your next NYC apartment hunt!

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/new-york-918985_1280.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3036"><img class="aligncenter  wp-image-3036" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/new-york-918985_1280.jpg" alt="How To: Save Money Apartment Hunting in New York" width="351" height="234" /></a>

&nbsp;

<strong>1. Pay for an official credit report for yourself and submit that for apartment applications.</strong>

Leasing companies love to rip off renters by overcharging you on an “application fee”, justifying this because they need to run a credit report on you. Get one yourself (a full one, that includes your credit score) online from places like Experian or Equifax for under $20 and bring that along instead. This has saved my husband and me hundreds of dollars by waiving apartment application fees.

&nbsp;

<strong>2. Ask if it’s a co-broker deal or not. Regardless, ask to lower the broker fee.</strong>

Co-brokered deals means there are two brokers being paid a fee, making it difficult to lower the broker fee below 10-12%. However, single broker apartment means that it’s all up to one broker to “budge” on their take-home fee, giving you ample opportunity to put some pressure on them. I’ve found the best way to do this is to say you’re ready to take the apartment (assuming you are) and want to sign now – if the total due for the apartment can be lowered to “X.” Since the landlord most likely will not lower the rent, you are asking indirectly for the broker to make up the room where you are hesitant, and generally once asked they will.

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/picjumbo.com_P1010057.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3038"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-3038" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/picjumbo.com_P1010057.jpg" alt="winter" width="379" height="253" /></a>

<strong>3. Hunt on off-peak months.</strong>

School season drives a good portion of the real estate market in NYC, making summer months (July and August especially) the height of rent prices. October through April is the slow season, giving brokers and landlords a greater incentive to fill their places and more opportunity for you to negotiate pricing. If your current rent expires in the summer but you’re leaving your place, see if you can extend a month-by-month until October so you can restart a lease in the off season.

&nbsp;

<strong>4. Ask about the security deposit.</strong>

Leasing companies make good money by taking your security deposit and putting it into an escrow account for the duration of your lease and earning interest on it. Obviously the more that amount is, the more they make. Some leasing companies will take three times the monthly rent upfront, effectively raising your actual rent price exponentially! Ask about the amount of security before getting an application so you can compare “apples to apples” when looking at apartments based on price. Ideally, security should only be 1 month’s worth of rent. And avoid those leasing companies charging three times rent like the plague.

&nbsp;

<strong>5. Check if your landlord is listed on the <a href="http://landlordwatchlist.com/">Landlord Watchlist</a>. Then, ask where your super lives.</strong>

Ideally, you want a live-in super to a) take packages b) fix anything broken promptly and 3) watch over your building. It may not seem like a big deal at first, but things like hot water outages and sinks overflowing become a timely (and costly) hassle when not dealt with quickly.

&nbsp;

<strong>6. Don’t go exclusive.</strong>

Unless you’ve got oodles of cash to burn, getting an exclusive broker severely limits how many apartments in NYC you can view. Brokers usually also work with one “type” of apartment, so seeing a mix of brick-exposed lofts and modern doorman high-rises usually doesn’t happen. My recommendation is to split up with your roommate or significant other and have one prowl through online listings (i.e. Craigslist) and one line up appointments with one or two brokers.

&nbsp;

<strong>7. Double check price and terms listed vs. those quoted to you.</strong>

This is a rare discrepancy now, but it’s still important to check. Terms like “First month free” or “landlord pays for trash” may be mentioned in the ad but never finalized in person.

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/drain-1060909_1280.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3039"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-3039" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/drain-1060909_1280.jpg" alt="drain-1060909_1280" width="371" height="247" /></a>

<strong>8. Ask about utilities, water, gas, garbage, and electricity fees per month and check internet availability.</strong>

Most commonly, the landlord only pays for gas and water but in newer buildings, tenants also split garbage fees. Ask how much the last tenant paid for electricity per month (a big part of this is if the heat in the building is gas or electrical). This way, you can tally up the costs of each apartment and compare side by side. If you’re reliant on fast WiFi, make sure to check that the apartment is zoned for your preferred network.

&nbsp;

<strong>9. Write down notes during the apartment walk-through.</strong>

If you find an apartment you’re serious about, be thorough during the showing. Jot down notes and take pictures on your phone for any issues you see (e.g. scratches on the floor, single-pane windows, mildew on furnace, clogged sink, missing bits of drywall). Not only can you negotiate the price down for taking the apartment “As-Is”, you can also use these pictures to ensure upon move-out that you’re not charged for these blemishes. Another option is for your ask if the landlord will cover all (or at least a portion) of the cost to fix or upgrade anything in the apartment. For instance, if you’d like a larger dishwasher, offer to buy the dishwasher if the landlord will reimburse the installation fees.

<em>TIP: to check the water pressure, turn on the sink, shower and flush the toilet simultaneously.</em>

&nbsp;

<strong>10. Ask about rent control, long-term leases, and lease to buy options.</strong>

Rent hikes are common in NYC, so ask beforehand to lock in rent control. Generally the broker will let you know if the landlord is the type of guy who would prefer to keep long-term tenants and semi-stabilize rent or if turnover is frequent in the building. Two-year leases are sometimes available, but generally more expensive than a one-year lease, so use your best judgment. Lease to buy is very rare in the city, but worth asking if it’s a space you can see yourself in for a very long time or the landlord/owner is near retirement.

<hr />

Now you’re an expert too! I hope you found these tips helpful and you’ll be able to use these tips right away on your next apartment search. New York is full of gems, it just takes a little time to find them. Good luck hunting!

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/giphy.gif" rel="attachment wp-att-3040"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-3040" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/giphy.gif" alt="giphy" width="344" height="258" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

		<title>How To: Perform A Self Breast Exam</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-perform-a-self-breast-exam/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 25 Jan 2016 19:41:24 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[twigg2014]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2994</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In November of 2015, TWIGG How-To partnered with <a href="http://www.cancanhealth.org/" target="_blank">CanCan Health</a> to spread the importance of breast health and self advocacy in two ways: hosting three workshops on UCLA's campus (which you can read more about <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/workshop-spotlight-party-on-with-cancan-health/">here</a>) and collaborating on the video below.

<a href="http://www.cancanhealth.org/">CanCan Health</a> and TWIGG How-To both believe that taking these precautionary health steps can help lead to early detection, and ultimately save lives. To answer any questions or to get more information, we urge you to visit <a href="http://cancanhealth.org">cancanhealth.org</a>.

Warning: this video contains nudity for breast health education.

&nbsp;

<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/dkKZmTPRVL0" width="560" height="315" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe>

&nbsp;

Special thank you to <a href="http://www.studio22.reslife.ucla.edu/" target="_blank">Studio22</a>!]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Workshop Spotlight: &#039;Party On&#039; with CanCan Health</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/workshop-spotlight-party-on-with-cancan-health/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 25 Jan 2016 20:56:45 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[twigg2014]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=3004</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In November of 2015, TWIGG How-To partnered with <a href="http://www.cancanhealth.org/" target="_blank">CanCan Health</a> to spread the importance of breast health and self advocacy in two ways: hosting three workshops on UCLA’s campus, and collaborating on <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-perform-a-self-breast-exam/" target="_blank">How To: Perform a Self Breast Exam</a>.

<a href="http://cancanhealth.org" target="_blank">CanCan</a> is all about putting people into action about their health, giving them tools for early detection, prevention and self-advocacy. They give students, from all walks of life, a fun way to learn what they can do to feel more in control and less in fear about cancer. TWIGG How-To really loves how they take the practical and make it approachable, which is always our aim whenever we post an article.

&nbsp;

<strong>Here are some of our favorite moments from the workshops: </strong>

[gallery ids="3010,3009,3008,3007,3006,3015,3005,3016"]

&nbsp;

<strong>Here are some highlights and more information about CanCan's workshops:</strong>

<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/EST7GY8Pg_g" width="560" height="315" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe>

&nbsp;

Special thanks to <a href="http://streetsaheadproductions.net/" target="_blank">Streets Ahead Productions</a>!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Build a Website, Pt. 1</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/howtobuildawebsitept1/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 08 Feb 2016 19:21:10 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[nisha]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=3058</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_3064" align="aligncenter" width="503"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/How-To-Build-a-Website-pt.-1.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3064"><img class=" wp-image-3064" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/How-To-Build-a-Website-pt.-1.jpg" alt="Thin line flat design of website under construction, web page building process, site form layout and menu buttons interface develop. Modern vector illustration concept, isolated on white background." width="503" height="199" /></a> Photo from optimagroupinc.com[/caption]

&nbsp;

Hi friends! My name is Nisha and, as you can probably guess from the title, I’m here to teach you a little bit about how to build a website. I just graduated from college studying computer science, and I now work in technology, but my experience with web design goes all the way back to the third grade. I wish I could say that I was teaching myself web design in the third grade because I was a super impressive child, but, unfortunately, I taught myself web design because I wanted to customize my Neopets home page. Really.

I’m not a professional website designer; I’m just someone who has built a ton of websites, a lot of which are pretty bad (error: link not found). There are many resources on the Internet about how to build websites, but I’m going to attempt to compile the best bits from all of them into three TWIGG How-To posts. Note that I’m not going to teach you how to use a template or how to use a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WYSIWYG">WYSIWYG</a> (What You See is What You Get) website editor, both of which are perfectly acceptable methods. I’m going to teach you what actual websites are made of and how to build them (almost) from scratch.

&nbsp;
<h2>Set up</h2>

<hr />

If you get down to the basics, there’s not a lot you have to do to get set up to build a website. All you need is a <strong>plain text editor</strong> and a <strong>browser</strong>. If you’re reading this article, you probably already have a browser downloaded. You probably also have a plain text editor already on your computer, such as vim or emacs, but those are hard to use, so I’d recommend downloading one, such as <a href="https://www.sublimetext.com/">Sublime Text</a> (the free version is fine), <a href="http://macromates.com/">TextMate</a>, or <a href="https://notepad-plus-plus.org/">Notepad++</a>. For reference, a plain text editor is NOT a word processor such as Microsoft Word, and your website will not work if you try to write it in a word processor. In this tutorial, I’m using <a href="https://www.sublimetext.com/">Sublime Text</a> as my plain text editor and <a href="https://www.google.com/chrome/browser/desktop/">Google Chrome</a> as my browser.

&nbsp;
<h2>Building the website</h2>

<hr />

<h3></h3>
<h3>Step 0: HTML and CSS</h3>
In this tutorial, we’re going to be using HTML and CSS to build this website.

&nbsp;

<strong>HTML</strong> (HyperText Markup Language) is a way of writing instructions that a web browser can read and turn into a website. In our website, we’re going to use HTML to create a layout for our website, and we’re going to put our content for the website inside that layout.

&nbsp;

For example, if you want to write a paragraph of text, you can set that paragraph of text in a series of &lt;p&gt;paragraph tags&lt;/p&gt;. The first tag, “&lt;p&gt;”, indicates the start of the paragraph, and the second tag, “&lt;/p&gt;”, indicates the end of the paragraph. Some of the different tags we’ll be using include:

&nbsp;
<ul style="list-style-type: circle;">
	<li>&lt;h1&gt;Header tags&lt;/h1&gt;. Header tags are used for things like titles. Usually, &lt;h1&gt; indicates the largest header and &lt;h2&gt;, &lt;h3&gt;, and so on indicate sub-headings.</li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;">&lt;p&gt;Paragraph tags&lt;/p&gt;. You already saw these, but these mark the start and end of a paragraph of text.</li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;">&lt;div&gt;Div tags&lt;/div&gt;. These tags create “sections” which we’ll use to create layouts. They can be used to divide a webpage into smaller blocks, so that you can organize your content.</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

<strong>CSS</strong> (Cascading StyleSheets) is a way of telling the browser what you want each HTML component to look like. With CSS, you can set the fonts, colors, and sizes of different HTML components of your website. For example, I could include CSS in my website that says:

&nbsp;

p {

color: red;

font-size: 12px;

}

&nbsp;

This means that all of the paragraphs (“p”) on my website are going to have <span style="color: #ff0000;">red text</span> (“color: red;”) and will have a font size of 12 (“font-size: 12px;”).

&nbsp;

You can also create “classes”, which are tags or indicators you can apply to an HTML tag to say that you want it to have the characteristics of that class. This is nice because it means you can apply it to different types of HTML tags. For example, I could write a class “red” as follows:

&nbsp;

.red {

color: red;

}

&nbsp;

Then, when I’m writing my website, I can write &lt;p class=“red”&gt;Hello, world!&lt;/p&gt; or &lt;h1 class=“red”&gt;This is a Title&lt;/h1&gt; and both the paragraph and the title will be red.

&nbsp;

We’ll learn a bit more about HTML and CSS as we build our website, but for now, this should be enough to get us started.

&nbsp;

Be sure to check out Krisha Agatep’s article <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-write-code/">“How To: Write Code”</a> for more information!
<h3></h3>
&nbsp;
<h3>Step 1: Getting started</h3>
In this tutorial, we’re going to build our homepage. By convention, every homepage for every website in the world is written in a file called “index.html”. Let’s go ahead and create our “index.html” file by going to <i>File &gt; New file</i> in the text editor or doing <i>ctrl-N</i> or <i>cmd-N</i> on your computer. You should end up with a blank file called untitled.
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image00.png" rel="attachment wp-att-3059"><img class="wp-image-3059 alignleft" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image00.png" alt="image00" width="249" height="155" /></a><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image03.png" rel="attachment wp-att-3062"><img class="wp-image-3062 alignleft" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image03.png" alt="image03" width="245" height="154" /></a></p>
&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

Go ahead and save that file by going to <i>File &gt; Save</i> or doing <i>ctrl-S</i> or <i>cmd-S</i> and typing “index.html” into the save box. Save it in a convenient location on your computer; we’re going to add more stuff to that folder later.

&nbsp;

Now, let’s add a bit of HTML to this file so that we can have a working website. Open up your file and type (don’t copy/paste!):

&nbsp;

&lt;head&gt;

&lt;title&gt;My first website!&lt;/title&gt;

&lt;/head&gt;

&nbsp;

&lt;body&gt;

&lt;div&gt;

&lt;h1&gt;Hello, world!&lt;/h1&gt;

&lt;/div&gt;

&lt;/body&gt;

&nbsp;

There are two components to this file: the head and the body. The head contains a lot of information that is useful to the browser when displaying the website, but doesn’t contain any actual content. The body contains all of the content of the website. So, if we’ve done this correct, only the stuff in the body is going to show on our website.

&nbsp;

Now, find the file on your computer and open it in your browser of choice (Firefox, Safari, Chrome, etc.). On a Mac or Windows computer, you can do this by right clicking on the file and choosing “Open with”, then choosing your favorite browser. You should end up with something that looks like this:

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image02.png" rel="attachment wp-att-3061"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-3061" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image02.png" alt="image02" width="502" height="300" /></a>

<i>(You can see the code for this page in the file </i><a href="http://nishamasharani.com/TWIGGsite/0.html"><i>0.html</i></a><i>)</i>

&nbsp;

There are a couple of things to note here:

&nbsp;
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;">In the top left of the screen, in the browser tab, it says “My first website!”. That was set by the “title” tag in the “head” of our HTML file.</li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;">Only the content in the h1 tag in our body shows on the website.</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;
<h3>Step 2: Add CSS</h3>
Also notable is the fact that this website is a bit ugly. That’s because we haven’t included any CSS yet. We could write our own CSS, but that takes a lot of time and effort, so we’re going to use CSS contained in an open source web framework, called <strong>Bootstrap</strong>. Bootstrap was written by some engineers at Twitter, and they open sourced it so that anyone can use the stylesheets and scripts that they wrote. To learn more about Bootstrap and what you can do with it, check out <a href="http://getbootstrap.com/">getbootstrap.com</a>.

&nbsp;

Add the CSS to your website by adding the following line to your header (this one you can copy/paste):

&nbsp;

&lt;link rel="stylesheet" href="https://maxcdn.bootstrapcdn.com/bootstrap/3.3.5/css/bootstrap.min.css" integrity="sha512-dTfge/zgoMYpP7QbHy4gWMEGsbsdZeCXz7irItjcC3sPUFtf0kuFbDz/ixG7ArTxmDjLXDmezHubeNikyKGVyQ==" crossorigin="anonymous"&gt;

&nbsp;

(For the most up-to-date version of Bootstrap, you might want to instead copy/paste this line from <a href="http://getbootstrap.com/getting-started/#download-cdn">http://getbootstrap.com/getting-started/#download-cdn</a>.)

&nbsp;

Then, modify the div tag around your header to have the class “container”. You should end up with code that looks something like this:

&nbsp;

&lt;div class=”container”&gt;

&lt;h1&gt;Hello, world!&lt;/h1&gt;

&lt;/div&gt;

&nbsp;

Now, refresh your website. You should see something like this:

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image01.png" rel="attachment wp-att-3060"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-3060" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image01.png" alt="image01" width="506" height="307" /></a>

&nbsp;

<i>(You can see the code for this page in the file </i><a href="http://nishamasharani.com/TWIGGsite/1.html"><i>1.html</i></a><i>)</i>

&nbsp;

Yay! That looks awesome! Now that we know the basics, the next part in the series will focus on building a layout for our content. Get stoked.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>3058</wp:post_id>

		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2016-02-08 19:21:10]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[howtobuildawebsitept1]]></wp:post_name>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Build a Website, Pt. 2</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-build-a-website-pt-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 12 Feb 2016 17:02:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[nisha]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=3072</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Hi friends! Welcome back to How to Build a Website (Part 2). Last time, we got ourselves set up, learned a bit about <strong>HTML</strong> and <strong>CSS</strong>, and started building our website. In this section, we’re going to talk about laying out your website.

&nbsp;
<h3>Step 3: Building a layout</h3>
Remember div tags from earlier? Div tags are used to create blocks or sections of the page, and are awesome for building layouts. We’re going to use div tags to create a layout with a title at the top, a column on the left, and an area for text on the right.

&nbsp;

The best way to think about website layouts is to think of them as grids of rows and columns. First, we’re going to use divs to create the rows, and then, we’re going to put divs inside those divs to divide each row into columns.

&nbsp;

Let’s first create the rows. Open up your index.html file and type the red text into your pre-existing “container” class:

&nbsp;

&lt;div class="container"&gt;

&nbsp;
<p style="text-align: left; padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;!-- row 1 --&gt;</span></p>
<p style="text-align: left; padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;div class="row"&gt;</span></p>
<p style="text-align: left; padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">Hello, world!</span></p>
<p style="text-align: left; padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;/div&gt; &lt;!-- /row 1 --&gt;</span></p>
<p style="text-align: left; padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;!-- row 2 --&gt;</span></p>
<p style="text-align: left; padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;div class="row"&gt;</span></p>
<p style="text-align: left; padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">Placeholder text</span></p>
<p style="text-align: left; padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;/div&gt; &lt;!-- /row 2 --&gt;</span></p>
&nbsp;

&lt;/div&gt; &lt;!-- /container --&gt;

&nbsp;

You’ll notice that there are some tags that aren’t in a normal tag format, but instead look like &lt;!-- this --&gt;. These are “comments”, and the browser doesn’t read them. They’re just there to make it easier for you to understand your code. I’ve included them here because, as we add more and more divs, it’s going to be hard to keep track of where we are.

&nbsp;

As you can see, there are two rows in this HTML (I marked them with comments). Now, let’s add the columns into our rows by adding “nested” divs inside of our rows (again, type the red text into the correct place):

&nbsp;

&lt;div class="container"&gt;
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">&lt;!-- row 1 --&gt;</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">&lt;div class="row"&gt;</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;!-- row 1 col 1 --&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;div class="col-md-12"&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 90px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;h1&gt;Hello, world!&lt;/h1&gt;</span></p>
&nbsp;
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;/div&gt; &lt;!-- /row 1 col 1 --&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">&lt;/div&gt; &lt;!-- /row 1 --&gt;</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">&lt;!-- row 2 --&gt;</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">&lt;div class="row"&gt;</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;!-- row 2 col 1 --&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;div class="col-md-3"&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 90px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;p&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 120px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">Welcome to my first ever website!</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 90px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;/p&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;/div&gt; &lt;!-- /row 2 col 1 --&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;!-- row 2 col 2 --&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;div class="col-md-9"&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 90px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;p&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 120px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">Placeholder text</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 90px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;/p&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;/div&gt; &lt;!-- /row 2 col 2 --&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">&lt;/div&gt; &lt;!-- /row 2 --&gt;</p>
&lt;/div&gt; &lt;!-- /container --&gt;

&nbsp;

Here’s where Bootstrap really shines. Creating these layouts can actually be kind of tricky when you're doing it from scratch, but the Bootstrap stylesheet contains all of the information for the browser so that we have to do very little work.

&nbsp;

Bootstrap has components built in for a layout that is twelve blocks wide. When we set the class of row 1 column 1 to be "col-md-12", that means that we want the column to take up all twelve blocks - meaning it'll take up the full row. For the second row, we set column 1 to take up three blocks and column 2 to take up nine blocks, meaning the first column will take up a quarter of the width and the second column will take up three quarters of the width of the row. To read more about the Bootstrap grid, <a href="http://getbootstrap.com/css/#grid">check out the Bootstrap website</a>.

&nbsp;

Now, reload your index.html. You should end up with something like this (I got my placeholder text from <a href="http://www.lipsum.com/feed/html">the lorem ipsum generator</a>):

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image01-1.png" rel="attachment wp-att-3074"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-3074" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image01-1.png" alt="image01" width="468" height="292" /></a>
<p style="text-align: center;"><i>(You can see the code for this page in the file </i><a href="http://nishamasharani.com/TWIGGsite/2.html"><i>2.html</i></a><i>)</i></p>
&nbsp;

Does your website look something like this? If not, compare your code to the code found in 2.html. It might take a couple of tries to get it right - there’s lots of divs in there!

&nbsp;

Now, this looks awesome, but it’s slightly wide for a lightweight website like the one we’re making. So let’s make it a bit narrow by putting one column on each side that’s empty, so we have a better layout:

&nbsp;

&lt;div class="container"&gt;
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">&lt;!-- row 1 --&gt;</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">&lt;div class="row"&gt;</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;!-- row 1 col 1 --&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;div class="col-md-1"&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 90px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&amp;nbsp;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;/div&gt; &lt;!-- /row 1 col 1 --&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;!-- row 1 col 2 --&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;div class="col-md-10"&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 90px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;h1&gt;Hello, world!&lt;/h1&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;/div&gt; </span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;"> &lt;!-- /row 1 col 2 --&gt;</span></p>
&nbsp;
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;!-- row 1 col 3 --&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;div class="col-md-1"&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 90px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&amp;nbsp;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;/div&gt; &lt;!-- /row 1 col 3 --&gt;</span></p>
&nbsp;

&lt;/div&gt; &lt;!-- /row 1 --&gt;

&nbsp;

&lt;!-- row 2 --&gt;

&lt;div class="row"&gt;
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">&lt;!-- row 2 col 1 --&gt;</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;div class="col-md-1"&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 90px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&amp;nbsp;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;/div&gt; &lt;!-- /row 2 col 1 --&gt;</span></p>
&nbsp;
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;!-- row 2 col 2 --&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;div class="col-md-3"&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 90px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;p&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 150px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">Welcome to my first ever website!</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 90px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;/p&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;/div&gt; &lt;!-- /row 2 col 2 --&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;!-- row 2 col 3 --&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;div class="col-md-7"&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 90px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;p&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 150px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">Placeholder text</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 90px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;/p&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;/div&gt; &lt;!-- /row 2 col 3 --&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;!-- row 2 col 4 --&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;div class="col-md-1"&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 90px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&amp;nbsp;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;/div&gt; &lt;!-- /row 2 col 4 --&gt;</span></p>
&nbsp;
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">&lt;/div&gt; &lt;!-- /row 2 --&gt;</p>
&nbsp;

&lt;/div&gt; &lt;!-- /container --&gt;

&nbsp;

You can see that, in each row, we’ve added an empty column on the left and right, each with width 1. You’ll notice that we put &amp;nbsp; in each empty column; that just adds white space so that the column has something in it. This means that the middle columns have also shrunk, so that the total width of the content of our page is 10 instead of 12 units. Your index.html should now look something like this when you open it in your browser:

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image00-1.png" rel="attachment wp-att-3073"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-3073" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image00-1.png" alt="image00" width="466" height="291" /></a>
<p style="text-align: center;"><i>(You can see the code for this page in the file </i><a href="http://nishamasharani.com/TWIGGsite/3.html"><i>3.html</i></a><i>)</i></p>
&nbsp;

Awesome! Now we have a skeleton that we can use to build our website. In the next section, I’ll teach you how to add your own personalized content to your website. Stay tuned.]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Build a Website, Pt. 3</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-build-a-website-pt-3/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 15 Feb 2016 10:04:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[nisha]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=3141</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Hi friends! Welcome to the final installment of our three-part series on website construction! Last time, we built the skeleton of our website. This time, we’re going to add our content and make it look pretty.

&nbsp;
<h3>Step 4: Adding content</h3>
We’re almost done with our website, and now it’s time to personalize it a little bit. I’m going to turn this website into a homepage for myself, and I recommend that you do the same, because who doesn’t deserve to build an internet shrine for themselves? We’re going to learn how to add a cute picture, a short bio, and a few links to social media.

&nbsp;

To start, let’s add a picture. Find a picture of yourself and put a copy of it in the same folder as your index.html file. Then, in row 2 column 2, add (again, type, don’t copy/paste!):

&nbsp;

&lt;!-- row 2 col 2 --&gt;

&lt;div class="col-md-3"&gt;
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;img src=”nisha.jpg” /&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">&lt;p&gt;</p>
<p style="padding-left: 90px;">Welcome to my first ever website!</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">&lt;/p&gt;</p>
&lt;/div&gt; &lt;!-- /row 2 col 2 --&gt;

&nbsp;

where nisha.jpg is replaced with the filename of your image.

&nbsp;

Now, if I load this with the image that I added, I get something pretty weird looking:

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image02-1.png" rel="attachment wp-att-3142"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-3142" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image02-1.png" alt="image02" width="514" height="321" /></a>

Yeah, that doesn’t look so good. To make it look better, we’re going to write a bit of CSS! Go up to the &lt;head&gt; part of your index.html and add:

&nbsp;

&lt;style&gt;
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">.portrait-container {</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">padding:10px;</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">text-align: center;</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">}</p>
&nbsp;
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">.portrait {</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">width:80%;</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">}</p>
&lt;/style&gt;

&nbsp;

Here, we’re creating two classes: portrait-container and portrait. The period before the class name identifies it as a class. Then, we’re setting a few attributes: padding, text-align, and width.

&nbsp;
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;">-Padding means space within the inside of a block. So, if the block’s borders are in black here:</li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image04.png" rel="attachment wp-att-3143"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-3143" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image04.png" alt="image04" width="141" height="141" /></a>
padding would be added to the inside of the block, like the red below</li>
	<li><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image00-2.png" rel="attachment wp-att-3144"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-3144" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image00-2.png" alt="image00" width="141" height="141" /></a>
meaning anything inside the block would be constrained to within the inner edge of the red padding.</li>
	<li></li>
	<li>-Text-align is exactly what it sounds like: the alignment of text and other things in a container. I want my picture to be centered, so I’m setting text-align to be center</li>
	<li></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;">-Width is again exactly what it sounds like. I could set the width to be a value, like 100px (100 pixels). However, I want the width to change dynamically based on the size of the column, so I’m setting the width to be 80% of the container size.</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

Now, let’s rewrite your row 2 column 2 so that it looks like this:

&nbsp;

&lt;!-- row 2 col 2 --&gt;

&lt;div class="col-md-3"&gt;
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;div class="portrait-container"&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;img src="nisha.jpg" class="portrait img-circle"/&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="color: #ff0000;">&lt;/div&gt;</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">&lt;p&gt;</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">Welcome to my first ever website! Look how cool this is.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">&lt;/p&gt;</p>
&lt;/div&gt; &lt;!-- /row 2 col 2 --&gt;

&nbsp;

We have a couple of things going on here. We’re creating a div to wrap the image. We’re giving that div the class “portrait-container”, so that it will have a padding of 10px and so that everything inside of it will be centered. We’re then putting the image inside of the div and giving it the class portrait, so it will have a width of 80% of its container. We’re also setting the class to be img-circle so that the image will be circular (this class is from <a href="http://getbootstrap.com/css/#images">Bootstrap’s style sheet</a>).

&nbsp;

Now,  your website should look something like this:

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image03-1.png" rel="attachment wp-att-3145"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-3145" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image03-1.png" alt="image03" width="550" height="344" /></a>

<i>(You can see the code for this page in the file </i><a href="http://nishamasharani.com/TWIGGsite/4.html"><i>4.html</i></a><i>)</i>

&nbsp;

That’s a lot better. Now, I’m going to replace the placeholder text with some info about me.

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image06.png" rel="attachment wp-att-3146"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-3146" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image06.png" alt="image06" width="600" height="375" /></a>

Now, I think it looks a little awkward how short the text is, so I’m going to increase the text size a little.
<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image07.png" rel="attachment wp-att-3147"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-3147" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image07.png" alt="image07" width="613" height="383" /></a>

That’s better. I made the text larger by setting the class of the paragraphs to be “lead” (&lt;p class=”lead”&gt;). This is another <a href="http://getbootstrap.com/css/#type-body-copy">Bootstrap CSS class</a> that you can use to emphasize text when you’re writing in long form, or just to make text larger when you’re writing short paragraphs.

&nbsp;

You might also notice that there are some links in that paragraph to other websites. To add links, use the &lt;a&gt; tag, like so:

&nbsp;

&lt;a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/"&gt;The Winging It Girl's Guide (TWIGG)&lt;/a&gt;

&nbsp;

If you want to link to something else, switch out the URL in the quotation marks, "http://www.twigghowto.com/", to be the page you want to link to, and change the text in the tags, “The Winging It Girls’ Guide (TWIGG)”, to whatever you’d like the link to say.

&nbsp;

Now, I also want to add some links in the left column to some other interesting information about me, but I want it to look really nice. So, I’m going to use a <a href="http://getbootstrap.com/components/#nav-pills">navigation component from Bootstrap </a>to make it look good:

&nbsp;

&lt;ul class="nav nav-pills nav-stacked centered bigtext"&gt;
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">&lt;li role="presentation"&gt;</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">&lt;a href="https://youtu.be/dQw4w9WgXcQ"&gt;Resume&lt;/a&gt;</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">&lt;/li&gt;</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">&lt;li role="presentation"&gt;</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">&lt;a href="<a href="http://linkedin.com">http://linkedin.com</a>"&gt;LinkedIn&lt;/a&gt;</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">&lt;/li&gt;</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">&lt;li role="presentation"&gt;</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">&lt;a href="http://twitter.com/nismatch"&gt;Twitter&lt;/a&gt;</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">&lt;/li&gt;</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">&lt;li role="presentation"&gt;</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">&lt;a href="http://github.com/nmasharani"&gt;Github&lt;/a&gt;</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">&lt;/li&gt;</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">&lt;/ul&gt;</p>
&nbsp;

The &lt;ul&gt; tag denotes an unordered list, and the &lt;li&gt; tag denotes an element of the list. We’re using the CSS classes from Bootstrap--nav, nav-pills, and nav-stacked--to get the nice Bootstrap styling. We’re also adding a couple of classes that I wrote: centered and bigtext. To get these classes, add the following to your style tags in the head:

&nbsp;

.centered {
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">text-align: center;</p>
}

&nbsp;

.bigtext {
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">font-size:16px;</p>
}

&nbsp;

Now, your website should look something like this:

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image05.png" rel="attachment wp-att-3148"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-3148" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image05.png" alt="image05" width="578" height="361" /></a>

<i>(You can see the code for this page in the file </i><a href="http://nishamasharani.com/TWIGGsite/5.html"><i>5.html</i></a><i>)</i>

&nbsp;

That’s a lot better.

&nbsp;

Now, there’s a lot more we can do to our website. However, I think this is enough to get started, so I’m going to stop here. There are tons of resources on the internet for how to build a website, so if you’d like to learn more, you can check out some of those, or you can just keep fiddling with what we’ve built so far. I think the best way to learn is just to try things, so definitely keep experimenting!
<h2></h2>
<h2>Publishing</h2>
There are many ways and places you can publish your website, i.e., put it on the internet. This is just one way to get a website up and running. We’re going to publish our website on GitHub Pages.

&nbsp;

Go to <a href="https://github.com/">github.com</a>. If you don’t have an account already, sign up and activate your account. Then, go to <a href="https://github.com/new">github.com/new</a> and create a repository named <i>username</i>.github.io, where username is the username you signed up for Github with. Make sure “initialize this repository with a README” is checked!

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image01-2.png" rel="attachment wp-att-3149"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-3149" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image01-2.png" alt="image01" width="565" height="353" /></a>

<i>I already have a repo with the name nmasharani.github.io.</i>

&nbsp;

Now, go to your computer and open a command line. On a Mac, you can do this by opening the “Terminal” application. On a PC, you can do this by clicking Start &gt; Program Files &gt; Accessories &gt; Command Prompt. Now, navigate to the folder that you saved your index.html file in by typing

&nbsp;

cd path/to/folder

&nbsp;

For example, on my computer, I saved my website in the Documents folder, so I’m going to type

&nbsp;

cd Documents/TWIGGsite

&nbsp;

and press “Enter”. Now, type the following into the command prompt:

&nbsp;

git clone <a href="https://github.com/username/username.github.io">https://github.com/<i>username</i>/<i>username</i>.github.io</a>

&nbsp;

and press “Enter” again. This will create a folder called <i>username</i>.github.io. Now, move your index.html, picture, and any other files you used in your website into the <i>username</i>.github.io folder. Go back to your command line and type

&nbsp;

git add --all

git commit -m "Initial commit"

git push -u origin master

&nbsp;

You may have to type your username and password. Now, go to <i>username.</i><span style="font-weight: 400;">github.io in your browser, and your website will be there. Congratulations, you have published your first website! </span>]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Home-Misc</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/?post_type=tablepress_table&#038;p=1512</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 02 Apr 2015 06:43:55 +0000</pubDate>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[["Household","Health","Finances","Technology","Miscellaneous"],["Fixing a Leaky Pipe","Breaking Down a Nutrition Label","Basis Trading","Mastering Excel","Understanding Restaurant Health Ratings"],["Home Security","Getting CPR Certified","Different Types of Bank Accounts","Fixing an Internet Router","Changing a Diaper"],["Household Painting","Understanding Insurance Co-Pays","Filing Tax Returns","Choosing the Right Computer","Opening a Wine Bottle"],["Installing Shelves","Tying a Tourniquet","Understanding Your Pay Stub","","Basic Knife Skills in Cooking"],["Different Types of Fire Extinguishers","Giving the Heimlich","Living on a Budget","","Using a Rice Cooker"],["Garbage Disposal Tips","","Starting a Retirement Fund","","Tying a Tie"],["Smoke Detector Rights","","Stock Market Basics","",""],["Renters Insurance 101","","What to do if your Credit Card is Stolen","",""]]]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Floss</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-floss/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 21 Mar 2016 08:00:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[alex-regalado]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=2884</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[A huge part of becoming an adult, at least for me, was finding my own dentist. I was a regular patient at my local family dentistry since the wee age of three, but I needed to find a new dentist after I moved to Los Angeles for college. Even though I was nervous about a new pair of hands getting all up in my teeth, I put on a brave face and booked my appointment.

&nbsp;

I ended up meeting Pam, a dentist hygienist who was so worried about the health of my teeth that she cleaned them <em>three times</em> during my check up! She also spent about fifteen minutes lecturing me on the importance of flossing and teaching me the correct technique, which no dental hygienist had ever taken the time to do. I took tedious notes during that lesson, and decided to share Pam’s fifteen years of wisdom and expertise with all of you today. Here we go:

<hr />

&nbsp;
<h3 style="text-align: center;">How Much Do I Use?</h3>
<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/oie_VCvX3hocNhGt.gif" rel="attachment wp-att-3303"><img class="size-medium wp-image-3303 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/oie_VCvX3hocNhGt-300x237.gif" alt="oie_VCvX3hocNhGt" width="300" height="237" /></a>

Pull out <strong>an arm’s length</strong> of floss from the container. The more you use a piece of floss, the weaker it gets and the less effective it is for cleaning (that’s why we use a new piece each time). Therefore, we want a long piece that we can move around between our fingers to always ensure we are using the strongest quality.

&nbsp;
<h3 style="text-align: center;">How Do I Hold It?</h3>
<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/oie_DNMxfx6GSNCi.gif" rel="attachment wp-att-3306"><img class="size-medium wp-image-3306 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/oie_DNMxfx6GSNCi-300x238.gif" alt="oie_DNMxfx6GSNCi" width="300" height="238" /></a>

<strong>Loop about half of the long piece of floss around your left middle finger, and about half around the right middle finger,</strong> leaving about an inch free in the middle between both fingers. While your middle fingers hold the extra floss, you’ll maneuver around your mouth with your index fingers and thumbs. If you tried to wrap the floss around the index fingers, you’d have to stuff your entire hand in your mouth, <strong>making it difficult to move around freely</strong>. By wrapping the floss around your middle fingers and then using only your index fingers to reach into your mouth, you can create more space to get in those hard-to-reach parts of your mouth like your back teeth and molars.

&nbsp;
<h3 style="text-align: center;">Why Am I Doing This?</h3>
I was surprised to learn that the goal of flossing is not to remove food, but actually to remove the buildup of plaque between your teeth and gums. Dental plaque is a “soft, sticky film that builds up on your teeth and contains millions of bacteria” (<a href="http://A huge part of becoming an adult, at least for me, was finding my own dentist. I was a regular patient at my local family dentistry since the wee age of three, but I needed to find a new dentist after I moved to Los Angeles for college. Even though I was nervous about a new pair of hands getting all up in my teeth, I put on a brave face and booked my appointment. I ended up meeting Pam, a dentist hygienist who was so worried about the health of my teeth that she cleaned them three times during my check up! She also spent about fifteen minutes lecturing me on the importance of flossing and teaching me the correct technique, which no dental hygienist had ever taken the time to do. I took tedious notes during that lesson, and decided to share Pam’s fifteen years of wisdom and expertise with all of you today. Here we go: How Much Do I Use? Pull out an arm’s length of floss from the container. The more you use a piece of floss, the weaker it gets and the less effective it is for cleaning (that’s why we use a new piece each time). Therefore, we want a long piece that we can move around between our fingers to always ensure we are using the strongest quality. How Do I Hold It? Loop about half of the long piece of floss around your left middle finger, and about half around the right middle finger, leaving about an inch free in the middle between both fingers. While your middle fingers hold the extra floss, you’ll maneuver around your mouth with your index fingers and thumbs. If you tried wrap the floss around the index fingers, you’d have to stuff your entire hand in your mouth, making it difficult to move around freely. By wrapping the floss around your middle fingers and then using only your index fingers to reach into your mouth, you can create more space to get in those hard-to-reach parts of your mouth like your back teeth and molars. Why Am I Doing This? I was surprised to learn that the goal of flossing is not to remove food, but actually to remove the buildup of plaque between your teeth. Dental plaque is a “soft, sticky film that builds up on your teeth and contains millions of bacteria” (Delta Dental) link: https://www.deltadentalins.com/oral_health/plaque.html so it’s important to get rid of as much of it as you can. When flossing, do not just scoop or quickly press the piece of floss in between two teeth; rub the floss up and down (GENTLY) against both sides of the tooth gap and gums. It’s natural for your gums to bleed if you don’t floss often- so don’t stress out! The more you floss, the tougher your gums will get and the less likely you’ll bleed in the future. How Do I Maneuver The Floss? For the back teeth, press your index fingers on top of the floss at the same time and just use those fingers to reach back. For the front teeth, press your thumbs under the floss at the same time and punch up with the floss in between the teeth. After rubbing against both sides of the tooth gap, follow the tooth up or down to where it touches the gum. Use the floss to hug your tooth and follow it under the gum as far as it can go. Plaque builds up under the gum, and that’s the one location that a toothbrush can’t reach. Naturally, there will be gunk or food on your floss; I normally floss in the bathroom and rinse this off with water. After flossing three teeth, untwist a new section of floss from either side of your hands and repeat the same previous steps indicated above. Make sure to try reaching your very back teeth, since they can be easily ignored/forgotten. Continue until you are finished with all of your teeth and gums! In Conclusion... Remembering to floss even once a day can make a big difference in keeping your gums and teeth healthy. There was a period of time before Pam came into my life, where I always forgot to floss and had painful teeth cleanings. But once I committed to flossing everyday, my teeth cleanings became less painful and finished faster than usual! To help you remember, pick a time of the day to floss and stick with that routine. Maybe floss during your lunch break, or when you sit down to watch the ten o’clock news. Even set an alarm on your phone if you have to. Whatever you decide to do, I hope you remember these tips and keep up with your flossing!">Delta Dental</a>) so it’s important to get rid of as much of it as you can. When flossing, do not just scoop or quickly press the piece of floss in between two teeth; <strong>rub the floss up and down (GENTLY)</strong> <strong>against both sides of the tooth gap</strong> and gums. It’s natural for your gums to bleed if you don’t floss often- so don’t stress out! The more you floss, the tougher your gums will get and the less likely you’ll bleed in the future.

&nbsp;
<h3 style="text-align: center;">How Do I Maneuver The Floss?</h3>
[caption id="attachment_3299" align="aligncenter" width="357"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/floss-1.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3299"><img class="wp-image-3299 " src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/floss-1-300x143.jpg" alt="floss 1" width="357" height="170" /></a> As beautiful as my gifs are, here's a great diagram from softtouchdds.com[/caption]

For the back teeth, press your index fingers on top of the floss at the same time and just use those fingers to reach back.

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/oie_kuMnSLBh47oH.gif" rel="attachment wp-att-3307"><img class="size-medium wp-image-3307 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/oie_kuMnSLBh47oH-300x238.gif" alt="oie_kuMnSLBh47oH" width="300" height="238" /></a>

For the front teeth, press your thumbs under the floss at the same time and punch up with the floss in between the teeth.

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/floss-2.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3301"><img class=" wp-image-3301 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/floss-2-300x156.jpg" alt="floss 2" width="354" height="184" /></a>

After rubbing against both sides of the tooth gap, follow the tooth up or down to where it touches the gum. Use the floss to hug your tooth and follow it under the gum as far as it can go. <strong>Plaque builds up under the gum, and that’s the one location that a toothbrush can’t reach. </strong>Be sure to rub the floss around the very back teeth as well!

&nbsp;

Naturally, there will be gunk or food on your floss; I normally floss in the bathroom and rinse this off with water.

[caption id="attachment_3293" align="aligncenter" width="300"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/670px-Floss-Step-2-Version-3.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3293"><img class="wp-image-3293 size-medium" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/670px-Floss-Step-2-Version-3-300x225.jpg" alt="670px-Floss-Step-2-Version-3" width="300" height="225" /></a> As we loosen on the left hand, we re-wrap and tighten on the right. Graphic from wikihow.[/caption]

<strong>After flossing three teeth, untwist a new section of floss from either side of your hands and repeat the same previous steps indicated above.</strong> Make sure to try reaching your very back teeth, since they can be easily ignored/forgotten. Continue until you are finished with all of your teeth and gums!

&nbsp;
<h3 style="text-align: center;">In Conclusion...</h3>
Remembering to floss even once a day can make a big difference in keeping your gums and teeth healthy. There was a period of time before Pam came into my life, where I always forgot to floss and had painful teeth cleanings. But once I committed to flossing everyday, my teeth cleanings became less painful and finished faster than usual!

&nbsp;

To help you remember, <strong>pick a time of the day to floss and stick with that routine</strong>. Maybe floss during your lunch break, or when you sit down to watch the ten o’clock news. Even set an alarm on your phone if you have to. Whatever you decide to do, I hope you remember these tips and keep up with your flossing!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Propagate Succulents</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-propagate-succulents/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 19 Feb 2016 09:24:31 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[karissa-chamblin]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=3080</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Watching plants grow is seriously so much fun and so rewarding. “Propagating”or creating more plants from cuttings off of a larger plant is an easy, awesome project that anyone can do. Just follow these simple steps to grow your own plant babies off of plants you already have!

&nbsp;

Things you'll need:
<ul style="list-style-type: disc;">
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">A healthy succulent(echeveria) plant</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Sharp pruning shears or scissors</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Cactus/succulent potting soil</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Containers such as Mini pots, mason jars, or teacups</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 14px;"><span style="font-size: 16px;">Pea gravel or fu</span>n colored small rocks/pebbles</span></li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

Fill the containers (whatever cute ones you have lying around. They do not need a drain hole) with the pea gravel ⅓ of the way up and fill the remaining ⅓ with the cactus soil. Leave about a ⅓ of space at the top to give your cuttings room to grow.

&nbsp;

<strong>Step 1:</strong>  Take your mature and healthy succulent plant and clip off a few leaves at the base of the plant. These are called “cuttings”.

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image01.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3085"><img class="aligncenter size-medium wp-image-3085" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image01-225x300.jpg" alt="image01" width="225" height="300" /></a>

&nbsp;

<strong>Step 2: </strong>Lay your cuttings on a plate and place them in a spot with indirect sunlight. I like to put mine in the windowsill.

&nbsp;

<strong>Step 3:</strong>  Keep your cuttings in the windowsill for two-four weeks and watch them callus over and sprout little hairs (roots)!

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image03.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3087"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-3087 size-medium" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image03-225x300.jpg" alt="image03" width="225" height="300" /></a>

&nbsp;

<strong>Step 4: </strong>Once they have sprouted their hairs, stick them up right in your container with their hairs covered by the soil.
<p style="text-align: center;">           <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image02.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3086"><img class="wp-image-3086 size-medium alignnone" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image02-225x300.jpg" alt="Processed with VSCOcam with a6 preset" width="225" height="300" /></a>             <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image04.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3088"><img class="wp-image-3088 size-medium alignnone" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image04-225x300.jpg" alt="Processed with VSCOcam with a6 preset" width="225" height="300" /></a></p>
&nbsp;

&nbsp;

<strong>Step 5: </strong>Let the cuttings establish their roots for about two weeks in the soil. Once they do, you can water them at the same time you water your mature succulents. Usually you need to water every two to four weeks depending on how warm the climate is where you live. In warmer climates like Arizona or California, water more. In milder climates like Washington, water less.  Succulents are drought resistant which means they like dry soil. Only water them when their soil has completely dried out on the surface.

&nbsp;

<strong>Step 6: </strong>Give your new baby succulents out to friends and family as gifts and they can watch them grow eventually into full grown(the size of your palm) succulents!

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image00.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3084"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-3084 size-medium" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image00-300x225.jpg" alt="Processed with VSCOcam with a6 preset" width="300" height="225" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<category domain="category" nicename="household"><![CDATA[Household]]></category>

			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_wp_rp_related_posts_query_result_cache_5]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:10:{i:0;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2171";s:5:"score";s:18:"36.145946370175714";}i:1;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2191";s:5:"score";s:18:"19.822530338963325";}i:2;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2027";s:5:"score";s:17:"17.34235257863066";}i:3;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2832";s:5:"score";s:17:"16.53142236235916";}i:4;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2411";s:5:"score";s:17:"16.53142236235916";}i:5;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"3192";s:5:"score";s:17:"16.39564818290698";}i:6;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2600";s:5:"score";s:17:"16.39564818290698";}i:7;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1066";s:5:"score";s:18:"16.031005069263898";}i:8;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"644";s:5:"score";s:18:"16.031005069263898";}i:9;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1045";s:5:"score";s:18:"15.720492146184208";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[No]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_featured_post]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[field_562d90b18894c]]></wp:meta_value>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Write a Senior Thesis</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-write-a-senior-thesis/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 11 Mar 2016 09:37:46 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jenna-perelman]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=3092</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Senior year of college. The last year of your undergraduate career – potentially your last year of schooling altogether. And standing between you and your diploma is that abstract, anxiety-inducing thing called a <em>senior thesis</em>.

&nbsp;

No matter how daunting it might seem at the beginning, I’m here to tell you that YOU CAN DO IT. Depending on your school and major, you may have a one- or two-semester thesis. I finished my one-semester thesis this past fall, so I did the bulk of my research and writing over that semester, but my topic was based on the internship I did over the summer and the spring semester before that. So essentially I was thinking about my thesis in one way or another for all of 2015. Which leads me to my first tip…

<span style="font-size: 8px;">  </span>

[caption id="attachment_3093" align="aligncenter" width="300"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/IMG_1512.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3093"><img class="size-medium wp-image-3093" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/IMG_1512-300x286.jpg" alt="Me with the finished product" width="300" height="286" /></a> Me with the finished product![/caption]

<span style="font-size: 8px;">   </span>
<h4>1. Treat assignments throughout your undergraduate years as ways to explore potential senior thesis topics.</h4>
It’s never too early to start thinking about your topic! This tip goes two ways: you can approach papers as potential thesis topics or, after you write the paper, you could discover that you want to learn more about those issues. For example, did you love writing about Obama’s environmental record? Maybe your senior thesis could be on presidential executive action on environmental issues.

&nbsp;
<h4>2. Write about what you know (aka do your research!).</h4>
With this tip I mean you should write about something that you’ve done extensive research on. You can start off not knowing a single thing about your topic, but at the end of the semester when you’re polishing off your final edits, you should be an expert on the subject. I chose to write about the organization at which I had interned for the past eight months, which gave me a solid background to draw from when I began the writing process. Because of my insider experience, I was able to interview employees and cut my research time in half.

&nbsp;
<h4>3. Make a writing schedule.</h4>
Early on in your writing process, make a schedule. Even if you don’t stick to it, making a schedule is a good way to see how you will spend your time over the next few months. I thought one semester was a really long time to write a paper, but once I laid it out, I realized I had to write 10-15 pages every two weeks, which is a lot for a slower writer like me. Work backwards to create a writing plan. Here’s a way to start: look at the deadline, decide how much time you want purely for copy editing, then decide how much time you need to write and revise each chapter which will help you figure out how many pages/sections you need to finish each week.

&nbsp;
<h4>4. Plan for longer breaks.</h4>
This comes back to a well thought out schedule à la tip number 3. Taking a weekend off can actually do you good because a) it lets your brain solve your thesis problems subconsciously and b) allows you to do something, <em>anything</em> else whether that be getting some exercise in, taking a weekend trip, or working on homework for your other classes (yeah, remember those? They still exist!). If you plan to take a weekend off, then you can actually enjoy your time off knowing that you prepared for it rather than being stressed out that you’re not working on your thesis.

&nbsp;
<h4>5. Pick a topic that you love.</h4>
Your thesis is a chance to write about practically anything. There are no prompts, no lessons to follow – this paper is all yours! So pick something you really love. You will be spending a lot of time with this topic so make sure it’s something that you care about. Two months and thirty pages in, everyone grows to sort of dread working on their thesis, so there’s no need to rush that process by picking something you don’t like.

&nbsp;

These are just a few of the tips I picked up along the way, and they can really be applied to any long paper that you’re assigned throughout college. I know it’s hard, but you can do it. Completing a thesis is by far one of the most rewarding things I have done in college.

&nbsp;

If you want to check mine out, here’s the link: <a href="http://scholarship.claremont.edu/scripps_theses/793/">http://scholarship.claremont.edu/scripps_theses/793/</a>

&nbsp;

Good luck!]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
