	<item>
		<title>How To: Understand the Nuances of American Politics</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-primer-to-american-politics/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 22 Feb 2016 09:48:10 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Caitlin Cohen]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=3154</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[2016 is a big year in American politics. We’re going to elect our next president. There are some major Congressional elections this year. Some states are voting on issues regarding marijuana laws, reproductive rights, taxes, and immigration.

A lot of buzzwords get thrown around, and some the meaning of some terms gets lost in biased connotation.

It is a right and a privilege as a US citizen to be able to vote. However, it is an obligation as a voter to be educated on how the process works and what/who you’re voting for. Here’s a basic rundown of political terms and basic political movements in the United States to better help you understand the climate today.

&nbsp;
<h3>Government</h3>
The United States of America is made up of 50 states, a capital district, and territories. It is a federal republic, which is a form of democracy. This means that each state has its own set of laws that are superseded by federal law, which governs the entire country. Furthermore, a republic is a form of indirect democracy in which citizens elect representatives to vote on the issues for them rather than every citizen doing so directly.

[caption id="attachment_3165" align="aligncenter" width="550"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image08.png" rel="attachment wp-att-3165"><img class="wp-image-3165" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image08.png" alt="This is the most American photo of America I could find, minus a terrifying bald eagle staring into your soul." width="550" height="345" /></a> This is the most American photo of America I could find, minus a terrifying bald eagle staring into your soul.[/caption]
<h3></h3>
&nbsp;
<h3>Political schools of thought</h3>
<h4>1. Liberalism</h4>
“Left-wing,” often progressive. Liberals believe the government should stay out of personal lives but that there should be basic protections for citizens. Liberals are most likely to be for gay marriage, the separation of church and state, equal pay laws, and a higher minimum wage, for example.

Current notable liberals: Paul Krugman, Debbie Wasserman Schultz, Stephen Colbert

[caption id="attachment_3164" align="aligncenter" width="461"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image07.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3164"><img class="wp-image-3164" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image07-859x1024.jpg" alt="Colbert often uses his current platform as host of The Late Show to discuss serious political and social issues." width="461" height="550" /></a> Colbert often uses his current platform as host of The Late Show to discuss serious political and social issues.[/caption]

&nbsp;
<h4>2. Conservatism</h4>
“Right-wing.” Conservatives believe in American exceptionalism and the preservation of American traditions. Conservatives are most likely to be for low taxes, business-friendly environments, a strong military, and stricter immigration law.

Current notable conservatives: Jonah Goldberg, Governor Nikki Haley, Chuck Norris

[caption id="attachment_3161" align="aligncenter" width="220"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image04-1.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3161"><img class="size-full wp-image-3161" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image04-1.jpg" alt="South Carolina Governor Nikki Haley gave the Republican response to Obama’s State of the Union." width="220" height="330" /></a> South Carolina Governor Nikki Haley gave the Republican response to Obama’s State of the Union.[/caption]

&nbsp;
<h4>3. Libertarianism</h4>
Libertarians believe in the smallest form of government. They are liberal on social issues and conservative on economic issues. Libertarians tend to believe in allowing gay marriage, legalizing drugs, separation of church and state, and lowering taxes. They tend to prefer the least amount of regulation possible, and prefer state government over federal government. They are also often outspoken against police brutality.

Current notable libertarians: Senator Rand Paul, Trey Parker, Charles Koch

[caption id="attachment_3170" align="aligncenter" width="300"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image13.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3170"><img class="wp-image-3170 size-medium" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image13-300x150.jpg" alt="image13" width="300" height="150" /></a> The Libertarian philosophy shows up frequently in South Park.[/caption]

&nbsp;

&nbsp;
<h4>4. Democratic Socialism</h4>
Democratic socialists believe in higher taxes, a bigger safety net for citizens, and an economic environment that fosters growth of the middle class. While all schools of thought are pro-middle class, democratic socialism believes unregulated capitalism leads to a wider gap between the rich and the poor. Democratic socialists focus on issues such as income inequality.

Current notable democratic socialists: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, Noam Chomsky, Senator Elizabeth Warren

[caption id="attachment_3167" align="aligncenter" width="397"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image10.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3167"><img class="wp-image-3167" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image10-238x300.jpg" alt="Senator Elizabeth Warren has spoken up frequently for Planned Parenthood and other feminist issues." width="397" height="500" /></a> Senator Elizabeth Warren has spoken up frequently for Planned Parenthood and other feminist issues.[/caption]

&nbsp;
<h4>5. Tea Party Movement</h4>
Tea Partiers are extremely conservative, almost reactionary. The Tea Party believes in Judeo-Christian values in government while also believing in low taxes. For example, a member of the Tea Party is most likely to disagree with climate change and to distrust Muslims and other non-Christians.

Current notable Tea Party members: Sarah Palin, Glenn Beck, Dr. Ben Carson

[caption id="attachment_3163" align="aligncenter" width="400"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image06-1.png" rel="attachment wp-att-3163"><img class="wp-image-3163" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image06-1-300x201.png" alt="This is Jay Pharoah playing Dr. Ben Carson on &quot;Saturday Night Live.&quot;" width="400" height="268" /></a> This is Jay Pharoah playing Dr. Ben Carson on "Saturday Night Live."[/caption]

&nbsp;
<h3>Political Parties</h3>
<h4>1. Democratic Party</h4>
Founded 1828

The Democratic Party is the second major party. The party is currently moderately liberal. For example, while many major Democrats believe in equal pay laws and more extensive background checks on guns, several of them also believe in a larger military. The more liberal members of the Democratic Party tend to be against military intervention.

Do not confuse “liberal” with “Democrat.” While there is often overlap, they are not synonymous.

The Democratic Party has changed a lot since 1828. Southern Democrats used to be a conservative wing of the party that believed wholeheartedly in Jim Crow laws and other reactionary measures that kept the status quo as is. The most notable shift in the modern history of the Democratic Party happened during the 1960s, when Southern Democrats – finding themselves at odds with Democratic President Lyndon B. Johnson – disagreed with many of the new civil rights acts being passed and joined the more conservative Republican Party.

2012 Presidential candidate: Barack Obama

&nbsp;
<h4>2. Republican Party (also known as Grand Old Party, or GOP)</h4>
Founded 1854

The Republican Party is the more conservative of the two major parties. At this point, Republicans tend to fit into one of two categories: libertarianism or Tea Party. Both groups believe in gun ownership and low taxes, but concerning social issues and religious issues there is a fairly large schism.

Do not confuse “conservative” with Republican. While there is often overlap, they are not synonymous.

The Republican Party has changed a lot since 1854. Abraham Lincoln was a Republican who believed in freeing the slaves and was considered progressive/liberal on social issues for that reason. Throughout the 20th century, Republicans became more conservative. By the 1960s, Republicans had cemented their ideology as the conservative party.

2012 Presidential candidate: Mitt Romney

&nbsp;
<h4>3. Libertarian Party</h4>
Founded 1971. The Libertarian Party is one of several third parties in the United States. Their beliefs are (obviously) strictly libertarian. Smallest possible government.

2012 Presidential candidate: Gary Johnson, the governor of New Mexico 1995-2003.

&nbsp;
<h4>4. Green Party</h4>
Founded in 2001. The Green Party is very progressive/liberal. Their major issues focus on environmentalism, social justice, nonviolence, and civil rights. One big concern of the Green Party is the rising costs of college tuition.

2012 Presidential candidate: Dr. Jill Stein, who helped found the Massachusetts Coalition for Healthy Communities.

&nbsp;
<h4>5. Cyber Party</h4>
Founded in 2015. Founded by Presidential candidate John McAfee, the Cyber Party focuses on internet privacy, internet freedom, and internet security. I’m adding this because John McAfee is quite possibly even more batshit insane than Donald Trump (sorry, my bias is showing) and reading about him is a fun way to waste thirty minutes. He might be the only Central American fugitive who actively admits to having had multiple sexual partners at the same time and doing a ton of drugs to ever run for President of the United States. He is not allowed back in Belize. Or Guatemala.

2012 Presidential candidate: none, did not exist yet

&nbsp;
<h3>Presidential Candidates</h3>
(For the sake of brevity, I am only including candidates who have an actual shot of getting their party’s nominations. Our sincerest apologies to Dr. Ben Carson.)

&nbsp;
<h4>Democrats</h4>
<strong>Hillary Clinton</strong> – moderate on most issues, interventionist in foreign policy, moderate on most social issues

Claim to fame: former First Lady, former Senator from New York, former Secretary of State

<strong>Bernie Sanders</strong> – democratic socialist, focuses on economic inequality and social justice issues

Claim to fame: Senator from Vermont, has been fighting income inequality and social injustices consistently throughout career, looks and sounds like Larry David

&nbsp;

[caption id="attachment_3162" align="aligncenter" width="634"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image05.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3162"><img class="wp-image-3162 size-full" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/image05.jpg" alt="This is a still from a &quot;Saturday Night Live&quot; sketch with Larry David and Kate McKinnon as Sanders and Clinton. " width="634" height="342" /></a> This is a still from a "Saturday Night Live" sketch with Larry David and Kate McKinnon as Sanders and Clinton.[/caption]
<h4></h4>
&nbsp;
<h4>Republicans</h4>
<strong>Ted Cruz</strong> – extremely conservative on most issues, appeals to the Tea Party and religious, fundamental Republicans; fairly conservative on immigration issues (but less so than Donald Trump – Cruz does not support wholesale deportation)

Claim to fame: senator from Texas, leading the shutdown of the government in his fight against the Affordable Care Act

<strong>John Kasich </strong>– economically conservative, moderate on health care (supports Medicaid but is opposed to single payer plan), would defund Planned Parenthood, moderate on immigration, opposed to sending ground troops abroad but also wants to lead fight to defeat ISIS

Claim to fame: current governor of Ohio, former Chairman of the House Budget Committee

<strong>Marco Rubio</strong> – economically conservative, supports attacking ISIS and Syria in the Middle East (pro-intervention), but fairly moderate-to-conservative on immigration

Claim to fame: senator from Florida, son of Cuban immigrants, part of the “Gang of Eight,” which was a group of politicians aiming to reach across the aisle for the sake of immigration reform

<strong>Donald Trump</strong> – hates everyone, spouts falsehoods, refuses to be corrected

Claim to fame – pretending to be good at business, inheriting

[caption id="attachment_3199" align="aligncenter" width="360"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/republicans.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3199"><img class="wp-image-3199" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/republicans-300x169.jpg" alt="republicans" width="360" height="203" /></a> John Kasich, Jeb Bush, Ted Cruz, Donald Trump, Marco Rubio and Ben Carson at a GOP Debate in South Carolina.[/caption]

&nbsp;
<div class="mceTemp"></div>
<h4>Green Party</h4>
<strong>Dr. Jill Stein</strong> – very progressive on all issues, anti-interventionist, believes in free college tuition

Claim to fame: ran for President in 2012, American physician

&nbsp;
<h4>Libertarian Party</h4>
<strong>Gary Johnson</strong> – very libertarian, believes in legalization of drugs, anti-gun regulations, wants lower taxes, smallest possible government

Claim to fame: former governor of New Mexico, prominent businessman

&nbsp;
<h3>Presidential election process</h3>
<h4>1. Primaries</h4>
Each state’s political party holds elections in early 2016 to nominate a candidate. For third parties, the candidate is usually set early on. For example, Dr. Jill Stein and Gary Johnson are already set to be the Green Party’s and the Libertarian Party’s respective candidates.

&nbsp;
<h4>2. Announcement of Vice Presidential running mate</h4>
This typically happens in the summer.

&nbsp;
<h4>3. Presidential election</h4>
This happens on the first Tuesday of November. Other issues, such as Congressional elections and state propositions, also come up on the November ballot.

<hr />

Again, this is a <em>very</em> brief overview. To figure out the pros and cons of libertarianism versus democratic socialism, be sure to read what the respected pundits of each school of thought have to say and draw your own conclusion from there!

&nbsp;

If you want to figure out which Presidential candidate you agree with the most, take <a href="https://www.isidewith.com/">this</a> quiz. It’s fun <em>and</em> informative! Hurray!
If you just want a quick answer on what each candidate believes, go <a href="http://www.ontheissues.org/default.htm">here</a>.

&nbsp;

And of course, you have to get out and vote! To register, go to <a href="https://www.usa.gov/register-to-vote">this site</a>. Primaries have already started. Make sure you’re ready to get out there and do your civic duty!

&nbsp;

&nbsp;
<blockquote><em>All articles featured on TWIGG How-To are the sole opinion of the contributor. Read the full Terms &amp; Conditions <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/terms-and-conditions/">here</a>.</em></blockquote>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Make a Space Feel Like a Home</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/make-space-feel-like-home/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 04 Mar 2016 01:43:01 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[chloe-taylor]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=3192</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[There truly is no place like home. Because we love our homes so much, we are constantly trying to make them even more beautiful. Sadly, those endeavors sometimes go way beyond the boundaries or our humble budgets. Does that mean we have to give up? Not a chance! There are some DIY projects that are really affordable and that can be done in no time. If you are trying to make your first apartment feel like home or just trying to spruce up a place you've had for years but you are getting lost in the millions of search results Google gives you for typing "DIY," don't worry! We have made a list of some of the best and simplest projects you can try as soon as today.

&nbsp;

[caption id="attachment_3240" align="aligncenter" width="300"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/sidebyside.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3240"><img class="wp-image-3240 size-medium" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/sidebyside-300x212.jpg" alt="sidebyside" width="300" height="212" /></a> <em>www.littlehousedesign.com</em>[/caption]
<h4 style="text-align: center;">Walls from Around the Globe</h4>
Today, when we are traveling we keep our memories in the form of digital files. In the past, people were sending postcards from all around the world to make their journey unforgettable. And truly, those postcards were somewhat like small pieces of art. Check your attic to see if a family member has saved some old travel memos. Not only they will look amazing on the wall, but they can also carry a real emotional value. If, however, you cannot find some from your family, you can visit a local flea market and buy them for a bargain. When you have collected enough you can frame them or hang them on the wall to create a <a href="http://espressomoments.dk/look-at-the-details/">unique vintage aura.</a>

&nbsp;

[caption id="attachment_3241" align="aligncenter" width="300"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Easy-wall-art-for-living-room.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3241"><img class="wp-image-3241 size-medium" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Easy-wall-art-for-living-room-300x225.jpg" alt="Easy-wall-art-for-living-room" width="300" height="225" /></a> <em>www.diyhomedecorguide.com</em>[/caption]
<h4 style="text-align: center;">Nailing the Strings</h4>
If you are short on time, and want to make something that will really stand out, you do not need anything more than an empty frame or piece of wood, nails or pins and a string. Use the frame or wood as a canvas into which you will stick pins or nails so they form a certain shape. It can be anything, from a tree to Batman’s sign. After, take a thread of string, tie it around one nail and braid around the others. You can even choose to combine different color strings to create a more vivid focal point.

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/breakfast-923928_1920.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3236"><img class="size-medium wp-image-3236 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/breakfast-923928_1920-300x225.jpg" alt="breakfast-923928_1920" width="300" height="225" /></a>
<h4 style="text-align: center;">Coffee, Please</h4>
Coffee tables are the real unsung heroes of every living room. We often do not give too much thought to their design, but they do attract plenty of attention by being in the middle of the room and in plain sight. So ditch your old coffee table and opt for a DIY project that will amaze your guests. All you need are two clone sizes of pallets with small wooden supports in between (which will connect those pallets and create some space between them) and wooden legs or wheels. After, you can personalize it by painting it in different colors or even try out your decoupage skills. A coffee table area would not be complete without a rug, so try to acquire some <a href="https://missamara.com.au/">affordable yet stylish rug</a> to go with the whole look.

&nbsp;

[caption id="attachment_3238" align="aligncenter" width="300"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/IMG_9505.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3238"><img class="wp-image-3238 size-medium" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/IMG_9505-300x200.jpg" alt="IMG_9505" width="300" height="200" /></a> <em>www.dishylamps.com</em>[/caption]
<h4 style="text-align: center;">Let There Be (Colander) Light</h4>
Moving on to the kitchen, you can add a little warmth with plain old colanders you probably keep somewhere in your pantry. Yes, this handy little items work pretty well as <a href="http://www.homeheartcraft.com/blog/kitchen-sneak-peek-vintage-tin-ceiling">pendant lamps</a>. Just drill a hole in the center of the colander’s bottom or simply enlarge the already existing hole. You will also need a hanging pendant (a cable with a bulb socket) you can buy at any Home Depot. Put it through the hole in the colander and insert the bulb. You can even paint a few colanders in different colors to create a fun and inviting atmosphere.

&nbsp;

[caption id="attachment_3239" align="aligncenter" width="300"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/living-room-furniture-white-oak-wood-display-ladder-shelf-with-laptop-desk-decor-with-gray-painted-wall-and-wooden-chair-ladder-shelf-computer-desk.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3239"><img class="wp-image-3239 size-medium" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/living-room-furniture-white-oak-wood-display-ladder-shelf-with-laptop-desk-decor-with-gray-painted-wall-and-wooden-chair-ladder-shelf-computer-desk-300x214.jpg" alt="living-room-furniture-white-oak-wood-display-ladder-shelf-with-laptop-desk-decor-with-gray-painted-wall-and-wooden-chair-ladder-shelf-computer-desk" width="300" height="214" /></a> <em>www.nathandecor.com</em>[/caption]
<h4 style="text-align: center;">Ladder Makeover</h4>
Do not throw away the old ladder you keep in your attic. You would not believe how they can completely elevate the look of your living room or even your hallway. For this project, you will need a ladder, a few planks, and, if you wish, some paint. Depending of your overall décor, you can leave the ladder as it is for a rustic appeal or paint it in some pastel or even a bright color. Open the ladder and arrange planks (chose the size you prefer, there are no rules) on the steps. If there is a need attach them with wood glue. You can use this shelving as a bookshelf, shoe shelf, or even a place to keep your houseplants.

&nbsp;

Few things are as satisfying as a successful DIY project. Luckily, all of the above are so simple, that we are sure you will pull them off easily, while having some great time. Now, roll up your sleeves, get to work, and soon enough you will be bragging to your friends about the beautiful works of art you have made.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Sign the Alphabet</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-sign-the-alphabet/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 26 Feb 2016 08:53:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[twigg2014]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=3212</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[TWIGG How-To is hosting our first American Sign Language workshop on Saturday, February 27. RSVP <a href="https://www.facebook.com/events/1696231360646557/">here</a>!

&nbsp;

TWIGG How-To was very excited to collaborate with Leslie Stratton, an Angeleno who is passionate about ASL and enjoys sharing it with others! The first step to learning any language is to master the alphabet, so we had Leslie break down each sign for you so you can practice along right at home!

<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/TlQ63afpkqg" width="420" height="315" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe>]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Drive in the Snow</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/3218-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 29 Feb 2016 16:51:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[theresa-ohalloran]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=3218</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA["<em>Drive really slow and don’t trust anyone</em>." This is what my roommate told me as I was walking out the door and about to drive in the snow for the first time. I was a 22-year-old southern California native and I was living in Colorado with my Ford Focus.

During the last several years, I have continued to attempt to drive my little two-wheel drive vehicle on Colorado’s snowy roads and I have not always been successful. I have gotten stuck on the interstate, and even in my own driveway. On the bright side, I think I have learned a few things and now I'm here to share them with you!

<hr />

&nbsp;
<h4>Preparing To Drive</h4>
Here are a few simple things that you should always ask yourself before you even start your car.

&nbsp;
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><strong>Are the roads open?</strong> I saw a sign last week that said, “I-70 closed from Limon to Kansas.” That is 90 miles of highway!</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><strong>Are there any local restrictions or state laws concerning traveling in the snow?</strong> For example, there is the <a href="https://www.codot.gov/travel/winter-driving/TractionLaw">Passenger Vehicle Traction Law</a> in Colorado. The Colorado Department of Transportation can activate these laws when the roads are snowy and passenger vehicles are required to have snow-tires, snow/mud tires, an all-wheel/four-wheel drive vehicle, or chains.</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><strong>Do you have enough gas to get to your destination?</strong> Because how embarrassing would it be if you ran out of gas in a snowstorm while trying to pick up some groceries.</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><strong>Do you have effective windshield wipers and antifreeze windshield wiper fluid?</strong> Visibility will already be enough of a challenge.</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><strong>How does the tread on your tires look? Are they bald? Are they all weather tires or snow tires?</strong> I might argue that the condition of your tires is more important than whether or not you have all-wheel/four wheel drive. All-wheel/four-wheel drive provides additional traction when moving forward, but <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9iP8SS9vQaU">snow tires</a> give you the tread and traction needed to slow down and brake.</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><strong>Where is your snow scraper?!</strong> Snow scrapers cost about two dollars and are just the handiest thing for scraping the snow and ice off of your car.</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/winter_car_kit.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3223"><img class="size-medium wp-image-3223 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/winter_car_kit-300x201.jpg" alt="winter_car_kit" width="300" height="201" /></a>

You also might want to consider a winter travel kit if you regularly drive in the snow. This can include a shovel, gloves, chains, extra water, and a overnight bag (in case you have to stay at a friend’s house). Items for a more serious winter survival kit can be found <a href="http://readywisconsin.wi.gov/winter/HowToMakeAKit.asp">here</a>.

&nbsp;
<h4>Behind The Wheel</h4>
Take your time and DRIVE <strong>SLOWLY</strong>. Accelerate and decelerate<strong> slowly</strong>, change lanes <strong>slowly</strong>, and make turns <strong>slowly</strong>. Sudden, jerky movements might cause you to lose control of your car and make you slide in an unwanted direction, so it is important to plan ahead and execute any driving maneuvers smoothly and slowly.

&nbsp;

Keep your momentum in the snow! Try not to stop when you are going uphill. This is especially important if you are in a two wheel drive vehicle. Even with snow tires, my car needs to be going at least 20 miles per hour when going up a hill. If I am driving through the mountains on a busy weekend, I will wait until there no traffic or until there is less snow on the road. If there is traffic while I am driving up a snowy mountain pass and my car comes to a come complete stop, there is a good chance I will get stuck. Know what your car can handle, and if doubt, keep chains in the trunk of your car..

&nbsp;

[caption id="attachment_3224" align="aligncenter" width="308"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/drivesnow.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3224"><img class="wp-image-3224 " src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/drivesnow-300x188.jpg" alt="drivesnow" width="308" height="193" /></a> <em>from waysandsteps.com</em>[/caption]

I am a little serious about not trusting other drivers. They might be inexperienced or reckless driving in the snow, or they might have inadequate tires. Whatever the case, it is possible for any driver to lose control of their vehicle (including yourself). Leave a lot of space between you and other drivers and remember to brake early and slowly. Also, if you are stopped at the stop sign or traffic light, make sure all other vehicles are stopped (and not sliding into traffic) before you enter the intersection. When changing lanes, turn on your signal and wait until it is safe before pulling in front or behind another vehicle.

&nbsp;
<h4>What To Do If:</h4>
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><strong>You start sliding or skidding…</strong> Ease your foot off the gas and <a href="http://dbulli.com/content/images/2014/12/85.gif">turn the wheels in the direction of the skid.</a> Try not to overcorrect or you will continue to fishtail. To understand this better, I’d recommend driving around an empty snowy parking lot.</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><strong>You are approaching an intersection and the light turn yellow…</strong> Decide whether or not your car will be able to come to a complete stop. If you can, then stop. If not, keep going. If there is a car in front of you, and you can’t stop, change lanes if possible.</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><strong>You are approaching a stop sign or a red light at an intersection and you try to brake but your car is not coming to a complete stop….</strong> Continue to brake, lay on the horn, flash your brights, basically do anything to bring attention to yourself, and try your best to avoid cars (but especially pedestrians).</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;
<ul>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"></li>
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><strong>You are stuck…</strong> Stay inside your car and turn on your emergency blinkers. You can keep your car running to stay warm, but remember to crack some windows open so you don’t get carbon monoxide poisoning. If possible, try to maneuver your car to the shoulder. (This was slightly nuts but once I could not drive forward because I was facing uphill, but I waited until there was no traffic and then drove in reverse across three lanes on the interstate,  so that I could move my car into the shoulder.)</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/picjumbo.com_HNCK8444.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3225"><img class="size-medium wp-image-3225 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/picjumbo.com_HNCK8444-300x200.jpg" alt="picjumbo.com_HNCK8444" width="300" height="200" /></a>
<h4>Be Calm And Carry On</h4>
Driving in the snow can be stressful! If possible, try to plan your route in order to avoid heavy traffic. Depart for your destination early, so you don’t feel rushed. Listen to a good podcast or audiobook to take your mind off the stress. And remember, you can always just stay home and drink a hot toddy.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>3218</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2016-02-29 16:51:00]]></wp:post_date>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Start a 401(k) With Your Employer</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-start-a-401k-with-your-employer/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 07 Mar 2016 01:48:53 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[krisha-agatep]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=3243</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[As young people, our biggest advantage is having time on our side. Which also means having more time to save for retirement and more time for our money to grow through <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-understand-compound-interest/">compound interest</a>. Basically, your money makes money without you really having to do all that much. Sounds pretty sweet, right? Sure you won’t see this money for the next 40 or so years. But chances are you won’t even notice that money’s missing. Setting aside just a little bit of cash every month now will save you a lot more grief in the future. Though there are several kinds of retirement savings accounts (i.e. IRA and Roth IRA) in this article, we’re just focusing on a 401(k) offered through your employer.

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/giphy-1.gif" rel="attachment wp-att-3249"><img class="size-medium wp-image-3249 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/giphy-1-300x163.gif" alt="giphy (1)" width="300" height="163" /></a>
<h3>What is a 401(k)?</h3>
A 401(k) is a savings plan set up through your employer that allows you to invest a portion of your monthly paycheck, tax-free until retirement.

&nbsp;
<h3>How to start one?</h3>
In some workplaces, your employer may set up some sort of orientation that helps you learn exactly what a 401(k) is and walk you through how to set up your account. If they don’t, then you’ll need to reach out to your HR representative to obtain the proper paperwork to set up your account.

&nbsp;
<h3>How much should I contribute?</h3>
First you have to determine if your employer matches the funds. An employer matching program typically means your employer will match dollar for dollar the contribution you make to your 401(k) as long as you contribute at least a certain percentage of your paycheck. The typical matching percentage is around 3-6% of your yearly salary. It’s also important to know if your employer has a “vesting period.” This means you must work at the company for a certain amount of time in order to receive their matched contribution (your contributions are vested immediately). Just because your company has a vesting period doesn’t mean you shouldn’t take advantage of their matching plan, however. Choosing not to participate in the employer matching program is basically like giving away free (untaxed) money. Should you choose to contribute more than that every month is up to you. Everyone’s financial situation is different. Check out our article on <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-create-a-monthly-budget/">How To: Create a Monthly Budget</a> to determine how much you’re willing to save each month and go from there.

&nbsp;

Not sure how much money you should have when you retire? Try one of these <a href="http://www.bankrate.com/calculators/retirement/retirement-calculator.aspx">401(k) calculators</a>.

&nbsp;
<h3>Where does my money go?</h3>
When you contribute money to your 401(k) it doesn’t just sit in a bank account somewhere waiting to be taken out. Most 401(k) plans offer a spread of mutual funds composed of stocks, bonds, and money market investments. Your HR representative will typically point out their suggested plan for where your money gets invested.

&nbsp;
<h3>Can I take out this money any time I want?</h3>
Technically yes, but you shouldn’t – at least until you’re 59 1/2. Doing so would be considered an early withdrawal by the IRS and is subject to a 10 percent penalty on top of regular income taxes. So just let the 401(k) do it’s thing and don’t even think about touching it unless you absolutely have to!

<hr />

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/A-Resource-on-Cash-Loans.png" rel="attachment wp-att-3252"><img class="size-full wp-image-3252 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/A-Resource-on-Cash-Loans.png" alt="A-Resource-on-Cash-Loans" width="250" height="168" /></a>

And there you have it! Just think of your 401(k) as a retirement gift to yourself that you also just so happened to fund for the past 40 years. Your 65-year-old self will be very glad you did.

Any questions about starting your 401(k) or other tips for financial planning? Ask away in the comments below!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Get Rid of Mosquito Bites</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/get-rid-mosquito-bites/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 14 Mar 2016 16:26:11 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[MJ@twigghowto.com]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=3271</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[If you happen to be someone who’s extremely prone to mosquito bites, I feel your pain. There’s the teasing when you’re caught manically applying repellent every hour, on the hour… or when you refuse to leave the house for anything less serious than a fire during summer nights. You get the skeptical “Is it <i>really</i> that bad?” from a family member who just doesn’t seem to be as bothered by their bites as you are. And of course, you deal with the anticipation of that burning itch that you <i>shouldn’t</i> scratch (but do anyway). Every. Single. Summer.

&nbsp;

Before we dive into how to take care of mosquito bites, it’s good to know what makes them  swell and itch in the first place. When mosquitoes bite, they release anticoagulants - which keep your blood from clotting - into your skin through their saliva. These anticoagulants can affect people differently, but for many people, they trigger mild allergic reactions in the form of redness, swelling, and that awful itchiness.  For some, the allergic reaction isn’t so mild; I myself have had bumps painfully swell to tumor-like proportions. Others may experience hives or more serious reactions, like <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anaphylaxis">anaphylaxis</a>. Studies also show that some people <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/why-some-people-are-more-prone-to-mosquito-bites-than-others/2013/07/22/0d46035c-ee34-11e2-a1f9-ea873b7e0424_story.html">really are more attractive to mosquitoes than others</a>. If you’re one of those people, you could be out with a group of buddies one night and be the only one to come home with multiple sores. Yikes.

&nbsp;

Since the itchiness of a mosquito bite is more or less an allergic reaction, the number one thing you can do to help minimize the effects is take an antihistamine. You may be used to antihistamines like Benadryl, Zyrtec, or Claritin in pill-form, but they can be found in topical creams and sprays as well. Try <a href="http://www.target.com/p/benadryl-extra-strength-anti-itch-cream-1-oz/-/A-14463627?ci_src=17588969&amp;ci_sku=14463627&amp;ref=tgt_adv_XS000000&amp;AFID=google_pla_df&amp;CPNG=PLA_Health%2BBeauty%2BShopping&amp;adgroup=SC_Health%2BBeauty&amp;LID=700000001170770pgs&amp;network=g&amp;device=c&amp;location=9061093&amp;gclid=Cj0KEQiAj8uyBRDawI3XhYqOy4gBEiQAl8BJbWiIY4-M13VKdRjBmAwhGZFjKGD9U1LN6Seht55C5RQaAiEF8P8HAQ&amp;gclsrc=aw.ds">Benadryl Extra Strength Anti-Itch Cream</a> or spray, which can work wonders. Swallowing a pill or two the good ol’ fashioned way will probably work just as well, so do whichever makes you most comfortable.

&nbsp;

Want to go with a route that’s natural, cheap, or both? You can try applying the following directly to the bite:

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/teabag-549799_1280.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3272"><img class=" wp-image-3272 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/teabag-549799_1280-275x300.jpg" alt="teabag-549799_1280" width="215" height="235" /></a>
<ul style="list-style-type: circle;">
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><strong>A cold tea bag.</strong> Tea contain compounds, including caffeine, that can really cut down on inflammation. Steep the bag in some cool water for maximum relief.</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/oatmeal-761434_1280.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3273"><img class=" wp-image-3273 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/oatmeal-761434_1280-300x225.jpg" alt="oatmeal-761434_1280" width="248" height="186" /></a>
<ul style="list-style-type: circle;">
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><strong>Cool oatmeal</strong> mixed with just enough water to make a paste. <a href="http://www.dermnetnz.org/treatments/oatmeal.html">Avenanthramides</a> in oatmeal have anti-inflammatory effects (shoutout to all the other kids who took oatmeal baths when they came down with chickenpox). To get the best results with oatmeal, <a href="http://www.dermnetnz.org/treatments/oatmeal.html">use a finely ground form</a> (or throw it in the food processor yourself) before adding water. Bonus: oatmeal is really, really good for dry skin, so don’t be surprised if you find yourself using it even after the itching stops.</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/aloe-vera-918662_1280.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3274"><img class=" wp-image-3274 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/aloe-vera-918662_1280-300x200.jpg" alt="aloe-vera-918662_1280" width="263" height="175" /></a>
<ul style="list-style-type: circle;">
	<li style="font-weight: 400;"><strong>Aloe vera,</strong> a succulent that’s pretty well-known for the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aloe_vera">soothing gel</a> stored in its leaves. Aloe vera plants are pretty cheap and easy to find, at least on the West Coast: <a href="http://www.homedepot.com/p/Delray-Plants-Aloe-Vera-in-4-in-Pot-90408/202676728?cm_mmc=Shopping%7cTHD%7cG%7c0%7cG-BASE-PLA-D28O-OutdoorGarden%7c&amp;gclid=Cj0KEQiAj8uyBRDawI3XhYqOy4gBEiQAl8BJbXyXHeiCBbG09jQr3Z52hjL9rL6lsYGU38x2ipRSHSAaAo6O8P8HAQ&amp;gclsrc=aw.ds">Home Depot</a> sells them for around $10. And if you’re not ready to commit to adding a new member to your household, you can always buy the gel ready-made at stores like Whole Foods, Target, and some drug and beauty supply stores.</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;

If mosquitos have already made you their victim this year, hopefully these tips can help you get your skin back in check. And please remember to pick up some insect repellent or some long-sleeved clothing for the next time you go out. The only thing better than a bad bite clearing up is not getting bites at all!
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Or just move to Los Angeles, where I haven’t seen a mosquito in years. </span>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Take Something Hot Out of the Oven</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/take-something-hot-oven/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 19 Mar 2016 03:10:33 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[CAITLYN]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=3277</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_3289" align="aligncenter" width="249"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/oven.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3289"><img class="wp-image-3289 size-medium" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/oven-249x300.jpg" alt="oven" width="249" height="300" /></a> Oil painting of me at 12 extracting food from the oven in my suburban home.[/caption]

I remember the first time I ever was put in charge of taking dinner out of the oven. I was in elementary school and I. was. terrified. I opened those oven doors and all I saw was a raging inferno with flames dancing around the casserole dish just waiting to melt my skin off.

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Animated_fire_by_nevit1.gif" rel="attachment wp-att-3278"><img class=" wp-image-3278 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Animated_fire_by_nevit1-300x169.gif" alt="Animated_fire_by_nevit[1]" width="360" height="203" /></a>

&nbsp;
<h4 style="text-align: center;"><strong>Never mind that it was an electronic oven...
And there were no flames within a 100 foot radius...</strong></h4>
With time, I became more comfortable with taking hot dishes and food out of the oven - but I remember it was only after getting reassurance and asking my mom over and over how to do it. For anyone new to the kitchen, being afraid of burning yourself is NATURAL. However, when we really get down to it, you don't want to go the rest of your life avoiding oven foods right? I mean what kind of life is that?

&nbsp;

<strong>No muffins - pot pie - pizza - cookies?!</strong>

&nbsp;

I didn't think so. Without any further ado, here is my piping hot '<em>How To: Take Something Hot Out of The Oven'</em>:

<hr />

&nbsp;
<blockquote><em>Setting the scene:</em>    <span style="color: #33cccc;"><strong>**Beep Beep** </strong></span></blockquote>
&nbsp;

The oven has sounded the alarm and your food is done. Before doing anything, I would suggest turning off the oven (unless you will be cooking more dishes). There are countless times where I have taken something out of the oven and forgotten to turn it off for hours. Therefore, I would say - turn it off first so you don't have to worry about it later and can just dig into your yummy food once you're done taking it out. Plus, this may help lower the temperature just bit when you go in for the extraction. (The tiniest bit, but anything helps, yeah?)

&nbsp;

1. If it's a casserole dish or pan that you need to take out, use an insulated oven mitt / pot holder. For beginner cooks, I would suggest the oven mitt since it protects your entire hand and a bit of your forearm:

[caption id="attachment_3281" align="aligncenter" width="201"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/image01.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3281"><img class="wp-image-3281 size-medium" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/image01-201x300.jpg" alt="image01" width="201" height="300" /></a> Oven mitts to keep your hands from howlin'.[/caption]

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

[caption id="attachment_3280" align="aligncenter" width="300"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/image00.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3280"><img class="wp-image-3280 size-full" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/image00.jpg" alt="image00" width="300" height="300" /></a> Pot holders are groovy too![/caption]

&nbsp;

2. If the food is directly cooking on the rack, use a spatula to lift it off the rack and place on a pan. Make sure to <strong>bring the pan with you when you first open the oven</strong> so you don't have to balance the food on the spatula across the kitchen to the counter. (I've lost a Tostino's pizza or two due to this mistake. RIP beautiful pepperoni souls).

&nbsp;

*Bonus tip - Once you take hot pans out of the oven, make sure you place them on a heat resistant surface. NOT all countertops are heat resistant and can crack /  break if a hot pan is placed on it. If you're nervous about your countertops, the easiest place to set down the pan is on your stove top!
<h4 style="text-align: center;">Don't be self conscious if opening the oven and handling business intimidates you at first, that's totally natural! Practice makes perfect.
<strong>You got this girl.</strong></h4>]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_wp_rp_related_posts_query_result_cache_expiration]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1460950029]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_wp_rp_related_posts_query_result_cache_5]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:10:{i:0;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1066";s:5:"score";s:18:"24.956671890882554";}i:1;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2871";s:5:"score";s:17:"21.65935463967942";}i:2;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2600";s:5:"score";s:17:"21.08399049477586";}i:3;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1987";s:5:"score";s:17:"19.40923222910766";}i:4;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2382";s:5:"score";s:18:"19.088958151210747";}i:5;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1775";s:5:"score";s:18:"17.184901719089694";}i:6;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"136";s:5:"score";s:18:"16.583432214134906";}i:7;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2431";s:5:"score";s:18:"13.959059436259304";}i:8;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2209";s:5:"score";s:18:"13.959059436259304";}i:9;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"644";s:5:"score";s:18:"13.959059436259304";}}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Treat a Bee Sting</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/treat-bee-sting/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 25 Mar 2016 08:27:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[maria-zhou]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=3311</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/daisies-558501_1280.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3334"><img class="size-medium wp-image-3334 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/daisies-558501_1280-300x201.jpg" alt="How To- Treat a Bee Sting" width="300" height="201" /></a>

Growing up, I was always warned by teachers and other adults to stay away from bees. While most children learn to fear them, I just ignored their existence.. Despite my fearlessness as a kid, I have been stung once while walking barefoot in my backyard. Even that didn’t make me hate bees; I think that it’s important to remember that bees are essential to our environment and not only produce honey, but also help pollinate many of our crops. They are our best frenemies and must be dealt with carefully.

&nbsp;
<h4>General Tips For Entering Areas with Heavy Bee Traffic</h4>
The <a href="http://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/insects/">Centers for Disease Control</a> (CDC) recommends these steps to avoid attracting bees:

<span style="font-size: 14px;">     <span style="font-size: 16px;"> • Wear light-colored clothing.</span></span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;">      • Avoid heavily perfumed products... especially banana scented.</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;">      • Bathe daily. Sweat may anger bees (and other people around you).</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;">      • Wear long clothes to cover up.</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;">      • Avoid plants with flowers.</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;">      • If they are around you, remain calm and still. DON’T SWAT AT THEM!</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;">      • If you are attacked by a group of them..run away!</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;">      • Don’t jump into water. they will wait for you.</span>

<span style="font-size: 16px;">      • Go inside or find a shaded place.</span>

&nbsp;

However, even if you follow those tips, you might still get stung. Don’t worry! We have steps for that as well.

&nbsp;
<h4>So you followed those tips and STILL got stung...</h4>
If the bee sting is only affecting the area of the sting and not causing an allergic reaction:
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">•  Remove the stinger. Try to use a straight edge, like a credit card, to push it out. Tweezers will pinch it and may release more venom.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">• Ice the affected area, take off any jewelry in anticipation of possible swelling, and elevate the sting if you were stung on an extremity.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">• For pain, Tylenol (acetaminophen) or Advil (ibuprofen) may help. Remember to read the label and follow all directions.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">• For itch, you can try taking an allergy medication like Benadryl (diphenhydramine), using calamine lotion, or putting a paste of baking soda and water over it.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">• Keep the area clean to prevent it from getting infected-it should heal in a few days.</p>
&nbsp;
<h4>Allergic Reactions</h4>
It is important to CALL 911 if someone is having an allergic reaction!

Some signs of allergic reactions are:
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">• Trouble breathing
• Feelings of faintness or dizziness
• Hives
• A swollen tongue
• Nausea, vomiting</p>
People who are severely allergic to bees may carry EpiPens, a prescription medical device containing a single dose of epinephrine. Epinephrine is an emergency treatment for life-threatening allergic reactions (also known as anaphylaxis). EpiPens should be injected in the outer upper thigh, through clothing if necessary. State laws vary on bystanders assisting someone with their EpiPen if they are unable to do so themselves. However, without an immediate epinephrine injection, people can die within minutes. After injection, the patient requires immediate medical attention. Read through this <a href="http://www.webmd.com/first-aid/allergy-insect-sting-treatment">WebMD</a> article for detailed instructions.

As long as you follow these steps you should be fine. Always contact a medical professional if anything seems to be getting worse instead of better.

&nbsp;

Let's hope that one day we can all learn to live in peace with our busy bee friends!

More resources:
<a href="https://www.epipen.com/en/about-epipen/how-to-use-epipen">https://www.epipen.com/en/about-epipen/how-to-use-epipen</a>

<a href="http://www.medicinenet.com/bee_sting_treatment-page2/views.htm">http://www.medicinenet.com/bee_sting_treatment-page2/views.htm</a>

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

Remember to vote for "This Part of Me" here: <a href="http://bit.ly/1SetC7p">http://bit.ly/1SetC7p</a> every day until April 3rd!

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

We were asked to define what feminism means to us, and this is our answer.

Watch our submission at the below link, and please <strong><a href="http://bit.ly/1SetC7p">vote</a></strong> every day until the contest closes on April 3rd, 2016 to help us win a feature on She Knows Media's website and a trip to the screening in New York City! Vote here:

	<item>
		<title>How To: Reduce Your Food Waste</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/reduce-food-waste/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 28 Mar 2016 08:05:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[jenna-perelman]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=3321</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Food waste is a huge problem in the United States. According to the United Nations Environmental Programme,<span style="color: #3366ff;"><a style="color: #3366ff;" href="http://www.unep.org/wed/2013/quickfacts/"> thirty percent</a></span> of all food in the US is thrown away. Our food waste is the second largest contributor to approximately , which is the largest contributor to methane gas, a major greenhouse gas. In August 2015, the always brilliant John Oliver did an <span style="color: #3366ff;"><a style="color: #3366ff;" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i8xwLWb0lLY">amazing exposé</a></span> on food waste focusing on waste within the food supply and industry. As a concerned consumer, what are some of the steps you can take to reduce food waste?

<hr />

&nbsp;
<h4 style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 16px;"><strong>Buy only the food you need.</strong> </span></h4>
<span style="font-size: 16px;">This one is simple. Don’t buy food you’re not going to eat! And commit to eating the food that you do buy. Get creative to use up those last few scallions or the rest of parsley. Try a new recipe or make a big salad or soup and throw it all in.</span>

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/refrigerator-359615_1280.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3341"><img class="size-medium wp-image-3341 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/refrigerator-359615_1280-300x300.jpg" alt="refrigerator-359615_1280" width="300" height="300" /></a>
<h4 style="text-align: center;"><strong style="font-size: 16px; line-height: 1.42857;">Keep your refrigerator organized.</strong></h4>
<span style="font-size: 16px; line-height: 1.42857;">Have you ever gotten home from the grocery store only to discover that already had a head of lettuce in your crisper? Keeping your fridge organized will help you see what you have before you go shopping.</span>

&nbsp;
<h4 style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 16px;"><strong>Make use of your freezer.</strong> </span></h4>
<span style="font-size: 16px;">I am a big proponent of batch cooking. I’ll make a big pot of beans and a grain on Sunday to eat throughout the week, but sometimes I don’t correctly gauge how much I’ll eat and they’re still sitting there on Thursday or Friday. To save them from going bad, I’ll put whatever is left in a freezer-safe container and then I’ll have already cooked food ready for weeks to come! Beans, grains, stews, soups, tortillas, and bread all freeze really well. If fruit is going bad, chop it up and stick it in your freezer for your next smoothie.</span>

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/box-592371_1280.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3342"><img class="size-medium wp-image-3342 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/box-592371_1280-300x225.jpg" alt="box-592371_1280" width="300" height="225" /></a>
<h4 style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 16px;"><strong>Take “use by,” “sell by,” and “best by” dates with a grain of salt.</strong> </span></h4>
<span style="font-size: 16px;">As John Oliver discusses in his segment, these labelled dates indicate peak freshness. Food doesn’t automatically go bad after those dates and oftentimes it is perfectly fine to eat. Your nose will really tell you when things have turned.</span>

&nbsp;
<h4 style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 16px;"><strong>Save vegetable scraps to make homemade vegetable broth.</strong> </span></h4>
<span style="font-size: 16px;">Keep a gallon-sized plastic bag in your freezer and fill it up with odds and ends of veggies – things like carrot tops, celery leaves, onion and garlic skins. When the bag is full, wash the scraps, put ‘em in a pot with 10 cups of water, a couple bay leaves and some spices, and let it simmer for an hour. In no time, you’ll have homemade vegetable broth! Avoid cruciferous veggies (broccoli, Brussels sprouts, kale etc.) as they make the broth bitter. This method is all over the internet, but <span style="color: #3366ff;"><a style="color: #3366ff;" href="http://www.veganrunnereats.com/616/how-to-make-vegetable-broth-at-home-the-easiest-and-cheapest-way/">here</a></span> are a <span style="color: #3366ff;"><a style="color: #3366ff;" href="https://happyherbivore.com/2013/03/minimalist-monday-make-vegetable-broth/">few</a> <a style="color: #3366ff;" href="http://ohmyveggies.com/how-to-make-vegetable-broth-with-kitchen-scraps/">links</a></span> to get you started.</span>

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/green-waste-513609_1280.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3343"><img class="size-medium wp-image-3343 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/green-waste-513609_1280-300x200.jpg" alt="green-waste-513609_1280" width="300" height="200" /></a>
<h4 style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 16px;"><strong>Compost.</strong> </span></h4>
<span style="font-size: 16px;">All plant-based foods, including paper tea bags and coffee grounds, can be composted and the rich, nutrient-dense fertilizer produced by composting can be used for your household plants or garden. This is where you can put all those cruciferous vegetables you left out of your freezer bag of scraps!  There are several different methods of composting (some even include worms!). Pick the method that works for you and check out this <span style="color: #3366ff;"><a style="color: #3366ff;" href="http://www.getcomposting.com/composting_guide.html">guide</a></span> to get you started.</span>

&nbsp;

Hope this helps you reduce food waste in your home! Do you have any other tips or tricks to reduce food waste? Let us know in the comments!]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<dc:creator><![CDATA[alexandraronco]]></dc:creator>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="text-align: center;">Stoves and microwaves and dishwashers! Oh my!</p>
<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/ginsburgconstruction-kitchen-3-330737_1280.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3392"><img class="size-medium wp-image-3392 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/ginsburgconstruction-kitchen-3-330737_1280-300x225.jpg" alt="How To: Buy Houseware" width="300" height="225" /></a>

&nbsp;

When it comes to shopping for home appliances, the process can be a bit treacherous. A fridge isn’t something you can just save the receipt and return if it doesn’t fit – at least not easily. So you want to be sure to get it right the first time! So put the Sears catalog down and take a step back.  Check out these steps for buying home appliances:

&nbsp;
<h3>1. Squad Goals!</h3>
Use your network. Talk to your mom, dad, best friend, the neighbor’s cousin’s mailman, WHOMEVER. Everyone uses appliances and, chances are, everyone has an opinion or two. Think you love your Aunt Vicky’s dishwasher? Take if for a test drive! I’m sure she won’t mind you doing her dishes.

Your friends and family are your best resources on this topic. Use them!

&nbsp;
<h3>2. Virtual Reality.</h3>
After asking people who you actually know, your friends on the Internet are the best resource for you! Hundreds of thousands of people have been disappointed by appliances, but you don’t have to be! Learn from their mistakes! Read reviews, watch videos, and ask questions on forums, which is the next best thing to actually seeing and using the appliance.

These two steps will help you get a much more realistic idea of what you need and what works best than just going to a showroom would.

&nbsp;
<h3>3. Be You.</h3>
If you mostly make ramen and hot pockets, a new stove isn’t going to turn you into Wolfgang Puck. Know what you actually need rather than just what you want. We get it – the oven has a touch screen and can walk your dog, but if the appliance doesn’t do what you need, then it is a waste. Especially if you don’t even have a dog. Make a list of what you need from the appliance, and that way, you can avoid the headache of impulse buying.

&nbsp;
<h3>4. Size Matters!</h3>
Sounds easy, but you’d be surprised how many people don’t realize this: the appliance needs to fit in your living space. Sure that shiny double washer/dryer with the attached steamer looked great on HGTV, but if it doesn’t fit in your apartment, then it won’t matter anyway. So measure, measure, and measure again! Carry that tape measure around like it’s an extra limb! And even then, just because it fits in the space doesn’t mean that it fits in the space. Make sure you can open all doors, cabinets, etc. without having to rearrange the furniture.

&nbsp;
<h3>5. The Perfect Fit.</h3>
Along with knowing yourself, know what you're bringing to the table. Does your dishware even fit in that microwave? Is there enough door space in the fridge to house your favorite juices? Make sure your new appliance fits in with what you already have.

&nbsp;
<h3>6. Money Matters!</h3>
Once you have decided on an appliance, do your price research. Many dealers will be willing to match a lower price or sometimes you can negotiate prices down if you’re buying more than one appliance. If nothing else, you can usually get away with some free delivery!

&nbsp;

So there you have it. It takes a village to buy an appliance, so tap into your resources! Know what <em>you</em> need out of the appliance, where you’re going to fit it, and how it’s going to fit in with your life, pots and pans, laundry loads, etc. Then and only then should you take that Sears catalog (along with three other catalogues from different stores to compare prices) and head in to buy that shiny new appliance!]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Fix a Flat Bike Tire</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/fix-flat-tire/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 04 Apr 2016 15:30:43 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[halle-zander]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=3384</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I got home one day covered in sticky, black bike grease. It was on my hands, my clothes, my forehead, my ears, my legs, and even my scalp. A lot of it was just smeared, but in some places you could see a detailed outline of a bike chain or the teeth of a cassette. My keys and the doorknob picked up some of it as I walked inside, leaving a noticeable trail. I was dirty, disheveled, sunburnt, sweaty, grimy, exhausted, and beaming with limitless pride. I knew it would take me a while to get over myself. This was not the first day I fixed a flat tire, but that was also a big milestone.

&nbsp;

For the past year and a half, I have been working as a part-time mechanic at a bike cooperative called “The Ontario Wheelhouse” in Southern California. At first, I didn’t know anything about fixing bikes. I just knew I liked to ride them. The veteran mechanics quickly threw me onto a project without any orientation or test-drive. I didn’t even know what a tube was.

&nbsp;

Over time, I started to pick up on a few things – one of which was the overwhelming realization that things can go terribly wrong when you are riding a bike. The most common risk you run is the potential of getting a flat tire. If you know how to fix it, you’ll be back on the road or on the trail in 15 minutes. If you don’t, you could get stranded waiting for AAA or a good samaritan.

&nbsp;

Here you’re going to get the insider scoop on how to fix a flat bike tire with all of my pro-tips.

&nbsp;
<h3>Step 1: Be Prepared</h3>
<ol style="list-style-type: lower-alpha;">
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">ALWAYS WEAR A HELMET! While this is unrelated to patching a tire, it is always relevant when talking about bikes. You will not be able to fix a flat if your head is split open.</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Remember to bring a few tools with you whenever you’re going on a bike ride--even if you’re just commuting to work. Flats can happen anywhere. Before you start riding, you will need:</span>
<ol>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">One CO<sub>2</sub> Cartridge OR one mini pump</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Two tire levers (sometimes one is OK too)</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Extra tube </span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Saddle Bag</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Optional: 15” Wrench (Check step 4 to see if your bike needs this tool)</span>
<span style="font-size: 16px;">***I also like to bring a few multi-tools, such as a set of Allen wrenches, a small flashlight, and a screwdriver. However, they are not necessary for this how-to***</span></li>
</ol>
</li>
</ol>
<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/step1-2.png" rel="attachment wp-att-3430"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-3430 size-large" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/step1-2-1024x222.png" alt="step1" width="1024" height="222" /></a>

&nbsp;
<h3>Step 2: Get a Flat</h3>
<ol style="list-style-type: lower-alpha;">
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Great tubes are not much use to us in this lesson, although they are highly valuable entities. </span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Understand the distinction between a tire, tube, rim, and wheel. The tube is thinner and lives inside the thicker tire.The rim is the metal frame where the tub</span>e and tire rest. The wheel is the entire tube, tire, and rim put together.</li>
</ol>
<h3> <a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/step2.png" rel="attachment wp-att-3421"><img class="alignright size-large wp-image-3421" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/step2-1024x269.png" alt="step2" width="1024" height="269" /></a></h3>
&nbsp;
<h3>Step 3: Assess the Flat</h3>
<ol style="list-style-type: lower-alpha;">
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Make sure that you are no longer in a lane of traffic, whether it is a trail or a road. Find a safe, flat space to look at your bike. </span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Turn your bike upside down. The bike should balance on the handlebars and the seat, and this makes it easier to take off the wheel. </span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Determine what caused the flat tire</span>
<ol>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">If you can see a culprit of the flat (i.e. a nail or a thorn), go ahead and pull it out. If you cannot see it, wait until you have taken apart the tire to go deep-sea diving for it.</span></li>
</ol>
</li>
</ol>
&nbsp;
<h3>Step 4: Take the Tire Off of your Bike (Front Wheel)</h3>
<ol style="list-style-type: lower-alpha;">
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Disengage your breaks. Depending on the type of brakes you have, this will look slightly different. Release the tension from the front brake cable so that the brakes will not impede you from taking the wheel off of the bike. You may need to look up the model of your brakes to learn how to do this.</span>
<ol>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">For V-brakes, push the brake arms together and pull the cable guide out of the cable bridge.<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/step4ai.png" rel="attachment wp-att-3411"><img class="size-full wp-image-3411 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/step4ai.png" alt="step4ai" width="246" height="231" /></a></span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">For Center-pull Cantilever brakes, push brake arms together and release the removable end of the cable from the brake arm. Yes, these brakes remind me of a vagina too.<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/4aii.png" rel="attachment wp-att-3398"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-3398" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/4aii.png" alt="4aii" width="244" height="207" /></a></span></li>
</ol>
</li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;"><span style="font-size: 16px;">If your front wheel has a quick release axle set, release the lever and unscrew it counter-clockwise until the wheel can easily slide out of the bike’s dropouts<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/Quickreleaseaxleset-e1459743381282.png" rel="attachment wp-att-3435"><img class="wp-image-3435 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/Quickreleaseaxleset-e1459743381282-300x240.png" alt="Quickreleaseaxleset" width="179" height="143" /></a><a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/Dropouts.png" rel="attachment wp-att-3434"><img class="wp-image-3434 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/Dropouts-300x251.png" alt="Dropouts" width="147" height="123" /></a></span></span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">If your front wheel has a bolt-on axle set, use a wrench (usually a 15” wrench) to unscrew one of the bolts until the wheel can easily slide out of the bike’s dropouts.</span></li>
</ol>
<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/Boltonaxleset-e1459743346241.png" rel="attachment wp-att-3436"><img class="wp-image-3436 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/Boltonaxleset-e1459743346241-300x287.png" alt="Boltonaxleset" width="146" height="139" /></a>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><span style="font-size: 16px;"> </span></p>

<h3>Step 5: Take the Tube Out of the Tire</h3>
<ol style="list-style-type: lower-alpha;">
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Make sure all the air has been released.</span>
<ol>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">If the tube has a presta valve, unscrew the valve tip slightly and press it inward until you no longer hear air coming out.<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/5ai.png" rel="attachment wp-att-3396"><img class="aligncenter size-thumbnail wp-image-3396" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/5ai-150x150.png" alt="5ai" width="150" height="150" /></a></span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">If the tube has a schrader valve, press the pin inward until you no longer hear air coming out.<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/5aii.png" rel="attachment wp-att-3399"><img class="aligncenter size-thumbnail wp-image-3399" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/5aii-150x150.png" alt="5aii" width="150" height="150" /></a></span></li>
</ol>
</li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Take the flat (not hook) end of one tire lever and place it in between the tire and the rim of the wheel. Press down on the lever so that the lip of the tire is now on the outside of the rim.</span>
<ol>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">This diagram shows where the tire lever goes and what the tire looks like after it has been engaged.<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/5bi.png" rel="attachment wp-att-3400"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-3400" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/5bi.png" alt="5bi" width="259" height="194" /></a></span></li>
</ol>
</li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Take the hook end of the tire lever and secure it around one of the spokes.</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Repeat step 5(b) with a second lever and move it in the opposite direction of the first tire lever along the rim so that one side of the tire is entirely off of the rim.</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">While paying attention to the valve, you can now pull the tire off of the rim and take the broken tube out of the tire</span></li>
</ol>
&nbsp;
<h3>Step 6: Replace Tube</h3>
<ol style="list-style-type: lower-alpha;">
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Before placing the tire back on the rim, run your fingers along the inside of the tire until you find the rascal that caused the flat. If you put a new tube in before doing this, you'll likely get another flat very soon. </span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Without the new tube, place one lip of the tire back inside of the rim, so that it looks like it did after step 5(d)</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Put the tube’s valve (presta or schrader) inside the hole of the rim<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/6c.png" rel="attachment wp-att-3401"><img class="aligncenter size-medium wp-image-3401" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/6c-300x225.png" alt="6c" width="300" height="225" /></a></span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Gently push the empty tube back inside of the tire.<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/6d.png" rel="attachment wp-att-3397"><img class="aligncenter size-medium wp-image-3397" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/6d-300x168.png" alt="6d" width="300" height="168" /></a></span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">As if the tire was a steering wheel, grip it with both hands at 11:30 and 12:30. Push the tire back so that the second lip of the tire returns to the inside of the rim. Move your hands away from each other and continue this motion until they meet again at the bottom of the wheel at 5:30 and 6:30.</span>
<ol>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">It will be most difficult to get the tire on the rim towards the bottom. Be patient.</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">If it feels impossible, check again to make sure all of the air is out of the tube.</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">If it still feels impossible, begin the process of moving the tire back and forth on the rim from the top. </span></li>
</ol>
</li>
</ol>
&nbsp;
<h3>Step 7: Place the wheel back onto the bike</h3>
<ol style="list-style-type: lower-alpha;">
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">This step is pretty self-explanatory. Return the axle of your wheel to the dropouts. Screw the quick release or the bolt clockwise so that the wheel is securely on the bike.</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Re-engage your brakes.</span></li>
</ol>
&nbsp;
<h3>Step 8: Re-inflate the tube</h3>
<ol style="list-style-type: lower-alpha;">
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Place the pump onto the valve and engage it so that the lever is parallel to the head of the pump.</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Pump until the tire is firm. There is no pressure gauge with a mini-pump, so you have to be careful not to over-inflate the tube. Keep checking the tire so that once it gets to the desired firmness, you can stop pumping.</span></li>
</ol>
&nbsp;
<h3>Step 9: Celebrate and Ride</h3>
<ol style="list-style-type: lower-alpha;">
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Smile. You killed it.</span></li>
	<li><span style="font-size: 16px;">Make sure you turn your bike right-side-up again before you try to ride away, otherwise you’re in for an interesting day.</span></li>
</ol>
&nbsp;

When I came home that day covered in grease, I had just gone on a ride up Mt. Baldy where my bike chain was jumping gears and my rear wheel was rubbing against the frame. I was able to fix it with minimal cursing and get back on the road. Becoming self-sufficient with my bike has taken a lot of practice, but it’s made my confidence dangerously strong. Good luck friends! Next time, patching a tube!]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_wpas_done_all]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
