		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_wp_rp_related_posts_query_result_cache_5]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:10:{i:0;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2652";s:5:"score";s:17:"25.72714208582435";}i:1;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:3:"791";s:5:"score";s:18:"21.835321787713724";}i:2;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1581";s:5:"score";s:17:"19.98001280607975";}i:3;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1045";s:5:"score";s:17:"18.15422252091875";}i:4;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1788";s:5:"score";s:18:"17.628637548916274";}i:5;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2671";s:5:"score";s:17:"17.13257127338677";}i:6;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2846";s:5:"score";s:18:"13.582666570978388";}i:7;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2654";s:5:"score";s:18:"13.582666570978388";}i:8;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2132";s:5:"score";s:18:"13.582666570978388";}i:9;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1965";s:5:"score";s:18:"11.756876285817388";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>How To: Split and Merge PDFs</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/split-merge-pdfs/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 08 Apr 2016 08:12:54 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Rachel Wiegardt-Egel]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=3425</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Have you ever finished a big scanning project only to realize that (DISASTER!) some of the pages have been scanned wrong—gone askew or (even worse!) are covered with giant black streaks because of a mishap with the scanning light? Maybe you’ve been emailed a PDF that needed one page extracted, and cursed the technology gods that you can’t easily copy and paste sections of a PDF into another document?

[caption id="attachment_3452" align="aligncenter" width="331"]<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/lady-papers-300x235.jpg" rel="attachment wp-att-3452"><img class="wp-image-3452 " src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/lady-papers-300x235-300x235.jpg" alt="lady-papers-300x235" width="331" height="259" /></a> Me giving up. (from brokenpencil.com)[/caption]

&nbsp;

I’m not sure how common these annoyances are, but as someone whose job title contains the word “literary,” I’ve spent a lot of quality time with a scanner and received a lot of PDF files in my inbox, and I can tell you from personal experience how frustrating Adobe Reader can be when you realize something in a PDF has gone awry. For anyone who has faced or may ever face a similar plight, I’m here to introduce you to the magical world of PDF merging and splitting!

&nbsp;

Here’s a possible scenario: as you’re doing research for a paper, you come across a chapter of a book that’s perfect for your source material. You scan the chapter you want to include, but when you check the file, you discover that ten of the pages right in the middle are basically unreadable. What do you do?

&nbsp;

1. Re-scan any pages that were problematic, so that you can replace the old, ruined pages. (Pro tip: save the new pages with a title that will make the file easy to find again! This coming from someone who has had to track down too many scans with “img-314150119-0001.pdf”-esque names.)

&nbsp;

2. Go to <span style="color: #3366ff;"><a style="color: #3366ff;" href="http://www.splitpdf.com">www.splitpdf.com</a></span> on your fave browser. (Shout-out to Google Chrome!)

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/Screen-Shot-2016-04-08-at-11.04.07-AM.png" rel="attachment wp-att-3450"><img class=" wp-image-3450 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/Screen-Shot-2016-04-08-at-11.04.07-AM-300x137.png" alt="Screen Shot 2016-04-08 at 11.04.07 AM" width="353" height="161" /></a>

&nbsp;

3. Enter page ranges of the pages of your PDF that you want to keep. For example, if pages 10 through 19 are the problem in a file with thirty pages, you’ll want to make the first range 1-9 (to keep the first nine pages) and the second range 20-30 (to keep the pages after 19). Don’t forget to list the page numbers of the PDF itself, not the page numbers in the book you’ve scanned. (Been there, done that…)

&nbsp;

4. Press “Split!” The website will download two new PDF files, one with pages 1-9 and one with pages 20-30. (If the ruined pages were spread all throughout the document and you entered many more page ranges in step 3, you’ll end up with a bunch of documents, but don’t worry, they’ll be named by page range.)

&nbsp;

5. Go to <span style="color: #3366ff;"><a style="color: #3366ff;" href="http://www.pdfmerge.com">www.pdfmerge.com</a></span>.

<a href="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/Screen-Shot-2016-04-08-at-11.04.54-AM.png" rel="attachment wp-att-3451"><img class=" wp-image-3451 aligncenter" src="http://www.twigghowto.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/Screen-Shot-2016-04-08-at-11.04.54-AM-300x139.png" alt="Screen Shot 2016-04-08 at 11.04.54 AM" width="335" height="155" /></a>

&nbsp;

6. Choose your files to be combined in the appropriate order: in this case, you’ll choose your split PDF with pages 1-9, then your brand new cleanly scanned pages 10-19 from step 1, then your split PDF with pages 20-30.

&nbsp;

7. Press “Merge!” This will download the three files as one PDF document.

&nbsp;

8. Rename the file as you wish, and you’re done!

&nbsp;

Whether or not it’s likely that you’ll encounter this exact scenario, splitting and merging PDFs can come in surprisingly handy. Say you’re applying for a new fellowship and you need to include a letter of recommendation from a past application that you only have on your computer as a PDF…split and merge it up!

&nbsp;

If you’re lucky enough to have access to Adobe Acrobat software (which can a little hard on the wallet), this is a non-issue—all of these things can easily be done in the program itself. So, be sure to check your home or work computer to see if that’s an option. And if you don’t have easy access to a scanner or wifi, this is a great opportunity to check out the resources at your local library!

&nbsp;

Know of another way to manipulate PDF files? Let us know in the comments below!]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:10:{i:0;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"1800";s:5:"score";s:18:"26.142153553048075";}i:1;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"3058";s:5:"score";s:18:"17.534023366639737";}i:2;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"3092";s:5:"score";s:18:"16.249407073120384";}i:3;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2483";s:5:"score";s:18:"14.741863468151411";}i:4;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2192";s:5:"score";s:18:"13.997384547948478";}i:5;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"3141";s:5:"score";s:17:"12.92885318016516";}i:6;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"3072";s:5:"score";s:17:"12.92885318016516";}i:7;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"3030";s:5:"score";s:17:"12.92885318016516";}i:8;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2969";s:5:"score";s:17:"12.92885318016516";}i:9;O:8:"stdClass":2:{s:7:"post_id";s:4:"2874";s:5:"score";s:17:"12.92885318016516";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
		<title>How To: Deal with Depression</title>
		<link>http://www.twigghowto.com/how-to-deal-with-depression/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 10 Apr 2016 23:31:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Caitlin Cohen]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.twigghowto.com/?p=3427</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[It’s a complete inability to control what you’re feeling. It’s crying on the treadmill in public when all you want is to be normal and happy. It’s as if you’re falling, constantly falling, without being able to grab on to anything to stop the fall.

&nbsp;

<span style="color: #3366ff;"><a style="color: #3366ff;" href="http://www.healthline.com/health/depression/statistics-infographic">Ten percent of Americans</a> </span>deal with depression at some point in their lives. Of those ten percent, eighty percent are not receiving any treatment for it. Women are twice as likely to have depression as men are. While these statistics are not great, they should reassure you of one thing: if you feel like you can’t control the sad or bad thoughts in your head, you are absolutely not alone.

&nbsp;

I was first diagnosed with “minor” depression when I was 11. It helped to talk to a therapist. For example, even though there were a couple years between my grandfather’s death and seeing the therapist, I realized I was blaming myself for not taking my grandpa’s sickness seriously, having used it as an excuse to see my cousins who would visit. When he died, I felt guilty (also, I didn’t have any friends at school, which affected my mood too, but I do distinctly remember the conversation with my therapist regarding my grandfather). I haven’t seen a therapist regularly since then - just a one-time visit to a mandated counselor in college when I was caught drinking, and then another session about two months ago when I decided I needed to do something about the fact that I had been crying multiple times a day for weeks. But I’ve done a lot of my own personal research about the disease, and I’m also able to speak from experience.

&nbsp;

There is no one right way to deal with depression, just like there is no one set list of symptoms you will exhibit. This is just how I’ve dealt with it.

&nbsp;
<h4>1. Recognize it.</h4>
You’re great. You’re just the greatest. So when you have that voice in your head telling you that you’re worthless and nobody likes you, stop and realize that voice is wrong. Depression is a liar. It makes you feel bad about yourself. Recognizing that is such an important first step to healing. People don’t hate other people for no reason (unless they’re terrible, in which case you can forget them), and you shouldn’t let depression make up a reason for you.

Sometimes, depression isn’t even related to how you feel about yourself. It’s a general malaise, being scared and sad and less lively than you usually are without any real reason for it. When I was 20, I remember being unhappy even though I had every reason to feel great. I was studying abroad, I was young, I was still in college, I had great friends, and I was having fun. I realized once I said it out loud, almost by accident, that I was unhappy because I was stressed about my future outside of school (which was fast approaching). Putting a name on it didn’t suddenly make me feel 100%, but it did make my feelings easier to deal with.

The most recent episode I had was perhaps the most intense. For weeks I fought against calling what I had depression. Honestly, I had fought against calling my low feelings depression for months before then, but I felt without a professional diagnosis that I didn’t have the authority to name what I was feeling. Getting it together to see a therapist seemed like a whole thing, and I put absolutely no effort into it. But once I named my emotional downswing depression, the beast had a name, and I could more easily wrestle it.

&nbsp;
<h4>2. Be easy on yourself.</h4>
You’re going to have days when you can barely get out of bed. Have them. Don’t beat yourself up. You’ll make yourself feel worse than you already do.

&nbsp;
<h4>3. Little things make you feel better.</h4>
This step is <em>sooo</em> boring but it’s also so important. Your emotional health is tied to your physical health. When you have a cold, you take care of yourself, right? This is the same idea. For the days when you’re feeling up to it, try to make them productive.

I know it’s dumb, but taking a shower and putting on clothes will make you feel better. That is not an opinion. It’s a fact. Sweatpants are comfortable and great and you are totally right to love them, but putting on nice clothes will improve your overall mood in the short term.

Doing laundry will also make you feel better, and laundry isn’t even that active!

Cooking food for yourself is also great. It is so easy to order Chinese food, and in the short term, Chinese food is the best. But if you cook yourself a healthy meal, not only will you feel more accomplished, your body (and your emotions!) will thank you in the long run. Eating healthy will make you feel better. (You can have ice cream. No one is taking away your ice cream. Just pepper in some healthy food when you’re feeling up to it.)

Cleaning your apartment is so easy too!

Exercise! Oh my god, yes, yes, yes, absolutely exercise. If you don’t feel up for a run or anything heavy-duty, go for a long walk. It will help. I promise.

I compared depression to endlessly falling in the beginning of this article, and I like to see little chores as branches to hold on to. Some days you’re not going to want to do any of these things. Fine. But the more you’re able to force yourself to do these boring everyday tasks, the better you’ll feel.

It’s annoying that all the things your mother nagged you about are actually important, but here we are. It’s almost like she only wanted the best for you.

&nbsp;
<h4>4. Take it one day at a time.</h4>
This might last a while. There is no overnight cure for depression. That’s okay. You can make it through today. That’s the only thing you need to do for right now.

&nbsp;
<h4>5. Go out and see friends, but don’t force yourself.</h4>
Seeing people who think you’re just the bee’s knees will remind you that the voice in your head is wrong and an idiot and stupid. It will also make you feel better.

BUT sometimes you need to be alone. If everything in your body is fighting going out, don’t go out. Letting yourself rest is important. Depression is exhausting.

&nbsp;
<h4>6. Cut out the things that make you upset if you can.</h4>
Sometimes you unfortunately can’t let go of the things making you sad (maybe it’s work or family, and for whatever reason that thing is here to stay). But sometimes you can cut out things that upset you. Sometimes you absolutely have to. Take a look at the people in your life who upset you, the activities in your life that bring you down, and either cut them out or change them.

&nbsp;
<h4>7. Do things that make you happy.</h4>
For the obvious reason that they will make you happy.

&nbsp;
<h4>8. If you notice a connection between your depression and any substance abuse, that’s a problem.</h4>
I miss wine. But I also embarrassed myself far too many times by being the drunkest biddy at the party. The longer you’re out of college, the less cute it gets. Going out with friends could be stressful because interacting with people is stressful. Alcohol became an imperative for me in those situations.

My boyfriend also noticed, when I was really grappling with my depression, that the more I drank, the worse it got. I haven’t totally cut out drinking – I had a coffee drink with kahlua in it for brunch just today – but I gave myself a one-drink limit and I’ve cut out getting drunk. It was absolutely related to me feeling better.

&nbsp;
<h4>9. If you can, see a therapist.</h4>
How to find a therapist is an article for another day, replete with tips about money management and health care and leaving voicemails for mental health care professionals who make a point to tell you, their prospective patient, how busy they are. (In this case, you are allowed to be finicky. This is your mental health, and this relationship needs to be all about you.) It’s frustrating, but talking it over with a professional can help. Be wary if they start offering advice – advice is not their job. Helping you work through these feelings is much more important.

&nbsp;
<h4>10. When in doubt, check out the endless supply of puppy and kitten videos on the internet.</h4>
There are so many. They’re all great.

&nbsp;

Everyone deals with depression differently, but these steps seemed to help me get through my last episode. Remember – you’re amazing, and if the voice in your head is saying differently, then it’s wrong.

&nbsp;

To check out more resources and get help, visit this website: http://www.adaa.org/living-with-anxiety/ask-and-learn/resources.]]></content:encoded>
